editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

To which is added the Surgeon's Che≈øt, Furni≈øhed both with In≈øtruments and Medicines, all u≈øeful: Illu≈øtrated with ≈øeveral Copper-Plates: And to make it more compleat, is adioyned a Treati≈øe of Di≈øea≈øes that for the mo≈øt part attend Camps and Fleets.

div.head: THE AUTHOR'S PREFACE TO THE JUDICIOUS READER.
div.p:
WHat ≈øhould be the ≈øcope of putting forth this my not ≈øufficient Poli≈øhed Treati≈øe, after ≈øo many Excellent and Learned Writings of Phy≈øicians, the Title before will declare unto thee, viz. That my De≈øign was both out of the Ancient and Modern, to extract the very Marrow, and plainly to ≈øhew the be≈øt way of Curing Di≈øea≈øes belonging to Chirurgery: Therefore I have purpo≈øed not to obtrude upon thee this or that Man's Fancy,
or Conceit, for Modern Practice: For who ever was ≈øo mad as to Embrace the Opinion of any one Region, City, or Man? Who ever, though mo≈øt ingenious and judicious, equally excelled in all the Parts of his Profe≈ø≈øion? Seeing it hath not plea≈øed the Giver of all Arts to grant this perfectne≈øs to Men: But I re≈øolve to ≈øet down that Practice which Rea≈øon and Experience, after a diligent Reading of the be≈øt Authors, and an exact ob≈øervation of ≈øeveral Operations, have Taught me to be the ≈øafe≈øt, conveniente≈øt and ea≈øie≈øt, for prolixity I have purpo≈øely avoided, and u≈øed not more words than only to expre≈øs the thing it ≈øelf. Neverthele≈øs I have ≈øtudied to conprehend the Foundation of the Art in few Chapters. Read over all diligently, and let not what I purpo≈øely
omitted trouble thee: Great Volumns ea≈øily affright the Reader, as tho≈øe that are too little betrays him: I have carefully endeavoured, what is hardly found, a mean; and therefore, I have rather in few words in≈øerted my Ob≈øervations, in the very de≈øcriptions of the Di≈øea≈øes, then to wa≈øte thy time with a prolix di≈øcour≈øe: To this end, that I might not repeat in particular Di≈øea≈øes, what I had once ≈øet down in generals.

Tumors, Wounds, and ∆≤lcers, which neither in Cau≈øe nor Cure differ, I have reduced under one Head, contrary to what mo≈øt Writers u≈øe to do, who only from the difference of the Part and Member affected, difference the Di≈øea≈øes, which aftewards giving them new names, they without any benefit multiply, and ≈øo
they render that Art which is difficult enough of it ≈øelf, much more difficult. The mo≈øt diligent of Students can ≈øcarce di≈øtingui≈øh them, who unprofitably ≈øpend much labour and time, in the Controver≈øies of the Ancients concerning the Name, who≈øe Opinions they ≈øuppo≈øe they ought to follow to a Tittle, if they will arrive at the degree of Doctor. We are the Mini≈øters of Nature, not the Slaves of tho≈øe Men that de≈øcribe it: We account neither them Prophets, nor their Writings ≈øacred, neither unlawful to add, or dimini≈øh to them without the name Heretick.

I have ≈øet down both few, and many Medicaments; for tho≈øe that I have produced, although few in number, yet of great vertue, which by va≈øt pains, and no le≈øs charges I have found out, and which dayly
Practice hath confirmed to me, as the ≈øafe≈øt of all. Other Medicines ≈øeek for among≈øt others.

Farewel kind Reader, and whil'≈øt I am imployed about other, and better (if I can po≈ø≈øible) Writings, receive the≈øe with a grateful mind; and as I ≈øtudy to be profitable to thee, ≈øo al≈øo do thou endeavour always by the≈øe to help others..

div.head: BARBETTY'S CHIRURGERY. The Fir≈øt Part.
CHAP. I. Of Manual Operations in general.
div.p: ALthough the word Chirurgery ≈øignifies all Manual Operations in general; yet, by rea≈øon of its pre-eminence above all the re≈øt, it is now only given to that Art, which endeavours to remove the Di≈øea≈øes of the Body, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Hands.

'Tis true, that External Accidents require not only the help of the Hands, but al≈øo Internal Means; therefore it is no wonder for a Part of Phy≈øick to require the whole: Chirurgery being a Part, which depends upon the Body of Phy≈øick: But the≈øe internal Medicines we impart to you, not as Chirurgeons, but as Phy≈øicians.
The General Operations of this Art, to which all the particular ones may be reduced, are of four ≈øorts:
1. Synthe≈øis, which teacheth how to unite parts disjointed.
2. Diaere≈øis, To ≈øeparate parts unnaturally joyned.
3. Exaere≈øis, To remove what is ≈øuperfluous.
4. Anaplero≈øis, To ≈øupply tho≈øe that are wanting.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of Synthe≈øis or ∆≤nition.
div.p: UNition is of two ≈øorts; one regards the Hard and Boney; the other the Soft and Fle≈øhy parts of the Body.
The Unition of Bones is again twofold; the one, ≈øetting Bones broken; the other, reducing Bones wrenched or di≈øjointed. We will begin with Fractures.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Nature, Difference, Signs, Progno≈øticks and Cure of Fractures in general.
div.p: A Fracture is a Solution of Continuity in the hard parts of the Body, cau≈øed by an hard In≈øtrument externally forced upon the part.

The Differences are taken, 1. From the Manner; there being ≈øome tran≈øver≈øe, which are properly called Fractures; others that are made according to the length of the Bone, called Fi≈ø≈øures: and others are Comminutions, when the Bone is
broken into many ≈ømall parts. 2. From the Part, it being ≈øome times in the Head, ≈øometimes in the Shoulders, Ribs, Arms, Legs, &c. 3. From the Accidents; there being ≈øometimes a Wound accompanying it; at other times, a Di≈ølocation, Inflamation, Gangrene, &c.
Cau≈øe] is, Whatever is able to break, brui≈øe, or cut: Sometimes al≈øo a Bone corrupted by the Pox, Gout, or otherwi≈øe, hath been broken without any external force.

Signs.] A Bone being tran≈øver≈øly or obliquely broke, by handling it, you perceive an inequality; the Patient is ≈øcarce able to move the Part affected, and ≈øometimes that Part is ≈øhorter than the other; the Thigh, Leg or Foot being broken, the Patient cannot ≈øtand at all; but he may ≈øomewhat, though with pain, in a Di≈ølocation: And this is the ≈øure≈øt difference between a Fracture and a Di≈ølocation. A Fi≈ø≈øure is di≈øcerned by the thickne≈øs, pain and unevenne≈øs of the Part, and requireth the judgment of a skilful Chirurgion. A Comminution is ea≈øie to be perceived, the Bone being very unequal, and here and there yielding to the Fingers.

Progno≈øticks] A Tran≈øver≈øe Fracture is more ea≈øie to cure than an Oblique; or when accompanied with apparent Inequalities; that, where but one Bone is broken, than where two are, or where the Bones are much ≈øhattered; that, which ‚Ä¢ s made in the mid≈øt of the Bone, than what happens to be near the Head; and a ≈øingle one, than a compound. If the Patient remain undre≈ø≈øed beyond the ≈øeventh day, the Member is in danger of mortifying, e≈øpecially if that the Part be too ‚Ä¢ ard bound.
The Cure.] A broken Bone requires the≈øe four Operations; Extention, Conjoining, Ligature, Well-placing; and withal, the application of outward and inward Remedies.

Extention can hardly be performed without pain; which yet will be much le≈øs, if the Member be ≈øo extended, that the Mu≈øcles do not labour; that is to ≈øay, The Part mu≈øt be ≈øo laid, that when in health, they could hold out longe≈øt without tiring. Sometimes the exten≈øion mu≈øt be greater, ≈øometimes le≈ø≈øer; which will be performed aright, if regard be had to the time of the Fracture, to the Age of the Patient, and to the greatne≈øs of the Bone. A recent Fracture, a tender Patient, a ≈ømall Bone, require a gentler Extention: on the contrary, an old Fracture, a ≈øtrong Patient, and a big Bone, a greater. The manner of extending I de≈øcribe not, becau≈øe it is better learnt by the frequent view of Practice, than by Reading.
After Extention, you are to join the Bones together; in the doing of which, the Mu≈øcles mu≈øt not be wre≈øted, but retain their natural po≈øition and figure.

Then the Part mu≈øt be bound with a double Rowler; the fir≈øt is to be rowled thrice about the Fracture, and then upwards. The (≈øecond (which mu≈øt be twice as long) is to be once wound about the Fracture, proceeding downwards, and then upwards again, a little higher than the fir≈øt Rowler; to which you will give more firmne≈øs, if you bind ≈øome convenient Splints (of Wood, or rather of Pa≈øt-board) round about the Member.

The Ligature ought not to be too ≈øtrait, le≈øt it
cau≈øe pain, and rob the Part of its nouri≈øhment; nor too loo≈øe, le≈øt the Bones ≈ølip out of their place. And unle≈øs great pain, or other ≈øymptoms require, it mu≈øt not be opened before the third day; and at the ≈øecond dre≈ø≈øing, it mu≈øt be bound ≈øomewhat clo≈øer; and afterwards changed but once every four, five or ≈øix dayes.

La≈øtly, The Part ought to be well placed, that is, ≈øoftly, evenly, and a little rai≈øed. If you lay it too low, the Bone will bend outwards; if too high, it will bend inwards: Wherefore you mu≈øt ob≈øerve a mean.
Now, whether the≈øe four Operations have been duly performed, may be known by the en≈øuing Signs.
The Extention is well done, if the part be ≈øtrait, and as long as its fellow; if it appear to outward view every where even, and a little hollow about the Fracture.
The joining together is duly made, if the Bone be any thing firm, and all about the Fracture be found equal.

The Ligature is as it ought to be, if the Patient, as ≈øoon as he is dre≈ø≈øed, find the pain abated; if the pain do ≈øomewhat encrea≈øe the fir≈øt and ≈øecond night, and there be perceived the third day, without the place of binding, a little ≈øwelling yielding to your hands.
The Bone is well placed, if in the ≈øecond dre≈ø≈øing you find all even.

Before you rowl the Ligature about the Member, bathe the part with Spirit of Wine or Red Wine; or, with Oyl, Wine and Vinegar mix'd together; Or, take the White of an Egg,
with ≈øome Bolus, Frankincen≈øe, Dragons-Blood, &c. Or anoint it with Oyl of Ro≈øes, Mirtles, Violets, &c. or lay Plai≈øters on it. In Winter, the Oxycroceum will do well: At all times that which follows;

Take Ma≈øtick, Frankincen≈øe, of each two drams, Aloes, Gum Tragacanth, Dragons-Blood, Bole-Armonick, of each a one dram; Lapis Haematitis, Burnt Talch, of each one dram; Whites of Eggs, and Oyl of Ro≈øes, as much as is ≈øufficient. Make it into a Plai≈øter.

If a Wound accompany the Fracture, then ought you to extend the Part fir≈øt (yet ≈øomewhat gentler than in a ≈øimple Fracture) then you are to join the Bones together; next, to ob≈øerve the Wound, to bring the Lips thereof together with Plai≈øters, rather than with a Needle, and to guard it with a Defen≈øive: And la≈øtly, rowl the Part, and lay it conveniently.

If there be a Cominution, or great ≈øhattering of the Bones joined with the Wound, then endeavour with Forceps to remove the ≈ømall loo≈øe Bones, leaving tho≈øe to Nature that are yet any way fixed; for ≈øhe will, though ≈øomewhat later, of her ≈øelf throw them out; and ≈øometimes ≈øhe will unite them again to the whole. Yet, to forward her, you may a≈ø≈øi≈øt Nature with the following Medicaments.
Take A≈øhes of Earth-worms, three drams; Virgins-Honey, an ounce and half, mix them, and make an Oyntment.
Or,

Take Aloes, Myrrhe, of each half a dram; Roots of Comfrey the great, Round-Birthwort, of each three drams, Euphorbium, two drams;
Turpentine and Wax, as much as is ≈øufficient, with a little Oyl of Lillies, to make it into an Oyntment.
If the Bone be bare, cover it with its own skin and Nu≈øcles, and defend it from the Air as much as is po≈ø≈øible.
If it be bare and al≈øo ≈øtarted out, endeavour to reduce it again into its place; but if it be got out too far, take away the pieces thus ≈øtarted out, with Saw or Nippers.

Now the≈øe Manual Operations being well performed, the Patient mu≈øt ob≈øerve a good Diet; open a Vein upon occa≈øion, and afterwards purge the Blood. In the Fractures of the lower parts, purging is not convenient; but if the Patients Belly be bound, he mu≈øt take a Suppo≈øitory.

In the Fractures of the upper parts, Purging or admini≈øtring Cly≈øters, is oftner nece≈ø≈øary, and may be done by the en≈øuing compounded or ≈øimple Medicines, which may al≈øo ≈øerve you in all other Accidents that we may de≈øcribe in this whole Treati≈øe.

div.head: CHAP IV. Of particular Fractures of Bones.
div.p: THe Fractures of the Skull are divided into ≈øix ≈øeveral kinds; A Fi≈ø≈øure, Contu≈øion, Fracture, Inci≈øion, Puncture and Contra fi≈ø≈øure.
A Fi≈ø≈øure is made by a hard and blunt In≈øtrument, and pa≈ø≈øeth ≈øometimes through both Tables, ≈øometimes through one only.

A Contu≈øion is made, when by a hard and blunt In≈øtrument the Skull is ≈øo hurt, that it appears whole from without, but yet is ≈øever'd from the
whole within: Which yet in little Children may be done without a Fracture.
A Fracture is made, when a part of the Skull is ≈øeparated from the whole.

An Inci≈øion is made by a cutting In≈øtrument; where ≈øometimes one part of the Bone is rais'd up and ≈øeparated, as it were, but is yet fa≈øt to the re≈øt of the Bone; ≈øometimes a part is quite taken away; ≈øometimes there remains a mark in the Bone according to the Figure of the In≈øtrument.
A Puncture is made by a pungent or thru≈øting In≈øtrument, and ≈øeldom pa≈ø≈øeth through both Tables.
A Contra-fi≈ø≈øure is made, when the part ≈øtruck remaining whole, the oppo≈øite part is cleft.

The Signs are, Swimming of the Head, dimne≈øs of the Eyes, Vomiting, Bleeding at the Mouth, No≈øe and Ears. The Patient grows dumb, and ≈øuddenly falls to the ground: whereupon follows Raving, a Feaver, Convul≈øions, Pal≈øie. Any hard thing, as a piece of Wood, a Spoon, &c. being put into his Mouth, he is not at all, or hardly able to bite upon it. Here it mu≈øt al≈øo be carefully enquired, in what manner, and with what In≈øtrument he hath been hurt? Whether he be young or old, tender or ≈øtrong, healthy or unhealthy? Pre≈øently after the Fall or Stroke, before the Part ≈øwells, you may ≈øometimes feel the hurt with your Fingers; and if there be a Wound with it, you may either ≈øee it, or find it out with a Probe.

Progno≈øticks.] The Fractures of the Skull, how fair ≈øoever they may look, is never without danger, but more dangerous, when both the Tables are hurt or broken; and more dangerous
yet, if the Dura Mater, and mo≈øt dangerous, if the Pia Mater be al≈øo hurt. The more Symptoms there are, the le≈øs hope of a good event. If the Bone grow black in the beginning, that is a mortal Sign.

Cure.] If the Skin be yet whole, or the wound not large enough, make a cro≈øs inci≈øion, and divide the Pericranium. If under it you find a fi≈ø≈øure, put ≈øome Ink into it, and bind up the wound. The ≈øecond day, or as ≈øoon as the bleeding is cea≈øed, ≈øcrape the Skull at once, or at ≈øeveral times, until the Ink with the Fi≈ø≈øure is altogether gone, and the Bone grow ≈øomewhat bloody, then throw the en≈øuing Powder upon it.
Take Dragons Blood, burnt Harts-horn, of each one dram and half; Myrrhe half a dram; Frankincen≈øe, and Orri≈øe roots, of each a dram; Make it into a very fine Powder.

If the Fi≈ø≈øure pa≈øs through both Tables, then are you to make u≈øe of Trepanning; as likewi≈øe in the Contra-fi≈ø≈øure, Fracture and Contu≈øion of the Skull, or el≈øe you will quickly lo≈øe your Patient.
The Inci≈øion is healed like the Fi≈ø≈øure.
In the Puncture you mu≈øt put the Trepan ju≈øt in the middle, and not on the ≈øides of the place hurt.

If you find a Fracture with a Cominution, then take out all the ≈ømall loo≈øe Bones, committing to Nature tho≈øe that are yet fa≈øt to the Pericranium, or cannot be taken away without force. And then if the Fracture be ≈øo large, that you can free the Brains from the coagulated or corrupted Blood, or from the pricking Bones, Trepanning will be needle≈øs; but if it ≈øhould happen otherwi≈øe,
you mu≈øt, with great care, apply the Trepan, unle≈øs the Patient be ≈øtrong, and the matter very little. The manner of Trepanning will be taught in another place.

2. In a Fracture of the No≈øe, what is rai≈øed, is to be pre≈ø≈øed down; and what is pre≈ø≈øed inward, to be rai≈øed with a Spatule, or other In≈øtrument: afterwards a Pipe or Quill is to be put up, and continually kept there, till the Cure be done, and a Fracture-Plai≈øter is to be laid on without. If the Bone be not corrupted, it will be healed in ten or twelve days.

3. A broken Jaw-bone is re≈øtored by ones fingers u≈øed both within and without the Mouth; and if tho≈øe be too weak, then one is to draw the Head backward, and the Chirurgeon forward, and ≈øo to put it in. It is cured in twenty days.

4. The Clavicle being broken, there mu≈øt be one to draw the Arm backward, and another to draw the Neck or Shoulder forward; the Chirurgeon him≈øelf, in the mean time, drawing upwards what was fallen down, and downwards what was rai≈øed too high. If a Ball be put into the Arm-pit, and the Elbow be pre≈ø≈øed again≈øt the Ribs, the Operation will prove more ea≈øie. It is cured in twenty four days.

5. If the Shoulder-Blade be broken about the place where it is united to the Arm, then is the hurt for the mo≈øt part incurable. If it break in the Acromion (which may be ea≈øily felt) then let the Arm or Shoulder be pulled down, either with Hands or Ligatures, and in the mean time ≈øet it in. If it be broken into ≈øeveral pieces, make an Inci≈øion, and take them out, unle≈øs they be yet fa≈øt to the Peri-e≈øtium; in which ca≈øe, you mu≈øt leave
Nature to her ≈øelf, which will either make them unite again, or throw them out. It is healed in forty days.

6. The Sternum, or Brea≈øt-bone happens either to be broken, and then you'll find an unevenne≈øs, which being toucht, will yield to the Fingers, and cau≈øe ≈øome cracking; or to be pre≈ø≈øed in, and then you'll feel a bending inwards, which will cau≈øe pain, a ≈øhort breath, coughing and ≈øpitting blood. To re≈øtore the ≈øame, lay the Patient on his Back upon a great ≈øtone, pre≈ø≈øing both his Shoulders downwards; then pre≈øs the Ribs backward and forward, until the Bone be reduced again in its right place. This is cured in twenty days.

7. A ≈øimple Fracture of the Ribs, which is without any great Contu≈øion, or Inflamation of the neighbouring parts, may be healed in twenty days, applying the Fracture-Plai≈øter. If the Ribs ≈øtand out, they mu≈øt with ones Hand be pre≈ø≈øed in. If they bend inward, let the Patient keep in his Breath, and ≈øo pre≈øs the Rib outward; in the mean time, a≈ø≈øi≈øting him with your hand. If that ≈øucceed not, then lay a ≈øticking Plai≈øter upon it, and pull the ≈øame off ≈øo often, until the Rib return into its place. Cupping-Gla≈ø≈øes here are of no u≈øe.

8. A ≈øimple Fracture of the Joynts of the Backbone is ea≈øily ≈øet again with ones finger, and is made whole in twenty days. But if the Marrow of the Back-bone be ≈øo hurt or pre≈ø≈øed in, that the Arms or Legs of the Patient become lame or ≈øen≈øele≈øs, that he cannot retain his Urine, or his Excrement, then he ≈øeldom e≈øcapeth death. Yet you are to do your utmo≈øt; and if one or more
≈ømall Bones be altogether loo≈øe from the Perio≈øtium, then make Inci≈øion, and take them out.
9. The ≈øame is to be under≈øtood of the Fracture of the Os ≈øacrum, which alone hath this peculiar, that you may put your fingers into the Anus, and re≈øtore it to its right place.

10. The Hip-bone being broken, is to be ≈øet as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible may be, and then it will heal in twenty four days; otherwi≈øe you may expect various accidents. But if it be fractured into many pieces, then you are forthwith, in the fir≈øt dre≈ø≈øing, to make an Inci≈øion; take out the ≈ømall Splinters, and re-place tho≈øe that have yet any hold-fa≈øt. Yet, by rea≈øon of the multitude of the Tendons, Mu≈øcles, Veins, Arteries and Nerves, that are ≈øpread over the whole part, ≈øuch an Inci≈øion cannot be made without great danger.

11. If the upper-Bone of the Arm be broken, fir≈øt bend the Elbow toward the Brea≈øt, then take the lower part of that Bone clo≈øe to the Elbow, pulling it ≈øtraight down towards the ground, and ≈øo re≈øtore it; well ob≈øerving here, that the Arm, during the whole time of Cure, mu≈øt remain in that po≈øture in which it was extended; otherwi≈øe the Fracture will, upon the lea≈øt change of its po≈øture, ≈ølip out again. Where yet 'tis to be under≈øtood, that the Chirurgeon after the ≈øecond or third dre≈ø≈øing, as often as after that he dre≈ø≈øeth the Patient, mu≈øt ≈øtretch out his Arm ≈øtrait, to the end that the Tendons which run from the Arm, and are in≈øerted below the Elbow, ≈øhrinking by the long lying ≈øtill, may not cau≈øe a trouble≈øome ≈øtiffne≈øs. However, this ≈øhrinking of Tendons (which are by pretenders to
Chirurgery, ridiculou≈øly call'd Nerves) may yet conveniently be cured in two or three months, if you make the Patient to carry every day ≈øome weight, and endeavor to relax and mollifie the Tendons with Fomentations and Embrocations, ab≈øtaining from the u≈øe of any Brandy, or any other corroborating and a≈øtringent Medicines. I have always found ≈øucce≈øsful the following Unguent.
Take Man's and Duck's Grea≈øe, of each one ounce; Oyntment of Mar≈øh-mallows, half an ounce; Oyl of Earth-worms, white Lilly, and Camomile, of each two drams. Make an Oyntment.
This broken Bone is cured in forty days. The re≈øtoring of the broken Thigh-bone, hath nothing different from this.

12. The Elbow hath two Bones; of which, the greater is called Radius, the le≈ø≈øer Ulna; both Fociles: The ≈ømall Focile being broken, 'tis ea≈øie to re≈øtore it. The Cure is harder, when the great one is broken; and yet harder, when both are broken: In which ca≈øe, the extention is to be made the ≈øtronger. When they be well ≈øet, and bound up, then mu≈øt the hand be placed a little higher upon the Che≈øt than the Elbow; and afterwards, every ≈øecond or third day (without pain or violence) the Arm is gently to be ≈øtretch'd out, to the end that the Humors flowing thither, and there ≈øtaying too long, may not cau≈øe a concretion in the Bones, and a ≈øtiffne≈øs in the Arm, as not exten≈øible any more. It is cured in thirty days.
13. The Leg hath al≈øo two Bones, the greater called Tibia, and the le≈ø≈øer Fibula. Their Cure had nothing different from the next foregoing.

14. If the Patella, or Knee-pan, break cro≈øsways,
the Patient commonly remains lame. If it break long-ways, then by the Mu≈øcles that draw upwards, without any great help of the hands, it is almo≈øt of it ≈øelf re≈øtored, and cured in twenty days.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Nature, Difference, Signs, Cau≈øes, Progno≈øticks, and Cure of Di≈ølocations in general.
div.p: A Di≈ølocation is a forcing of the Bone out of its cavity and natural place into another, hindering voluntary motion.

The Differences are taken, 1. From the manner; for ≈øometimes the Bone is altogether forced out of its place, and that is properly called Luxation or Di≈ølocation: Sometimes it is got out but a little or half, which is called Sub-laxation, or Elongation. 2. From the Cau≈øe; for ≈øometimes it is from an external accident, as by wre≈øtlings, Falls, or Blows, &c. Sometimes from internal Cau≈øes, by the afflux of Humors.

The Cau≈øes are of two ≈øorts; 1. External, Such as are Falling, Beating, Running, Wre≈øtling, and vehement extention, as it often happens to Women in Labour, through the unskilfulne≈øs of Midwives; yea, by a violent ≈øtroke or fall, even the Bones of the Infant in the Womb, may be di≈ølocated. 2. Internal, By the afflux of Humors, which falling into the Joints, relax and re≈øolve the Ligaments, and ≈øo cau≈øeth the Bones to ≈ølip out of their places.

The Signs, e≈øpecially in a lean Body, are manife≈øt enough. The Bone cau≈øeth in the place to which it is forced, a tumor or ri≈øing; and in that whence it is forced, a cavity. If there be a perfect Di≈ølocation, the Member will be drawn up, and ≈øhorter (unle≈øs the luxation happen by the laxity of the Ligaments, than it becomes longer) the part is painful, chiefly upon motion. In a Subluxation, the≈øe Accidents are le≈ø≈øer, and ≈øeldom all together.

Progno≈øticks.] In Children and other tender Bodies, the Bones may be reduced more ea≈øily; but are kept in with more difficulty; the contrary happens in ≈øtrong and full grown per≈øons: The Di≈ølocation of the Head is mortal, that of the Vertebra's dangerous; and that which is inveterate is hard to be cured. That which proceeds from an inward Cau≈øe, is of a ≈ølower Cure, and does ea≈øily return.

Cure.] The Bone forced out, mu≈øt be reduced to its place, either by the Hands, Ligatures, or In≈øtruments; but by which of the≈øe three it ≈øhall be performed, the Nature of the affected part will declare. 'Tis certain, that the≈øe four Manual Operations (Extention, Setting, Binding and Well-placing) mu≈øt here be u≈øed as well as in Fractures of Bones.

Extention mu≈øt be made ≈øo great, that there may be a cavity between the Bone that remains well, and that which hath been forced away, to the end that in the ≈øetting, the one may not rub again≈øt the other; whence afterwards are wont to ri≈øe very grievious, and ≈øometimes incurable Accidents.

In the Setting, care mu≈øt be had not to wre≈øt the
Bones nor the Mu≈øcles, but to keep their natural figure. Before you proceed to binding up the Member, endeavour to pre≈øerve the part from inflammation and flux of Humors, and ≈øtrengthen it with the following Medicines.

div.head: A ≈øtrengthening Pla≈øter.
div.p: Take Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, Bole-armonick, Dragons-Blood, of each half an ounce; fine-Flower, an ounce; Roots of great Comfrey, two drams; Weather-Sewet, three ounces; white-Wax, as much as ≈øufficeth to make a Plai≈øter.
Another.

Take Litharge, Wax, Ro≈øin, of each three ounces; being melted over the fire, add to them, of great Comfrey, Bean-Meal, Bole-armonick ≈øteeped in Vinegar, and dried, of each three ounces; Tragacanth, two ounces. Make it into a Plai≈øter.

If the pain, or other ≈øymptoms do not nece≈ø≈øarily require it, you ought not to loo≈øen the Bandage before the fifth, ≈øixth, or ≈øeventh day, and then do it with as little motion as is po≈ø≈øible. La≈øtly, lay the Part even, and in ≈øuch a po≈øture, in which, when found, it can longe≈øt remain without trouble.

If you find the Di≈ølocation accompanied by an Inflammation, beware of extending the part, or doing ought to it before that be removed; which you are to do, fir≈øt with emollient, and afterwards with di≈øcutient, Medicines.

div.head: An Emollient Unguent.
div.p:
Take the compound Ointment of Mar≈øh-mallows,
two drams; Hogs-grea≈øe, half an ounce; Oyl of white-Lillies, Ro≈øes and Mirtles, as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into a Linament.

div.head: A Di≈øcutient Plai≈øter.
div.p: Take Colophony, Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, Pitch of each an Ounce; Cummin-≈øeeds, Fennel-≈øeeds, of each ≈øix drams; Wax and Oyl of Dill, as much as ≈øufficeth. Mix them, and make it into a Plai≈øter.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of particular Di≈ølocations.
div.p: 1. THe Jaw-bone, except it be in young Children, can hardly be di≈ølocated otherwi≈øe than forwards. Sometimes it is only di≈ølocated in one ≈øide, and is ea≈øily re≈øtored; ≈øometimes in both, in which ca≈øe it is difficult to ≈øet, and very dangerous, and often mortal.

It is very ≈øeldom luxated from a debility of the Mu≈øcles; ≈øometimes from the laxity of the Ligaments; for the mo≈øt part, from a too wide opening of the Mouth. If it be di≈ølocated but on one ≈øide, it ≈øtands a-skew, and is turned towards the ≈øide hurt; ≈øome thing is prominent, the Teeth ≈øtand not directly under one another, nor can they be brought together, ≈øo that the Mouth remains open. You mu≈øt draw it towards the oppo≈øite ≈øide, and reduce it to its place, which is not hard to do; yea, by a ≈øtiff box on the Ear it hath often been re≈øtored.

If it be di≈ølocated on both ≈øides, then does it fall forwards, the Mouth ≈øtands open, both the Apophy≈øes are prominent, the lower Teeth ≈øtand further than the upper, and the temporal Mu≈øcles are di≈øtended. In this ca≈øe, let yout Servant hold the Patient's Head firm, or hold it again≈øt a Wall; draw the Jaw-bone fir≈øt downward, putting both your Thumbs in the Mouth, then backward, and la≈øtly upward.

2. The Collar-bone rarely happens to be luxated, and is ≈øeldom ≈øet, but it ≈øtands ≈øomewhat out; whereby it often comes to pa≈øs, that the Patient cannot lift up his hand to his mouth, much le≈øs to his head. For re≈øtoring it, you are to lay the Patient on his back, and a ≈øtone under his ≈øhoulder; then you mu≈øt draw his Arm forward and backward, as the Di≈ølocation requires; then pre≈øs the Clavicle, ≈øo rai≈øed, down into its place.

3. The Great Bone of the Arm (Adjutorium) is never di≈ølocated backward; ≈øeldom upwards and forwards, but for the mo≈øt part downward: a certain ≈øign of it is, if you find it roundi≈øh hardne≈øs under the Arm-pits, and on the top of the Shoulder a hollowne≈øs, and the Arm be longer, and the Patient cannot bring his hand to his Mouth. It may be reduced ≈øeveral ways; but the≈øe are the mo≈øt convenient, and the mo≈øt ≈øure. 1. Let a ≈øtrong man hold the Patient fa≈øt about the hurt Shoulder, and let another draw the Arm downwards; then lift the upper part of the Arm into its Cavity, and the Bone will be ≈øoon re≈øtored into its place. 2. Take a ≈øtrong Ladder, at the foot thereof put a ‚Ä¢ tool for the Patient to ≈øtand upon; on the uppermo≈øt
≈øtep, bind ≈øomething round that may ju≈øt fit the Arm-pits; put the Patients Arm upon it, and draw it downward, moving the Shoulder-bone to and fro; let your Servant, mean while, draw the ≈øound Arm downward, and withal, thru≈øt away the Stool from under the Patient, that whil≈øt he is thus pendulous, the Shoulder-bone may be re≈øtored. 3. Lay the Armpits of the Patient upon the Shoulder of a ≈øtrong and taller man than him≈øelf; draw the di≈ølocated Arm downward, ≈øo that he lifting up his own Shoulder, the Patient may remain in a pendulous po≈øture: In the mean time, pre≈øs his Shoulder downward, working the Arm to and fro, until it be re≈øtored to its due place. 4. The Glo≈ø≈øoc ‚Ä¢
mium de≈øcribed by Hyppocrates, and approved by Paraeus, is the mo≈øt convenient of all; to be ≈øeen in the Authors them≈øelves.

4. If the Vertebrae of the Neck be out of joint, the Patient is to be ≈øet upon a little low Stool, and his Shoulders pre≈ø≈øed downward. After this, his Head is to be lifted up with both hands, turning it to and fro (yet with as little force as may be) and thus they are to be reduced. Whereupon the Patient will pre≈øently find him≈øelf at ea≈øe, and turn his head whithe ‚Ä¢ he plea≈øeth.

5. If the Vertebrae of the Back be forced outwards, the Patient is to be laid upon his Belly and by two Men and two Ligatures, one tied under the Arm-pits, the other about the Hip he mu≈øt be ≈øtrongly ≈øtretched out, and the Ve ‚Ä¢
tebroe's be thru≈øt in again. If they be forced i ‚Ä¢
wards, it is mortal.

6. If the Os ≈øacrum be out of joint, put you ‚Ä¢
fingers into the Anus, and pre≈øs it from within as well as from without, into its place.

7. A Rib di≈ølocated, mu≈øt not remain long out of its place, le≈øt more grievous Accidents follow. If it be removed out of its Vertebra upwards, then hang the Patient by his Arms over a Door, and ≈øo pre≈øs it in. If it be out of joint downward, the Patient mu≈øt bend him≈øelf, laying his hands upon his Knees, and the Chirurgeon in the mean time, mu≈øt move to and again the di≈øplaced Rib till it be re≈øtored to its right place. If it be di≈ølocated inward, lay a ≈øticking Plai≈øter on it, and often pull it away with violence; and thus ≈øometimes it may be re≈øtored; if not, it often proveth mortal, not being capable to be reduced by the Hands.

8. The Cubitus may be di≈ølocated forward or backward, inward or outward. And ≈øometimes the Radius is likewi≈øe di≈ølocated with it, ≈øometimes it remains in its place; which by handling the part, is ea≈øily perceived. If the Cubitus be out forwards, the Arm thereby becomes ≈øhorter, & cannot be bent; the Bone ≈øtands out forwards, and behind there is a preternatural hallowne≈øs. The forcedout Bone mu≈øt, as well in this, as in all other kinds of di≈ølocation of the Elbow, be ≈øpeedily re≈øtored; otherwi≈øe there will follow grievous Pain, Inflammation, Feaver, Vomiting of Choler, and ≈øometimes Death it ≈øelf. Let the Arm be extended obliquely, and ≈øo far, that one Bone may not hurt the other in the ≈øetting. If the Hands be not ≈øtrong enough, then bend the di≈ølocated Arm about a Pillar or a Bed-po≈øt, and by the help of a Bandage extend it, pre≈ø≈øing the Bone backward, until it be replaced. If it be di≈ølocated back-ward, the Arm will then al≈øo be ≈øhorter, and
cannot be bent, the Bone will ≈øtand out behind; and before there is a preternatural cavity. If it be inward or outward, there are the like ≈øigns; only the Tumor will be in the place, to which the Bone hath been forced; whereas the hollowne≈øs is there, whence it hath been forced. All the≈øe three di≈ølocations may be ea≈øily cured by a convenient Extention, if they be not inveterate. The ≈øame is to be under≈øtood of the Radius, when forced out of its place.

9. The Hip may be put out of joint four manner of ways chiefly; inward, outward and forward, but ≈øeldom backward. If inward, the Leg is longer, and moveth with difficulty; the Knee is turned outward, and the head of the Thigh-bone by the hands may be perceiv'd in the Groin. As it is difficult to put in, ≈øo ea≈øily doth it ≈ølip out again, whereby the Part affected is wa≈øted, and the Patient lamed. To reduce it to its place, lay the Patient upon the mid≈øt of a Bench or Table; between his Legs put a ≈øtrong ≈øtick, wound about with Linnen, and upon it let him ≈øtifly ≈øtretch out his Leg, and the Chirurgeon in the mean time with his hands ≈øet it. If outwardly di≈ølocated, the Leg grows ≈øhorter, and the Foot is turned inwards. The Patient can then indeed bend his Leg, but hardly bring it to the ground. Though it be not ≈øet aright, yet the pain vani≈øheth of it ≈øelf, and the Patient in time is able to go without Crutches. Lay him on a Bench or Table as above; let the Leg be ≈øtrongly extended, either with hands or Bandage, and mean while reduce it into its place. If the Hip be forced out forward, the Groin is ≈øwoln, and the Buttocks fallen, the Leg is neither longer nor ≈øhorter, nor
cannot be bent but with trouble; and the Urine is ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed. Though it be not ≈øet aright, yet the Patient in time will be able to go well enough upon it; though ≈øometimes it falls out, that he mu≈øt ≈øomewhat trail his Leg after him. To re≈øtore it, let the Patient lie on his ≈øound ≈øide, and ≈øtrongly ≈øtretch out his Leg, pre≈øs it into its former place; and in ca≈øe the hand be too weak, thru≈øt it in with your Knee. If it be di≈ølocated backward, the Patient can neither ≈øtretch out, nor bend his Leg, nor is he able to bring his Heel to the ground, and if he ≈øhould force him≈øelf to do ≈øo, he would fall backward; the Leg is ≈øhorter, there is a hollowle≈øs in the Groins, and if the Buttocks be pre≈ø≈øed upwards, you ≈øhall find an unu≈øual ≈øwelling. Though it be not put in, yet the pain will in time vani≈øh, and then the Leg may be bent again, but it remains ≈øhorter and ≈øtraight, nor is the Foot turned inward nor outward. Lay the Patient on his Belly, and ≈øtrongly extend his Leg; mean time apprehend the Thigh bone above the Knee; ≈øtretch it outward from off the ≈øound Leg; pre≈øs the Head into its Cavity, in which yet it will not ≈øtay, if thenceforth the Patient do not keep him≈øelf very quiet.
10. The Di≈ølocations of the Tibia and Fibula, are cured after the ≈øame manner as tho≈øe of the Cubitus and Radius.

11. If the Knee pan be out of its place, let the Patient ≈øtand upright, and pre≈øs it in again; lay on the ≈øide whence it hath been forced away, a hollow Splint, an≈øwerable to the ≈øhape of the ≈øaid Pan, and below in the cavity of the Leg, put one or more compre≈ø≈øing Splints, binding the whole Leg ≈øo ≈øtiff, that the Knee may not bend.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Ruptures.
div.p: HAving thus roughly handled the boney and hard parts of the Body, it now follows, that I treat the ≈øoft and fle≈øhie more gently, and de≈øcribe their Synthe≈øis or re-unition again. Therefore I begin with the broken Peritonaeum, which ≈øometimes gives way to the Inte≈øtines, at other times to the Cawl, and not ≈øeldom to both, to get out of their natural place into the Groins or Scrotum, there cau≈øing a Rupture called Entorocele, or Hernia Inte≈øtinalis, if the Guts come out; an Epiplocele, or Hernia Omentalis, if the Omentum or Cawl be out.

The Peritonaeum is made up of two ≈øtrong, but ≈øoft Membranes, which do ≈øo contain what≈øoever is included in the Belly or lowe≈øt Cavity, that when ≈øound, nothing can fall out. In Women, the Os Pubis is its utmo≈øt Limit. In Men, its outermo≈øt Membrane reaches farther; and con≈øtitutes the fir≈øt proper Coat of the Te≈øticles. In the Groins, it comprehends the Seminal Ve≈ø≈øels as in a Sheath, called Proce≈ø≈øus, or Productio Peritonaei. This being ≈øtretch'd, or enlarged, or coming to bur≈øt, is the proximate cau≈øe to the lately mentioned Ruptures. The Groins therefore are the u≈øual places of Ruptures: But do not imagine, that the Peritonoeum cannot be di≈øtended or bur≈øt in other places, and there to cau≈øe a Rupture. It happens ≈øometimes above the Navel, yet ≈øeldom: Beneath, and on the ≈øide of the Navel, far
above the Groins, I have not only ≈øeen it often, with many others, but ≈øeen it ordered and dre≈ø≈øed ju≈øt like an Ab≈øce≈øs; the Chirurgeon giving no other rea≈øon for his mi≈øtake, than that it was not the place of Ruptures; which tho≈øe that love the Art and their own Honour, may take notice of.

Mo≈øt times the Ileon falls down, yet ≈øometimes the other Guts come out with it, and fall into the Scrotum; which cannot come to pa≈øs by a ≈øimple di≈øtention of the above≈øaid proce≈øs, but that nece≈ø≈øarily in all ≈øuch great Ruptures it mu≈øt be broken.

The Cau≈øes which make the Peritonaeum to bur≈øt or to dilate, are Falling, Leaping, Blows, bearing of heavy Burdens, ≈øtrong Vomiting or Coughing, difficult going to Stool, Winds retained, and all vehement Motions of the Body.

Signs.] The Tumor is ≈øometimes bigger, ≈øometimes le≈ø≈øer, ≈øometimes altogether vani≈øht, but with the lea≈øt Motion returning. Though the Caul or Inte≈øtines ≈øhould be fallen down never ≈øo much, they may ea≈øily, without any pain, be thru≈øt in again, unle≈øs Wind or Excrement hinder it, in which ca≈øe the Rupture is very painful.

If the Inte≈øtines be full of Wind, the whole belly is ten≈øe; you may hear a noi≈øe, and the Patient breaks Wind upwards and downwards. If the Excrements be grown hard, the Patient goes with difficulty to Stool, and the ≈øwelling, weight and hardne≈øs, little by little encrea≈øeth. If the Peritonaeum be only relaxed and widened, then the Tumor from little becomes bigger by degrees; but if it be broken, it ≈øuddenly de≈øcends.

Progno≈øticks.] In little Children, Ruptures are ea≈øily cured; in aged people, ≈ølowly or not at all, e≈øpecially if the Peritonaeum be bur≈øt. If
the Inte≈øtines be filled with Wind or Excrements, there follows pain; and if that be not ≈øuddenly removed, an Inflamation, Gangrene, and at la≈øt Death it ≈øelf.

Cure.] Lay the Patient on his Back with his Legs on high, and a little a≈øunder, by which it often comes to pa≈øs, that the Caul or the Inte≈øtines return of them≈øelves into their former place; but that not happening, pre≈øs them in gently with your fingers. And if you cannot effect this, by rea≈øon of Wind or hardened Excrements, then u≈øe the following Medicines.

div.head: Where the Excrements are indurated,
div.p: Take Roots of Mar≈øh-mallows, two ounces: of white Lillies, one ounce; Leaves of Mallows, Violets, Pellitory of the Wall, of each half a handful; Flowers of Camomile and Melilot, of each two pugils; Bran, half a handful: Boil them in Water, and to the Liquor,
Add of
Barly and Bean-meal, of each three ounces; Lin-≈øeed and Fenugreek, of each two drams; Oyl of Ro≈øes and white Lillies, Ducks-Fat, and Hens Fat, of each an ounce. Make it into Catapla≈øm.

In ca≈øe this Catapla≈øm be not ≈øufficient, or ≈øeems not to be ≈øo, then bathe the Patient two or three hours in Oyl, ≈øweet Milk, or Water, wherein Emollients have been boyled; not forgetting in the mean time Cly≈øters and Purges.

div.head: Again≈øt Wind.
div.p:
Take Oyl of Camomile, Rue, of each one
ounce; Oyl of Nard and Dill, of each three drams; Spirit of Wine, two drams; a little Wax: Make it into an Oyntment.
Another,

Take Oyl of Wormwood, one ounce; Oyl of Nard and Nutmeg expre≈øt, of each half an ounce: Oyl of Mace and Carraways di≈øtilled, of each one dram; Malm≈øey, an ounce and half: Boil it a little, then add to it as much Wax as is ≈øufficient to make it into an Ointment.
Inwardly u≈øe the ≈øeeds of Ani≈øe, Fenel, Carraways, and others Medicines di≈øpelling Wind; which al≈øo are to be mixt in the peculiar Cly≈øters requi≈øite to this purpo≈øe.
Al≈øo the Cumin Plai≈øter u≈øed by ≈øome, may here do good ≈øervice.
Or,
Take the Styptick Plai≈øter of Crollius, Gum-Caranna, Tacamahac, of each half a dram; Ol. Philo≈øophorum, and Carraways di≈øtilled, of each an ounce: Make it into a Plai≈øter.

The≈øe impediments being thus removed, and the Caul or Inte≈øtines reduced to their place; you mu≈øt then with convenient Bands or Tru≈ø≈øes ≈øo long keep them in, until the bur≈øt Peritonaeum be ≈øo firmly grown, either together again, or to the Mu≈øcles of the Belly, that nothing can fall out of it any more. And this you will the ≈øooner obtain, if you outwardly lay on it the following Plai≈øter, and inwardly a≈ø≈øi≈øt Nature with appropriated Medicines. But here remember, that in old Ruptures, and aged People, the edges of the bur≈øt Peritonaeum are ≈øometimes callous, that how fitly ≈øoever they are brought together, yet they can never grow together; and
in that ca≈øe Bands mu≈øt do the be≈øt; but in young Children they ea≈øily grow together; and here Tru≈ø≈øes are better than the be≈øt Bands: Tho≈øe that are not acquainted with them, mu≈øt confult tho≈øe that are.

div.head: A Plai≈øter for a Rupture.
div.p: Take Roots of the great Comfrey, Bi≈øtort, of each an ounce and half; Round Birthwort, two drams; Galls, Cypre≈øs-Nuts, Pomegranate-Rinds, of each one dram and half; Flowers of Balau≈øtians, Red-Ro≈øes, Oak-Leaves, of each half a dram; Aloes, Dragons-Blood, Acacia, Earth-worms dried, Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, Myrrhe, Sarcocols, Mummy, of each one dram; Pitch, Colophony, Burnt-Talch, of each one dram; Lytharge, Bole-Armonick, Lap. Hematitis, prepared Steel, of each one ≈øcruple; Venice-Turpentine, as much as is ≈øufficient to make a Plai≈øter.

div.head: An Apozem, that the Patient may take five ounces two or three time a day.
div.p: Take O≈ømund-Royal, Rupture wort, of each one handful; Roots of the great Comfrey, Bi≈øtort of each one ounce and half; St. Johns-wort Flowers, one handful; Ani≈øeeds, two drams; Boyl them in Red-Wine, and to a pint and half of the ≈øtrained Liquor,
Add,
Of the Syrup of Comfrey of Fernelius, two ounces: Make it an Apozem.

div.head: Pills that the Patient may take five or ≈øix of, mornings and evenings.
div.p: Take Mummy, one dram; Galbanum di≈ø≈øolved in Vinegar, two drams; Myrrhe, Filings of Steel, dried Hares-Dung, of each half a dram; Powder of Earth-Worms, two ≈øcruples: Make them into Pils about the bigne≈øs of a great Pea≈øe.

If by a Wound, the Caul or Inte≈øtines come out, you are to endeavour to put them in again, before they lo≈øe their natural warmth or colour by the Air, otherwi≈øe there will remain but ≈ømall hopes of recovery.

If the Inte≈øtines be wounded, then with a waxed Thread ≈øtitch the Lips together, and with a gentle hand return it into the Body; as al≈øo the Omentum ≈ølipt out, unle≈øs it ≈øhould have lo≈øt its natural colour and warmth; in which ca≈øe, you mu≈øt tie it in the place where it is ≈øound, cutting off the part that is putrid, and reduce it into the Belly, leaving the Thread hanging out of the Wound, that after Suppuration, it may be conveniently fetcht out.

And then you mu≈øt ≈øtitch together the Wound of the Belly and the Peritonaeum, which is to be done after this manner; Take a Needle, thred it with a Waxen Thread, thru≈øt it from without through the Skin and Mu≈øcles unto the very Peritonaeum; leaving it on this ≈øide untoucht, but lay hold on it on the other ≈øide; pierce it through, and the Mu≈øcles and the Skin al≈øo, drawing the Lips together; then pa≈ø≈øing over the ≈øpace of an inch, thru≈øt in the Needle on the ≈øame ≈øide again, on which you drew it out la≈øt, through the Skin
and Mu≈øcles, leaving again the Peritonaeum on the ≈øame ≈øide untoucht, but holding it on the other ≈øide, thru≈øt it through together with the Skin and Mu≈øcles, and ≈øo on: Then ≈øeeing that by rea≈øon of the continual motion of the Belly, your ≈øtitches may be ea≈øily undone, the rather, becau≈øe the ha≈øte, ≈øometimes here to be u≈øed, will not permit to make them with Exactne≈øs, it is always nece≈ø≈øary to apply to the Wound a ≈øticking-Plai≈øter.

Among the≈øe Ruptures is to be reckoned the Navel-Rupture (called Exomphalos, or Hernia Umbilicalis) which proceeds from the ≈øame cau≈øe, and is cured by the ≈øame means: Only you are here to ob≈øerve, That upon the Plai≈øter, you mu≈øt put Bol≈øters of Leather, or other hard things, and this according to the bigne≈øs of the Rupture; that by this means it may be ≈øufficiently and perfectly kept in.

It is worthy nothing that the Peritonaeum ≈øeldom bur≈øts in this part. I have divers times found and ≈øhewed in di≈ø≈øected Bodies, that the Navil, together with the Inte≈øtine following, ≈øtood out bigger than a mans Head, in≈øomuch that the right Mu≈øcles of the Belly were pre≈ø≈øed to the ≈øide, and ≈øevered from one another; and yet was the Peritonaeum but ≈øtretched, and no where broken.

The≈øe are the ≈øimple and compounded Ruptures that are commonly de≈øcribed; but Practice ≈øhews us many others, not mention'd by Writers. For, Experience hath taught me, that the Peritonaeum may bur≈øt in the back-part, and there cau≈øe a Rupture. We al≈øo find, that the Proce≈ø≈øus Peritonaei near to the Groins, may come
≈øo to be lacerated, that the Guts pre≈øs not into the Scrotum, but between the Skin and Mu≈øcles falls down toward the Thigh. Be≈øides, we have more than once found, that the V√°s deferens was fallen twi≈øted into the Scrotum, and had there made a Rupture; which happening, it may with the Hands be ea≈øily reduced, yet, goes in of it ≈øelf by lying backward, without any further inconvenience.
The manner of cure had nothing peculiar in it ≈øelf, but that you contrive ≈øuch Bands, that may reduce the parts fallen out into their right place, without prejudicing the ≈øound ones.

Among the≈øe Ruptures, are commonly reckoned divers Swellings, that belong to other Chapters; where al≈øo we intend to de≈øcribe them. But to comply with young Students, I ≈øhall here enumerate tho≈øe that in the modern Practice do occur; Namely,
1. Entero-cele, Hernia Inte≈øtinalis, or the falling down of the Guts into the Groin.
2. Epiplo-cele, Hernia Omentalis, or the falling down of the Caul.
3. Omphalo-cele, Hernia Umbilicalis, or the Rupture of the Navel.
4. Pneumato-cele, Hernia Vento≈øa, or the Wind-Rupture.
5. Hydro-cele, Hernia Aquo≈øa, Water-Rupture.
6. Bubono-cele, Swelling of the Glandules in the Groin.
7. Cir≈øo-cele, a ≈øwelling of the Seminal Ve≈ø≈øels in the Scrotum.
8. Hernia-Veneris, an hardening of the Te≈øticles by an impure Concu√≥itus.
9. Hernia-Humoralis, a Repletion of the Te≈øticles with unnatural Humors.
10. Hernia Carno≈øa, a fle≈øhy Rupture.
11. Broncho-cele, Hernia Gutturis, a ≈øwelling in the Throat.
12. Spermato-cele, figuratively ≈øo called by me, when the Vas deferens falls twi≈øted into the Scrotum.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the falling down of the Matrix.
div.p: THe Matrix does not ea≈øily fall down by Relaxation, much le≈øs by Laceration of her broad Ligaments, as mo≈øt Writers imagin; from hard Labour, or by an indi≈øcreet drawing away of the Secundine. Others with me have ≈øeen, that the bottom of the Matrix hath been plainly inverted in pudendis, ≈øo that the inward part ≈øhewed it ≈øelf as the outward. We have al≈øo found (e≈øpecially in tho≈øe that were ≈øubject to Co≈øtivene≈øs or Belly-ach) that the membranes of the Pudenda were ≈øo far ≈øtretcht out, that the unskilful have taken it for the Matrix it ≈øelf, and do ≈øo ≈øtill. For though many Authors have dared to write, that the Womb may be cut out without danger of life, ≈øeems altogether impo≈ø≈øible to a skilful Anatomi≈øt.

To cure this Di≈øea≈øe, lay the Patient on her back, with her Knees on high, and Legs a≈øunder; then take a Wax-Candle of a competent thickne≈øs, mix therewith ≈øome Ca≈øtoreum or A≈ø≈øa Foetida, and with it gently pre≈øs the Womb inward, and having ≈øa≈øtened the Candle with a Bandage,
apply outwardly to the Belly the Empla≈øtrum Barbarum, or the following:

Take the Roots of Cyprus, Bi≈øtort, of each a dram; Galls, Acacia, of each half a dram: Cypre≈øs-Nuts, Date-≈øtones, Myrtle-Berries, of each one dram; Pitch and Colophony, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Plai≈øter.
Then pre≈øently enjoyn the Patient to lie ≈øtill, with the Legs cro≈øs, and to beware of ≈øpeaking aloud, of ≈øcolding, and of whatever may occa≈øion coughing or ≈øneezing.

Here great care is to be had, that your Wax-Candle be not too thick, to the end that by its continual friction it may not cau≈øe Fluorem Album, whereby the ≈øtrength of the Body would certainly come to decay. Yet becau≈øe ev'n by the greate≈øt care and circum≈øpection, this inconvenience will hardly be altogether or always prevented; therefore tho≈øe do very well and di≈øcreetly, that longways perforat the Candle, and thereby give a convenient pa≈ø≈øage for the humors flowing that way.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the falling down of the Fundament.
div.p: IF the Gut be ≈øunk down, anoint it with Oyl of Ro≈øe and Myrtle, mixing a little Powder of Galls among≈øt it, and with your Fingers and a ≈ømall Linnen-Rag, put it in. If an Inflamation hinder the reducing it, then bathe the Anus with the≈øe Medicines,

Take Flowers of Elder, Camomile, and St.
John's-wort, of each a handful; Red Ro≈øes, rwo Pugils; the tops of Wormwood and Melilot, of each half a handful: Boil therein Milk and Red Wine, and bathe the part.

Here e≈øpecially care is to be had, that no external cold may come to the fallen-out Anus; for then you may ≈øooner than you are aware of, be ≈øurprized with a Gangreen. Wherefore do your utmo≈øt to put it in again with ≈øpeed; and in the mean time, endeavor with the above pre≈øcrib'd Bathing and warm Linnen Rags, to pre≈øerve its natural heat.

There is yet another, though in appearance ridiculous, yet in reality a good way of reducing the Gut. With a ≈øtrong hand ≈øtrike five or ≈øix times the Patient's Buttocks, and thereby the Mu≈øcles, called Ani levatores, will pre≈øently draw the Anus into its right place again. But before the Patient be thus cha≈øtized, take care that the Gut may fir≈øt be anointed with Oyl of Ro≈øes, or of Myrtle.

div.head: CHAP X. Of the ≈øecond Operation called Diaere≈øis, or the ≈øeperation of what was united together.
div.p: HItherto we have joined together again what had been disjoined; now it follows, that we ≈øeparate what is united, and treat of the ≈øecond Manual Operation, called Diaere≈øis, which teacheth us the manner of Cutting and Burning, and that both in the hard and ≈øoft parts of the Body.

In the ≈øoft, the Cutting is called Inci≈øion. In the hard, it is performed four manner of ways: By Terebration or Perforation; by Ra≈øion or Scraping; by Limation, or Filing; by Serration, or Sawing. Burning is done either by an Iron (which is the Actual Cautery) or by Medicaments (called the Potential Cautery) as ≈øhall be declared particularly hereafter.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of opening a Vein.
div.p: BLeeding (one of the greate≈øt Remedies in the Art of Phy≈øick) is ≈øometimes highly nece≈ø≈øary, but ≈øometimes ≈øo dangerous, that it ought not to be u≈øed without very urgent Cau≈øes. Here therefore I think it will be better ≈øomewhat to digre≈øs for fuller information, than to leave the unskilful in their error.

The Blood is the darling of Nature, by who≈øe a≈ø≈øi≈øtance ≈øhe performeth all her Operations, and which can hardly be drawn from her without dammage; yet does Art require, that tho≈øe who meddle with it, being neither venturous nor timorous, but di≈øcreet and couragious, and making out of nece≈ø≈øity a virtue, do ≈øometimes proceed to the opening a Vein; yet for no other than the≈øe four following cau≈øes.
1. In a Plethora, or ≈øuper-abundance of blood, that by this means Nature may be ea≈øed of her too heavy burden, and the innate heat pre≈øerved from ≈øuffocation.

2. For Revul≈øion-≈øake, when the blood and the (therein) mingled humors, by flowing too plentifully to this or that part, hinder the Cure: Here you are always to chu≈øe a Vein of the oppo≈øite ≈øide, and that ≈øometimes the farthe≈øt di≈øtant, ≈øometimes the neare≈øt.

3. For the Derivation or conveyance of the Blood (which is already got into the part, but is not yet altogether ≈øetled there, nor extrava≈øated) into another place; in which ca≈øe a Vein is to be opened the neare≈øt to the Part.
4. For Refrigeration, when the heat of the Blood is ≈øo exce≈ø≈øive, that it cannot be allayed by cooling Medicines, or not time enough.

The≈øe limits are too narrow for ≈øome, who will needs take into tho≈øe a fifth cau≈øe, which they make the Corruption of the Blood, held by them to be as great an inducement for bleeding as any of the four by us recited; to the end, ≈øay they, that Nature being rid of part of what is corrupt, may be the better able to correct what remains.

But I much wi≈øh, 1. That they could make this di≈øcharge without the lo≈øs of that ≈øtrength which is ≈øo highly nece≈ø≈øary. 2. That they would be pre≈øent when their Patient is to bleed, and preci≈øely tell to what degree of corruption his blood is come, that ≈øo the Chirurgeon may know how much of it he is to take, and how often; fora≈ømuch as they will not allow, that Bleeding is good in all ≈øorts of the Blood's corruption, but in that only which is not gone con≈øiderably far. 3. That they would declare, why they will have cur'd the greater corruption by Purging, and the le≈ø≈øer by Bleeding, ≈øince that they give to the one as well as to the other (and that duly) the name of Cacho-Chimia.
Let them ≈øhew, that things differing only ≈øecundum Majus & Minus, do differ in ≈øpecie, and ≈øo require ≈øpecifically different Remedies.

Others proceed yet further, and ≈øhed innocent Blood in all ≈øorts of Fevers, without any con≈øideration of ≈øpots of the Plague, or of Poi≈øon it ≈øelf; thus freeing them≈øelves from a great deal of labor and trouble, otherwi≈øe caus'd to the Phy≈øitian from the variety of Fevers. But becau≈øe the nature of all Poy≈øon and Malignant Humors is continually to a≈ø≈øault the Heart, and ≈øuddenly to pro≈øtrate the ≈øtrength of the ≈øtronge≈øt Per≈øons; and ≈øince Bleeding doth likewi≈øe both, not only dimini≈øhing ≈øtrength, but al≈øo drawing the malignity toward the Heart, and driving in again, for the oppre≈ø≈øion of Nature, what ≈øhe had thrown out for her relief: I do intreat and warn all the Practi≈øers of our Art, That as they love the quiet of their Mind, and the good of their Patients, they would beware of bleeding in Pe≈øtilential and other Malignant Fevers; as al≈øo in all ca≈øes that may befal People by Poy≈øon, either inward or outward.

The French, Italians, Spaniards and Portugue≈øes (great Blood-letters) will, I expect, tell me; That Nature, when by bleeding ≈øhe hath vent, and is ≈øomewhat di≈øcharg'd, ≈øhall be better able to throw out the remaining Evil. And this ≈øeems to be true, for the blood indeed receives Air, that the Spirits may the better flie away, and is robb'd of that ≈øtrength which it ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarily wants; whereupon Nature exchangeth the Life of the Patient for death, and extorts tears from the By-≈øtanders.

Without alledging other Rea≈øons, they ground them≈øelves upon Experience. And it were to be wi≈øhed they had that ground indeed; for we find
≈øuch Patients of theirs, who in the morning were in no danger, even after but the taking away of five or ≈øix ounces of Blood, to be cold and ≈øtiff at night. Whence it may ea≈øily be collected, what it is they call Experience, viz. If the Patient by chance e≈øcape death, then Bleeding mu≈øt have the honor of it; but if he die, as for the mo≈øt part, then the malignity of the Di≈øea≈øe was the cau≈øe of it. Wherefore I alledge Experience again≈øt Experience, and prai≈øe God Almighty, that he hath vouch≈øafed to furni≈øh all tho≈øe, who without envy, pa≈ø≈øion, or ≈ølavi≈øh dependance upon others, will duly con≈øider Di≈øea≈øes with ≈øurer means.

The more moderate ≈øort of them would have Bleeding only admini≈øtred in the beginning of the Di≈øea≈øe, and before the Malignity appears outwardly. This I ≈øhall willingly allow them; 1. In very hot Countreys. 2. In a Plethorick Body. 3. If the humors flying to the head, cau≈øe any grievous ≈øymptoms there; in which ca≈øe, bleeding in the Hand or Foot may be, I think, very beneficial. Otherwi≈øe tho≈øe that u≈øe it in all bodies, and without di≈øtinction in the≈øe cold and moi≈øt parts, will find the ill effects of it, and be puzled withal to give a rea≈øon for their Practice, allowable by Art; the rather becau≈øe, by their own confe≈ø≈øion, they dare not u≈øe this their Darling of Bleeding at certain times, but find them≈øelves be≈øt in the u≈øe of Sudorificks and cooling Drinks. But enough of this.

Now how many Ounces of Blood ought to be taken at once; the degree of the Di≈øea≈øe, and the Patients more or le≈øs ≈øtrength, will indicate. And 'tis better too little than too much. I have never taken more from the ≈øtronge≈øt and mo≈øt plethoric
Per≈øon under my Cure, than twelve ounces at once, chu≈øing rather, in ca≈øe of need, to let out twenty ounces at two times, than fifteen at once; of which method I have found good ≈øucce≈øs.

As to the ≈øea≈øon of the year, and the hour of the day, little regard needs to be had in tho≈øe Di≈øea≈øes, wherein bleeding cannot be deferred without danger, as in Pluri≈øies, Squinancies, &c. Otherwi≈øe, the Spring and Autumn, and the Morning are be≈øt.

The veins that are wont commonly to be opened, are the≈øe: In the Forehead, the Vena frontis; in the Temples, the Vena Temporalis; in the Mouth, the Vena ≈øublingualis, or Ranularis; in the Neck, the Jugularis externa; in the Arm, the Ba≈øilica, under which lieth an Artery; the Mediana, under which lieth a Nerve, and under both of them a Tendon; and the Cephalica, which hath under, or near it, neither Artery, Nerve, nor Tendon, and therefore may ≈øafely be opened: This la≈øt hath but one ≈ømall Branch that runs outward to the head, whence it hath got the name of the Head Vein. Without this con≈øideration, it little matters which of the≈øe three be opened, in regard that about the Arm-pits they all acknowledge no more but one Branch. In the Hand, between the little finger and its neighbour, the Salvatella; in the Foot, the Saphena and I≈øchiatica.

The manner of Bleeding is ≈øo well known, that I think it needle≈øs here to de≈øcribe it; only I could wi≈øh, that ≈øome of tho≈øe that let blood, would take care ≈øomewhat better to gue≈øs of the number of Ounces of Blood they take from their Patients, that ≈øo we might not find 12, 16, 18, yea, 22 ounces drawn away in≈øtead of 6 or 8, that
were pre≈øcribed. To prevent ≈øo intolerable a mi≈øtake, I would advi≈øe, that ≈ømall Porringers of Tin or Copper were made, in which the number of ounces were mark'd; though expert Ma≈øters do not at all need them, as knowing that Blood is really weightier, than it outwardly ≈øeems.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the opening of Ab≈øce≈ø≈øes, or Impo≈øthumes.
div.p: THe Humors here and there gathered, do often cau≈øe a Swelling, which nature is not always able to di≈ø≈øipate, unle≈øs Art do ≈øuccor her by fit means; which if fruitle≈øs, you mu≈øt u≈øe Suppuration, and then ≈øtay till ≈øhe of her ≈øelf make an opening, except there be a nece≈ø≈øity to ha≈øten one, or even not to ≈øtay for a perfect Suppuration: As, 1. When the matter being very ≈øharp or malign, upon which happens a Corro≈øion of the neighboring parts, and a corruption of the Bones, Tendons or Nerves. 2. When it may affect a nobler part. 3. When it lieth in the Joynts. 4. When it is ca≈øt out by a Cri≈øis.

Before you proceed to the opening, you are to con≈øider, whether the matter be contain'd in its own proper Tunicle, or whether it be without any Tunicle. If without any, then make your apertion with a right Line, ob≈øerving the Fibres of the Mu≈øcles. For Example; In the head, according to the po≈øition of the Hair, long-ways; in the Eyelids, tran≈øver≈øe; in the Temples, the No≈øe, Neck, Brea≈øt, Back, Arms, Feet, Joynts, long-ways;
in the mid≈øt of the Abdomen, let it be long-ways; in the ≈øides of it ≈øomewhat oblique; in the Groins, tran≈øver≈øe; but not very deep, by ≈øea≈øon of the ≈øubjacent ≈øeminary Ve≈ø≈øels. Always beware of touching any great Vein, Artery or Nerve, though the Fibres be cut a-cro≈øs, le≈øt from a le≈ø≈øer evil there ≈øhould ari≈øe a greater.

The propere≈øt place for the opening, is the mo≈øt rai≈øed and ≈øofte≈øt part of the Ab≈øce≈øs, if po≈ø≈øible in the depending, that the purulent matter may the more conveniently be di≈øcharged: To which end al≈øo you are with a Tent ≈øo long to keep open the wound, until the part, being altogether clean≈øed of its preternatural Humors, may return to its former Functions.

In the opening, thru≈øt not in the Launcet too deep, nor further into the Cavity than to the matter; and as ≈øoon as you perceive that, draw it a little back, and turn the point upward; making your opening through the Skin ≈øo big as may afford the contained matter a free vent.

If the Ab≈øce≈øs be included in a Tunicle, if ≈ømall, make the Inci≈øion long ways; if big, then make a double inci≈øion, that is, cro≈øs-ways; and beware of touching the Ve≈øicle, otherwi≈øe you mu≈øt expect a foetide and almo≈øt incurable Ulceration. This being well done, pre≈øs out with your Fingers the Ve≈øicle, which ≈øeldom or never ≈øticks to the Skin, and ea≈øily follows; cut off the little Artery by which it is fed; and have a care, that not the lea≈øt Particle of the Bag may remain on it, le≈øt it gather again.

Fora≈ømuch as in this Operation I find, that Chirurgeons differ in the In≈øtrument they ought to u≈øe, ≈øome chu≈øing the Launcet, others the Potential Cautery,
and extol it far above the former: I think my ≈øelf obliged to declare here what I judge of this matter.

The Potential Cautery hath this Advantage, that it doth not terrifie timorous Patients, nor is painful to the tender; e≈øpecially joyning with it the pre≈øent and known good Remedies: For unquenched Lime, mixed with Holland Sope, worketh deep enough into the fle≈øh, yet much gentlier than the Corro≈øive of Ambr. Paraeus. But it hath the≈øe Inconveniencies:

1. That according to the tenderne≈øs or ≈øtrength of the Skin or Bodies, ≈øometimes it eats in deeper than needs; for we have found by experience, that in ≈øome it hath eaten through the Skin and Mu≈øcles, to the very cavity of the Belly; in others irrecoverably wounded the proce≈ø≈øes of the Peritonaeum, together with the ≈øeminal ve≈ø≈øels therein.

2. Commonly it ≈øpreads it ≈øelf in length and breadth ≈øomewhat further than you would have it, e≈øpecially if it be to be applied under the Armpits, in the Groin, or in the Joynts; for it no ≈øooner grows warm, but it melts, and ≈øo ≈øpreads abroad, notwith≈øtanding the Plai≈øter with which the Surgeon de≈øigned to bound it.
3. There are nece≈ø≈øarily required ≈øome hours (in ≈øome Bodies more, in others le≈øs) before it can perform its Operation; and this the Humor will not always bear, e≈øpecially if it be malign.

4. And the Scar falls not pre≈øently off; and if you would give a pre≈øent vent to the Humors, you will be obliged ≈øtill to make u≈øe of a Launcet. Be as circum≈øpect as you can, I am ≈øure, you will hardly avoid the≈øe Inconveniencies.

On the other hand, the Launcet hath this trouble,
that many people are affrighted at it, and that it is painful: But the fear may be prevented by ≈øilence, and the pain is little con≈øiderable; mean time you have the≈øe Advantages:
1. That with the Launcet, the Apertion may be made as long and as deep as the Chirurgeon de≈øireth.
2. The matter is ≈øuddenly di≈øcharged, and the Patient hath pre≈øent relief.
3. The unconcocted remainder may be the ≈øooner concocted, by a≈ø≈øi≈øting Nature with convenient Remedies, both inwardly and outwardly.

4. You will not be troubled with a long gleet, which if it happens, the fault is a≈ø≈øuredly in the Chirurgeon. For almo≈øt all Tumors that appear behind the Ears, in the Neck, under the Armpits, or in the Groin, ≈øpring from indurated Glandules, replete with a preternatural humor; the≈øe Glandules are all included in their own Membranes, which being toucht, either with a Launcet, or with Corro≈øive Medicines, there mu≈øt needs follow a gleet (for 'tis impo≈ø≈øible that the Glandule ≈øhould be able to pre≈øerve it ≈øelf, or the contained Humor, its Tunicle being divided) which will continue until the whole Glandule and Tunicle are both con≈øumed.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Separation of Parts unnaturally joyned.
div.p: WIthin the Ear is a thin, but ≈øtrong Membrane called the Drum. This being overgrown with another preternatural Membrane, or a Caruncle, the Patient lo≈øeth his hearing; which is not at all to be cured by any Manual Art, and difficultly by Medicines. But if the Cavity of the Ear come to be clo≈øed up with a Membrane, and thereby the hearing lo≈øt, then is it to be opened with a fit In≈øtrument, and as ≈øoon as may be, cicatriz'd.

That many have been born with the Anus imperforated, and the Inte≈øtine covered with a Membrane, hath been often ob≈øerved; which if the Membrane be tender and thin, is to be opened with the Fingers; if thick, with a Launcet, long-ways; and afterwards kept open with a ≈ømall leaden Pipe, and drying Medicines.

The Pudenda Virginum are ≈øometimes al≈øo clos'd with a preternatural Membrane, which cau≈øeth mo≈øt grievous Accidents, when they are grown marriageable. Sometimes the part is altogether grown together; ≈øometimes upon an ill-treated Ulcer, coale≈øcunt Labia & Membrum illud ineptum reddunt congre≈ø≈øui virili. Sometimes a preternatural Caruncle ≈øhuts the Os Vulvae. The two fir≈øt are to be opened long ways with a ≈øharp In≈øtrument, in part wound about with linnen Rags,
and then cured according to Art. To the la≈øt, which cau≈øeth mo≈øt difficulty, you'l need in the Operation a Speculum Matricis, and in the latter end of the Cure, a ≈ømall Pipe, perforated throughout in length, to promote the Cicatrizing.

Here we ≈øhall take leave to ≈øpeak ≈øomething of the Tongue, not of a long and ≈øharp one, for which I have found either none, or at lea≈øt, no better remedy than contempts, patience and commi≈øeration; but of tho≈øe, that being ≈øhort and tied, deprive Children, fir≈øt, of Sucking, afterwards of Speaking: Which is ea≈øily remedied, by loo≈øening the ≈øtring of the Tongue, by cutting it tran≈øver≈øe with a pair of Sci≈ø≈øars, and anointing it afterwards with Honey of Ro≈øes three or four times a day. In the cutting, the neighboring parts and veins mu≈øt be carefully ≈øhunned; and ≈øometimes the Nerve of the ≈øixth pair of its Branches run ≈øo near the String, that by a deep inci≈øion they may be ea≈øily hurt, and the Patient fall into ≈øad Accidents. Here let the Chirurgeon know, that of an hundred Children, ≈øcarce one needs this Manual Operation; and that tho≈øe Midwives are as ra≈øh as ignorant, who in all new-born Babes, do forthwith dilacerate this String, whereby the found parts being hurt, they are often deprived of their nece≈ø≈øary Sucking, and, by ≈øub≈øequent ≈øymptoms, of their Life.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the Paracenthe≈øis.
div.p: ALthough the word Paracenthe≈øis, ≈øignifies all Punctures, yet cu≈øtom hath appropriated it ≈øolely to the opening of the Belly in a Drop≈øie, and to that of the Brea≈øt in Empyema, though more to that than to this.

This Manual Operation is ancient, and full of danger; yet ≈øometimes pre≈øerves the life of the Patient. Nature and Succe≈øs have emboldened us now and then to make u≈øe of it; but Experience hath taught us, that the greate≈øt difficulty con≈øi≈øts herein: 1. That the parts debilitated, and de≈øerted of their natural heat, do ea≈øily, after opening, mortifie. 2. That together with the Water, i≈ø≈øues out likewi≈øe the Spirits. 3. That the pre≈ø≈øing water can hardly be ≈øo kept in, but it will run out in de≈øpight of the Chirurgeon; and if, the better to clo≈øe the Wound, you do forcibly pre≈øs in the Pipe, a Gangrene ≈øoon and ea≈øily en≈øueth.

Who therefore expects a good i≈ø≈øue of this Operation, mu≈øt u≈øe it only upon a Body that is not emaciated or wa≈øted; in a Drop≈øie that is recent (or at lea≈øt, when the Tumor in a ≈øhort time hath ri≈øen to a great bulk) and which, upon the u≈øe of proper Remedies, would not pre≈øently be removed; in ≈øuch Patients that are not mole≈øted with a Fever, or with difficulty of breathing, and where the noble parts are yet ≈øound and uncorrupted; and in per≈øons of a middle age, ≈øince in Children and in old people it ≈øucceeds not ≈øo pro≈øperou≈øly.

As to the Place; if the Navel ≈øtands out, ≈øeek for no other, but make your opening therein: But if that be much drawn in (as it commonly happens to be in Hydropical Per≈øons) it is not proper for it: In which ca≈øe you mu≈øt take for your place three inches beneath the Navel, not in the white-Line, which, to my wonder, I find propo≈øed by ≈øome; but, on the ≈øide of the right Mu≈øcle, in the Mu≈øcle called Oblique De≈øcendens: Mark it fir≈øt with Ink, and then make a ≈ømall Apertion through the Skin, Mu≈øcles, and Peritonaeum, taking great care that the Omentum, or Guts, be not wounded; which al≈øo, by rea≈øon of the interpo≈øing Water, cannot ea≈øily be hurt. He that will be very careful of the opening, mu≈øt make it according to the Ductus of the Fibres, a little obliquely downwards (according to this \) in the left ≈øide; and (according to this, /) in the right ≈øide.

As ≈øoon as you perceive Water to come forth, take a Golden, Silver, or Leaden ≈ømall Pipe, that is, 1. Smooth. 2. Furni≈øht at the Head with a Button or Wing. 3. Perforated on the ≈øides with three or four holes. 4. No longer than the thickne≈øs of the di≈ø≈øected part, that is, an inch broad. 5. Somewhat crooked at the end. 6. Exactly fitting the ≈øize of the Orifice. Put this into the Apertion, lay over it a ≈øticking-Plai≈øter (others take a Spunge, or a four double linnen Rag) bind up the Patient, and let him re≈øt two or three hours; then open the Bandage again, and take away one, two, three, ≈øeldom or never more pints of Water, and ≈øo repeating it once or twice a day, till the water be almo≈øt all di≈øcharged. You mu≈øt not take away all at fir≈øt, for the chilne≈øs of
the parts, following ≈øo great an Evacuation, very often cau≈øeth death. The Pipe is not to be taken out, but mu≈øt remain all the time of the cure in the Wound, which you mu≈øt at length heal up according to Art.

For the opening of an Hydropical Belly, this is the ≈øafe≈øt as hitherto practi≈øed way, that is left us by the Ancients; but the indu≈øtry of their Po≈øterity hath invented for us a much convenienter In≈øtrument, whereby we not only do avoid many of the above-mentioned difficulties, but al≈øo with le≈øs trouble pre≈øerve the lives otherwi≈øe incurable Patients, freeing them from ≈øtretching, pain and trouble, according to our plea≈øure, or the degree of their ≈øtrength.

This never enough commended In≈øtrument was fir≈øt of all brought out of Italy; by the experienced Chirurgeon of this City, Mr. Jacob Block, and by him put into practice, to the great benefit of many Patients.

Commonly he chu≈øeth the place lately pointed out by us, viz. about three inches below the Navel, and perforates the Skin, Mu≈øcles and Peritonaeum, unto the very Water, taking away no more at once than a quart.

That done, he draws out his In≈øtrument again, puts nothing upon the made hole but dry Lint and a ≈øticking-Plai≈øter, whereby he ≈øufficiently hinders the running out, again≈øt your Will, of even a drop of Water; for, upon the withdrawing of the In≈øtrument, the opened Skin, Mu≈øcles and Peritonaeum are ea≈øily by their natural motion ≈øo far drawn a≈øunder, that the holes cannot any more exactly clo≈øe upon one another.

This being once performed, we regulate our≈øelves
according to the ≈øtrength of the Patient, ≈øtaying two, three or more days, before we repeat this Operation; then either the fir≈øt Orifice is to be opened, or again a new one to be made, e≈øpecially if the Chirurgeon finds, that the Water may be more conveniently drawn away in another place.

In an Hydrocele (when the water is fallen into the Scrotum) the ≈øaid Chirurgeon doth by this In≈øtrument ≈øo dexterou≈øly di≈øcharge the Water out of the Scrotum, that the next day you ≈øhall not, or hardly be able to find where the Hole was.

The Perforation ≈øeems to me a little inconvenient, wherefore I have cau≈øed this In≈øtrument ≈øo far to be altered, as that I make the end not to be wrought round, but ≈øharp on both ≈øides, Launcetwi≈øe, by which means it may be ≈øooner thru≈øt through the Mu≈øcles. But then, his may be made of Silver, mine mu≈øt be of Steel.
To the end that you may the better comprehend what we ≈øay, we ≈øhall repre≈øent to your view the In≈øtrument, and the Operation it ≈øelf, in the en≈øuing Figures.
