div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Opening of the Brea≈øt.
div.p: THere is ≈øometimes collected in the Cavity of the Brea≈øt a water or purulent matter.

The Water gathers either by ≈øome Lymphatick Ve≈ø≈øels bur≈øt, or from an unconcocted watrine≈øs of the Blood. The purulent Matter follows upon Inflammations of the Throat, or Lungs, or a Pleuri≈øie, &c.
If it be Matter that is collected, it is called Empyema; if Water, Hydrops pectoris vel pulmonis, the Drop≈øie of the Brea≈øt or Lungs.

The Marks of the Water are, a dry Cough, a painful heavine≈øs, a difficulty of breathing, even to Suffocation, great Thir≈øt, little Appetite, a pale Look and ≈øometimes a ≈øwelling of the Legs, now and then accompanied with a Feaver; and when the Patient turns him≈øelf, you may perceive a rumbling noi≈øe.

The collected Sanies may be known by the following Signs; When the Inflamation of the Lungs or Pleura, will not, upon Bleeding, or other convenient means, be ≈øufficiently removed, then may you apprehend a collection of ≈øuch matter to come within a fortnight. Between the thirtieth and fortieth day the Tumor commonly breaks. The Patient ≈øhall find a great heavine≈øs in his Che≈øt without con≈øiderable pain; and in ca≈øe it is accompanied with pain, then you are to Expect a new Flux, which you mu≈øt divert by Bleeding. The
Patient hath a difficulty in breathing; in motion, he hears a rumbling, at lea≈øt he is ≈øen≈øible that the matter changeth place, and the ≈øide affected is to the touch, hotter than the other. He ca≈øts up, with violent coughing, a purulent matter, having a continual Fever; he finds an anxiety at his heart, and hath little ≈øtomach to his meat.
If we cannot expel the≈øe Humors by Expectorating, nor by Diureticks, nor Diaphoreticks, nor by purging Medicines, then are we forc'd to come to Manual Operation.

This cannot be done without danger, and is not to be attempted in ca≈øe the Patient be weak, and the inward parts already corrupted. However, this Operation hath le≈øs danger than the next foregoing, and people oftner recover upon it; yea, Learned Writers a≈ø≈øure us, that by this Operation, and the u≈øe of Injection, they have cured many of Ulcers of the Lungs.

Concerning the Place of Opening, Authors are not agreed in it; the rea≈øon whereof is obvious: For, the Diaphragma runs higher in ≈øome per≈øons than in others; whence it comes to pa≈øs, that the collected Humors in ≈øome Patients, lie higher than in others. Secondly, the Che≈øt is rai≈øed in ≈øome, flat in others; which here much alters the ca≈øe. Be≈øides, the Lungs do often grow ≈øo fa≈øt to the Pleura, that the ≈øanious matter cannot ea≈øily be carried into the Cavity of the Brea≈øt: In which ca≈øe it would be ill done, to cho≈øe the place of Opening lowe≈øt, in re≈øpect of the Diaphragma. And in regard that in this, as in other ≈øwellings, the mo≈øt eminent place is, e≈øteemed the mo≈øt convenient for opening, it cannot be otherwi≈øe but that one Chirurgeon hath made
choice of this place, and another u≈øeth that place as the be≈øt. Upon which account, Hyppocrates Guido, Amatus Lu≈øitanus, &c. do make the apertion between the third and fourth Rib, counting from beneath upwards: Fienus, Riverius, and many others, between the fourth and fifth; Paulus Aegineta, Vidus Vidius, Fabritius ab Aquapendente, Sennertus, &c. between the fifth and ≈øixth; which place, in my opinion, is the ≈øafe≈øt; for, if higher, the Pericardium, if lower, the Diaphragma may be wounded, of which there have been many ≈øad Examples. But in this difference of di≈ø≈øenting Writers, what hath been ≈øaid, will direct you to pa≈øs into the ≈øafe≈øt Haven.

All things therefore well con≈øidered, chu≈øe the place where to make your Apertion; not the forepart (for, before, the Sternum or Brea≈øt-bone will hinder your operation here; nor in the back-part, for the Ribs are ≈øo clo≈øe to one another, that without hurting ≈øome Ve≈ø≈øels, you cannot make any Apertion there) but on the ≈øide, four or five inches from the Sternum: Neither ought the Inci≈øion to be ≈øo near to the upper Ribs, as to the lower, becau≈øe the interco≈øtal Ve≈ø≈øels, viz. the Vein, Artery and Nerve, lie in the lower part of each Rib, where Nature hath a≈ø≈øigned them a place, branching them≈øelves into the middle of the interco≈øtal Mu≈øcles; which di≈ø≈øemination neverthele≈øs hinders not, but that the Inci≈øion may be made in the middle between the two Ribs.

After you have marked the place with Ink, charge the Patient to breath forth as long as po≈ø≈øibly he can, without taking it in, and in the mean time make an oblique, but ≈ømall Orifice, and put into it a Silver or Leaden Pipe, and take forth four
or five ounces of Matter to run out in a day. In ca≈øe the Matter does not come forth well, place your Patient on the wounded ≈øide, and make him to cough; if by rea≈øon of its toughne≈øs it will not yet come forth, then inject into the cavity ≈øome ab≈øter≈øive, ex≈øiccating and healing Medicines; As,
Take Goats whey, eighteen ounces; Honey of Ro≈øes, four ounces; the Juice of Celandine and Smallage, of each ≈øix drams: Mingle it.
Or,

Take the Roots of Comfrey the greater, an ounce; of Sanicle, half an ounce; the Leaves of Betony, Agrimony, Periwincle, Burnet, of each half a handful; the Cordial Flowers, two pugils; the Seed of St. John'swort, Holy-Thi≈øtle, Roman-Nettle, of each half a dram: Boil them in Water and Honey to a pint and half; ≈øtrain it, and keep it for your u≈øe.
Of this Injection, the Patient may al≈øo drink a little twice or thrice a day.

It is yet further to be ob≈øerved, that the collected Matter is often contained in a Membrane of its own, and by its ri≈øing, manife≈øts it ≈øelf from without; and then the Latines call it Vomica Pulmonis: In which ca≈øe, you mu≈øt not ≈øtay till the Membrane breaks of its ≈øelf; for by delay, the Matter flowing up and down is more difficulty to be got out of the Brea≈øt; but open it pre≈øently, taking no other place, but the mo≈øt rai≈øed part of the ≈øwelling.

Now, ≈øince an Empyema for the mo≈øt part follows upon a Pleuri≈øie, and 'tis dayly found, that ignorant Chirurgeons take all kind of pain in the Sides, Belly and Brea≈øt, although cau≈øed from Winds only, for a Pleuri≈øie; thereupon immediately
opening a Vein; I thought therefore nece≈ø≈øary to write in this place of the Pleuri≈øie, as much as is nece≈ø≈øary for a Chirurgeon to know, for the preventing ≈øuch mi≈øtakes.

The Pleuri≈øie then is an inflammation of the Pleura, and commonly of the Lungs them≈øelves, cau≈øed from afflux of Blood, accompanied with Pain Cough, ≈øpitting of Blood, ≈øhortne≈øs of Breath, continual Feaver, ≈øtrong and quick Pul≈øe.
The Cau≈øe is the Blood, ≈øometimes alone (when a true Pleuri≈øie) ≈øometimes mixt with other Humors then it occa≈øions a Ba≈øtard one.
The Signs, as may be ≈øeen in the De≈øcription, are ≈øo evident, that tho≈øe who know not how to di≈øtingui≈øh it from a Cholick, are not worthy of any excu≈øe.

The Progno≈øticks.] The ≈øooner the matter is concocted, and the whiter and ea≈øier 'tis ejected, the quicker and ≈øafer is the I≈ø≈øue. If the Cough, and difficulty of breathing le≈ø≈øen not by a copious Expectoration, 'tis an ill ≈øign. If the Patient come not to ≈øpit the third or fourth day, then will he ≈øcarce ≈øee the ≈øeventh. If upon Bleeding, and other fit means, the pain cea≈øe not, the Patient mu≈øt either die, or the Pleuri≈øie will turn to a Con≈øumption, or an Empyema.

The Cure.] In this ca≈øe, Bleeding is one of the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary and ≈øafe≈øt means of Cure; and if u≈øed in time, the Patient, in the very Operation, and before the Vein be clo≈øed, will find relief, and ≈øometimes be altogether freed of the pain. Nor do I know any Di≈øea≈øe, in which there may, to the Patient's benefit, be ≈øo much Blood taken away at once, as in this.

There are different Opinions concerning what
≈øide the Patient is to bleed on: But tho≈øe have had little Experience of this ≈øickne≈øs, who have not found, that Patients (at lea≈øt in the≈øe Countreys) are relieved much more and ≈øooner, when they are bled in the Arm of the ≈øame ≈øide where the Pain is, than when it is done in the oppo≈øite ≈øide.
The Pain not cea≈øing in four and twenty hours, we are nece≈ø≈øitated to bleed twice or thrice, mo≈øt commonly in the ≈øame Arm; but here you mu≈øt well ob≈øerve the Patient's ≈øtrength.

After letting Blood, ≈øometimes Purging, Swearing and Expectorating Remedies, are very nece≈ø≈øary. One only Medicine I cannot conceal from you, becau≈øe of its Excellency. The Indu≈øtrious Phy≈øitian Dr. Hadden in his Cure of the Pleuri≈øie, hath much commended it, and I have, after once Bleeding, always in the beginning u≈øed it with great ≈øucce≈øs, viz.
Take the Juice of Dandelion, an ounce and half; the Water of Plantane, two ounces; of Holy-Thi≈øtle and Scabious, Syrup of Poppies Erratick, of each an ounce; Crabs-Eyes, a ≈øcruple and half: Mix it.
Let the Patient every half hour take down a ≈øpoonful or two of it, until the Flux be ≈øtopped: After which you are to u≈øe other Remedies.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of Removing a Cataract of the Eye.
div.p: A Cataract (by the Greeks called Hypochyma by the Latines, Suffu≈øio; in the German and Belgick Tongue, De Staer) is a concretion of ≈øuperfluous Humors, by little and little generating a preternatural Membrane betwixt the Cornea and the Cry≈øtalline Humor, covering either totally, or in part, the Pupil of the Eye, and ≈øo depriving the Patient, of his ≈øight, or hindring it.

Difference.] It is either Imperfect, when the Humor is thin, or the Apple of the Eye not totally covered; or Perfect, when it is changed into a Membrane, or the Pupil is quite covered. Sometimes 'tis white, gray, yellow, green, ≈øometimes of a leaden colour, &c. according as the green, yellow or black Choler is mingled among≈øt it.
The Seat of it is between the Cornea and the Cry≈øtalline humor, being ≈øometimes nearer to this, ≈øometimes to that.
The Cau≈øe is a Phlegmatick Humor, either collected there by the weakne≈øs of the Eyes, or by the Brain tran≈ømitted thither by rea≈øon of its abundance.

Signs.] In the beginning, the Patient ≈øees every thing double, and of many colours; the Air ≈øeems to him full of Flies, Nets and Clouds, and cannot endure a great light. Thereupon his ≈øight le≈ø≈øens, and all things appear as Spots, and at length there follows blindne≈øs. If it be ju≈øt in
the Center of the Pupil, yet covers not the whole Pupil; but leaveth round about the ≈øight ≈øome place free, and then all the Patient ≈øees, ≈øeems perforated. If the Pupil ≈øpreads it ≈øelf, when you rub the Eye with your Fingers, then is it yet imperfect; if it remains unmoved, there is no doubt of its being perfect.

The Progno≈øticks.] The imperfect Cataract may ea≈øily be cured in the beginning, by convenient External and Internal Medicines, in ≈øound Bodies, and in Patients of a middle Age. The le≈øs the Pupil is dilated, the le≈øs hope of Cure. The nearer the Suffu≈øion is to the Cry≈øtalline Humor, the more dangerous. If the Eye be turned to the Sun, and the Patient then ≈øees no glimmering of Light, there is no benefit to be expected from the Manual Operation. If the Humors of the Eye be commixt by the Needle, though the Membrane be removed, then blindne≈øs will certainly remain. If in the Operation you happen to touch the Membrane of the Eye, called the Retina, the Patient will after that always ≈øee the Air, as if full of ≈ømall Hair and Flies. A Cataract commonly remains ≈øo ≈øoft unto the third year, that it will not follow the Needle; after the third or fourth year, it is ≈øo firm and hard, that it can by no Art be loo≈øned. The Blood ≈øpilt by the u≈øe of the Needle, cau≈øeth no danger, and ≈øoon cea≈øeth of it ≈øelf. Though the Cataract be not altogether ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, but divided into ≈øeveral pieces, the ≈øight doth often perfectly return within ≈øix or eight weeks, though before that time the whole Operation ≈øhould ≈øeem to be fruitle≈øs; which I ≈øpeak from manifold Experience.

The Cure.] The Imperfect Cataract requires
≈øolely the Aid of the Phy≈øitian, who by Medicines and ≈øtrengthening the Stomach and Head, have done much; to which purpo≈øe the con≈øerve of Marjoram, Ro≈øemary, Beteny, Pulv. Diambre, &c. are very good. And outwardly u≈øe the following means.
Take Gum Tragacanth di≈ø≈øolved in Eyebright water, two drams; Burnt Allom, one ≈øcruple: Make a Collyrium.
Or,

Take Celandine water, an ounce and half; White wine, half an ounce; Spirit of Wine, two drams; White Vitriol, ≈øix grains; Prepared Tutty, a ≈øcruple; Gla≈øs of Antimony, five grains; Sugar-Candy, two drams and an half; Camphire, ≈øix grains: Mix it, and make a Collyrium.
Or,

Take Juyce of Fennel, of Celandine, of each two ounces; Leaves of Rue and Marjoram, of each a Pugil; Eye-bright, one handful; of the Gall of an Oxe, four ounces; the Gall of Hens; an ounce; Red-Myrrhe, Aloes, of each a dram and half; Sarcocols, half an ounce; Camphire, two ≈øcruples: Mingle them, and let them be dilled in B. M.

If the Cataract be confirmed, then let the Manual Operation be your only refuge; but beware of attempting the Operation, if the Patient have long before complained, and ≈øtill complains of Head ach or pain of his Eyes; if the Body hath not been clean≈øed in general, nor the Head in particular; and if the Patient be yet mole≈øted with a Fever, Sneezing, Coughing or Vomiting.

Having cho≈øen a convenient ≈øea≈øon of the year, ≈øome morning in the decrea≈øe of the Moon, and a
clear and ≈øerene Air, ≈øet the Patient in a Chair, and again≈øt him let the Operator ≈øit in one ≈øomewhat higher than his, bind up his ≈øound Eye, and make him clap his hand about your wa≈øte, without ≈øtirring them at all as long as you are bu≈øie in the Operation. Let ≈øome body hold his Head fa≈øt behind, and hold you a≈øunder his Eye-lids, charging him to turn the Eye towards his No≈øe, which when he doth, quickly thru≈øt your Needle into the Cornea, half a ≈øtraws bredth from the Iris, and bring it unto the hollow of the Eye; when the Needle hath toucht the Cataract, endeavour therewith to pre≈øs it gently, and ≈øo long from above downwards until it remains there; if it be ≈øtubborn, in ≈øpringing up again and again, divide it into ≈øeveral parts, and keep the≈øe particles, or the whole Cataract a little while under, that it may not return again before the Pupil of the Eye; then draw out the Needle, and bind up as well the ≈øound as the un≈øound Eye, with Linnen-cloths moi≈øtened in ≈øome Ro≈øe water, the White of an Egg, and a little Allom mixed together. Beware in the Operation, of hurting the Cry≈øtalline Humor, and the ≈øound Tunicles.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of Leeches.
div.p:
LEeches more advantagious than Scarification, and ≈øafer than Bleeding, may with benefit be applied, as well in ≈øtrong as in weak Bodies, they only draw Blood from the Cutaneous Ve≈ø≈øels, by which they cure light Di≈øea≈øes, if only applyed
to the Skin; but if applyed to ≈øome greater Ve≈ø≈øel, they draw al≈øo Blood from the Internal Parts, and ≈øo remove internal and more de≈øperate Di≈øea≈øes.

There is great care required in the choice of Leeches, for tho≈øe with great Heads, and that are green and ≈øhining, with hair or blew ≈øtripes on their Backs, are not without Poy≈øon; as al≈øo tho≈øe that live in ≈øtanding or putrid Waters: But tho≈øe are to be cho≈øen that are ≈ølender and long, with little heads, and red Bellies, and ≈øuch as are nouri≈øhed in clear running Water: They are never to be applied to the Part new taken, but after they have been taken a day or more in fair Water, and fed with a little Blood, that they may be clean≈øed of all their impurities; the place where they are to be applied, is to be rubb'd till it be red; and if they fa≈øten not, 'tis to be moi≈øtened with Cream, or with Blood fre≈øh taken from a Pigeon, or the part it ≈øelf to be prickt with a Needle till it bleed; if they draw ≈øluggi≈øhly, cut their tails off with a pair of Sci≈ø≈øars. After they have ≈øuckt a ≈øufficient quantity of Blood, and they fall not off them≈øelves, put upon their Heads a little A≈øhes or Salt, and they will ≈øuddenly de≈øi≈øt from their work: they are not to be pull'd off by force, le≈øt they leave their heads behind them, from whence incurable wounds, and oftentimes Death ≈øucceeds. 'Tis to be noted, that they rather draw Arterial Blood than Venal, therefore they ought to ≈øuck the le≈øs.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the Cutting in the Hard Parts.
div.p: THe Section which is u≈øed in the Hard and Bony Parts, is of four kinds, viz. Scraping, Filing, Sawing and Perforating, that is, Trepanning.

Scraping is u≈øed in a Fi≈ø≈øure and foul Bone, in the Teeth al≈øo, when they are cru≈øted over with a Tartarous black ≈øub≈øtance; the Bones are to be ≈øcraped till you come to the ≈øound part, which is white and ≈øolid, and a little blood ca≈øt forth; and to the Bone thus ≈øcraped, ≈øome drying Powder is to be applied; the Pericranium and Perio≈øtium mu≈øt fir≈øt be ≈øeperated from the Bone, before you go about this Operation; for by no means are they to be touched with the In≈øtrumenr, neither likewi≈øe the lips of the Wound.

Filing is u≈øed in the Teeth; for when they unnaturally ≈øtand forth, and either in Eating or Speaking, are any hinderance to a man; then that which thus ≈øticks forth, is with a File to be taken off, which mu≈øt be done carefully, without any injury to the neighouring parts, and by degrees, neither with two great a Violence, le≈øt it loo≈øen the Tooth.
The u≈øe of the Saw is in a mortified part, when the Bone is to be cut a ≈øunder; concerning which Operation I ≈øhall ≈øuddenly ≈øpeak.

Perforating or Trepanning is of great u≈øe, when the Bones are extreamly ≈øoul, but 'tis of greate≈øt u≈øe in tho≈øe effects, which the Fi≈ø≈øure or a Fracture
of the Skull, or a Contu≈øion may produce: Seeing therefore this Operation is ≈øo full of danger, 'tis diligently to be enquired in what Ca≈øes 'tis nece≈ø≈øary, and in what 'tis not; for a Fi≈ø≈øure as a Fi≈ø≈øure, as likewi≈øe a Fracture as a Fracture, requires not the Trepan as an operation without which they cannot be cured: In like manner a ≈ølight Contu≈øion doth not always occa≈øion ≈øuch dangerous ≈øymptoms, that the Trepan may not cau≈øe wor≈øe; for oftentimes a ≈ømall quantity of extrava≈øated Blood, in Robu≈øt People, is often di≈øcu≈ø≈øed by the work of Nature her ≈øelf; except the innate heat be weakened by external Cold, which in the u≈øe of the Trepan, let what care po≈ø≈øibly be had, cannot be totally avoided; be≈øides this, the Blood is more often extrava≈øated between the two Membranes, the Dura-Mater and the Pia Mater, there the Trepan can ≈øeem to promi≈øe but little good; but in this ca≈øe I would not much matter to divide the Dura Mater; Experience having taught us, that by the help of Art and Nature, hath an Inci≈øion, nay, Gangrene of the Part it ≈øelf been cured: Therefore for the mo≈øt part but in three ca≈øes is the Trepan required.

1. Where the loo≈øe pieces of the Bones prick and wound the Meninges; which is to be known by the continual pricking pain pre≈øently from the very hurting perceived, granted the Patient be ≈øen≈øible; but if not, he is always feeling the Part affected wirh his hands: There happens likewi≈øe Contu≈øions of the Eyes, and Convul≈øions of the Limbs: Be≈øides, the quality of the In≈øtrument which the Fracture hath made, will more plainly demon≈øtrate it.

2. Where the fir≈øt Table is only depre≈ø≈øed, but the
≈øecond broke; there being no way to give pa≈ø≈øage to the pieces, how well ≈øoever by Art or Nature ≈øeparated. The Signs of this, are, a Dimne≈øs, a Giddine≈øs, a Fever, Vomiting, and ≈øometimes an Apoplexy; a feeble ≈ømall Pul≈øe, and e≈øpecially about the Temples, the depre≈ø≈øed Bone in ≈øome manner ob≈øtructing the Circulation of the Blood in the Brain.

3. Extrava≈øation of Blood, upon which follows Putrefaction, and if not remedied, Death it ≈øelf: The Signs which declare this Putrefaction, is a continued Fever, a great Heat in the Head, unquiet Sleep, Watchings, Inflammation of the Eyes, and light Delirium; and moreover, the Temperaments of Bodies are diligently to be con≈øider'd; for in Plethorick People, to tho≈øe above-named Symptoms are joyned, a Laughing, Talking idly, and Redne≈øs of ‚Ä¢ he whole Face. In the Cholerick appears a yellowne≈øs of the Face and Eyes, great Heat, and Madne≈øs. In the Phlegmatick, all the Symptoms are le≈øs; but ≈øometimes it is accompanied with a Pal≈øie, ≈øometimes with an Apoplexy. In Melancholy men, a dread impertinent Talk, and Laughing is u≈øual.
Where the Trepan is nece≈ø≈øary, apply it as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, le≈øt the putrifying Blood cau≈øeth greater evils, that is, on the third, fourth, or fifth day.

The manner of Trepanning is thus, The Hair being ≈øhav'd, Let the Skin be divided with a double Inci≈øion, inform of a Cro≈øs to the Pericranium, avoiding with the greate≈øt diligence always the temperal Mu≈øcles, and the Sutures of the Head; this done, bind up the Wound, except the Hemorage be ≈ømall (which very often is ≈øo violent,
that it hinders the Chirurgeon for ≈øome days from any further Operation) if it will then give leave, to divide likewi≈øe the Pericranium from the Skull: After ≈øome few hours (the Skull already bar'd of its Pericranium) the Patient well plac'd, his Head mu≈øt by ≈øome Per≈øon be firmly held, his Ears being ≈øtopt with Cotton; then ≈øet on the Trepan with a Pin, which mu≈øt neither be upon the Fracture, nor upon the Sutures (although there are ≈øome that venture to apply it upon the very Sutures them≈øelves) the Surgeon holding in his left hand the In≈øtrument, and with his right, let him gently turn about the Trepan until it hath taken good hold round; then take out the Pin, and ≈øet the Trepan on again without it, moving it ≈øtill about, and if you ≈øee any ≈ømall Filings of the Skull, take off the Trepan and wipe them away; and the Trepan it ≈øelf is ≈øometimes to be dipt in the Oyl, that it may the ea≈øier be turned about; and ≈øometimes in Water, that it grows not hot. If any Blood appears, you may be certain that the Trepan had pa≈øt the fir≈øt Table, then are you to have a greater care, le≈øt the Trepan ≈øhould unawares ≈ølip in, and wound the Meninges, from whence oftentimes follows ≈øudden Death: For the Dura Mater inve≈øts the in≈øide of the Scull, in the ≈øame manner as the Pericranium doth the out-≈øide, but yet not ≈øo ≈øtrongly joined to it, but that by a fall or blow, it may be ea≈øily ≈øeparated from the Skull.

When the piece of Bone, ≈øeparated by the Trepan, begins to be loo≈øe, you mu≈øt with a little In≈øtrument put in, between the Skull and the Trepan'd part, and free it from the whole, and ≈øo gently take it out with a pair of Forceps.
If there remain any inequality from Trepanning, in the in≈øide of the inward Table, that may cau≈øe injury to the Meninx, 'tis to be taken away with an In≈øtrument called Lenticula.

And that there may be a di≈øcharge given to the coagulated Blood and Matter, the Dura Mater is to be compre≈ø≈øed with an In≈øtrument called a Decu≈ø≈øorium. To effect the ≈øame, 'tis commended that the Patient (if ≈øen≈øible) his Mouth and No≈øe being ≈øhut, hold his Breath, ≈øo that the Brain being rai≈øed upward, the concreted and corrupted Matter may be thrown forth; but very ≈øeldom is the Matter di≈øcharg'd by this only remedy; for the Chirurgion hath need enough of the Decu≈ø≈øorium, Spunges, Lint, and the like In≈øtruments; the de≈øcription and delineation of the which, you may find in Joh. Andr. √† Cruce, Paraeus, and others. Read the 4th. Chapter of this Chirurgery, where Fractures of the Skull is de≈øcribed.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of ∆≤≈øtion, or Burning.
div.p:
ENough hath been ≈øaid of Cutting, now a little of Burning; when neither Medicine nor Knife bring relief, we mu≈øt then come to the Fire, as well in the ≈øoft as hard parts: In all Burning, great care is to be taken that the neighboring parts be not hurt; therefore it is very nece≈ø≈øary to defend them again≈øt it with Lint: That burning is certaine≈øt, which is made by an actual Cautery, viz. a red hot Iron, than that which is performed
a Potential, that is, by Corro≈øive Medicines; yet for the mo≈øt part, the Patients fearfulne≈øs makes choice of this; which≈øoever you u≈øe, beware of applying Oyl alone, or Butter, to remove the E≈øcar, for it hath been ob≈øerved not once only to to have occa≈øioned a Gangrene, Diapalma Plai≈øter, or Lint, wet in Wine, will be ≈øufficient.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of I≈ø≈øues.

p.hi: IS≈øues are little Ulcers made by Art in a ≈øound part of the Body by a red-hot Iron, Launcet, Sci≈ø≈øars, or corro≈øive Medicine, to evacuate ≈øuperfluous humors, and ≈øo either to cure or prevent Di≈øea≈øes.

div.p: The≈øe trouble≈øome Gue≈øts are rarely courted, and are chiefly pre≈øcribed when we ≈øee gentler Medicines to profit nothing, and after the Body hath been well purged.

In what part ≈øoever they are made, it is always to be ob≈øerv'd they never ought to be in≈øerted in the beginning, middle or end of a Mu≈øcle, but always in the ≈øpace between two Mu≈øcles, which requireth the knowledge of Anatomy, except according to the example of Quacks, who≈øe cu≈øtom hath taught them to find out a place ev'n blindfold. In the Head, the place is the middle of the Coronal Suture, made oftner by other Nations than is a practice among≈øt us. In the Neck they are not ≈øo often made, how nece≈ø≈øary ≈øoever they may appear. The Italians u≈øe to make them between the Shoulders with ≈øucce≈øs. In other places they are either very trouble≈øome or inconvenient.

The Manner of making I≈ø≈øues is divers: If you make u≈øe of the Potential Cautery, apply a Plai≈øter to the part, having a hole in the middle about the bigne≈øs of a Pea, in which lay a little Co≈øtick, and over that a Bol≈øter and another Plai≈øter; and after three or four hours, take off the Plai≈øters, and laying on the E≈øcar a Plai≈øter of Diapalma; dre≈øs it twice a day, that it may the ≈øooner ≈øeparate.

Tho≈øe which de≈øire it rather by Inci≈øion, the Skin being taken up either by the Forceps, or by the Hand, divide it with a pair of Sci≈ø≈øars or Launcet. If Burning be preferred before the other ways, burn the Skin, but not the ≈øubjacent Mu≈øcles; for indeed the Skin it ≈øelf is not to be wholly penetrated, oftentimes the touching only the Superficies of it is enough.

When the Scar falls off, take little hard Do≈ø≈øels made of Lint, ≈øpred upon them ≈øome Deter≈øive Medicine, and pre≈øs them into the Ulcer, until they have made a ≈øufficient Impre≈ø≈øion; then afterward keep in this Cavity a Ball of Wax, Wood, or Silver, or a Pea, which is to be often taken out, and another put in, and ≈øo is to be continued till the Di≈øea≈øe be cured, or Weakne≈øs hinder.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the Seton
div.p: ALthough the application of a Seton be with greater trouble than an I≈ø≈øue, yet it brings much greater advantage to the ≈øick Patient; for what two I≈ø≈øues cannot remove, oftentimes is performed by one Seton.

It may be made in the Arms and Legs, and many other parts of the Body; but in the Nape of the Neck, between the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Vertebra, or ≈øecond and third; yea, between the third and fourth, is only in u≈øe among≈øt us, but I could wi≈øh it was more frequent.

There are three In≈øtruments nece≈ø≈øary to perform this Operation; A pair of Forceps, a Needle, and String. The Forceps which are to hold up the Skin, mu≈øt be perforated of each ≈øide; the Needle mu≈øt be three-pointed, and an≈øwer to the hole of the Forceps, which it mu≈øt pa≈øs through. The String is to be of Silk, not exceeding the thickne≈øs of the Needle: Let the Chirurgion take up the Skin with the Forceps and gripe it hard, which being ≈øomewhat ≈øtupified, the Patient will feel the le≈øs pain; then let him pa≈øs the Needle red-hot through both the holes of the Forceps, Skin and all; after which, with another Needle let him bring through the thread: The fir≈øt day, to ea≈øe pain, apply to the Part Lint dipt in Whites of Eggs and Ro≈øewater mixt together: Afterward let Dige≈øtion be procured by the u≈øe of convenient Medicines; when dige≈øted, let the String be drawn every day, ≈øometimes to this ≈øide, ≈øometimes to that, ≈øo that the mattery part may hang out of the Wound. Thus the Operation being perfected, the Ulcer may be kept open as long as occa≈øion requires, or the Patient plea≈øeth.

After this manner many Authors, both Antient and Modern, order the making the Seton; but this Oparation is much ea≈øier perform'd, if in the right place the Chirurgion take up the Skin with one hand, and his Servant with another, and ≈øo pa≈øs it through with a ≈øharp-pointed Needle, but
not made hot; the String being of Thread, not Silk, of convenient Thickne≈øs, and rubb'd with Wax.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of the drawing forth of Bullets.
div.p: NOw we are come to the Third Part of Chirurgery call'd Exere≈øis, which removes things ≈øuperfluous: They are of a two-fold Nature, either they are generated in the Body it ≈øelf, or el≈øe brought thither by Accident.

We treat of the la≈øt fir≈øt, to wit, The Extraction of Bullets out of the Body; which is not difficult, if it appears whether it be nearer to the part where it made its entrance, or to the oppo≈øite to which it hath penetrated.

If it be ob≈øerved to be near the Orifice; let it be drawn forth with a convenient In≈øtrument; if nearer to the oppo≈øite part, let the Inci≈øion be made upon it, and there taken forth: But if the Bullet cannot be found out by a Probe, the Member is to be ≈øo placed, that the Bullet by its own weight may come forth; which if it happens not to do, the Wound is to be cured; and let the Chirurgeon expect until the Bullet ≈øhews it ≈øelf near the Skin, which very often requires a long time.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Of the Extraction of a Dead Child and the Secundine.
div.p: THat the Birth may be Natural, it is nece≈ø≈øary, That the Infant the whole time of its continuance in its Mothers-womb, lies in ≈øuch a po≈øture, that the Arms and Feet being contracted, the Head downwards, having the Face towards the Mothers Back; the whole Foetus lying tran≈øver≈øe in the bottom of the Womb; until requiring greater room, which happens in the ≈øeventh, ≈øometimes in the eighth or tenth, for the mo≈øt part in the ninth Month, the head of the Infant de≈øcends towards the mouth of the womb; the Limbs which were before contracted, being extended, it breaks through the Membranes wherein it was included, by which the water that is contained in them, flows forth, which ≈øerve to make the parts ≈ølippery, and ≈øo is convenient to facilitate the Birth.

If any one of the≈øe be wanting, then one of the≈øe four things nece≈ø≈øarily happens; either, 1. Both the Mother and the Child, although they may live, yet there follows no Exclu≈øion. 2. Or the Mother lives, and the Child dies. 3. Or the Child lives, and the Mother dies. 4. Or both the Mother and Infant dies.

Cau≈øes hindering Labour] are, 1. When the Pains of the Birth are none, or not ≈øufficient. 2. The great weakne≈øs of the Mother. 3. The greatne≈øs and ≈øtrength of the Child; and on the contrary, the
≈ølender and tender Con≈øtitution of the Mother, or when the pa≈ø≈øages are ≈øo ≈øtraight that the Infant cannot come through them. 4. The number of Children, e≈øpecially if they endeavor to come forth at the ≈øame time. 5. The tran≈øver≈øe, or any other preternatural po≈øture of the Child. 6. If the Child in the Birth it ≈øelf be fallen down with its Head upon the fore-port of the O≈ø≈øa-Pubis: which ca≈øe Authors of the greate≈øt account, whom I know, and our Midwives have not at all ob≈øerved; ≈øo by how much the greater the Pains of the Birth are, there is ≈øo much the le≈øs hope of coming out, except the Head be fir≈øt a little rai≈øed, and the Foetus be turned towards the back, and ≈øo into its true pa≈ø≈øage by the hand of the Midwife. 7. The Weakne≈øs of the Child it ≈øelf, which makes it not able to add any thing towards its Exclu≈øion. 8. The Death of the Child. 9. The not ≈øufficient rece≈ø≈øes of the Hip-bones towards the Back; for the O≈ø≈øa-Pubis, except in the very harde≈øt Labours, and then but very ≈øeldom do divide.

div.head: The Signs of a Dead Child are as followeth.
div.p: The Mother feels no more the Motion of the Infant, although ≈øtrengthening Cordials be exhibit'd; but in this ca≈øe when the Infant is as it were tir'd, ≈øtirs it ≈øelf a little, you have a much more certain Sign. Take a piece of the Crum of Bread, and dip it in Canary Wine, and apply it to the Navel of the Mother, then open a Vein in the Foot, and if by the u≈øe of the≈øe things, there follows not a motion of the Infant, it is a very ill Sign.

When the Mother turns her ≈øelf from one ≈øide to the other, and perceives the Child to fall on the
≈øide laid upon, like a ≈øtone or a great weight; the Face, and chiefly the Lips grow pale, the extream parts cold, as likewi≈øe the lower Belly, the Paps begin to grow lank, the Breath becomes fetid, great pains of the Head, Faintings and Fevers, Water and ≈øtinking Gleet flows out of the Womb; If the After-Birth be excluded before the Child, 'tis impo≈ø≈øible the Child can live long; but the ≈øure≈øt ≈øign of all is, if the Membrane of the Head of the Child be not ob≈øerved to be any longer ten≈øe; for as long as it is ten≈øe, the Infant lives.

Progno≈øtick.] Except the dead Child be ≈øuddenly drawn forth, it puts the Mother in great hazard of Life. The Fever not being great, other Symptoms, though great and fearful, yet take not away the hope of recovery.

The Cure.] If Medicines, with the aid of Mother and Midwife, profit little, then mu≈øt the bu≈øine≈øs be committed wholly to the Chirurgeon, except the Woman be too weak, or the Child having been dead for many days, which he ought to con≈øider, le≈øt he lo≈øe both his Credit and Labour.

But fir≈øt, it is diligently to be enquired into, which of the Cau≈øes it is that hinders the Birth: If the Child be greater and the pa≈ø≈øage ≈øtraighter than u≈øually, they ought to be dilated; this ≈øome Midwives do with convenient In≈øtruments, and ≈øo draw forth the Child alive; but where they are wanting, the Midwife mu≈øt clutch her hand very clo≈øe, and thru≈øt through the Internal Orifice into the Womb it ≈øelf; then putting her Fingers one after another through the Orifice into the inner part of the Womb, to di≈øcover the ≈øituation of the Child; and if ≈øhe finds the Arms or Feet to come inconveniently, let her gently rai≈øe it up, bringing
the Head downwards, which if ≈øhe finds to be next the Orifice, if po≈ø≈øible, let her put in her other hand through the Pudenda into the Womb, and ≈øo with both her hands laying hold of it, draw it forth.

But if this Operation cannot be performed, then with a hook firmly fixt (le≈øt it injure the in≈øide of the Womb) in the Mouth, Eye or Ear of the Child, and ≈øo gently draw it forth; and if the Faetus will not follow, then with another Hook, blunt on the out-≈øide, and ≈øharp within, let him cut in pieces the Belly, Brea≈øt, or Head of the Child; and if the Arms or Legs cannot be brought forth, let him cut them off; ≈øo at length, being deprived of its Limbs, the remainder may be drawn forth.

But if by this way the Woman can neither be deliver'd, with a ≈øharp and ≈øtrong Knife, the Limbs one after another are to be cut out, and ≈øo the Child be drawn forth by piece-meal: It is nece≈ø≈øary that this be perform'd by none but a good Anatomi≈øt.

The Secundine will pre≈øently follow the Birth, for it's of no u≈øe, that being excluded; for the Mouth of the Womb, ≈øuddenly after delivery, is ≈øo clo≈øly ≈øhut, that not without great pain it can admit the Hand of the Midwife; therefore the Midwife, as ≈øoon as may be, is to draw it forth, and with her fingers, if it ≈øticks very clo≈øe to the Womb, gently to ≈øeparate it, but not pluck it a way forcibly, which is mortal; and although many Writers and Midwives of inferior Rank, little regard the retention of the After-Birth for ≈øome time after delivery; yet I think I have good rea≈øon to pronounce it, one of the greate≈øt Symptoms of Womens Labour.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. Of the Extirpating of a Mortified Part.
div.p: WHen a Dead Part altogether becomes u≈øele≈øs, that it may not do any injury to the neighboring Parts, it is to be taken away: But in what place? Mo≈øt convenient is the Joynt; but the cure by ≈øuch Extirpation is render'd more difficult, and the u≈øe of the Part altogether lo≈øt; therefore the Extirpation is better to be made two, or three, or more fingers breadth below the Joynt, except the Mortification hath extended it ≈øelf to the uppermo≈øt part of the Arms or Thighs; for then we are forced to take the Joynt it ≈øelf: But again in what Part: whether in the whole or Mortified? The Amputation is more ≈øafe in the ≈øound Part, although accompanied with greater Pain.

div.head: The common way both of the Ancient and Modern.
div.p:
The Patient having receiv'd convenient nouri≈øhment, is to be placed upon a Form; then let the Skin and fubjacent Mu≈øcles be drawn up as much as po≈ø≈øible, by a ≈øtrong Man, and there kept; and an inch above the place where the Member is de≈øign'd to be taken off, with a narrow Ligature is the Part to be very hard bound; this done, with a di≈ømembring Knife, the Skin with the Fle≈øh is ≈øpeedily to be cut all round to the Part, and the Perio≈øtium, by ≈øcraping, is to be ≈øeparated from the Bone; and
if it be where there is a double Bone, as in the Leg, and below the Elbow, the Fle≈øh and Ligaments between them is to be divided; which being performed, let the Bone be ≈øeparated with a very ≈øharp Saw. If the Flux of Blood be not great, to apply only tho≈øe Medicines that ≈øtop Blood, will be ≈øufficient; but if great, an actual Cautery is to be u≈øed, which is only to be applied upon the great Ve≈ø≈øels; then let the Ligature be taken off, and the Part be fitly bound up.

If either the Patient or Chirurgeon be aver≈øe to the u≈øe of a Cautery, then as ≈øoon as the Member is taken off, let the Skin together with the Fle≈øh, in four di≈øtinct places oppo≈øite one to the other, be taken up with a Needle and waxed Thread, and the Ligature being loo≈øened above, or drawn down, that, if po≈ø≈øible, they may meet: So by this way is the Hemorage ≈øtaid, the Bone pre≈øerved from all danger, and the Wound ≈øooner cured. But this way is painful and trouble≈øom, therefore ought it the ≈øeldomer to be u≈øed.

div.head: Aquapendens his way.
div.p:
When the principal de≈øign of Art in this Operation, is to put a ≈øtop to Putrefaction, to cau≈øe as little pain as may be, and to ≈øtay the Flux of Blood, all which the above-quoted Author thinks may be done, if the Member be amputated in the dead Part, but near to the ≈øound; then the Bone being divided with burning-hot Irons, let the remainder of the dead Part be cauterized, till the Patient perceive the heat of the Fire: So he writes, that by this cour≈øe a Flux of Blood is not to be feared, le≈øs pain is cau≈øed, and within the ≈øpace of two
or three days, will appear a ≈øeparation of the Mortified Part from the Sound; but in my opinion, we ought to con≈øider well of the Cau≈øe. For in a Spacelus, ≈øprung from an Internal Cau≈øe, in a Body otherwi≈øe ≈øound, this way is the be≈øt; but in a Spacelus cau≈øed from a defect of innate Heat, the former is more profitable.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. Of the Fle≈øhy Rupture.
div.p: SArcocele, which is a Fle≈øhy Rupture, is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, produced from impure Blood, flowing in too great quantity itno the Te≈øticles, and there degenerated into Fle≈øh.

In this Definition, received by the be≈øt Phy≈øitians and Chirurgeons, I note two things: 1. The cau≈øe of this Tumor, not to be impure Blood, ≈øeeing the be≈øt, may produce it; not ≈øimply abounding in quantity, becau≈øe it al≈øo happens in wa≈øted Bodies, though 'tis not ≈øo ≈øoon generated, nor arrives to ≈øuch a greatne≈øs in the≈øe, as in tho≈øe Bodies; but the true cau≈øe is the Ero≈øion, Rupture or Dilatation of the Membranes which clo≈øe the Mouths of the Capillary Ve≈ø≈øels, that the nutritious Blood may not flow too ≈øuddenly into the Part; from whence, more Blood flows into the Part than what is required for its nouri≈øhment; and Nature changeth that Blood which otherwi≈øe would purifie into a fle≈øhy Sub≈øtance. 2. This fle≈øh ≈øometimes grows to the ≈øecond of the common Tunicles of the Scrotum, and not to the Te≈øticles, in which ca≈øe it may be taken aways,
without either hurting, or cutting of them out.
Signs are, the hardne≈øs, and ≈ølow encrea≈øe of the Tumor, which is rather more trouble≈øome than painful, except accompanied with ≈øharp Humors; no appearance of any Tumor in the Groin.

Progno≈øticks.] A Sarcocele is hardly cured by the help of Medicines, and ≈øeldom by manual Operation, without taking off the Te≈øticle, if it extends it ≈øelf into the Groins, for the mo≈øt part incurable.

Cure.] In the beginning, when the Membranes of the Ve≈ø≈øels being eroded, broke or dilated, do give leave for too much leave to i≈ø≈øue forth, Bleeding, and the u≈øe of Repelling and Re≈øtringent Medicines profit much; but when it hath begun to augment, then we may u≈øe the≈øe following means: Let there be made a little Orifice into the Scrotum, rather in its Superior then Inferior Part, through which, by the help of Plegets let Suppurating Medicines be applied, ≈øo that if po≈ø≈øible, to wa≈øte the Fle≈øh, every dre≈ø≈øing diligently wiping away the Matter, but not at all, that the remaining Fle≈øh may be the better con≈øumed.

If the≈øe things ≈øucceed not, draw forth the Te≈øticle, and by Inci≈øion take off as much Fle≈øh as may be done without injury to it; then re≈øtore it again into its place, and the remainder of the Fle≈øh endeavor to con≈øume by Suppuration.

But if there be no hope of curing this Rupture by the recited means, draw forth the Hernious Te≈øticle as far as you may, then pa≈øs once or twice a Silken Thred above the Tumor by the Proce≈øs of the Peritonaeum; then pa≈øs both ends of the Silk through the Orifice it ≈øelf, ≈øo that which
was on the right ≈øide, may be on the left, and that of the left, on the right; and having ordered that the proce≈øs of the Peritonaeum may be tied with a knot, then cut off the Te≈øticle, letting both the ends of the Silk hang out of the Scrotum, and ≈øo cure it as another Wound.

I cannot here but friendly advi≈øe, 1. The Chirurgeon ought to con≈øider well of the Cau≈øe, before he comes to the Operation it ≈øelf; for ≈øometimes the Para≈øtates are ≈øo ≈øwell'd, e≈øpecially the Te≈øticles being Scirrhous, that they may ea≈øily deceive a very curious Examiner. 2. The Ligature ought to be made as near to the Tumor as po≈ø≈øible, for by how much the higher part of the Proce≈øs of the Peritonaeum be perforated, it is ob≈øerved to be ≈øo much the thicker, which thing will retard the Suppuration and the falling of the Thread; in the mean time Convul≈øions coming on, denounce death. 3. The Spermatick Ve≈ø≈øels detain'd in the Scrotum, oftentimes by Natures variety, exceed the Te≈øticles them≈øelves in greatne≈øs, which cau≈øes no other inconvenience but only Fear, which I have ob≈øerved to be true, in more than one.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. The Extraction of the Stone out of the Bladder.

p.hi: THe Stone is a hard Body concreted from Slimy, Salt or Earthy Matter, by a peculiar Lapidifying quality, cau≈øing Pain, Ob≈øtruction; and other Symptoms in the place where it is detained.

div.p: The Cau≈øe is a Pituitous, Salt or Earthy Matter, which neither by heat nor cold, by a peculiar lapidifying quality is changed into a Stone.

Signs.] The Urine is white, ≈ølimy, crude and troubled, ≈øuddenly adhering to the Urinal; ≈øometimes it is bloody, ≈øometimes ≈øandy or gravelly; ≈øometimes full of little Threads, and not ≈øeldom ≈øuppre≈øt; a great thir≈øt, a frequent making of Urine, but with pain and by drops: The Patients place them≈øelves with their Thighs acro≈øs, always holding their Privy-Parts in their hands, pre≈ø≈øing the bottom of their Belly; the Privy-Part is always erected, very painful to go or walk, in the Region of the Belly a weight perceived, the Patient ≈øeldom making Water without going to Stool, the Inte≈øtine commonly falls out, e≈øpecially in young People.

Although all the≈øe Signs ≈øeem plain, yet they may ≈øometimes deceive a Phi≈øician; it was formerly the Cu≈øtom with a Catheter pa≈ø≈øed through the Ureter into the Bladder, then thru≈øting in one or two fingers into the Anus, not only to ≈øearch for the Stone, but al≈øo under≈øtand its greatne≈øs. But this ≈øearching was ≈øo very painful, that it was difficult, through fear of pain, to have it permitted a ≈øecond time; and this thing gave occa≈øion to have ready at the ≈øecond time of ≈øearching, all In≈øtruments nece≈ø≈øary for cutting out the Stone; but the Omnipotent and great Prince of Phy≈øicians hath now granted to tho≈øe mi≈øerable Patients, tho≈øe Chirurgeons, who not only without Catheter, but al≈øo without pain, both in old People and Children, which can mo≈øt certainly find out the Stone; and for this Rea≈øon they Excel the ≈øo much E≈øteem'd French-men. I wi≈øh other places may may enjoy the ≈øame Arti≈øts.

Progno≈øtick.] A crumbling Stone ≈øeldom, a hard Stone can never be wa≈øted by Medicines, what≈øoever boa≈øting per≈øons may ≈øay; ≈øometimes it is ≈øo ≈øoft, that by the very Catheter it ≈øelf it may be broke to pieces in the neck of the Bladder, and be brought forth; ≈øometimes through its ≈ømalne≈øs it comes forth whole; ≈øometimes it ≈øticks in the Urethra, out of which, without danger and great pain it cannot be removed; if it ≈øticks in the Tunicles of the Bladder, or grows to the Superficies of the Interior Coat, it cannot be taken away by Section, without the death of the Patient: By how much the greater the Stone is, the Operation is the more dangerous and painful. Stones are often drawn forth out of Womens Bladders about the bigne≈øs of an Olive, or a Walnut, without Inci≈øion: but this way by Dilatation, of Extracting the Stone, is ≈øo dangerous, that it ought not to be performed but by experienced Chirurgeons.

Cure.] Stones generated in the Kidneys, Bladder, or other parts of the Body (for, they may in any) in general, require the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Phy≈øician; but we in this place treat only of the manner of drawing them forth out of the Bladder by Inci≈øion. There are ≈øeveral ways by various Authors propo≈øed; but that which follows, is the mo≈øt common, and mo≈øt ≈øure.

Let the Chirurgeon place his Patient on a ≈øoft Pillow in a ≈øtrong mans Lap, after he has three or four times jumpt from a high place, then let him tie both his hands to the ≈øoles of his Feet, and let two ≈øtanders by hold each Knee, extending them as far as may be one from the other; then let him take the fir≈øt Finger of his left-Hand, or if nece≈ø≈øity requires, the two fir≈øt, anointed with Oyl of
Lillies, Ro≈øes, or fre≈øh Almonds, and thru≈øt them up the Fundament, with his right hand gently compre≈ø≈øing above the Os Pubis, ≈øo that the Stone may ≈ølip down under the Os Pubis, into the Perinaeum, which when brought thither by the fore≈øaid Fingers, let him make Inci≈øion with a ≈øharp Knife in the left ≈øide between the Te≈øticles and the Anus, near to the Suture of the Perinaeum, cutting to the very Stone it ≈øelf; and if it comes not out of the Wound it ≈øelf, nor by the thru≈øting forth of the Fingers which are in the Inte≈øtinum rectum, let him draw it forth with a pair of Forceps, or which is better, with the Lapidillum or Spoon. The Stone being taken out, and all the Ligatures loo≈øed, let the Wound be bound up according to Art, applying Medicines, ≈øtopping Blood, viz. of Meal and Bole, &c. with the greate≈øt care to con≈øolidate it as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, le≈øt the Patient labour with a dropping of his Urine through the wounded part: And this is the manner of drawing forth the Stone, which Chirurgeons u≈øe to call Apparatus Minor, which chiefly is u≈øed in Children, although there are tho≈øe which proceed thus in People of full growth: But in our Country always this Inci≈øion is made by them who≈øe Fingers are fitted for this Operation,

But in People of full Age it is ≈øometimes very difficult to reach the Stone by the Fingers put up into the Fundament, and after the ≈øame manner to bring it down into the Perinoeum, if not altogether impo≈ø≈øible, as many think it; therefore there is another way found out, which they call Apparatus Major; the Patient is put on a Table, and bound, and held as above, the Chirurgeon through the Uretra pa≈ø≈øeth a Director into the
Bladder to the Stone, then Inci≈øion being made as obove, in the hollow of the Director, puts in the Conductor, taking the Director out of the Uretra, he pa≈ø≈øeth into the Wound the Forceps, the Lapidillum, or other In≈øtrument convenient for drawing out the Stone, by which he may both lay hold of it, and draw it forth, not making u≈øe of his Fingers in the Anus, except great nece≈ø≈øity compel him to it. Where the Stone is bigger than the Orifice, and cannot come forth, the Wound is to be enlarged, or the Stone to be broken into pieces by the Forceps, and ≈øo drawn forth in parts: This done, the Binding and Con≈øolidating the Wound, ought to be the ≈øame as in Children, giving it a ≈øtitch if it be too great, putting in a Silver-Pipe for two or three days, that may give pa≈ø≈øage to the Concreted Blood, Slime and Sandy Urine.
The manner is the ≈øame in Women, but only the Fingers are not put into the Anus, but into the Privy-Parts, and the Catheter mu≈øt not be crooked, but ≈øtraight, and much ≈øhorter than the other.

There is likewi≈øe another manner of drawing forth the Stone; the Chirurgeon thru≈øting his Finger into the Anus, pre≈ø≈øeth the Stone upwards to the Belly; then through the Wound made in the right Mu≈øcle above the Os Pubis, according to the ductus of its Fibres, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Lapidillum or Forceps draw forth the Stone; by this way is never ob≈øerved any coming forth of the Urine, and the place ≈øuppo≈øed convenient to draw forth the Stone: But this Operation in it ≈øelf is dangerous and trouble≈øome, and if the Lips of the Wound made in the Bladder unite not to the Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen, there follows an Ulcer of the Bladder, more painful, but le≈øs cureable
than the Stone it ≈øelf; which inconveniences have cau≈øed it not to be reckoned among other Operations by true Practi≈øers.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of the Hare-Lip.
div.p: THe fourth and la≈øt Part of Chirurgery call'd Anaplero≈øis, which re≈øtores what is deficient, is chiefly u≈øed when any part of the No≈øe, Lip, or Ear is wanting, whether it be from the Birth, or from an External Cau≈øe,

div.head: BARBETTY'S CHIRURGERY. The Second Part.
Which treats of Tumors, Wounds and Ulcers: In three Books.
The Fir≈øt Book of the Second Part of Chirurgery. Of Tumors.
CHAP. I. Of Tumors in general.
div.p: A Tumor be≈øides Nature, is a Di≈øea≈øe in which the Parts of the Body are indecently inlarlarged and extended, ≈øo that they are rendred unfit to perform its Actions.
The Differences of Tumors are taken, 1. From the Part affected; as an Inflammation of the Eyes, Jaws, &c. 2. From the Cau≈øes.

The Cau≈øes are, 1. The Parts of the Body removed out of their Natural place. 2. The Four Humors,
as well Natural as Preternatural, viz, Blood‚ñ™ Choler, Phlegm, Melancholy, to which likewi≈øe we add Serum and Wind.
Tumors for the mo≈øt part are generated from the Humors, and that either by Conge≈øtion, or Fluxion.
They come by Conge≈øtion, when the Natural heat of the Part being dimini≈øhed, the good Humors are ill concocted, or the vicious are not ≈øufficiently evacuated.
By Fluxion, from a two-fold Cau≈øe, External, viz. a Fall, Blow, External Heat, too great Motion, &c. Internal, viz. Pain, Superabundancy, Thinne≈øs, Acrimony of Humors, &c.
The Signs of Tumors are, an Extention of the Part, Pain, Redne≈øs, Heat, Hardne≈øs, &c. But the≈øe are better explained in particular Tumors, than in general.

The times of Tumors (for all curable Tumors have four) are as followeth, Beginning, when the Part begins to ≈øwell; Increa≈øe, the ≈øwelling, pain, and other Symptoms are augmented; State, the Symptoms ≈øtand at a ≈øtay, and grow not wor≈øer; Declination, when the Symptoms are dimini≈øhed.

Progno≈øtick.] Tumors produced from Phlegm or Melancholy, are hard of Cure. Tho≈øe are dangerous, which are generated from corrupt Blood or Choler, which ≈øeizeth the Internal Parts, which ≈øhew them≈øelves about the greater Ve≈ø≈øels, Joynts, Nerves, and the Membranous or Noble Parts: Tho≈øe that are of great bigne≈øs, and that happen in Cacochymick Bodies.

They are Terminated four ways; 1. By Di≈ø≈øipation, which the le≈ø≈øening of the Symptoms do declare. 2. By Suppuration, wherein the Pain
and Pul≈øation is increa≈øed together with a Fever. 3. By Induration, which the too often and immoderate u≈øe of Repelling and Di≈ø≈øipating Medicines hath cau≈øed. 4. Degenerating into a Gangrene, from the defect of Natural Heat.
The Cure is performed two ways: 1. By hindering any further Flux to the Part. 2. In removing that which is already gathered in the Part.
We ≈øtay the Flux of Humors, 1. By Intercepting. 2. By Repelling. 3. By Revelling. 4. By Derivation. 5. By Corroborating the Part it ≈øelf.

The Matter already gathered, is taken away, 1. By A≈øtringing and Repelling Medicines, to wit, when 'tis thin, and ≈øticks not too firm to the Parts. 2. By Re≈øolvents, when it is thick, and adheres more firmly to the Part. 3. By Suppuratives, when the other are too weak. 4. By Fire and Cutting, when other means effect nothing.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of Inflammation.
div.p: A Phlegmon or Inflammation is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, from Blood thrown forth into the Skin or Subjacent Mu≈øcles, cau≈øing Heat, Redne≈øs, Pain, Pul≈øation and Ten≈øion.
Difference.] 'Tis Perfect, when from Blood alone: Imperfect, when Choler Phlegm, or Melancholy is mix'd with the Blood, and then 'tis called Phlegmone, Ery≈øipelatodes, Oedematodes, Schirrhodes.
The Cau≈øe is ≈øometimes Blood alone, ≈øometimes mixt with other Humors.
Signs, are Heat, Redne≈øs, Pain, Pul≈øation, Shining, Ten≈øion, Hardne≈øs, Renitency.

Progno≈øticks.] An Inflammation of the External Parts frees the Internal from many Di≈øea≈øes; always whole≈øome, except from its too great Extention it produceth a Gangrene; dangerous and of hard cure is that which ≈øeizeth on the Eyes, Jaws, Penis, Pudendum Muliebre and Joynts. In a young Per≈øon, and in Summer ≈øoon cured; longer of Cure, in a fat, than a lean Body.

The Cure hath four Indications. The fir≈øt of the≈øe re≈øpects a good Diet; let him chu≈øe a clear Air, his Meat and Drink little, and that cooling; all hot, ≈øweet and fat things, as Pepper and Ginger, are hurtful; as al≈øo the motion of the Body, e≈øpecially of the Part affected; Sleep is very convenient: All Co≈øtivenefs, Anger and Venery are noxious,

Second, that ≈øtops the further Flux of the Humor, which may be performed by Revul≈øion, Derivation, Repelling and Interception; therefore let a Vein be opened as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, it being mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary: Revul≈øion is made in the Oppo≈øite and mo≈øt Remote part, Derivation in the neare≈øt: If you may not open a Vein, you mu≈øt u≈øe Leeches and Scarifications. Whil≈øt the≈øe things are done, ≈øeeing the Body is ≈øeldom clean, but that always there are ill Humors mixt with the Blood, by Purging rightly u≈øed, and often repeated, as al≈øo Bleeding, we effect much.

In the mean time, the Part affected requires Repelling Medicines, from which we mu≈øt ab≈øtain, Where, 1. The Noble Parts ≈øend the Humors
to convenient places, and to the Glandules. 2. Where the Humors are Malignant. 3. When Critical. 4. When the Body is very impure. 5. When the part affected is very weak or painful. 6. Where the Inflammation is about ≈øome Noble Part.

div.head: CHAP. III. Ery≈øipelas.
div.p: ERy≈øipelas is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, from Choler, thrown forth for the mo≈øt part only into the Skin it ≈øelf, ≈øometimes on the ≈øubjacent Mu≈øcles, cau≈øing Pain, Heat and other Symptoms.

Difference.] 'Tis perfect, when ≈øprung from Choler alone; as it is imperfect, when Blood, Phlegm or Melancholy is mixt with it; from who≈øe Appellation it likewi≈øe takes its name, and is called Ery≈øipelas, Phlegmonodes, Oedematodes, Scirrhodes; ≈øometimes an Ulcer is joined with it, which ≈øometimes con≈øumes only the Skin, other times the Fle≈øh it ≈øelf.

Cau≈øe is Choler, ≈øeldom alone, ≈øometimes mixt with Phlegm and Melancholy, but oftentimes with Blood or Serum; whence, tho≈øe Medicines that are proper for a Phlegmon, oftentimes do good in an Ery≈øipelas.

Signs.] Great heat, ≈øharp pain, Redne≈øs mixt with Yellowne≈øs, ea≈øily giving way to the touch, but as ≈øuddenly returning; the Swelling and Extention of the part little, and the Pul≈øation le≈ø≈øer: which la≈øt gave occa≈øion to Authors, of que≈øtioning whether an Ery≈øipelas ought to be reckoned among≈øt Tumors. It is accompanied always with a Fever, except from an External Cau≈øe.

Progno≈øticks.] An Ery≈øipelas is ≈øeldom dangerous, except the Matter be repell'd from the External parts to the Internal; yet more dangerous,
when it ≈øeizeth on the Noble Parts and Jaws; and when a Wound; Fracture, Di≈ølocation or Putrefaction are join'd with it.

Cure.] What concerns Diet here, is fir≈øt and chiefly to be con≈øidered; Air, Meat and Drink mu≈øt be cooling; all ≈øharp, hot, fat and ≈øweet things hurt; as likewi≈øe do too great Motion of the Body, Watchings, Co≈øtivene≈øs, Venery and Anger.
Purging is very nece≈ø≈øary, therefore tho≈øe Medicines de≈øcribed in the third Chapter of the fir≈øt Part, are here convenient.

A perfect Ery≈øipelas admits not of Bleeding; for the fatne≈øs of the Blood bridles the ≈øharpne≈øs of the Choler: But if the Fever be vehement, the Flux great, and any Blood (which for the mo≈øt part happens) be mingled with the Choler, 'tis convenient to bleed, e≈øpecially in Plethorick Bodies: In delicate and weak Bodies, Cupping-Gla≈ø≈øes, with Scarification or Leeches, if things ≈øhould require, will ≈øerve,
The≈øe being thus done, to provoke Sweat, is the be≈øt of all other Remedies.

Outwardly to the affected part, ought not to be applied, 1. Oyl, or any fat thing; as tho≈øe things which yield matter to the Choler, ea≈øily increa≈øe Putrefaction: But if yet it is your plea≈øure to u≈øe them, they mu≈øt be tempered by mixing them with other Medicines. 2. The Catapla≈øms de≈øcribed in the foregoing Chapter, may for the mo≈øt part be applied here with ≈øucce≈øs.

The Plai≈øter of Diapalma di≈ø≈øolved in Vinegar, is in dayly u≈øe; the leaves of Tobacco, Colewort, and Henbane applied to the part affected, ≈øtrongly draw forth the heat. div.head: CHAP. IV. Of Oedema.
div.p: OEdema, is a Tumor be≈øide Nature, ari≈øing from Pituitous Matter, white, ≈øoft, without pain, oftner cau≈øed by Conge≈øtion, than by Fluxion.
Difference.] It is perfect, when it proceeds only from Phlegm: Imperfect, when mixt with other Humors; Thus Oedema, Phegmonodes, Ery≈øipelatodes, Schirrhodes.
Cau≈øe is Phlegm, ≈øometimes alone, ≈øometimes confu≈øed with other Humors; for the mo≈øt part it is produced from the ill di≈øpo≈øition of the Limphaeducts.

Progno≈øticks.] If an Oedema degenerate into a Scirrhus, or Ab≈øce≈øs, it is hard of Cure. Cure.] This, as the precedent Tumors, requires a good Diet Meat and Drink, as al≈øo the Air mu≈øt be moderately hot and dry: Ro≈øted Meat is better than Boiled; Fruit, Chee≈øe, and Fi≈øh hurt; as al≈øo too great a quantity of Meat and Drink: Wine, either of it ≈øelf,, or altered with hot Herbs is good; moderate Exerci≈øes of the body before Meals, is as profitable, as much Sleep, e≈øpecially
diurnal is prejudicial; Co≈øtivene≈øs, Re≈øt, and Sadne≈øs are Noxious.
Bleeding is altogether here unprofitable, and very ≈øeldom u≈øed; but Sweating and Purging very nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øometimes Vomiting: Always regard mu≈øt be had to the Stomach.

To the Tumor it ≈øelf. In the beginning we apply Repelling Medicines mixt with Di≈øcu≈ø≈øives, but ≈øo, that the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øives exceed; afterwards we u≈øe only Di≈øcu≈ø≈øives, though ≈øometimes ≈øtronger, ≈øometimes weaker, according to the condition of the Di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of Scirrhus.
div.p: SCirrhus is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, ≈øometimes generated of Tough, Vi≈øcous Phlegm; ≈øometimes of Melancholy, hard, not yielding to the touch, nor painful.
Differences; It is perfect when ≈øprung from Melancholy, or Phlegm alone: Imperfect, when other Humors are unnaturally mixt with it.

Progno≈øtick.] A Scirrhus, where there is no pain, and upon which the hair grows, is altogether incurable, and if Livid, it is very dangerous, and often degenerates into a Cancer: An imperfect, ≈ømall, and painful one, by means ≈øometimes (although very rare) may be cured.

Cure.] If the Scirrhus be produced from Phlegm, the ≈øame manner of Diet is to be ob≈øerved as in an Oedema; but if from Melancholy, you mu≈øt chu≈øe a clear Air, moderately hot, and

Among≈øt the External Remedies are Di≈øcu≈ø≈øives and Emollients; but yet the whole cour≈øe of the Cure mu≈øt be mixt, now increa≈øing the quantity of the one, then of the other.
