div.head: CHAP. VI. De Tumore Aquo≈øo, or Watry Tumor.
div.p: TUmor Aquo≈øus is a Collection of a Watry Humor in the whole body, or in ≈øome one part; ≈øoft, and without pain, yielding to the Fingers, but ≈øuddenly returning.

Difference. Sometimes the whole body is ≈øwell'd with water; which Tumor is call'd Ana≈øarca, ≈øometimes the lower Belly only, or with the Legs, and then it is called A≈øcites; if Wind, mixing with the water, extends the Belly like to a Drum, it is call'd Tympanites: The≈øe are three kinds of Drop≈øies, who≈øe Cure rather appertains to the Phy≈øician than Chirurgion; Water collected in the Head, is call'd Hydrocephalos; in the Brea≈øt, a Drop≈øie of the Lungs; in the Navel, a Hydromphalos; in the Cods, Hydrocele.
Cau≈øe is Serum, to wit Salt-water, produced from the lo≈øt heat of the parts that ≈øerv'd to Sanguification, and Chylification.
Signs; This Tumor is ≈øofter then Oedema, and more yielding to the Fingers, without pain, with ≈øome itching, and if you look on it by Candlelight, very ≈øhining.
Progno≈øticks.] Watry Tumors are not dangerous, if the principle parts that feed it, are not too much debilitated, yet all are of difficult Cure, e≈øpecially tho≈øe in and about the Joynts.

Cure. Diet is here the ≈øame as in Oedema: All Salt things indurated with Smoak, and too great a quantity of Drink, are very hurtful; as al≈øo Spirit of Wine and Pepper; otherwi≈øe hot and dry Aliments are be≈øt.
Purging is very nece≈ø≈øary, provided it be not too great, le≈øt the parts already weak, are more weakned: provoking Sweat and Urine, here are very profitable.
Bleeding, by experience I know it to be hurtful to all Hydropick People.

div.head: Medicines, Purging Water.
div.p: Roots of A≈øarum, Dwarf-Elder, Jalap, white Mechoacans, Leaves and Bark of Elder, Euphorbium, Turbith, Gum Gutta, Syrup, and Species of Diacarthamum, Cream of Tartar.
Take Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive, with Senna, Diacarthamum, of each an ounce; Jalap, eight grains, Cream of Tartar, two ≈øcruples, Par≈øley-water, as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into a Potion.

div.head: A Purging Wine, which cures the Drop≈øie it ≈øelf.
div.p: Take Roots of Orri≈øe, Gentian, Succhory, Fennel, Ma≈øterwort, of each an Ounce; the middle Bark of Elder, an Ounce and half; Leaves of Ground-pine, a handful; Ro≈øemary, two Pugils; Flowers of Centaury the le≈øs, one Pugil; Seeds of Smallage, Coriander, Carraway, Roman-Nettle, Fennel, of each a Dram, Senna two ounces; Agarick three Drams; Jalap half an ounce; Turbith, a Dram and half: Let them be cut, and infu≈øed in ≈øix Pints of Rheni≈øh-wine: Do≈øe four ounces.

div.head: Medicines con≈øuming Water, outwardly u≈øed.
div.p: Roots of Orri≈øe, Bryony, Birthwort, Flowers of Elder, Camomil, leaves of Celandine, Centaury, Calamint, Rue, Dill, wild Majoram, Sulphur vivum, Salt, Allum, Bay-berries, Ammoniacum, Bdellium.

Take Cows-dung, half an ounce; Pidgeons dung two drams; Sulphur vivum half an ounce; Nitre two drams; Honey, Vinegar, of each an ounce and half; Bean meal two ounces; Bay-berries, Cummin-≈øeeds, of each half an ounce; Oyl of Dill, Nard, of each an ounce; White-wine, as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into a Poultice.
Or,

Take Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, Myrrhe, of each half an ounce; Camphire, half a Dram; Goats-dung, an ounce and half; Brim≈øtone, Salt, Cummin-≈øeeds, of each three drams; Turpentine and Wax, as much as ≈øufficeth: According to Art, make it into a Plai≈øter.

Hydrocephalus is always of difficult Cure: Water contained in the Ventricles of the Brain, or between the Brain and Meninges, is very dangerous; but le≈øs dangerous, when collected between the Dura, and Pia Mater, or between the Dura Mater, and the Skull: For the Dura Mater may be divided into a Lancet, if you can come at it; but lea≈øt danger of all, when detained without the Skull.

Purging Sudorificks and Diureticks, ≈øeldom do any good here; but Cauteries, Bli≈øters, I≈ø≈øues, Setons are more profitable; but ≈øometimes we are forc'd to come to Inci≈øion or U≈øtion, which Remedies, although dangerous, have cured ≈øeveral.

Some Chyrurgeons u≈øe with an actual Cautery to burn the Skin of the Head in five, ≈øix, or more
places, but not together and at once, but at ≈øeveral times, le≈øt the Patients ≈øtrength ≈øhould be too much ≈øpent, continually choo≈øing that place, which the watry Humor makes, to appear mo≈øt convenient.
Some with a Lancet open the Skin near to the Sagital Suture.

Which of the≈øe Remedies are be≈øt, cannot ab≈øolutely be declared. I mu≈øt e≈øteem an Actual Cautery, when the Water is between the Skin and the Skull; but if under the Skull, between the Meninges, I do not ≈øee how this operation can be performed without a Lancet.

But which of them ≈øoever you chu≈øe, have a care of di≈øcharging all the Water at once, for in the very Operation it ≈øelf the Patient dies, or at lea≈øt is very much debilitated; for till the end of the Cure, all the Water is not to be taken away, le≈øt the debilitated Parts be deprived of that heat which the Water po≈ø≈øe≈øt, do corrupt: but rather what remains mu≈øt be con≈øumed by Internal and External Di≈øcu≈ø≈øives; and this is to be ob≈øerved in all Watry Tumors that are Cured by a Paracenthe≈øis.
In the ≈øame manner the Watry Tumor in the Navel and Cod ought to be handled, after other Medicines have been applied in vain.
Drop≈øie of the Brea≈øt belongs not to Chirurgery, except where a Paracenthe≈øis is convenient; concerning which, Read the 15th. Chapter of the fir≈øt Part.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Flatuous, or Windy Tumor.
div.p: THe Flatuous Tumor is a Di≈øea≈øe produced of Wind, not yielding without re≈øi≈øtance to the Fingers.
Difference. Some are without pain, others with it; in the one, the wind is in motion, in the other, quiet.

Cau≈øes of Wind, are Phlegm, e≈øpecially when mingled with Choler, which, as Ferment doth froth, ≈øo it proceedeth wind; it always happens upon a debility of the Parts, by rea≈øon of which, although endeavoring to concoct the Humors, yet are notable.
Signs are Inflation, with a re≈øi≈øtance yielding to the Fingers, a rumbling noi≈øe, e≈øpecially if ≈øhaken.
Progno≈øticks.] It ≈øeldom comes is fle≈øhy parts; in other parts it brings many inconveniencies, in weak and Cacochymick bodies, it's of difficult and tedious Cure.

Cure.] The ≈øame Diet in here to be ob≈øerved as in an Oedema: Pea≈øe, Beans, Turnips, Che≈øtnuts, and all Crude Fruit do extreamly hurt; On the contrary, Wine, and other things moderately warming, profit; as al≈øo Spices, and tho≈øe things which di≈øper≈øe Wind, as Nutmegs, Mace, Ani≈øe, Carraways, Lovage.

The Stomach, and the whole Body require
purging and corroborating Medicines, always mixing with them tho≈øe that di≈øper≈øe Wind, and ≈øometimes al≈øo where Corroboratives are u≈øed, Anodines, Laudanum; Opiatum cautiou≈øly u≈øed (that is, half a grain, or a grain for a Do≈øe) is here excellent: For be≈øides that it cea≈øeth pain, it al≈øo by its Diaphoretick quality removes the Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe: To cau≈øe Sweat, is as nece≈ø≈øary as Bleeding is unnece≈ø≈øary.

div.head: Outward Medicines di≈øcu≈ø≈øing Wind.
div.p: Roots of Galangale, Lovage, Herbs, Dill, Mint, Marjoram, Peniroyal, Ro≈øemary, Rue, Chervil; Flowers of Elder, Mellilot, Camomil; Seeds, Ani≈øe, Carraways, Cummin, Fennel; Nutmegs, Cardamum, Ca≈øtor; Oyl of Rue, Nard, Spike, Dill, Carraway di≈øtill'd; Mace, Nuci≈øta expre≈øt and di≈øtill'd, Mellilot-plai≈øter.
Take Oyl of Wormwood, Rue, of each two Drams; Oyl of Nuci≈øtae expre≈øt, one Dram; of Mace di≈øtilled, half a Dram; Ca≈øtor, di≈ø≈øolved in Aqua vitae, two Scruples: Make it into a Linament.
Or,

Take the Leaves of Rue, Calamint, of each half an handful; Bean-meal, two Ounces; Seeds of Cummin and Ani≈øe, of each half an Ounce; Bayberries, Salt, of each three Drams; Nitre, Brim≈øtone, of each a Dram; Goats dung, ≈øix Ounces; White-wine, as much as is ≈øufficient: Mix them, and boyl them into the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Catapla≈øm.
Or,

Take the Roots of Pelitory of Spain, half a Dram; Venice-Sope, three Drams; Ca≈øtor di≈ø≈øolved in Aqua vitae, one dram; Seeds of Cummin,
Carraways, of each two drams; A≈øhes of Earthworms, half a dram; Oil of Spike, half an ounce; Ma≈øtick, three drams, Wax and Turpentine, as much as ≈øufficeth: Make it into a Plai≈øter according to Art.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. De Herpete.
div.p: HErpes is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, ≈øprung from yellow Choler, disfiguring the Skin with corroding and ≈øpreading Pu≈øtules.
Difference.] Where Choler ≈øolely predominates, it produceth Herpes exedens, but where Phlegm is mixt with Choler, a Herpes Miliaris.

Cau≈øe is ≈øometimes Choler alone, ≈øometimes mixt with Phlegm; and I ≈øee not why the ≈øerum of the Blood may not often be here taken as a Cau≈øe: For the Lymphaeducts being out of order, do produce Mutations in mans body, heretofore unknown.
Signs.] Are little Pu≈øtules, like to Millet-≈øeed; a heat, itching; and after rubbing, a moi≈øtne≈øs, and little Ulcers.
Progno≈øticks.] Herpes is of difficult Cure, but of little danger, unle≈øs ≈øo rendred by the immoderate u≈øe of Repellents.

Cure.] The ≈øame Diet is here required, as in an Ery≈øipelas. Moreover, Purging is here very nece≈ø≈øary; Bleeding not to be allowed of; the u≈øe of Baths is excellent, and their Waters taken at fit
times, ≈øafely Cure this Di≈øea≈øe: The Decoctions of China, Sal≈øa, &c. al≈øo benefit much.
Outwardly.] Fa≈øting-Spittle oftentimes doth good, becau≈øe if it ≈øhould be repelled to the Internal parts, it cau≈øeth a Feaver, and other ill Symptoms.

With great ≈øucce≈øs many times, have I ≈øeen applyed the Powder of Lapis Sci≈øilis, mixt with Vinegar; ≈øome u≈øed Mu≈øtard boyl'd in Butter; to which they add ≈øome Gunpowder. Lye al≈øo, and Urine have helpt many; Unguent, Fu≈øcum, of Felix Wurtz is excellent here; as al≈øo the following Plai≈øter.

Take Sarcocols, Crude Brim≈øtone, of each two drrms; Ma≈øtick, Frankincen≈øe, Lapis Calaminaris, of each half an ounce; white Troches of Rha≈øis, Litharge of Gold, Myrrhe, of each three drams; Goats Suit, half an ounce; Wax and Turpentine, ≈øo much as is ≈øufficient to make it into a Plai≈øter, according to Art.
Take the Powder of Chalk mixt with Cream, and anoint the part, fomenting it before with the hot Lees of White-wine.

div.head: In a Rebellious Herpes.
div.p: Take the brown Oyntment of Felix Wurtz, three drams; white Ointment with Camphire, one dram and half; Cera≈øe, Brim≈øtone, Myrrhe, of each a dram; Litharge a dram and half; Mercurius dulcis, Verdigrea≈øe, of each a ≈øcruple and half; Oyl of Ro≈øes, as much as ≈øufficeth: Make it into an Oyntment.
Or,
Take Lapis Prunella, one dram; Flower of Brim≈øtone, half an ounce; Salt of Saturn, a dram and half; old Oyl of Rape, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Linament.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Atheroma, Steatoma, and Meliceris.
div.p: A Theroma is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, contained in a proper Ci≈øt, cau≈øed from a Humor like to the Pap of a ≈øodden Barley, without pain, of the colour of the skin, not yeilding to the ≈øingers, nor when they are removed, ≈øuddenly ≈øwelling out again.

Steatoma is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, contained in its own proper Tunicle, cau≈øed from a Matter like to Suet, and of the ≈øame colour, ≈øoft, from a ≈ømall beginning, by degrees increa≈øing, difficulty yielding to to the Fingers, but they being removed, returning again to its former greatne≈øs.

Meliceris is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, included in its proper Tunicle, engendered from a Humor, like to Hony, without pain, round, ea≈øily yeilding to the Fingers, which being removed, returns again to its fir≈øt Figure.

Differences.] This Matter like to Honey, Suet, or Pap, if gathered about the Joynts, is call'd a Ganglion; if about the Glandules of the Neck, a Glandula, Scrophula, or Struma; if in the Arms, Legs, or Head, Turberculum; if from the Pox, Tophus.
Cau≈øe of the≈øe Tumors is Phlegm, in the one more, in the other le≈øs, receding from its Natural Con≈øtitution; and ≈øometimes, but very ≈øeldom, mixt with Melancholy.
Signs are declared in their Definition.

Progno≈øticks.] They are ≈øcarce ever cured, but by Manual Operation: If the Ve≈øicle be broken,
or not all taken out, there remains a Fi≈øtula, or a foul Ulcer: The Cure of which will be both difficult and tedious.
Cure.] They are ≈øometimes, but very rare, removed by ≈øtrong Re≈øolvents: I have Cured ≈øome with Bal≈øom of Peru; ≈øome u≈øe Oxicroceum Plai≈øter, or the following:
Take Laudanum an ounce; Red Myrrhe, three drams; Camphire a dram: Mix them; and make it into a Plai≈øter according to Art.
Another,
Take Gum Sagapenum, Ammoniacum, of each half an ounce; Roots of Pellitory, Euphorbium, of each a ≈øcruple and half; Brim≈øtone three drams; Oyl of Amber a dram: Make it into a Plai≈øter.
If it break, and the Matter di≈øcharge out of the Tunicle, then mu≈øt you u≈øe Corro≈øives, for other Medicines are too weak.

div.head: Corro≈øives, and Cathereticks.
div.p: Roots of the black Hellebore, burnt Galls, burnt Date-≈øtones, Verdigrea≈øe, burnt Alum, Quick Lime, Vitriol, Mercury Sublimate, and Precipitate; Spirit and Oyl of Vitriol, Spirit of Salt; the Liquor of Tartar; Oyntments of Aegyptiacum Fu≈øcum of Felix Wurtz; A≈øhes of Oak, and Vine branches.

Some u≈øe Ar≈ønick, and Orpment; but they are not u≈øed but with the greate≈øt danger in tho≈øe places known by Anatomy, under which the Nerves lye; to the Skin, and Carnous Excre≈øcencies, they may be applyed with the le≈øs danger.

div.head: The following Ointment will ≈øuffice.
div.p:
Take Vitriol well ≈øweetned, a dram; Verdigrea≈øe, a ≈øcruple, Ointment of Aegyptiacum,
half an ounce: Make it into an Oyntment.

If they tend to Suppuration, which is very ≈øeldom, let the Surgeon a≈ø≈øi≈øt Nature with Maturatives; but the ≈øafe≈øt Method of taking away the≈øe Tumors, we have ≈øhewn in the twelfth Chapter of the fir≈øt Part.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Scrophula, Struma, or King's-Evil.
div.p: STruma or Scrophula are Tumors be≈øides Nature, contained in a proper Tunicle of their own, from a Melancholick or Pituitous Humor; ≈øhewing them≈øelves in manner of Tubercles in the Neck and adjoyning Parts.
Difference.] They are ≈øometimes noveable, ≈øometimes fixt; ≈øometimes but one, ≈øometimes many.
Cau≈øe, is Melancholy or Phlegm, or both mixt together.
Signs.] Are Hardne≈øs, Inequality, and ≈øeldom painful.

Progno≈øticks.] The≈øe Tumors are of long and difficult Cure; e≈øpecially if many, or fixt; they are dangerous when they grow painful, and threaten to become cancerous; or if fixt to any great Nerve or Vein, ≈øometimes they are Hereditary, and ≈øometimes peculiar to a Region or City; when cured, they for the mo≈øt part leave behind them great Skars; where the recurrent Nerve is divided, the Speech is lo≈øt, and oftentimes Life it ≈øelf.
Cure.] Diet mu≈øt be here the ≈øame, as in a Oedema or Scirrhus.
Purging is nece≈ø≈øary, but not Bleeding: provoking Sweat, by the ≈øame way and means as in the French-Pox, effects much; yea, it alone cures the King's-Evil.
Sometimes they are con≈øumed by Internal Remedies, that have appropriated Qualities of curing Scrophulas.
Such are the≈øe:

Roots of round Birthwort, Briony, Sow-Bread, Dropwort, Devil's-bit, Orri≈øe, Pimpernel, Pellitory of Spain, Squills, Vervain, Figwort, Leaves of Cypre≈øs, Bawm, Rue, Savory, Flowers of Broom, burnt Crabs, burnt Egg-≈øhells, Sal Gemmae, Spunges.

New Spunges are much commended, if boiled in Ale; drinking thereof three or four times a day; or calcined, and taking half a dram of the Powder Morning and Evening. The following Powder is likewi≈øe very much prai≈øed:

Take the A≈øhes of Sea-Spunges, Os Sepiae, Long Pepper, Cinamon, Sal Gemmae, Pellitory of Spain, Cypre≈øs-Nuts, Galls, Red-Ro≈øe Leaves, of each half an ounce: Make a Powder. Do≈øe, two Scruples or a Dram.
Or,
Take of Spunge-≈øtone, three drams; Sal Gemmae, two drams; Salt of Tartar, a dram: Make a Powder. Do≈øe, two ≈øcruples, or a dram.
Outwardly Re≈øolving and Emollient Medicines are applied; which if they effect it not, then u≈øe Suppuratives; when 'tis ≈øuppurated, it is to be cured as a malignant Ulcer.

But if the above-named Medicines ≈øignifie nothing,
then we come to corro≈øive Medicines, and to the Inci≈øion-Knife.

div.head: An excellent Re≈øolving Emollient Plai≈øter.
div.p: Take Gum, Galbanum, Ammoniacum, Bdellium, of each half an ounce; Bay-berries, Stavesacre, Pellitory of Spain, Cummin, of each ≈øix drams; Pigeon's dung, a dram; Goat's-dung, three drams; Hog's-grea≈øe, an Ounce and half; Oyl of Camomile, an ounce; Wax and Pitch, as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into a Plai≈øter.

div.head: A Liniment that ≈øtops the Flux of Humors, and oftentimes wholly cures the King's-Evil.
div.p: Take Oyl of Myrtles and Bayes, of each half an ounce; Ointment of Martiaton, an ounce; Quick≈øilver extinct with Flower of Brim≈øtone, ≈øix drams: Make it into an Ointment.

Let the Scrophula be annointed with it twice a day; and if they are not con≈øumed, at lea≈øt they will be dimini≈øhed: but the Chirurgeon mu≈øt look into the Patient's Mouth each day, le≈øt upon the continual u≈øe of Mercury, there follows a Flux, which cau≈øes a ≈øwelling of the Tongue and Jaws: The Plai≈øter of Frogs, with Mercury, is likewi≈øe good here.
Or,
Take Gum-Caranna, an ounce; crude Mercury extinct in Turpentine, three drams: Make a Plai≈øter.
If the Tumor he painful, there may be added to this Plai≈øter a dram of Opium, which hath the virtue of re≈øolving and ea≈øing pain, and is not cold, but hot.
Suppurating Medicines are ≈øet down in the ≈øecond Chapter, and Corro≈øive in the foregoing Chapter.
In Suppurated and open Scrophulaes, this Ligament is much e≈øteemed:
Take Oyl of Bayes, Ceru≈øe powdered and allayed with Aqua-vitae, of each an ounce; Roch-Allom, half an ounce; Salt, two drams: Make it into an Ointment.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of a Bubo.
div.p: BUbo is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, of the Glandules, from impure Blood, Red, Painful and hard.

Difference.] Where little, and not painful, and ea≈øily brought to Suppuration, 'tis called Phyma; but where there is more of Choler in it Phygeton; in the Arm-pits, Panus; behind the Ears, Parotis: The one Malign or Pe≈øtilential, the other not; ≈øometimes contracted from uncha≈øte Embraces, then 'tis called a Venereal Bubo.
Cau≈øe is Blood, never alone, but always mixt with ≈øome other preternatural Humor.
Signs, are Redne≈øs about the Glandules, pain, heat, ten≈øion, hardne≈øs, pul≈øation, and ≈øometimes a Fever.

The Liver and Spleen, according to the opinion of the Ancients, di≈øcharge them≈øelves into the Groins; the Brea≈øt and Heart, at the Arm-pits; the Brain, at the Glandules of the Ear; but now far other u≈øe is attributed to the Glandules. Of which there are ≈øeveral Tracts written, and we ≈øhall give our Opinion in another place.

Progno≈øticks.] The Bubo that is not Malign, is
not dangerous, except it be long di≈øcu≈ø≈øing, or ≈øuppurating, and then fear le≈øt it Fi≈øtulate: In the Arm-pits it is ≈øooner brought to maturity than in the Groins; and here ≈øooner than behind the Ears: On the contrary, a Malign is for the mo≈øt part a ≈øign of ≈øudden Death, although all outward ≈øigns may appear well.

The Venereal is not mortal, but of hard Cure, and for the mo≈øt part precedes the Pox; chiefly when by Bleeding, or the u≈øe of repelling Medicines, the Matter is returned from the External, into Internal parts.

Cure.] Diet the ≈øame as in a Phlegmon: In a Benign, Purging is nece≈ø≈øary, provided it be not with too ≈øtrong Medicines: Bleeding, except a great Fever, or a Plethora require, I admit no more of it here, than of Repellent Medicines; for 'tis un≈øeemly that Natures A≈ø≈øi≈øter ≈øhould return that into the interior parts, which Nature her ≈øelf did eject (which for the mo≈øt part is Critical.) Sweating in all Buboes, profits much: Scarification hath no place here, except in Malignant, nor Leeches, but where very much inflamed.

The External Cure is to be managed ≈øo, that the Humor may be di≈ø≈øipated with Re≈øolvents, which by rea≈øon of the frigidity of the Glandules, are required the ≈øtronger; adding al≈øo Attractives to them; for in all, I ≈øu≈øpect le≈øt the Matter be not perfectly thrown forth: But in a painful Bubo, 'tis fir≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to ea≈øe the pain, before you come to any other Medicines.

div.head: In extream Pain.
div.p: Take Mu≈øilages of the Seeds of Flea-wort, an ounce and half; the Yolk of an Egg, Saffron, a dram; fre≈øh Butter, half an ounce: Make it into a Liniment,
Or,

Take Leaves of Mallows, an handful; Meal of Mar≈øh-Mallow Roots, and Fenugreek-≈øeeds, of each two ounces; Barley-meal, an ounce; Ducks-grea≈øe, Oyl of Dill, of each half an ounce: Boil them in Milk, to the con≈øi≈øtence of a Catapla≈øm.
Re≈øolvents are above de≈øcribed; Attractives ≈øhall be pre≈øently ≈øet down.

If it yield not to di≈øcu≈ø≈øion, Suppuration is to be endeavoured; which is of all, the ≈øafe≈øt Method: Being ≈øuppurated, let it forthwith be opened; but rather by Inci≈øion, than Cautery: And ≈øo let it be kept opened until the whole Tumor be di≈ø≈øolved.

In Children, for the mo≈øt part, we commit it wholly to Nature; only pre≈øcribing a good Diet, and forbidding the often touch of the part affected with the hands; or we apply the Plai≈øter of Diachilon, or of Mu≈øilages: 'tis al≈øo often cured by the only u≈øing of Oyl of Olives, Rape, Camomil, or white Lillies.
In a Pe≈øtilential Bubo, neither Bleeding or Purging (what≈øoever others ≈øay) mu≈øt be u≈øed: Sudorificks and Refrigeratives are convenient; outwardly Attractives in the beginning, are nece≈ø≈øary.

div.head: Attractives.
div.p: Roots of Aron, Briony, Birthwort, Pellitory of Spain, Dittany, Cre≈ø≈øes, Virgins-Flower, Leeks, Nettles, Garlick, Onions, Figs, Mu≈øtard, Gums, Galbanum, Ammoniacum, Euphorbium, Succinum, Cantharides, Ca≈øtor, Ox gall, Pigeons grea≈øe, and Goats-dung; Quick-Lime, Nitre, Brim≈øtone; Leaven, Black-≈øope, Plai≈øters of Diachilon, Oxicroceum, Thereacle, Mithridate.

Take Roots of Mar≈øh-mallows, an ounce; Onions, two ounces; Elder and Camomil-Flowers, of each a pugil; Figs, No xij. Fenugreek-meal, two ounces; Pigeons-dung, two drams; Thereacle, three drams: Make a Catapla≈øm.
Or,
Take Roots of Pellitory of Spain, Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, of each two ≈øcruples; Salt, two drams; Treacle, three drams; Gum Ammoniacum, di≈ø≈øolved in Vinegar, as much as ≈øufficeth to make a Plai≈øter.

Many take a Hen or Frog divided in the mid≈øt, and apply them warm to the affected Part, often changing them: Some apply to the Part the Breech of a live Hen or Pigeon, the Feathers being pulled off: Others take away all by Inci≈øion, which is very dangerous, and not to be permitted: But they proceed be≈øt, who forthwith in the very beginning apply a Ve≈øicatory to the Bubo; then the following Morning or Evening open the Bli≈øter, and afterwards dre≈ø≈øing it with Attractives: This is of great U≈øe, and of much E≈øteem.

Take the Plai≈øter of Diachilon with Gums, of Mu≈øilages, of each half a pound; Ointment of Ba≈øilicon, four ounces; Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, three ounces: Make a Plai≈øter. More of the Cure of a Bubo, look in our De≈øcription of the Plague.

In a Venereal Bubo, you mu≈øt neither Bleed nor Purge, as long as there remains any hope of Curing it by External Remedies, le≈øt the Malignant Humors which Nature threw out, ≈øhould be returned again into the Body, and ≈øo occa≈øion the Pox: But Suppuration is to be endeavoured by all means, and the Suppurated Tumor
forthwith, yea, although the Matter be not perfectly concocted, is to be opened; if it is tough, as for the mo≈øt part it is, Attractives are to be applied, e≈øpecially Cupping-Gla≈ø≈øes; they not being ≈øufficient, when the whole Ma≈øs of Blood is infected, the Cure of the Pox is to be pre≈øcribed; often u≈øing this following Decoction.

Take Roots of China, Sar≈øaparilla, of each three ounces; Polipody, an ounce; Bark of Guaicum, three ounces; Senna, two ounces; Agarick Trochi≈øcatum, two drams; Cinamon, two drams: Infu≈øe in a ≈øufficient quantity of Water over the Fire for 24 hours, then boil them to three quarts, and to the ≈øtrained Liquor add Syrup of Ro≈øes, Sol. with Senna, four ounces: Mix them. Do≈øe, ≈øix or eight ounces.

Some make this Decoction with ≈øtale Beer or Wine; but in the≈øe things the Surgeon ought to con≈øider the pa≈øt manner of living of his Patient, his Temperature and Age: If you de≈øire that it purge you more, you may add a dram or two of Trochi≈øe Alhandal; and if not ≈øtrong enough, then you may mix it with five or ≈øix grains of white Precipitate, provided ≈øtrength gives leave.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the Carbuncle.
div.p: A Carbuncle is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, from adu≈øt Blood, corrupting the Part where it is collected.

Difference.] 'Tis called by the Greeks, Anthrax; by the Latines, Ignis Per≈øicus; by the Germans, Een Kool: Some endeavour a Difference between an Anthrax and Carbuncle, but lo≈øe their Labour. There is is no other Difference, but ≈øometimes it is bigger, ≈øometimes le≈ø≈øer, ≈øometimes more Malignant, other times le≈øs.
Cau≈øe is adu≈øt Blood, a≈ø≈øuming the Nature of black Choler, and ≈øo apt to putrifie.

Signs are, ≈øometimes but one great Pu≈øtule, ≈øometimes many litttle ones; which being opened, appear black, and all about enflamed: The Cru≈øt being removed, in≈øtead of Matter, you find ≈øpungy Fle≈øh; the Part affected is very painful, a Fever pre≈øent and Watchings.
Progno≈øticks.] Very dangerous, when black, e≈øpecially in Plague time; when near to to a principal part, if great, and ≈øuddenly vani≈øhing.

Cure.] Strong Purging Medicines I much mi≈øtru≈øt; Cli≈øters or loo≈øening Medicines will ≈øuffice; viz. Ca≈ø≈øia Fi≈øtula, Manna, Tamarinds, Cream of Tartar, &c. But more ≈øu≈øpicious to me is Bleeding to fainting (as Galen writes) and in its room, Leeches or Cups with Scarification will be ≈øufficient. But I rely mo≈øt upon Sudorifick and Refrigerating
Medicines; u≈øing outwardly the ≈øame Medicines as in the Plague.
This Plai≈øter is much commended to make a ≈øeparation of the Eskar.

Take old Thereacle, Mithridate, of each half an ounce; Leaven, Turpentine, of each two ounces; Honey of Ro≈øes, an ounce and a half; Fre≈øh Butter, two ounces; White Vitriol, an ounce; Soot, two ounces and half; Black-≈øope, three ounces; Saffron, three drams; Yelks of Eggs, No iij. Mix them, and make a Plai≈øter according to Art.

The External Medicines ought often to be changed: Here is no need of Suppuratives; for the Humors are ea≈øily corrupted of them≈øelves; in the place of which, the Eskar being ≈øeparated, may be u≈øed Ung. Fu≈øcum of Felix Wurtz, Aegyptiacum, and Honey of Ro≈øes, &c.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of a Cancer.
div.p: A Cancer is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, ≈øprung from Black Choler, round, hard, livid, painful, full of turgid Veins, re≈øembling the feet of a Crab.
Difference.] Where not exulcerated, by the Greeks it is named Carcinoma; when ulcerated, Plagedaena, by the Greeks; and by the Germans, De Wolf.

Signs.] In the beginning difficultly known, ≈øcarce equalling a Pea in bigne≈øs; then ≈øometimes increa≈øing ≈øuddenly, ≈øometimes ≈ølowly; it makes
it ≈øelf, by its grievous Symptoms, ea≈øily enough to be known: The Tumor is hard, painful, hot, livid, or black, round with ≈øome inequality, full of ≈øwell'd Veins.

Progno≈øticks.] A Cancer is ≈øeldom Cured by Medicines, often by Chirurgery, but not without danger; ≈øharp Medicines exulcerate it: It is imprudence to attempt an occult Cancer, or that is detained in any Cavity of the Body, except it be very little, and may ea≈øily be taken away by Inci≈øion.
Cure.] Diet the ≈øame as in Schirrhus; frequent Purging convenient; be cautious in Bleeding, as al≈øo in Scarification. The Moneths flowing in Women, and in Men, the Hemorrhoids, are very beneficial.
Externally, Suppuratives and ≈øtrong Di≈øcutients are hurtful; the following, good.

div.head: Medicines in a Cancer.
div.p: Roots of Arum, Dropwort, Gentian, Figwort, Mullein; Leaves of Maidenhair, Hou≈øleek the greater, Agrimony, Tobacco, Plantain, Night≈øhade, Hounds-tongue, the Spawn of Frogs, of Whales, Burnt-Crabs, Burnt-Lead, Mans-Dung, Plai≈øters of Diapompholigos, of Lead, Diafulpharis, of Frogs with Mercury, Sugar of Sat√πrn, Camphire.

div.head: For a Cancer not ulcerated.
div.p:
Take the Juice of Plantain, Endive, Hou≈øleek the greater, Night-≈øhade, Ro≈øe-Vinegar, Oyl of Myrtle, of each an ounce; Venice-Turpentine, two drams: Stir them together in a Leaden Mortar, with a Leaden Pe≈øtle; adding of the Rinds of Pomegranates and Citrons, of each a dram; Bole-armonick, Burnt-lead, Camphire,
of each half a dram: Make it into a Liniment

div.head: For an Ulcerated Cancer.
div.p: Take Galls, Pomegranate-Rinds, of each half an ounce; Burnt Talk, an ounce; Bole-armenick, half an ounce; Burnt-Lead, two drams; A≈øhes of Crab-≈øhells, a dram; Turpentine and Honey, as much as is ≈øufficient: Make an Ointment.

By the u≈øe of the≈øe or the like Medicines, Cancers that are not ulcerated, have been often cured; and ulcerated Cancers have been for many years kept in the ≈øame condition; but for the mo≈øt part, the bu≈øine≈øs is committed to Chirurgery: The Part affected being held by a pair of Forceps, is to be cut off by the help of a convenient Knife, but ≈øo that nothing of the Cancer be left behind, left it bud afre≈øh; others holding it only with their left hands, or pa≈ø≈øing a ≈øtring quite cro≈øs, take it off by Inci≈øion.
Many with great Prai≈øes extol prepared Ar≈øenick, or Mercury ≈øublimate; but its Deeds an≈øwer not their Words: Its Preparation John Faber in his Myrotheico Spargirico teaches.

div.head: The Quinte≈ø≈øence of Ar≈øenick.
div.p:
Take Cri≈øtalline, Ar≈øenick, with the like weight of Salt-Petre, and reduce all into the fine≈øt Alchool, and put them into a very ≈øtrong Gla≈øs-Retort; to which joyn a Recipient big and large enough; being well luted together, di≈øtil them with Embers, ob≈øerving the degrees of the Fire, at fir≈øt gentle, at the end very ≈øtrong and violent, until all the Spirits of the Ar≈øenick and Salt Petre are gone forth: They being come forth, and the Ve≈ø≈øels cold, disjoyn the Recipient
from the neck of the Retort, having great care of the Spirits that are within, which are venomous; ≈øuddenly ≈øtopping the mouth of the Receiver with a ≈øtrong Lute; afterwards breaking the Retort, and that which is in the bottom, mu≈øt be powdered, and put into a new Retort, and upon the Powder that is put into the Retort, the Spirits of Ar≈øenick which were in the Receiver, is to be powred and di≈øtill'd again, being luted well, as at fir≈øt: This is to be done three or four times, till the Ar≈øenick be well calcin'd with the Salt-Petre; then lay the Ar≈øenick upon a ≈øtrong Tile, and for a whole day make a ≈øtrong fire about it; ≈øo that which could not be Calcined by Di≈øtillation, may be Calcined and burnt by an open Fire: This Calx of Ar≈øenick is to be di≈ø≈øolv'd in di≈øtilled Rain-water, and the Solution ≈øo clean≈øed and depurated, from its Terre≈øtrial Excrements, and by filtring made clear and limphid, is to be evaporated and dried, and calcined again with a very ≈øtrong Fire, until it remits no Faeces in the Solution, but the whole Calx is di≈ø≈øolved, and the Water remains mo≈øt clear and limphid; then the Water being evaporated, it is to be dried. Then la≈øtly, its above re≈øerved Spirit is to be powred upon it, and mixt with it; but fir≈øt it ought to he ≈øeven times rectified: You mu≈øt make this Conjunction in a Matrace (a Gla≈øs-Ve≈ø≈øel ≈øo called, by rea≈øon of its roundne≈øs in the bottom, and long neck) and in a warm Balneum, till the Calx hath imbibed its Spirit; then in a Gla≈øs-Alembick, you ≈øhall ≈øeparate by Balneum what≈øoever of wateri≈øh Humidity can be ≈øeparated, and there will remain in the bottom the Buttery Calx of Ar≈øenick: of great virtue, which mu≈øt be kept in a Gla≈øs-Ve≈ø≈øel well ≈øtopt.

p.hi:
Take ≈øome of this Powder, mix it with
Ba≈øilicon, or a Dige≈øtive; and thus mixt, apply to the ulcerated Cancer.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of a Gangrene and Sphacelus.
div.p: A Gangrene, is a beginning Mortification of the the ≈øoft Parts of the Body, mo≈øt commonly following a great Inflammation, or ill cured.

p.hi: Sphacelus, Necro≈øis, Syderatio, is a perfect Mortification, not only of the ≈øoft, but of the hard parts al≈øo.

div.p: Differences.] In a Sphacelus, the parts are altogether dead; but in a Gangrene, they begin but to die, and the ≈øen≈øe is not perfectly aboli≈øhed; there the Skin is fir≈øt pallid, ≈øuddenly livid, then black; here in a manner red; greater ≈øtink in that, than in this.

The Cau≈øes of both are ≈øix. 1. The External Cold of the Air, or Repelling Medicines. 2. External Heat, from burning, or u≈øe of Corro≈øive Medicines. 3. A Defect of Nutriment, as in an Atrophia, either by the compre≈ø≈øion or ob≈øtruction of the Ve≈ø≈øels, by rea≈øon of which ≈øtraightne≈øs the Blood cannot pa≈øs to the Part. 4. The ≈øtopping of the Pores, or Per≈øpiration hindred; from whence comes a Suffocation of the Natural Heat. 5. Malign Humor, either begotten in the Body, or contractee from venomous Bea≈øts, or Medicines. 6. The Scurvy, which by a peculiar property, cau≈øeth the Parts ≈øometimes to mortifie.
Signs.] A Sphacelus is ea≈øily to be known, the Part looks black; Spungy Fle≈øh; Sen≈øe, Heat, and Pul≈øation aboli≈øh'd.

But the Signs of a Gangrene vary according to the variety of the Cau≈øes: If contracted from Cold, a great pricking Pain is felt in the affected Part: Fir≈øt, 'tis red, then pale, at length black: The Natural heat by degrees is extingui≈øhed, and there happens a ≈øhaking, not unlike that in a Quartane Ague.

If cau≈øed from an External Heat, or ≈øtopping of the Pores, the Redne≈øs is changed into White, then into Black; Pul≈øation and Pain cea≈øe; the Sen≈øes le≈ø≈øened; and at la≈øt there appear ≈øome Pu≈øtules, from whence i≈ø≈øue a gleety Humor.
If from defect of Aliment, there is neither Pain, Inflammation or Tumor; the Body waxeth cold, and for the mo≈øt part ≈øeizeth upon the Joynts.

If from a venomous Creature or Humor, great Pain and Fever always accompany it; frequent Faintings, and oftentimes Deliriums: Here ari≈øeth a Pu≈øtule, under which appears a black Spot, which ≈øpreads it ≈øelf over the whole part.

If from the Scurvy, it for the mo≈øt part begins at the Toes, it ≈øhews it ≈øelf outwardly with blacki≈øh ≈øpots and lines, which degenerates into a dry Cru≈øt; upon which follows a Numne≈øs of the Part, and at length a Mortification it ≈øelf, without any Stink: Sometimes without pain, other times very great, e≈øpecially in them that are given to Pa≈ø≈øion or Sadne≈øs.

Progno≈øticks.] Except a Gangrene be ≈øuddenly ≈øtopt, it degenerates into a Sphacelus; ea≈øilier cured in young, than old People: The Humors continually flowing to the part affected, bring danger with them, and that very great, if they are Malignant: In the Cavities of the Body, to wit, in the Mouth, Privy Parts, and Fundament, &c.
a Gangrene is always difficult of Cure, as al≈øo that which happens among the Nerves and Tendons; in Hydropicks always mortal: That which happens from the Scurvy, may be ≈øpun out from many Months, but ≈øeldom cured.
A Sphacelus is not cured but by the Knife and Fire.

Cure.] Diet mu≈øt be good, the Air, Meat and Drink generally cooling and drying: But ≈øeeing the Cau≈øes are various, we leave it to the Phy≈øitian to pre≈øcribe what is convenient; who al≈øo mu≈øt well di≈øtingui≈øh concerning Bleeding and Purging, when to be u≈øed with advantage or di≈øadvantage. Sudori≈øicks and Cordials are of great u≈øe here; and becau≈øe that in this, and other Di≈øea≈øes, they are often u≈øed, I thought it convenient to ≈øet them down in this Place.

div.head: Diaphoreticks or Sudori≈øicks.
div.p: Roots of Angelica, Scorzonera, Lovage, Contrayerva; Herbs, Holy-Thi≈øtle, Fumitory, Scordium; Harts Horn, Unicorns-Horn, Bezoar, the Stone of an Indian Hog, called Pedro Porco; Waters, of Threacle, Alexipharmick; Dia≈øcordium, Threacle, Mithridate; Species Liberantis; Antimony, Diaphoretick; Salts, of Wormwood, Prunella, Holy-Thi≈øtle, Rob. Sambuct.
Take Dia≈øcordium Farca≈øtorii, one dram; Alexipharmick-Water, two drams; Holy-Thi≈øtle water, as much as is ≈øufficient; Syrup of Limons, half an ounce: Make a Potion.

div.head: Cordials.
div.p:
Waters of Ro≈øes, Borage, Buglo≈øs; Con≈øerves, of Ro≈øemary-flowers, of Ro≈øes, Violets & Borage; Bezoar, Harts horn, Unicorns horn; Confections of Alchermes, Hiacynthus; Rob. of Red Currans,
of Barberries; of Scorzonera Roots Candied, Citron and Orange-peels Candied, Saccharum Perlatum, Salt of Coral.

Take Water of Borage, Buglo≈øs, of each two ounces and an half; Alexipharmick-water, three Drams; Cinnamon-water, two Drams; Saccharum Perlatum, half an ounce; Confection of Hiacinth, half a Dram; prepared Crabs eyes, two Scruples; Spirit of Salt, four Drops: Mix them.
Let the Patient now and then take one or two Spoonfuls.

Externally, Cupping gla≈ø≈øes, and Leeches; but chiefly Scarification mu≈øt be u≈øed; although there are ≈øome of our Chirurgeons, which altogether reject Scarification; neverthele≈øs happily curing their Patients, by the following Medicines, which re≈øi≈øt Putrefaction.

div.head: External Medicaments again≈øt a Gangrene.
div.p: Roots of Angelica, round Birthwort; Herbs, of Wormwood, Holy-Thi≈øtle, Tobacco, Rue, Colewort, Germander; Flowers of Elder, St. John's Wort, Mellilot, Camomil; Lye, Brine, Ink, Urine, Spirit of Wine, Treacle, Ung. Aegyptiacum, Fu≈øcum of Felix Wortz, Hor≈øe-dung.
Some mix Hemlock in Plai≈øters or Poultices, and u≈øe it with ≈øucce≈øs:
Or,

Take the Tops of Wormwood, Camomil, and Elder flowers, of each half a handful; Leaves of Germander, a handful and half; Rue, half a handful; Crums of brown Bread, ≈øeven ounces; Hor≈øe-dung, three ounces: Boyl them in Brine, in the end adding to them, Ink, two ounces; Spirit of Wine, three ounces: Make it into a Catapla≈øm.

The ≈øound part ought al≈øo to be pre≈øerved;
partly by keeping the Humors from flowing, and partly by keeping the Gangrene from ≈øpreading: For this purpo≈øe the Red defen≈øive Plai≈øter, or the Cerot of Virgo is good; as al≈øo this following Catapla≈øm.

Take Bolearmonick, half an ounce; Powder of Galls, Cypre≈øs-nuts, Pomegranate-rinds, of each three Drams; Barley-meal, ≈øix Ounces; Oxymel ≈øimplex; as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into a Catapla≈øm.
Or,

Take Seal'd Earth, Bolearmenick, of each half an ounce; prepared Harts-horn, a dram; Camphire, a Scruple; Ro≈øe-vinegar, an Ounce; Oyl of Mirtles, three ounces; white of an Egg: Make it into a Linament.

div.head: Cure of a Gangrene, cau≈øed from Cold.
div.p: The part gangren'd, if not grown black; but as yet appears very red with pain; the Patient is to be placed at the Fire; but not too near; but at a di≈øtance, that the heat by degrees may be again re≈øtored to the part; and to that purpo≈øe, ≈øtrongly rubbing it with Snow, or cold Water; giving al≈øo to the Patient, Treacle, or Mithridate, in warm Wine. If the pain and cold remit, let the part be embrocated very warm with Oyl of Dill, Camomil, bitter Almonds, or Earth-worms, &c. A Decoction of congeal'd Turnips, is good to foment withal; then are required both ≈øtronger and hotter Medicines, viz. Oyl of Earth, of Tiles, Turpentine, Ca≈øtor, Treacle-water, Mithridate: Or u≈øe the following Fomentation.

Take Herbs of Scordium, a handful and half; Swallow-wort, a handful; Rue, half a handful; Seeds of Roman Nettle, Cre≈ø≈øes, of each three
Drams; boyl them in White-wine, let them be ≈øtrained; and to a Pint of the Liquor, add Spirit of Wine, two ounces: Mingle it.
When the part hath begun to Mortifie, Scarifie; continue the u≈øe of the above pre≈øcribed Medicines.

div.head: Cure of a Gangrene from external Heat, or hindred by Per≈øpiration.
div.p: Let the cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe be removed, if po≈ø≈øible; which if it happens from external Ligature, Hot, or two A≈øtringent Medicines; let them be forthwith removed from the part affected; and let it be wa≈øhed, being fir≈øt Scarified with the following Decoction.

Take the Water of Endive, Night-≈øhade, of each ≈øix Ounces; of Sorrel-water, eight Ounces, Vinegar, half a pint; Salt, an Ounce and half; Scordium, a handful; Lupines, half an Ounce; Mix them, and boyl them to the Con≈øumption of the third part.
Then let the Chirurgeon u≈øe Ung. Aegyptiacum, or any other of the above pre≈øcribed Medicines.

div.head: Cure of a Gangrene from the Defect of Nutriment.
div.p: Let the Patient u≈øe nouri≈øhing Aliments; all ≈øtrong External, or Internal Dryers hurt; Friction of the part, with moderately hot Medicines, as with Oyl of Sweet Almonds, Olives, Earth-worms, Scorpions, Vipers, Man's Fat, Bears, or Hens, is good. Scarifie, if nece≈ø≈øity require. Di≈øcu≈ø≈øives here are very injurious.

div.head: Cure of a Gangrene from a venemous Humor.
div.p: If the malignant Humor be in the Body it ≈øelf, Sudorifick, cooling, and Cordial Medicines are be≈øt: For Purging and Bleeding, I have ≈øeen them oftner to do hurt than good.
Outwardly, Defen≈øives are u≈øele≈øs; but Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes, Leeches, and attractive Medicines are nece≈ø≈øary.

But if the Malignant Humor come from an external Cau≈øe; the ≈øure≈øt remedy is an actual Cautery, le≈øt the Malignity ≈øpread it ≈øelf, which is to be u≈øed the very fir≈øt time; and al≈øo to put a further ≈øtop, apply a Defen≈øive to the ≈øound part, two fingers breadth di≈øtance from the wounded part; ≈øo al≈øo it will put a ≈øtop to the Flux of Humors, or el≈øe all the hope con≈øi≈øts in Leeches, Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes, Attractive Medicines, and others ≈øet down above.

div.head: Cure of a Gangrene ≈øprung from the Scurvy.
div.p: Internal Remedies we commit to the Phy≈øitian; Externally, the≈øe are commended.

Take Seeds of Broom, Roman-Nettle, Rue, of each a Dram; Tops of Wormwood, two Drams; Gum, Galbanum Ammoniacum, di≈ø≈øolv'd in Vinegar, of each ≈øix drams; Oyl of Juniper, three drams; Wax, as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into a Plai≈øter.
Or,
Take Oyl of Earth-worms, Bayes, Rue, of each two Drams; Ca≈øtor, a Dram; Spirit of Wine, three Drams: Make it into a Linament.
Or,

Take the Ra≈øpings of Guaiacum, Sa≈ø≈øafras, of each an ounce; Root of Angelica, Celandines the greater, Tamarisk-bark, of each ≈øix Drams; Leaves of Scurvy-gra≈øs, Water-cre≈ø≈øes, of each a handful; Fennel-≈øeeds, an ounce; Spirit of Wine, a pint and half: Infu≈øe them a Night; then di≈øtil them in Balneo Mariae.
Foment the part affected with this, and ≈øcarifie, if there be occa≈øion; and let the Chirurgeon proceed according to Art.
Where a Gangrene hath degenerated into a Sphacelus, e≈øpecially in the Joynts, let the Part be amputated; concerning which, look in the Fir≈øt Part.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of a Paronychia.
div.p: PAnaritium, or Paronychia, is a Tumor very painful, in the end of the Finger, from a ≈øharp Malignant Humor, corroding the Tendons, Nerves, Perio≈øtium, and Bone it ≈øelf.
Cau≈øe is a ≈øharp humor, proceeding from Choler or Serum.
Signs are, an intollerable pain about the Nail, tormenting the Patient day and night; an Inflammation, oftentimes extending over the whole Arm: A Fever for the mo≈øt part, and ≈øometimes Delirium.

Progno≈øtick.] By how much the Humor is the more malignant, the greater Symptoms it rai≈øeth, corrupting ≈øometimes the Bone, the Finger, the whole Hand, and ≈øometimes from extream pain, it occa≈øions the death of the Patient.
Cure.] Foment the Finger a while in this Decoction.
Take Flowers of Camomile, Mellilot, Elder, of each half a handful; Lin≈øeed and Fenugreek, each two drams: Boil them in Milk.
Or, let this Catapla≈øm be applied.
Take Flowers of Dill, Elder, Leaves of Hen-Bane, of each a handful; Poppy-≈øeeds and Lin≈øeed, of each three drams; Mar≈øh-mallow-powder, an ounce and half.
Boil them in Milk, to the con≈øi≈øtence of a Catapla≈øm.

Then make Inci≈øion upon the Part affected, according to the length of the Finger; and for the mo≈øt part there appears one or more red ≈øpots, containing a ≈øharp Matter, but little in quantity, which is the cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe.

After the Apertion of the Tumor, at the fir≈øt dre≈ø≈øing, apply to the Finger Treacle di≈ø≈øolv'd in Spirit of Wine, and a Defen≈øive to the whole Hand; ≈øo in a day or two, the Cure will be perfected.

But if this Part ≈øhould be gangren'd or Sphacelated, either by the neglect of Patient or Chirurgeon, let it be taken off: Except you will commit the bu≈øine≈øs to Nature, which oftentimes ≈øeparates, and throws out this Bone. A great Inflammation ≈øometimes here produceth a Fle≈øhy Excre≈øcency, occult and ≈øen≈øle≈øs; this is removed by Knife, or exeding Medicines: Then cure according to Art.

But if being too late call'd you find a great collection of Humors, let Di≈øcu≈ø≈øives or Suppuratives be applied; then the Tumor being either broke, or opened, take great care, le≈øt the Tendons (which do very ea≈øily) putrifie, or incline to putrefaction: Separation is here nece≈ø≈øary, whether it be by Medicines, or a cutting In≈øtrument: Repellents in this ca≈øe, greatly hurtful.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of an Aneuri≈øm.
div.p: ANeuri≈øma is a Tumor be≈øides Nature, from a Rupture of an Artery, continually beating, ea≈øily yielding to the Fingers, and as ≈øuddenly returning.

Cau≈øe.] All Arteries, except tho≈øe that are di≈øper≈øed, through the Brain and upper parts, con≈øi≈øt of a double Tunicle; the inmo≈øt of which being either corroded or broke, the External may be extended ≈øo much (without a Rupture of it, what≈øoever others ≈øay) as to cau≈øe an Aneuri≈øm: Neverthele≈øs, where the Tumor is of the bigne≈øs of ones Fi≈øt, it cannot be but that the External al≈øo mu≈øt be either corroded or broke. Anatomy doth confirm this Opinion, which the Studious in the Art of Chirurgery may enquire into.
This Tumor al≈øo may be cau≈øed, where an Artery be divided; ≈øo that the External Tunicle united to the Mu≈øcles, the Internal, by rea≈øon of the continual pul≈øation, remains open.

Signs.] A Swelling increa≈øing by degrees, of the ≈øame colour as the skin; a continual Pul≈øation: If the Tumor be little, it ea≈øily yields to the Fingers, ≈øo that it altogether di≈øappears, but ≈øuddenly returns again; but if great, not ≈øo ea≈øily yielding to the touch, not ≈øo ≈øtrong a Pul≈øation: but there is a noi≈øe ob≈øerved, as of boiling Water; yet in the Head and Jaw, I have found after death an Aneuri≈øm, which while the man was alive,
there could be no Pul≈øe perceived: In the hard parts is greater Circum≈øpection to be u≈øed, than in the ≈øoft and fle≈øhy.

Progno≈øticks.] It is difficultly cured; if great, not at all, except with the taking off the Member; for the mo≈øt part it is a long Di≈øea≈øe, although I have ≈øeen it kill, without any other accidental Cau≈øe, within two years: If Inci≈øion be made, Death ≈øuddenly follows.

Cure.] In the beginning there may be ≈øome Hopes. A≈øtringents and Repellents, and convenient Ligatures, by which we do not ≈øeldom admini≈øter ≈øomething of Remedy to the Patient; as al≈øo the applying a piece of Lead ≈øtraightly bound on, have ≈øometimes cured little Aneuri≈øms.

But where the Tumor is encrea≈øed, there are ≈øome would have the Skin divided, and the Artery tied both above and below, and cut out the middle with the Tumor, and loo≈øen not the Ligatures, till the Wound is perfectly cured, and there is no fear of an Hemorrage; but this Operation is dangerous, painful and trouble≈øome, and oft-times of little Benefit: But to pre≈øerve Life, I would take off the Member.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of Opthalmia.
div.p: OPthalmia is an Inflammation of the Membranes of the Eye from Blood, with Redne≈øs, Pain, and ≈øhedding of Tears.

Difference.] A light Inflammation, and which depends from external Cau≈øes, is called a Ba≈øtard-Opthalmia, Taraxis, or Epiphora; but a great Inflammation, accompanied with pain and tears, a true Opthalmia. And if it be ≈øo great, that the Eye-lids are ≈øo inflamed, and as it were turned inward, 'tis called Chemo≈øis.
Cau≈øes are two. 1. Internal, as Blood, oft-times mixt with Serum or Choler; ≈øeldom with Phlegm or Melancholy. 2. External, as Smoak, Du≈øt, &c.

Signs vary according to the variety of Cau≈øes: If it proceed from too great a quantity of Blood, the Face looks red, and the Ve≈ø≈øels of the Eyes are extended: If either from more of Serum or Choler, the Redne≈øs of the Face is le≈øs, but the Tears are more ≈øharp, and the pain greater; if from more of Phlegm, the reddi≈øh pain, Heat and Acrimony of Tears are more remi≈øs; and the Eye-lids at night are as it were glewed together: If from any thing of Melancholy, there are but few Tears, and the Eye-lids are not clo≈øed together, the Inflammation is not great, but ≈øtubborn.
Progno≈øticks.] An Opthalmia is flower cured in Children, than in old people. Continual pain menaceth Blindne≈øs, by how much greater the Inflammation is, ≈øo much the more dangerous it is.

Cure.] The Diet mu≈øt be the ≈øame as in a Phlegmon; all ≈øharp things are carefully to be avoided; as Garlick, Radi≈øhes, Mu≈øtard, &c. little or no Suppers profit: Purging, the u≈øe of Gli≈øters, Bleeding ought to be oft-times re-iterated; as al≈øo Cupping-Gla≈ø≈øes, Leeches, Bli≈øters; ≈øometimes al≈øo Seatons, I≈ø≈øues, and Artereotomy it ≈øelf, which is not to be done by any but an expert Chirurgeon;
Sneezing is hurtful; Provoking of Sweat is ≈øometimes nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øometimes not; which the Phy≈øician mu≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh: Dieureticks are of great u≈øe, provided they are not too hot.
External Remedies vary according to the variety of Cau≈øes; if from Smoke or Fire, let them be extingui≈øhed.
If from Du≈øt, or any thing got into the Eyes, 'tis to be taken forth, which is often performed by blowing, or by the ≈øpurting in of Ro≈øe-water.
If from the inver≈øion of the Eye-lids; the Hairs are to be cut off, or wholly to be pull'd out.

If the Eye-lids are glew'd together, they are to be ≈øeparated, with Butter, Beer, or Cream, the Rheum is gently to be wiped; and let the Patient have a Care, le≈øt by the rubbing of his Eyes, he increa≈øeth his Di≈øea≈øe.
Fat things are here hurtful: Repellent Medicines, except in the very beginning, are not to be u≈øed, or in a very ≈ølight Opthalmia.

div.head: Medicines good for the Eyes.
div.p: Roots of Valerian, Solomons-Seal, Orri≈øe, Vervain, Herbs, Betony, Celandine the great, Eyebright, Fennel, Fumitory, Plantain: Flowers of Ro≈øes, Violets; Anni-≈øeeds, Quince-≈øeeds, Lin≈øeeds: Pippins, boil'd or rotten; Camphire; Mu≈ø≈øilage of Lin-≈øeeds, Tragacanth; Fre≈øh Veal; Whites of Eggs; all ≈øorts of Milk, e≈øpecially Womans; Tutty; white and green Vitriol; Saccharum Saturni; Gla≈øs of Antimony; White Troches of Rha≈øis; fre≈øh Chee≈øe not ≈øalted; Ung. Saturni.

div.head: A Water for the Eyes.
div.p:
Take Waters of Eyebright and Celandine the greater, of each an ounce and half; White-wine, ≈øix drams; Gla≈øs of Antimony, eight grains; prepared
Tutty, fifteen grains; White-Vitriol, two grains; Sugar-Candy two drams; Camphire, four grains: Make it into a Collirium.
Another excellent one.

Take Wheat, three handfuls; Brui≈øed Ginger, three drams; Common Salt, a handful and half; White-wine, Water of Ro≈øes, of Fennel, Plantain, of each ten ounces: Infu≈øe them in a Copper Ve≈ø≈øel the ≈øpace of forty days, ≈øtrain them, and re≈øerve the Liquor for your u≈øe.
Another very much e≈øteemed.

Take a whole Egg, boil it hard, then the ≈øhell and Yolk being taking away, put into the Cavity, Sugar of Saturn, ≈øix grains; Camphire, two grains; White-Vitriol, three Grains; Honey of Ro≈øes, half an ounce; then pre≈øs it very hard, and let the pre≈øt out Liquor be dropt into the Eyes twice or thrice a day.
Another, ≈øecond to none.
Take Waters of Fennel and Eyebright, of each a pint; Common Salt, ≈øix drams; prepared Tutty, white Vitriol, of each half an ounce: Let them boil a little, and re≈øerve for u≈øe.

Let not the great quantity of Vitriol afright any; it cau≈øeth only a ≈ølight pain, which ≈øuddenly vani≈øheth; but 'tis of ≈øo great virtue, that it cannot ≈øufficiently be extoll'd; but its u≈øe will prove it true.

div.head: A Powder for the Eyes.
div.p: Take Dulcified Vitriol, half a dram, prepar'd Tutty, fifteen grains; Sugar-candy, a ≈øcruple: Make it into a fine Powder.
Unctious Medicines ≈øeldom are applied to the Eyes, or el≈øe this Ointment is much commended.
Take Verdigrea≈øe, twelve grains; Camphire, Lapis Calaminaris, of each half an ounce; prepared Tutty, half a dram; fre≈øh-Butter wa≈øhed in Ro≈øe-water, two ounces: Make it into an Ointment.

div.head: An Anodine Catapla≈øm.
div.p: Take Camomile and Melilot Flowers, of each a pugil, rotten Apples, two ounces; Fenugreek-≈øeed, an ounce; Crums of Brown Bread, three ounces; two yolks of Eggs, Saffron, half a dram; Boil them in Cows-milk, to the con≈øi≈øtence of a Poultice.

div.head: An Anodine Collirium.
div.p: Take the Juice of Hou≈øleek, two drams; Whites of Eggs, half an ounce; Womens-Milk, two ounces; Ro≈øe-water, an ounce; white Troches of Rha≈øis, one ≈øcruple; Opium, three grains: Mix them.
Another, which I have often found excellent in the greate≈øt pain.

Take Gum Tragacanth, two drams; Mu≈ø≈øilage of the ≈øeeds of Fleawort, three drams; Ro≈øe-water, and Plantain-water, of each as much as ≈øufficeth: Make it into a Collyrium of an indifferent Con≈øi≈øtence; and let it be in≈øtilled by drops into the Eyes, and Linnen-Cloaths wet in it, outwardly applied.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of a Quin≈øie.
div.p: A Quin≈øie is a Tumor of the Jaws, from Blood, hindring Deglutition and Re≈øpiration.

Difference.] 'Tis divided into three ≈øpecies; the fir≈øt is called Cynanthe, when the Mu≈øcles of the Larinx are inflamed: the Symptoms here are very dangerous, although neither internally nor externally appear any Tumor; the Patient puts forth his Tongue like a tired Dog, to fetch his breath. Second is Synanche, when the Tumor ≈øhews it ≈øelf within the Jaws; the Symptoms are likewi≈øe here great, but much le≈øs than in Cynanthe. Third is, Para≈øynanche, when the Tumor appears more Externally than Internally; and in this the Symptomes are lea≈øt of all.
Cau≈øe is Blood, for the mo≈øt part mixt with Serum or Choler; ≈øeldom with Phlegm or Melancholy.
Signs of an approaching Quin≈øie, are, a ≈øtiffne≈øs of the Neck, ≈øwallowing and breathing ≈øomewhat hindred, an unu≈øual heat and pain in the Jaws, e≈øpecially when Quin≈øies are Epidemick.

Signs of a pre≈øent are, a ≈øuffocating A≈øthma: ≈øwallowing hindred, which often increa≈øeth to ≈øo great a heighth, that Drink taken in at the Mouth, comes forth again through the No≈øtrils, Pain, Redne≈øs, Tumor for the mo≈øt part, al≈øo a continual Fever; the Tongue likewi≈øe ≈øwell'd, and the Voice altered.

Progno≈øtick.] A perfect Quin≈øie never wants danger, but ≈øometimes ≈øuffocates the Patient the fir≈øt day, generally before the fourth: If the Matter be not ≈øuddenly concocted and thrown forth, it is de≈øperate; if the Vertebraes be laxated, death is near at hand; foaming at mouth is a ≈øign of pre≈øent death; if the Patient be taken with a pain of the Head, a Delirium, raving and death it ≈øelf ≈øuddenly follows.

Cure.] Bleeding in this ca≈øe effects much, both by taking away of the Inflammation, and by hindering its increa≈øe, which is to be performed at fir≈øt ≈øight therefore let the Median or Cephalick Vein of the ≈øide mo≈øt affected be opened, though in Women with Child, then the Vein under the Tongue: Cupping Gla≈ø≈øes with Scarification may al≈øo be applied to the Neck about the ≈øecond Verrebra, Shoulders and Brea≈øt; Leeches, Cauteries, and Bli≈øters do much good, e≈øpecially in them that are Subject to Quin≈øie: In the mean time, if the Patient can ≈øwallow, let ≈øome purging Medicines be given him; if not, let a Cli≈øter be ca≈øt in, with Bleeding, which mu≈øt be often reiterated as occa≈øion requires.

Gargari≈øms then, and other External Medicines are to be u≈øed; which in the beginning are to be more Repelling, afterwards more Di≈øcu≈ø≈øing; for Experience and be≈øt Authors have taught, 1. Repellents never are to be u≈øed alone, except in the beginning, and in a light Quin≈øie. 2. That Repellents ought always to be mixt with Re≈øolvents; for Repellents de≈øtroy the heat of the Part; Re≈øolvents cau≈øe Fluxion.

div.head: Medicines in a Quin≈øie.
div.p: Roots of Mar≈øh-mallows, Liquoras; Herbs, Comfrey, Myrtle, Prunella, Dandelion, Scabious, Plantain, Hou≈øleek the greater, Sage, Alehoof, Violets, Flowers of Balau≈øtians, Red Ro≈øes, Saffron; the four cold Seeds, Poppy the Rinds and Juice of Pomegranates; Figs, Album Graecum, Burnt-Swallows, Burnt-Allom, Swallows Ne≈øts, Syrups of Maidenhair, Violets, Pur≈ølane, Jujubies, Scabious, Lungwort, Honey of Ro≈øes, Rob. Diamori.

div.p: Take Flowers of Red-Ro≈øes, Balau≈øtians, of each two pugils; Pomegranate-Rinds, half an ounce; Oak-leaves, a handful; Burnt-Allom, half a dram: Boil them in Smith's Water, and add to a pint of the Liquor, two ounces of Rob. Diamori: Mix them.
Another very convenient in the beginning of the Di≈øea≈øe.

Take leaves of Dandelion, two handfuls; Alehoof, Violets, of each half an handful; boil them in Barley-water, and to a point of the ≈øtrained Liquor, add of common Honey of Ro≈øes, and ≈øtrained, of each an ounce and half; Spirit of Vitriol, 15 drops: Mix them.

div.head: A Repellent, and ≈øomewhat Di≈øcu≈ø≈øive Gargari≈øm.
div.p:
Take Liquoras, Pomegranate-Rinds, of each
two drams; Balau≈øtia Flowers, a pugil; Jujubies, No. xij. Figs, No. iij. Rai≈øins, ≈øix drams; boil them in Barley-water. To a pint of the Decoction, add of common and ≈øtrained Honey of Ro≈øes, Syrup of Maiden-hair, of each an ounce: Mix them.

div.p: Take the Roots of Dwarf Elder, Orri≈øe, of each two drams, Flowers of Camomil, a pugil; Red-Ro≈øes, Hy≈øop, of each two pugils, Dates, No. iij. Figs, No. vj. Fenugreek-≈øeeds, two drams; Album Graecum, one dram: Boil them in Turnep-Broth. Add to it Syrup of Maiden-hair, and Jujubies, of each an ounce: Mix them.

div.p: Oyl of Nuts, White-Lillies, Almonds, Camomile, Dill, Capons-grea≈øe, Hoggs-grea≈øe, Ointment of Mar≈øh-mallows, Plai≈øter of Mu≈øilages, Dogs and Pigeons-Dung, Swallows-Ne≈øts.

Take Roots of Mar≈øh-Mallows, White-Lillies, of each an ounce; one Swallows Ne≈øt, Figs, Dates, of each No. iij. Take Juice of Onions, two ounces; Oyl of white-Lillies, Ori≈øe, of each an ounce and half; boil them a little, adding to them of Swallows-Ne≈øt, a dram; Pitch and Wax, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Plai≈øter.

Lin-≈øeed and Fenugreek, of each two drams; Leaves of Mallows and Coleworts, of each half a handful; boil them in Barley-water, and to a pint of the ≈øtrained Liquor, add of Syrup of Maiden-hair, two ounces: Mix them.

a ≈øcruple; Oximel ≈øimple, an ounce: Mix them.
But if it doth not forthwith break by the≈øe Medicines, 'tis to be opened by a Launcet, or ≈øome other In≈øtrument; afterwards u≈øing Emollient Gargari≈ømes, and ≈øomewhat ab≈øter≈øive.

div.head: BARBETTY'S CHIRURGERY. The Second Book of the Second Part Of CHIRURGERY. Of Wounds.
CHAP. I. Of the Nature, Differences, Cau≈øes, and Signs of Wounds.
div.p: A Wound is a Solution of continuity in the ≈øoft parts of the Body, from a hard In≈øtrument, cau≈øing an Abolition or Immination of Action.

Differences are taken, 1. From the Form; ≈øome are long, others oblique; ≈øome are little, others great, ≈øome are deep, others ≈øuperficial. 2. From the wounded Part, as, the Head, Lungs, Heart, Stomach, Liver, Spleen, Guts, Nerve, Tendon, Vein or Mu≈øcle; ≈øometimes the Skin is only penetrated, then 'tis a ≈øimple Wound; ≈øometimes a Part of the Fle≈øh is taken away,
and then 'tis call'd a compound or hollow Wound. 3. From the Cau≈øes, which ≈øhall pre≈øently be ≈øet down; ≈øometimes a wound happens to be poi≈øoned, and to have many Symptoms joined with it.

Cau≈øes are five-fold, viz. 1. All things that cut, as a Knife, Sword, Gla≈øs, 2. Al things that prick; as Needles, Arrows, Teeth. 3. Which perforate; as hot Iron, Bullets. 4. Which break; as a Fall, Stroke, or the carrying or lifting of any great Burdens. 5. All things which contu≈øe; as a Stone, Stick, &c.

Signs.] External Wounds are of them≈øelves manife≈øt enough; but tho≈øe of the Internal parts, are not always ≈øo ea≈øily judged of; the≈øe therefore are to be known by Anatomy; 1. What is the ≈øituation of each part. 2. What the u≈øe. 3. The Symptoms are to be con≈øidered. 4. The Quality of tho≈øe things are to be noted, that Nature ejected through the Wound: The other Signs you ≈øhall have in their proper places.

Progno≈øticks. [To know the Events of Wounds, e≈øpecially to predict which are Mortal, which not, is a thing ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary for a Surgeon: For from this judgment oft-times depends the Life of unfortunate Man.

p.hi: A mortal Wound is that, which in the ≈øpace of few hours or days, of nece≈ø≈øity cau≈øes Death, and cannot by any Art be cured.

div.p:
For tho≈øe that in them≈øelves are curable, yet by rea≈øon of ill Symptoms, or through the neglect either of the Patient or Chirurgeon, do occa≈øion Death, ought not to be accounted mortal Wounds: Incurable Wounds them≈øelves are not to be call'd Mortal, if they are not the cau≈øe of Death
≈øuddenly to the Patient; but that he not only lives many weeks, but oftentimes many years after.

1. Among the Wounds that are Mortal, are to be accounted the Wounds of the Brain, but not all of them; for Experience hath taught us, that part of the Brain hath been taken forth, and the Life pre≈øerved, though the Under≈øtanding lo≈øt.

Therefore tho≈øe Wounds of the Brain that be ab≈øolutely mortal, are, 1. When be≈øides the Brains, a Nerve is al≈øo wounded. 2. When Blood, or ≈øome other Humor ob≈øtructs the beginning of the Nerves: 3. When after a few days the concrete and putrified Blood produceth a Fever, Delirium, and Death it ≈øelf.

By concreted Blood, I under≈øtand not that which lies between the Dura-Mater and the Skull; for that is to be taken forth by the Trepan, and the Patient this way may be pre≈øerved; but that which is included between the Dura and Pia-Mater, or between the Pia and the Brain: Although ≈øometimes, that which is detained between both Membranes, by the dividing of the Dura, may be taken forth, and ≈øo the Patient pre≈øerved.
2. The Wounds of the Spinal Marrow are al≈øo mortal, which happens in the Neck, or nearer to the Head; but tho≈øe which happen lower, as about the Os Sacrum, are of le≈ø≈øer danger.

3. The Wounds of the Lungs are mortal, if great and deep, where the great Ve≈ø≈øels, or the Branches of the A≈øpera Arteria are hurt: Where the Ve≈ø≈øels are divided, there follows a great effu≈øion of Blood; where the Branches of the A≈øpera Arteria, the Breath comes forth more through the Wound than the Mouth.

4. Wounds of the heart are always mortal;
for though one or two wounded in the heart, have lived, two, three, or four days, it was never found yet, that ever any e≈øcaped.

5. The Wound of the Wind-pipe may be cured, if the Membranes only behind, to which the Cartilaginous Rings are join'd, be hurt; but if the Rings them≈øelves are wounded, there's no cure to be expected; yet ≈øometimes tho≈øe wounds being a lingering Death; ≈øo that I have ≈øeen on ≈øo wounded, live Eighteen weeks before he died.

6. Wounds of the Diaphragma, tho≈øe that are inflicted in the fle≈øhy Part of it, are curable; but tho≈øe that are in the Nervous Part, though the≈øe always occa≈øion not ≈øudden Death, yet 'tis impo≈ø≈øible ever to cure them.
7. Wounds of the Stomach are ≈øometimes cured; tho≈øe chiefly being mortal, that happen in the upper Orifice, or in Nerves that are di≈øtributed over the Stomach.
8. The Wounds of the Small Guts are ≈øeldom cured, but the Wounds of the Great Guts much oftner, e≈øpecially if they are not great.
9. Wounds of the Liver and Spleen are mortal, where the Ve≈ø≈øels them≈øelves are wounded; where not, they may be cured.

10. Wounds of the Kidneys are not mortal; if the Wound penetrate into the Cavity it ≈øelf, for the mo≈øt part an Ulcer follows, which con≈øumes the whole Kidney, yet the Patient may continue many years: If the Parachyma, only be wounded, ≈øometimes, through difficulty, it may be cured.
11. Wounds of the Bladder are ≈øeldom ≈øo perfectly cured, but that for the mo≈øt part there remains a Fi≈øtula; but tho≈øe that are made at the neck of the bladder, are daily cured.

12. Wounds of the great Veins and Arteries are often mortal; but every Surgeon under≈øtands not rightly to bind up ≈øuch Wounds; therefore the cau≈øe of death is not always to be ca≈øt upon the guilty.
13. Wounds of the great Nerves are for the mo≈øt part incurable, and ≈øometimes mortal.
14. Wounds from poi≈øoned In≈øtruments or Creatures, generally are mortal.
Wounds of Nerves, Veins, Tendons and Membranes, are more difficultly, and longer of Cure, than tho≈øe of the fle≈øhy parts.
A Wound from a pricking In≈øtrument, is of le≈øs danger, than from a brui≈øing.
A Nerve, Vein or Artery, if wholly divided, are le≈øs dangerous, than if they were but in part.
A great Inflamation coming upon a great Wound, is of no great danger, except it continue too long; but a great Inflamation falling upon a little Wound, is an ill ≈øign.
The Inflamation for the mo≈øt part vani≈øheth by the fifth day; therefore if the Wound then appear white, livid or black, 'tis not void of danger.
A Fever, Vomiting and Convul≈øion, are dangerous; but a Fever and Vomiting of le≈øs danger than a Convul≈øion.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Cure of Wounds in general.
div.p: HEre are required four Intentions: 1. To pre≈øerve the ≈øtrength and native heat of the wounded Part. 2. To remove the Symptoms. 3. To endeavour that nothing remains, or be left behind in the Wound. 4. That the gaping Lips of the Wound be joined together; and being ≈øo joined, be kept‚ñ™

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the pre≈øervation of the ≈øtrength and Native heat in the wounded Part.
div.p: CHirurgery removes the impediments of Cure, but Nature her ≈øelf cures the Di≈øea≈øe; which it will ≈øcarce effect, where the Native heat is weak, or the Blood vitiated; or where it flows in too great or too little quantity to the Wound: in flowing in too great quantity, it produceth an Inflammation, Pain, Putrefaction, and many other Symptoms; where in too little quantity, the Wound is robbed of its Natural Bal≈øam, nece≈ø≈øary to con≈øolidate it.

The natural ≈øtrength and native heat is pre≈øerved by a convenient Diet, fitted to the temperament of Mans body in general, and in particular, to the Part affected. Of the Diet of the Sanguine,
Cholerick, Phlegmatick and Melancholick, we have treated of before, when we ≈øpoke concerning a Phlegmon, Ery≈øipelas, Oedema, Schirrhus.

Then Care is to be had of the Blood, ≈øeeing it affords a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to the matter, and ≈øerves to unite the Wound. Where it is vitiated, it requires purging: But if it flow in too great quantity, Intercipients, Repellents, Revellents and Derivation mu≈øt be us'd.
If it flow in too ≈ømall quantity, Aliments that nouri≈øh, are convenient, as al≈øo Medicines that ≈øtrengthen, and that move Sweat: Outwardly, gentle Frictions and Embrocations moderately hot.
Then the Cure is to be perfected by External Medicines; which ≈øhall be declared in the following Chapter, when we ≈øpeak of the removal of the Symptoms, and the Cure of Wounds them≈øelves.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Symptoms of Wounds.
div.p:
THe chief Symptoms of Wounds are, 1. A Fever who≈øe Cure we commend to the Phy≈øitian' 2. A Flegmon or Inflamation. 3. An Ery≈øipelas. Of the Cure of both which, look in the ≈øecond and third Chapter of the fir≈øt Book. 4. Hemorage, which not only impedes the Cure, but al≈øo deprives of ≈øtrength and life it ≈øelf; therefore great Care is to be taken that it be ≈øtopped as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, which in the greater Ve≈ø≈øels, e≈øpecially the Arteries, is very hard to do; therefore tho≈øe Wounds are for the mo≈øt part Mortal: For Medicines that ≈øtop Blood are too weak, and hard
Ligatures occa≈øion a Gangrene; the ≈øure≈øt way therefore in my opinion, is an actual Cautery; the le≈ø≈øer Ve≈ø≈øels may and will clo≈øe, Some clo≈øe the Wound of the Ve≈ø≈øels with their Fingers, and ≈øo hold them there while the Blood is coagulated, and the Flux ≈øtopt; but this Operation ≈øeldom ≈øucceeds; be≈øides the long holding of the Finger in the Wound is hurtful.

Therefore let the Wound together with the Ve≈ø≈øels be forthwith clos'd by the Fingers, but if you cannot come to do this, outwardly make a compre≈øs upon the Ve≈ø≈øel; which done, wipe away the Blood with a Spunge, then ≈øprinkle ≈øome re≈øtringent Powder; but not over the whole Wound (which is u≈øed to be done by the ignorant) but only upon the Ve≈ø≈øels; then bind up the Wound, continuing the u≈øe of the Medicines ≈øtopping Bleeding, while there appears no longer any Blood; not neglecting in the mean time, Generals, viz. Scarification and Bleeding, &c.

div.head: Medicines that ≈øtop a Flux of Blood.
div.p: Roots of Bi≈øtort, Cinquefoil, Tormentil, Comfrey the greater, Red Saunders, Lignum Leuti≈øci, Pomegranate-rinds, Ma≈øtick, Talk, Acacia, Dragons-Blood, Amber, Sarcocols, Frankincen≈øe; the hairs of a Hare, Os ≈øepiae, burnt-Crabs; Whites of Eggs, Mummy, Cobwebs, red, Coral Chalk, Blood≈øtone, Bole-Armenick, Aloes ≈øuccotrine, Frogs dried and powdered, crude Vitriol, burnt Vitriol.

Take fine Meal, three ounces; Dragons-Blood, Frankincen≈øe, of each an ounce and half; Bole, Sealed Earth, of each two drams, Talk, ≈øix
drams; dried Frogs, an ounce; Hares hair cut very ≈ømall, a dram and a half; Whites of Eggs dried in the Sun, and powdered half an ounce; New Spunges torrified, an ounce; white Vitriol, a dram: Mix them, and make them into a fine Powder.

5. Pain; which mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity be ea≈øed, becau≈øe it creates watchings, and dejects the Spirits, and is cau≈øe of the Flux of Humors to the Party affected; and of Inflamation, Fever and Gangrene; but the Cau≈øes are diligently to be con≈øidered: For if either Medicines that are ≈øharp, or too hot, occa≈øion it, they are pre≈øently to be altered: 'Tis better to confe≈øs the Error, than pertinaciou≈øly to per≈øevere in it.
If any foreign Body remains in the Wound, it mu≈øt be drawn forth.
If pain comes from the choaking in of the Matter, you mu≈øt allow it a free pa≈ø≈øage.

If an Inflamation be the cau≈øe of it, its Remedies are ≈øet down in the ≈øecond Chapter of the fir≈øt Book: You mu≈øt apply to the Wound tho≈øe things which ea≈øe pain, and are anodine; as Oyl of Ro≈øes, Lin≈øeed, Camomile, Worms, ≈øweet Almonds, Poppies, &c.
Take Oyl of Ro≈øes, of Poppy-≈øeeds, of Camomile, of each an ounce; the White of an Egg, Saffron, a ≈øcruple; Mix them.
But if the pain cea≈øe not with the≈øe or the like Medicines, it is a ≈øign that ≈øome Nerve is wounded, or affected by con≈øent: The Cure ≈øhall be ≈øet down in the following.

6. Convul≈øion or Spa≈øm; this ≈øhews the Malignity of the Humor, or the ill con≈øtitution of the Nerves, neither of them promi≈øing any good:
Here mu≈øt be u≈øed both Internal and External Medicines, appropriated to the Di≈øea≈øe; the Internal, by rea≈øon of the diver≈øity of cau≈øes, we commend to the Phy≈øitian.

div.head: External Medicines for a Convul≈øion.
div.p: Bal≈øam of Peru, the fat of Gee≈øe, Ca≈øtor, Foxes, Rams, Mans: Hor≈øe-dung, Oyls of Juniper, Lavender, Ol. Philo≈øophorum, Amber, Turpentine, Rue, Marjoram, Worms, Ca≈øtor, Ori≈øe, Bays, Petraeleum; Ointments of Agrippa, Martiatum, Ung. Nervorum, Spirit of Wine.

Take Oyl of Snails, Worms, Se≈øamin, of each an ounce; of the Grea≈øe of Rams and Foxes, of each half an ounce; fre≈øh Butter, ≈øix drams; Spirit of Wine, three ounces: Let them boil till the Spirit be con≈øumed; then add Oyl of Spike di≈øtilled, Ro≈øemary, Amber, of each two drams: Mix it into an Ointment.
Again≈øt a Convul≈øion there cannot a better Remedy be invented than di≈øtill'd Oyl of Lavender, ≈øome few drops being given in ≈øome convenient Liquor; and anointing well the convul≈øed part.

7. Hyper≈øarco≈øis, or too great increa≈øe of fle≈øh; which if it happens from abundance of Blood, the fle≈øh is ≈øolid, and otherwi≈øe well conditioned; but if from the too weak quality of drying Medicines, it is ≈øpungy; of the ≈øame nature, as when the Bone underneath is rotten. In the former Ca≈øe, Bleeding is convenient, and ≈øometimes fa≈øting, and the u≈øe of ≈øtrong drying Medicines: In the latter, the Medicines mu≈øt be very ≈øtrongly drying that are applied: Deter≈øive and Corroding Remedies are here good.

div.head: Medicines again≈øt too great increa≈øe of Fle≈øh.
div.p: Burnt-Spunges, Burnt-Allom, Galls, Aloes, the Bark of Frankincen≈øe, Tutty, Verdigrea≈øe, burnt Vitriol, Praecipitate, Ar≈øenick.

div.head: A Green Corro≈øive Water,
div.p: Take crude Allom, Verdigrea≈øe of each two drams; boil them in eighteen ounces of white-Wine, to a wa≈øting of the fourth part; ≈øtrain them, and add Camphire, a dram: Mix them.

div.head: A Powder very drying, and ≈øomewhat corroding.
div.p: Take Galls, Balau≈øtions, burnt-Allom, Frankincen≈øe, Myrrhe, of each a dram; Dragons-Blood, Ceru≈øe, Verdigrea≈øe, of each half a dram: Make it into a Powder.
8. A Gangrene and Sphacelus, concerning which, look in the fourteenth Chapter of the fir≈øt Book of the ≈øecond Part of Chirurgery.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the drawing forth Extraneous Bodies out of the Wound.
div.p:
NO Wound ought to be joined together, as long as any Extraneous Body remains in it; for otherwi≈øe, after ≈øome little time, it will break out into an Ulcer: The Blood, by which Nature unites the divided Parts, if it flow in great quantity
to the wounded Part, and there coagulates, 'tis to be removed by Expre≈ø≈øion, ≈øucking it out, or by any other way; for ≈øo there will be le≈øs Matter generated, and the Symptoms fewer; but where an Haemorage is feared, all the Blood is not to be clean≈øed away.
Where Hairs are about the Wound, they are to be removed.
If Sand; or any ≈øuch like thing remain within the Lips of the Wound, they are to be wa≈øhed away with warm Wine.

Broken-Bones, if loo≈øe, are to be taken away the fir≈øt dre≈ø≈øing, except an Haemorage hinder; but if they yet ≈øtick to the other Bones, then Natures endeavours are to be expected, and ≈øee whether they will be united again to the other Bone, or ≈øeparated from it.

If a piece of Gla≈øs, Thorn, Arrow or Bullet, or any like thing remains in the Wound, 'tis forthwith to be taken forth; but before the Chirurgeon goes about to draw them forth, let him con≈øider well, whether the Patient, that Extraneous Body being extracted, can live or not; le≈øt the Chirurgeon be thought to have occa≈øioned the Patients death.

Of the manner of Extracting Bullets, we have treated before; and Arrows are to be drawn forth almo≈øt after the ≈øame manner; but they are not in u≈øe at this day among Chri≈øtian Soldiers: But if neither with the Hand nor In≈øtruments, what remains in the wound can be drawn forth, then you mu≈øt endeavour it with Medicines indeed with an extractive quality.

div.head: Medicines drawing forth Thorns, Bones, Bullets, &c.
div.p: Roots of Aron, Birthwort, Ba≈øtard Dittany, Ma≈øterwort, Polypody, Radi≈øhes, Valerian: Herbs, Southernwood, Pimpernel, Anemone, Red-Beet, Ditany: Gums, Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Sagapenum, Succinum, Pitch, the Brains and Grea≈øe of Hares, Crabs, a live Mou≈øe cut in two, Common Flies, Earth-worms, Burnt Frogs, Goo≈øe-dung, Load-≈øtone, Leaven, Plai≈øter of Opodeldoch.

Take Roots of round Birthwort, Ditany of Crete, of each a dram and an half; Ro≈øin of the Pine, Colophony, of each ≈øix drams; yellow Amber, three drams; Gum Ammoniacum, Appoponax, of each an ounce; Pigeons dung, three drams; Oyl of Bays, half an ounce; Turpentine and Pitch, as much as to make it into a Plai≈øter.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the manner of joining the Lips of Wounds together.
div.p:
THe Lips of the Wound are joined together, either by Ligature or Stitching. Ligature is convenient in Wounds made according to the length of the Member, and not deep; let the Bandage be neither too hard, nor too loo≈øe, and of that breadth that it may take in the whole
Wound. If it be a long Wound, the Rowler mu≈øt be three Fingers broad, and laying the mid≈øt of it upon the Wound, rowl one part upward, and the other downward; which mu≈øt neither be too loo≈øe, for then it will not keep the Lips of the Wound together; nor too ≈øtraight, le≈øt it cau≈øe an Inflamation: In the Winter the Rowlers mu≈øt be of greater length than in the Summer: In great Wounds, be≈øides Rowlers, the Surgeon ≈øtands in need of Boul≈øters.

Stitching is performed either by Needle or ≈øticking Medicines. It is requi≈øite that the Chirurgeon never be without a Needle; for by it he frees his Patient from Pain, the Wound from Inflamation, and him≈øelf from many inconveniences; and the Wound ≈øo requiring it, let him take a three-pointed Needle, with a waxed Thred, which let him pa≈øs through the Skin, and ≈øometimes al≈øo through the ≈øubjacent Fle≈øh, taking Care that the Tendons be not prickt; and al≈øo that the Stitches be not too few nor too many; but keeping ≈øuch di≈øtance between each, that the Skin may be drawn together, and the edges them≈øelves joyned, leaving a little part for the putting in of a Tent, that may give pa≈ø≈øage to the ≈øuperfluous Matter: The≈øe Tents are not nece≈ø≈øary in little Wounds; and in great, they mu≈øt neither touch the Nerve or Tendon, nor reach to the bottom of the Wound.

Where Ligature is not ≈øufficient, and a Stitch with a Needle not convenient, the ≈øticking Plai≈øter is very nece≈ø≈øary; for ≈øo firmly doth this Plai≈øter adhere to the Wound, that neither the matter flowing out of the Wound, nor the Blood, nor any other moi≈øture loo≈øens it. Oftentimes in this
ca≈øe is u≈øed, the Stiptick Plai≈øter of Crollius, or Paracel≈øus, but this ≈øticks more firmly.
Take Sarcocols, Bole, Ma≈øtick, Dragons-blood, Ro≈øin of the Pine, of each a dram; Gum-Tacamahack, a dram and an half; Naval-pitch, as much as ≈øufficeth: Make it into a Plai≈øter.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Medicines nece≈ø≈øary for the Curing of Wounds.
div.p: MEdicines nece≈ø≈øary for the Cure of Wounds, are of three ≈øorts: 1. Dige≈øtives, or moving matter. 2. Sarcoticks, or generating Fle≈øh. 3. Epuloticks, or inducing a Cicatrice.

Experience hath taught, that a Wound may be cured oftentimes only by Dige≈øtive or Sarcotick Medicines; but this is better, and more certain, when they are both mixt together: In the Fle≈øhy Parts, Dige≈øtives may alone ≈øerve; but in Tendinous, Nervous, Membranous, or other drier Parts, Sarcoticks are convenient, either alone, or mixt with Dige≈øtives.

div.head: Dige≈øtives.
