half an ounce; Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, of each a dram; the yolk of an Egg, fre≈øh Butter, as much as is ≈øufficient: Make it into an Ointment.

div.head: Sarcoticks.
div.p: Roots of Birthwort, Orri≈øe, Sanicle, Comfrey the greater; Herbs, Betony, Centaury, Comfrey, St. John's-wort, Pimpernel, Plantain, Scabious, Scordium, Vervain; of Seeds, Beans, Fenugreek, Lin≈øeed, Barley; Frankincen≈øe, Aloes, Bole, ≈øealed Earth, Colophony; Gums of Elemny, Pine, Laudanum, Ma≈øtick, Myrrhe, Dragons-Blood, Sarcocols, Turpentine, Tragacanth; Wax, Honey, Mummy, Cadmia, Ceru≈øe, Lapis Calaminaris, Litharge, Burnt-Lead, Phomholix, Lapis Haematitis; Oyls of St. John's wort, Bays, Ma≈øtick, Myrrhe; Ointment, Aureum, Ba≈øilicum, Fu≈øcum, of Felix Wurtz, Diapompholigos; Plai≈øters, Stipticum of Crollius and Paracel≈øus, Oppodeldoch, of Betony, Dia≈øulphuris of Rulandus; Bal≈øoms, of Peru, of Crollius, of Magatus, Aqua vitae; the fat of Gee≈øe, Foxes, Bears, Goats, Mans.

div.head: An Excellent Vulnerary Bal≈øom.
div.p: Take Turpentine, half a pound; Gum Galbanum, Elemny, Ivy, Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, Myrrhe, of each an ounce; Aloes, Xylo aloes, Galangal, Cloves, Cinamon, Nutmegs, Cubebs, of each half an ounce: Infu≈øe them four and twenty hours in a ≈øufficient quantity of Spirit of Wine; di≈øtil them and pre≈øerve the Oyl for your u≈øe.

div.p: Roots of Comfry, Tormentil; Herbs, St. Johns-wort, Plantain, Sanicle, Fluellin, Betony; Flowers of Balau≈øtians, Red Ro≈øes; Saunders, Aloes, Myrrhe, Ma≈øtick, Sarcocols, Lapis Calaminaris, Red Lead, Lead, Litharge, Tutty; Ointments of Diapompholigos, Album Camphoratum; Plai≈øters, Gry≈øeum de plumbo, Op ‚Ä¢ deldoch de Minio, Barbarum.

Take Oyl of Ro≈øes, of unripe Olives, of each three ounces; of Myrtles, Ointment of Poplars, of each an ounce and half; Leaves of Plantain and Night-≈øhade, of each an handful; let them ≈øteep together eight days: afterwards add to the ≈øtrain'd Liquor, Wax, two ounces; mingle them over the fire, adding Litharge of Gold, three ounces; Ceru≈øe, an ounce; Tutty, a dram; Burnt Lead, three drams; Burnt Bra≈øs, a dram and an half; Camphire, a dram; let them be rubb'd in a Leaden Mortar into the form of an Ointment.
Take Roots of Tormentil, Bi≈øtort, round Birth-wort, burnt Egg-≈øhels, Frankincen≈øe, Dragons-blood, of each half an ounce; Lapis Calaminaris, a dram; Litharge, two drams: Make it into a Powder.
Take Ung. Pompholigos, Diapalmae Gri≈øei, of each an ounce; Gum Elemny, two drams; Saccharum Saturni, half a dram; Wax, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Plai≈øter.
I never knew any better Medicine, if applied in a fitting time, to bring to a Cicatrice, than an Amalgama of Mercury, of which, this is the de≈øcription.
Take two ounces of Lead, melt it, then add to it two ounces of Quick ≈øilver, pour it upon Paper dried and powdered; it may be mixt with the Plai≈øter of Lead or Diapompholigos.
To the≈øe External Remedies, we join al≈øo Internal Medicines, which have been ob≈øerved to profit much at all times in the Cure of Wounds.

div.head: Vulneraries.
div.p: Wintergreen, Sanicle, Ladies-Mantle, Comfry, Mugwort, Saxifrage, Tormentil, Agrimony, Milfoil, Hor≈øe-tail, Hounds-tongue, Betony, Periwincle, Mou≈øe Ear, Golden rod, Birthwort, Bi≈øtort, Dictany, Centory the le≈øs, Gentain.

div.p: Take Roots of Comfrey the greater, half an ounce; of Wintergreen, two handfuls; of Sanicle, two pugils; Straw-berries, Ladies-Mantle, Sage, of each an handful; boil them in red Wine, and to a pint and half of the ≈øtrained Liquor, add of the white≈øt Sugar, as much as is ≈øufficient; Do≈øe, three ounces.
Another very effectual, even when the Bone is hurt.

Do≈øe, two ounces.

A Sympathetick Ointment.
Take Mo≈øs, two ounces; Mummy, half an ounce; Mans fat, two ounces; Mans-blood, half an ounce; Oyl of Lin≈øeed, two drams; Oyl of Ro≈øes, Bole, of each an ounce: Mix it, and make an Ointment.

Some u≈øe only Vitriol calcin'd in the Sun; but who≈øoever ≈øhall u≈øe them without Super≈øtition, ≈øhall find many things attributed to Medicines, that are due to Nature; therefore 'tis ≈øafe≈øt to proceed in the beaten way.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of Wounds of the Nerves.
div.p: IN Treating of the Wounds of the Nerves, we al≈øo comprehend tho≈øe of the Tendons; becau≈øe there is ≈øcarce any difference in the Cure it ≈øelf.
'Tis to be di≈øtingui≈øhed here, where the Nerve or Tendon be divided, or only prick'd.

This Wound is known, 1. By con≈øidering the wounded place, and by Anatomy, which teacheth in what Members the Nerves are in≈øerted; but the Tendons ≈øeeing they terminate near the Joynts, the Hands and Feet having many; if a Wound ≈øhould be inflicted in the≈øe parts, who would not fear them to be ≈øo hurt, e≈øpecially if it be with a tran≈øver≈øe
wound. 2. From the great Pain, which cau≈øes Pul≈øation, Inflamation, Convul≈øion and Delirium, &c. except the Nerves be wholly tran≈øver≈øly divided, and then the Symptoms are altogether not ≈øo grievous.

Progno≈øticks.] All the wounds of the Nerves are dangerous; a Puncture more dangerous than an Inci≈øion: Wounds of Tendons are le≈øs dangerous than Nerves. Convul≈øion is an ill ≈øign; Nerves and Tendons wounded, do ea≈øily putrifie.

Cure.] In all Wounds of Nerves or Tendons, ≈øeeing pain greatly mole≈øts, occa≈øioning many Symptoms, care is to be taken that it be alleviated as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible. Outward cold things do here hugely injure, not only the Air, but Medicines them≈øelves: For Experience hath taught us, that cold, moi≈øt and a≈øtringent Medicines do nought but hurt; therefore 'tis be≈øt to u≈øe Medicines moderately hot and drying, but void of any ≈øharpne≈øs. The Wound al≈øo is to be kept open, till the Cure be ab≈øolutely performed, that the Matter may flow freely forth; which if kept in, may increa≈øe the pain, and cau≈øe the putrefaction of the Nerve; which, if it ≈øhould happen, the corrupt Part is to be cut off, or removed by an actual Cautery.

Moreover it is to be ob≈øerved, whether the Nerve or Tendon lies bare or not; if bare, warm Medicines are convenient; but if covered, hotter Medicines are required; in the mean time, Purging and Bleeding are not to be neglected.

div.head: External Medicines in Wounds of the Nerves and Tendons.
div.p:
Old Oyl of Olives, of Earth-worms, of Dill,
Rue, Ro≈øemary, Co≈øtmary, white-Lillies, St. John's wort, Ca≈øtore, of Turpentine, Wax, Lavender, Bal≈øom of Peru; Gums, Elemi, Tacamahac, Caranna, Opobal≈øamum, Capayvae, Spirit of Wine.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Wounds by Gun-≈øhot.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Poy≈øoned Wounds.
div.p:
POy≈øoned Wounds are made ≈øometimes by Bullets, Arrows, Swords and other In≈øtruments;

Progno≈øticks.] A poy≈øoned Wound, though little, may bring death, e≈øpecially if near to the Heart, or any other Noble Part; or the Chirurgeon not call'd ≈øoon enough.

That corroborates the Part, extracts the Venom, produceth Matter, and incarns the Wound.

Take Gums, Galbanum, Sagapenum, Opoponax, A≈ø≈øa Foetida, Mirtle, Pepper, Brim≈øtone, of

div.p: IN Wounds of the Head, where the Pericranium is hurt, a ≈øtitch either by Needle or Plai≈øter, is not convenient; fat things hurt, but comforting and drying profit much.

p.hi: AN Ulcer is a Solution of continuity with Diminution of Magnitude in the ≈øoft Parts, from a Corroding Matter.

div.p: Differences are taken, .1. From the Form of the Ulcer; ≈øo 'tis great, little; long, ≈øhort; broad, narrow; right, tran≈øver≈øe; equal, unequal; deep, ≈øuperficial. 2. From the Part affected; which ≈øometimes is the Skin and Fle≈øh only, ≈øometimes the Tendons; Nerves and Ve≈ø≈øels that carry the Blood. 3. From the Cau≈øes; which ≈øhall be pre≈øently ≈øpoken of. 4. Cau≈øe is a ≈øharp and corro≈øive Humor, and that is twofold. 1. Internal, as Choler, Melancholy, Serum, Salt, Phlegm, and other Malignant Humors. 2. External, as Burning and Corro≈øive Medicines: the Sweat of Man infected with the Itch, Lepro≈øie or Pox.

Progno≈øtick.] By how much deeper the Ulcer is, ≈øo much the longer 'tis in Curing. Ulcers in Parts that are ≈øubject to much Humidity, are difficultly cured. If an Ulcer cannot be cured in a long time, or when Cicatriz'd, breaks out again, the Cau≈øe is, the Bone being foul under it. Ulcers near to the Nerves, Veins or Tendons are dangerous. In Cacochimick Bodies, their Cure is tedious. If the Matter which comes from them be good, it gives hope of an ea≈øie Cure. Good Matter is of a middle con≈øi≈øtence between thin and thick, white, light, equal, and not at all ≈øtinking. That which is ill, is thin and fluid, pale, livid, and of ill ≈ømell. div.p: IT falls out ≈øometimes that the Bone which lies underneath the Ulcer to be foul: Bones are corrupted and contract a rottenne≈øs, either from the long Flux of Humors, or from the Acrimony and Malignity of them, or from an Occult quality, or from a Contu≈øion, in ≈øome manner injuring the bone it ≈øelf, or from ≈øharp Medicines.

Signs of Corruptions are many: Where the Bone lies open to the ≈øight, at fir≈øt it appears of the colour of fat, then yellow, afterwards black and unequal; but where it cannot be ≈øeen, Chirurgeons may judge that there it is a Corruption. 1. If a Fi≈øtula preceded, or the Ulcer hath been of long continuance. 2. If the Ulcer being skinn'd break out again. 3. If the fle≈øh above it becomes loo≈øe, ≈øpungy, pale or livid. 4. div.head: CHAP. V. Of Fi≈øtula's.
div.p: A Fi≈øtula is a long, narrow hollowne≈øs, or a ≈øinewous Ulcer, narrow and callous, not ea≈øily receiving Cure; for the mo≈øt part, taking its beginning from an Ab≈øce≈øs.

Signs.] The edges of this Ulcer are white, hard, without pain, or but little; ≈øometimes moi≈øt, but commonly dry: Outwardly the Cavity may be perceived in one place or other by pre≈ø≈øing the Part; in which al≈øo ≈øometimes there is a noi≈øe perceived, and the Matter now in le≈ø≈øer quantity, otherwhiles in greater, is pre≈øt out through the Orifice of the Fi≈øtula: By a Probe we can ≈øearch the Cavity of a ≈øtraight Fi≈øtula; but in an oblique, we u≈øe a Wax-Candle in≈øtead of a Probe. That is more convenient when the Fi≈øtula penetrates to the Bone; this, when it is in the fle≈øhy and ≈øen≈øible parts: If the Fi≈øtula remains only in the fle≈øhy parts, that which is touched by the Probe, is ≈øoft, and the Matter that comes out, is white, equal, and in great quantity. If it extend to the Nerve, there is great pain in ≈øearching it to the bottom of the hollowne≈øs, and the Matter is fat and oyly, but is le≈øs in quantity, and the action of that Member which the Nerve goes to, is rendred very
unea≈øie: If it pa≈ø≈øeth to the Bone, that which is touched by the Probe, is hard, not yielding, and painful, where the Perio≈øtium is not con≈øumed; The Bone, is foul, is rough, and ≈øeems unequal to the touch, the Matter is black, ≈øtinking and very thin: If the Cavity joins to a Vein, the Matter is like dregs, but reder and thicker, where the Vein is eroded: If it penetrates the Arteries, that which comes forth, is thin and ≈øhining, and comes forth with a leaping.
Progno≈øtick.] All Fi≈øtulas are of hard Cure; ≈øome incurable, others that ought not to be cured; to wit, tho≈øe by which the ≈øuperfluous Humors have for long time been vented.
A recent Fi≈øtula, and not deep, in a young body, and otherwi≈øe ≈øound is ea≈øily cured; but an old deep Fi≈øtula, having many Sinew's in an ancient, emaciated, cachochimick Body, is very difficult.

Tho≈øe are al≈øo difficultly cured, yea, for the mo≈øt part incurable, which touch the Tendons, Nerves, Veins, Arteries, Bones, and tho≈øe that are in the joints, Vertebra's, Cavity of the Brea≈øt, and lower Belly, the Womb, Bladder, or Guts.
Fi≈øtulas are wont to come in tho≈øe places, where Nature is accu≈øtomed to di≈øcharge her ≈øelf of vitiated Humors, to wit, in the Abdomen, Groins, Buttocks, Fundament, Cod and Perinaeum.
Where the edges are not very hard, but ≈øomewhat ≈øoft and mattery, they do promi≈øe ≈øpeedier Cure.

Cure of Fi≈øtulas are two≈øold, one Real, and the other Palliative; by this the Fi≈øtula is dried within, and skinned without; the hollowne≈øs neverthele≈øs remaining, commonly continuing ≈øome
little while clo≈øed, but ea≈øily breaks forth again, except by a good Diet, often Purging and Bleeding, it be perfectly cured: The true Cure is performed in this manner; good Diet, Purging, Bleeding and Wound-Drinks effect here very much; but the Haemorrhoids flowing more. Natural Baths do oftentimes cure the greate≈øt Fi≈øtula's; in defect of them, may be prepared Artificial, of Brim≈øtone, Alom, Salt and Tartar, boil'd in Water; afterwards let the Fi≈øtula be dre≈øt according to Art: Externally, the Part is to be corroborated, the Humor contained in the Sinus to be dried; but e≈øpecially the Callo≈øity of the edges is to be taken away; therefore are Medicines for this purpo≈øe to be us'd; by who≈øe help many Fi≈øtulas have been cured: but the≈øe not being ≈øufficient, an actual Cautery is to be applied, having fir≈øt divided the edges; for which purpo≈øe the Syringotomon of Fabritius Aquapendents is a mo≈øt u≈øeful In≈øtrument.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of Burns.

p.hi: BUrning is a Solution of Continuity, cau≈øed by an External burning-Matter always hurting the Scarf-skin, for the mo≈øt part the Skin, and ≈øometimes al≈øo the Mu≈øcles, Veins, Nerves and Tendons.

div.p:
Difference.] It admits of three ≈øorts. 1. Sometimes there is a Heat and Pain, at lea≈øt in the Part affected, cau≈øed from burning; and except Remedies are pre≈øently applied, the Scarf-skin is ≈øeparated and divided from the Skin, and Bli≈øters are rai≈øed, which contains in them clear Water. 2. Sometimes the Skin it ≈øelf is burnt, then pre≈øently
a Bli≈øter is rai≈øed, but no E≈øcar made. 3. Sometimes al≈øo the ≈øubjacent fle≈øh is burnt, here the Skin is black and void of ≈øen≈øe, and after the E≈øcar falls off, leaves a deep Ulcer.
The Differences ≈øpring from the Cau≈øes; for Lead, Tin, Iron, Powder, Lightning, do vehemently burn; Oyl, Vernice, Pitch and Wax le≈øs; Straw, Water, Flax, and the like, lea≈øt of all.
Signs, by what hath been ≈øpoken, are manife≈øt enough.

Progno≈øtick.] A deep and great Burn, very ≈øeldom but leaves ugly Scars behind it; Burning from Lightning, is for the mo≈øt part Mortal: That which penetrates to the great Ve≈ø≈øels, generally occa≈øions a Gangrene; if to the Inte≈øtines, incurable; Burns of the Eyes and Groins, very dangerous. If a hairy part be burnt, it remains bald; never hair grows there again.

Cure.] The chief care mu≈øt be to draw out the fire, by which in a light burning you pre≈øerve from Bli≈øters and Ulcers; in a great one, you free from all danger; therefore what Medicine ≈øoever is at hand, is pre≈øently to be u≈øed; let the hurt Part be held to the Fire, and fomented with warm Water, Ink, Lye; or let there be applied Soot, or an Onion beaten with Salt, or any the following.

div.head: Medicines in Burning.
div.p:
Roots of White Lillies, Liquoras; Leaves of Bete, Coleworts, Hemp, Onions, Garlick, Henbane, Tabacco, Leeks, St. John's-wort; Flowers of Camomile, Melilot, Elders; Seeds of Quinces, of Line; Camphire, Myrrhe, Olibanum, Soot,

div.head: An Ointment.
div.p: Take Juice of Oni ‚Ä¢ ns, two ounces; Venice-Sope, three ounces; common Salt, two drams; Hogs-grea≈øe, two ounces; Wa≈øht Lime, three drams; Oyl of Rape, Mu≈ø≈øilage of Quince-≈øeeds, of each an ounce; Turpentine, as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into a Liniment.
Another, by who≈øe means a poor Souldier became rich.

Take Leaves of new gathered Sage, a handful; of Plantain, two handfuls; Fre≈øh Butter without Salt, ≈øix ounces; New Hens-dung, and the white≈øt as you can, three ounces; fry them together for the ≈øpace of a quarter of an hour, pre≈øs them hard out, and re≈øerve the pre≈øt-out Liquor for your u≈øe.

This Ointment is excellent in Burning of all ≈øorts, even in the greate≈øt; it being melted, let the hurt Part be often anointed with it in a day; then lay over it a fre≈øh Leaf of Colewort, Bete, or Plantain.
If any Pu≈øtules are rai≈øed, and yet the Burnt not great, open them the third day, and let not the opening be prolonged further, le≈øt there follow a Corro≈øion.
If the Skin be wrinkled and dried, all the Pu≈øtules are pre≈øently to be cut, then let the precedent Ointment, or this following be applied.

Take Oyl of Violets, white Lillies, ≈øweet Almonds, Butter without Salt, of each an ounce; Mu≈ø≈øilage of Fleawort-≈øeed, Meal of Mar≈øhmallows, of each an ounce and half; Saffron, half a Dram; Soot, Ung. Ba≈øilicon, of each an ounce: Make it into an Ointment.

If there be an E≈øcar, let its Separation be endeavoured the fir≈øt or ≈øecond day; for which the la≈øt above-pre≈øcribed Ointment is exceeding good; but if it ≈øeparates not, then Inci≈øion is to be made into the ≈øound Fle≈øh: When 'tis ≈øeparated, it is to be cured as a common Ulcer.
If there be danger of a Gangrene, or already pre≈øent, it requires its Cure, which is already treated of in its place.
Where the Eye brows, Lips, Fingers, or Toes are burnt, a clean Linnen Cloth, or Plate of Lead is to be put between them.
If a tender part be burnt, you mu≈øt ab≈øtain from the u≈øe of Onions, Sope, Salt, and ≈øuch like ≈øharp Medicines.
That ugly Cicatrices may not be left, you mu≈øt forbear the u≈øe of ≈øtrong, drying Medicines.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of particular ∆≤lcers.
div.p:
IN an Ulcer of the Head, neither Unctious, or Repellent Medicines are convenient. If the ill quality of the Humor requires the u≈øe of Mercury, great care is to be had, that it be well prepared; for Crude is very dangerous; which ought not to
be applied where the Ulcers are about the Sutures, ≈øeeing a Salivation may be ea≈øily rai≈øed, which will difficultly afterwards be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed.

Ulcers of the Eyes, for the mo≈øt part, leave Blindne≈øs, e≈øpecially where the horny Tunicle is wholly corroded, by which the Watry Humor is let out, as al≈øo oftentimes the Chri≈øtaline. An Inflammation generally is very painful, which is forthwith to be removed by tho≈øe Remedies delivered in the ≈øeventeenth Chapter of the Fir≈øt Book. div.head: An Ab≈øter≈øive Collyrium.
div.p: Take white Amber, red Mirrhe, of each half a Scruple; Ea≈øtern Saffron ≈øix Grains; white of an Egg, Sugar-Candy, a Dram; Eye-bright-water, two ounces and an half: Mix them.

div.head: A Cicatrizing Collyrium.
div.p:
Take burnt Lead, white Troches of Rha≈øis,
Sarcocols, Sac. Saturni, of each half a Scruple; Ro≈øe-water, four Ounces: Mix them.

Ulcers of the No≈øe mo≈øt commonly yield an ill Scent, whence they are called Ozaenae. They are hard of Cure, and therefore re≈øpect mu≈øt be had to the whole Body; at lea≈øt the Head, which requires corroborating, and moderate Drying.

Fumes of the following powder, put upon Coals is very good, provided it is u≈øed cautiou≈øly, and not above once, or at mo≈øt, twice a day, le≈øt a Salivation ≈øhould be rai≈øed; which al≈øo will cure the Ulcer: The quantity of a Nutmeg is ≈øufficient for a Do≈øe.

Ulcers of the Mouth require often Purgings, ≈øometimes Bleeding; and if there be Malignity, Antivenereal, Sudorifick Decoctions, which are here of great u≈øe.

The Fume for Ulcers of the No≈øe, is here u≈øeful;
as al≈øo common Ink. If Medicines effect nothing, an actual Cautery mu≈øt be u≈øed.

An Ulcer of the Bladder is trouble≈øome, and for the mo≈øt part incurable, having its beginning from a Wound, the Stone, a ≈øharp Humor, or Diuretick Medicine, it requires many Internal and External Remedies; which that we may not exceed our bounds, we leave to be pre≈øcribed by the Phy≈øician, except ≈øome few, who≈øe vertue hath been often experimented by us.

The≈øe are to be known by the pained Part, and by the coming forth of the Matter, before or after making of the Urine; except timely you endeavor their Cure, the Di≈øea≈øe ≈ølides inwardly, and will perforate either the Bladder or Perinaeum: Sometimes there are here one or more Caruncles, which, becau≈øe they cannot always be cured by Medicaments, they may be taken away by Chirurgery, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of an In≈øtrument de≈øcribed by Pary and others; yet many times have I cured the≈øe Excre≈øcen≈øies, by u≈øing of ≈ømall Suppo≈øitories made of the following Ointment, thickned by gentle boiling.

div.head: THE AUTHOR'S PREFACE TO THE STUDIOUS READER.
div.p:
AS Chirurgery is a of Phy≈øick, that ought not to be ≈øeparated from it; ≈øo al≈øo let not any imagine to him≈øelf, that he can de≈øerve the name of an Experienced Chirurgeon, except he underder≈øtand ≈øome part of it, e≈øpecially Anatomy, the only Foundation of Chirurgery. But ≈øeeing that the ≈øtudy of ≈øome mo≈øt curious Anatomi≈øts, hath found out many excellent things in this happy Age, altogether unknown to the Ancients (though ≈øome fooli≈øhly affirm the contrary, with great pains, a≈øcribing tho≈øe things to them, which they never ≈øo much as dream'd of) which indeed are not to be accounted of, as ingenious ≈øubtleties; but as the Fundamental Rules
and Cyno≈øure to tho≈øe that Navigate through the va≈øt Ocean of this Art. It is every ones part to labour in it, that it may be perfected, and every day more and more illu≈øtrated; which may at length be brought to pa≈øs, if with the greater Pains, Indu≈øtry and Curio≈øity, we enquire into the unknown Regions and Tracts of the Microco≈øm, and not given to ≈øloth, plough our Ground with other Mens Oxen, only tru≈øting on the Authority of the Ancients, which the Learned wi≈øely call A≈øinorum Pontem. As for me, I have ventured to introduce ≈øome new Opinions; becau≈øe that I deemed them in the nature of things, to exceed thee and me, and all in Antiquity. If thou enquire≈øt into it with the ≈øame labour, perchance thou maye≈øt embrace the ≈øame Opinions: That of the Circulation of the Blood is now ≈øpread over all Europe; yea, the principal Profe≈ø≈øors in the Illu≈øtrious Univer≈øities, do all with one voice approve it; the Salivous pa≈ø≈øages and Limphaducts, as al≈øo the Lacteal Ve≈ø≈øels, both the greater and le≈ø≈øer, may ≈øo plainly be demon≈øtrated, that they may be perceived as it were with one Eye. My own proper and peculiar Opinions I have confirmed with Rea≈øons, which I ≈øuppo≈øe are agreeable to our Art: In the re≈øt, if thou finde≈øt any thing new,
it is nothing but what can be demon≈øtrated by Di≈ø≈øection. What others have writ at another time, plea≈øeth us al≈øo; for I cannot, nor ought not to change the parts of the Body; neverthele≈øs the Di≈øpo≈øition of my Genius is ≈øo pregnant, that I hope it will free thee from great pains and trouble.

For, fir≈øt I thought it convenient largely to di≈øcour≈øe of the ≈øimple Parts, their Affections and ∆≤≈øe, that thou mighte≈øt not be nece≈ø≈øitated to repeat in following the ≈øame thing a hundred times.
To this end I have retained the Terms of our Art, u≈øed by the Ancient Latine Writers.

Then I expound the elaborating the Blood, which properly is the Foundation of all Phy≈øick, and which the Wits of the Learned have long and much wre≈øted: O foelici≈ø≈øimum qui metam proxim√® attigerit.

Choler requires not Bleeding, yet permits it, if there be a quantity of Blood joined with it; but it mu≈øt neither be exce≈ø≈øive, nor oftner repeated, than ju≈øt nece≈ø≈øity requires, le≈øt the Choler ≈øhews its Malignity; gentle Purges relieve it, but ≈øtrong irritate it; it produceth vehement and dangerous Di≈øea≈øes, and for the mo≈øt part ≈øhort.

The Melancholick are almo≈øt de≈øtitute of Hair, which is lank and black, of a grim Countenance, the whole skin livid, lean, ≈ølow, and addicted to Venery, prudent, moro≈øe in conver≈øation, readier to give coun≈øel to others, than to them≈øelves; not ≈øubject to Laughter or Anger, but long before appea≈øed; they eat and ≈øleep much; Urine copious, Excrements little, grievous Dreams, Pul≈øe ≈ømall, ≈ølow and hard.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Parts in general¬∑
div.p: A Part (properly ≈øo call'd) is a firm, limited Body, which is nouri≈øhed by other living Parts but doth not nouri≈øh; having a peculiar u≈øe and operation for the advantage of the whole.

It is di≈øtingui≈øhed, 1. Into the Principal Parts, or or tho≈øe not ≈øo: Principal are tho≈øe that perform ≈øome Noble Operation common to the whole Body as the Heart, Liver, Brain, Te≈øticles: Tho≈øe not ≈øo, are tho≈øe that ≈øerve the Principal, and whence they are call'd their Servants, as the Eye, Ear, Hands, &c.

This di≈øtinction plea≈øed ≈øome Anatomi≈øts many years ≈øince, whom I much e≈øteem; yet not me: For if the Liver and Heart are numbred among≈øt the Principal Parts becau≈øe they elaborate the Blood for the advantage of the whole Body, why is not the Tongue accounted a Principal Part al≈øo? which is not only an In≈øtrument of Speech, by which we are di≈øtingui≈øhed from Bea≈øts, but al≈øo of Ta≈øtes, by who≈øe a≈ø≈øi≈øtance we chu≈øe tho≈øe Aliments which are be≈øt; which if wanting, how the Heart and Liver could ≈øupply the Body with good Nutriment, I ≈øee not. The Brain governs all, but how I be≈øeech you? If the Inte≈øtines did not perform their Orifice aright, what would it effect? How ≈øhould we be e≈øteem'd, if, like an Oi≈øter, we ≈øhould want Eyes and Ears? How de≈øpi≈øed are the Feet and Hands, yet in how many conditions
do they ≈øerve? All things in our Body are joyned together as in a Clock, one cannot be without the other; neither is the mo≈øt de≈øpicable Wheel le≈øs nece≈ø≈øary than the Hand of the Clock it≈øelf, without which, it cannot be accounted a Clock.
2. Into ≈øimilar Parts and di≈ø≈øimilar: A ≈øimilar, which divided into many parts, yet, who≈øe ≈øingle parts be of the ≈øame Nature with the whole.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of Bones.
div.p: A Bone is a Similar Part, cold and dry, compo≈øed of Seed, that it might afford ≈øtrength to the Body, and help its motion.

Naturally, 1. It is hard. 2. Covered with a Membrane. 3. White, with ≈øome Redne≈øs, 4. Hollow, or Spungy. 5. About the Extremities covered with a Cartilage. 6. Smooth. 7. Moi≈øtened with a fat Humor.

It is nouri≈øhed by Blood brought from the Arteries (every where ≈øo ≈ømall, excepting the lower Jaw, that Writers of great e≈øteem have denied them to the Bones) but e≈øpecially contained in the Marrow.

The Marrow is inve≈øted with a Membrane, it ≈øelf is altogether in≈øen≈øible; in the Cavities of great Bones, 'tis White mixed with Red; in the
le≈ø≈øer, White; in the Spungy Bones, ≈øoft and juicy
Its Sen≈øe it borrows from the covering Tunicle for the mo≈øt curious Ob≈øerver never ≈øaw Nerves.
The Bones are joined together, partly for the greater firmne≈øs, partly for the better Motion.
That Conjunction which is for their firmne≈øs, is called Symphy≈øis, and is ≈øix-fold.
1. Suture, as in the Bones of the Skull.
2. Harmony, whigh is by a right or oblique Line, as in the upper Jaw.
3. Gompho≈øis, as the Teeth in the Jaws.
4. Sinchondro≈øis, which is by an interpo≈øing Cartilage, as in the Os Pubis, or the Sternum.
5. Syneuro≈øis, which is by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of a Ligament, as the Thigh-Bone with the Hips.
6. Sy≈ø≈øarco≈øis, which is by the acce≈ø≈øion of fle≈øh, as in the Os Hyodis.
That Conjunction which is for Motion, is call'd Articulation, and is twofold.

And both is performed by three manner of ways. 1. Enarthro≈øis, When the Cavity receiving the Bone is great, and the proce≈øs of the Bone to be received al≈øo great, as in the joining of the Thigh-bone with the Hips.

3. Gynglymus, When one Bone takes into its Cavity the proce≈øs of another, and contrariwi≈øe the other Bone receives into its Cavity the Proce≈øs of the former; as the Bone of the Thigh with the Tibia, and the Shoulder-bone, the Ulna.

The number of Bones is greater in Children than in adult People; for by years, many of them ≈øo grow together, as that they cannot be ≈øeparated any more; al≈øo their number is much le≈ø≈øened, when con≈øideration of the Proce≈ø≈øes and ≈ømall Bones is not had; from hence it is that ≈øome reckon 360. ≈øome, 304, others, 249,

Although the Bones ought to be de≈øcribed in particular by us in their proper places, yet an Anatomi≈øt cannot be perfect, that is ignorant of the Bones; therefore, before we begin the Examination of other parts, we think it convenient to exhibit to you the Skeleton in this place.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: The Bones are ≈øubject to many Di≈øea≈øes. Fractures and Di≈ølocations are already di≈øcour≈øed of, as al≈øo Putrefaction: But ≈øeeing there may be ≈øeveral ways produced, we will declare tho≈øe which are chiefly worth our con≈øideration.

Preternatural Humors, by what cau≈øe ≈øoever, either General or Particular, penetrating the Bone, ≈øometimes produce an Ulcerous Excre≈øcency with moi≈øtne≈øs of the Bone; ≈øometimes a Cancer of the Bone, to wit, Spina Vento≈øa, effects nece≈ø≈øary to be di≈øtingui≈øhed; which becau≈øe no Phy≈øician hath made it his bu≈øine≈øs to de≈øcribe, I will impart that which Rea≈øon and Experience hath taught us.

The cau≈øe of an Ulcerous Excre≈øcency with the Humidity of the Bone (which effect is called by the Dutch, een Been≈øuyger) is preternatural Phlegm, depriving the Bone of its temper and hardne≈øs; the fle≈øh cannot be ≈øaid from this ≈øoft foundation to keep al≈øo its Natural ≈øtate; but its nouri≈øhment pa≈ø≈øeth into ≈øoft ≈øpongy fle≈øh, which by degrees encrea≈øeth, and at length cau≈øeth an Ulcer; from

2. The Cau≈øe of a Cancer of the Bone (by the Dutch named een Beenvreeter) is a ≈øharp Humor, fir≈øt corroding the Bone, then making its way through the Perio≈øtium; then follows an Ulcer of the Fle≈øh and Skin, incurable, before the Bone be made ≈øound; its Orifice is very little, the edges are pale, the Matter that flows forth, is thin, the Fle≈øh ≈øoft, and ≈øomewhat ≈øwell'd, at lea≈øt (as we have

4. Moreover it is to be ob≈øerved, that no Fat, or Oyly Medicines are to be u≈øed to the Bone, except they are dxtream drying, or that by Di≈øtillation, have lo≈øt all their Unctiou≈øne≈øs.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of a Cartilage.
div.p: A Cartilage is a ≈øimilar, ≈øpermatick Part, drier and harder than a Ligament, but moi≈øter and ≈øofter than a Bone, rendring the Articulation the more pliable, and defending ≈øeveral parts from external injuries.
Difference.] Some are ≈øofter, e≈øpecially about the Joynts; others harder, and differing not much from the nature of a Bone.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: Not ≈øeldom are the Cartilages, together with the Bones, both corrupted and cured; other particular Di≈øea≈øes it ≈øcarce hath any, be≈øides too great a hardne≈øs or ≈øoftne≈øs: Of both which we will give Examples.

1. The Epiglotis ≈øometimes is ≈øo indurated, as that it not only deprives of Speech, but al≈øo hinders the Patient from ≈øwallowing, except a great piece; for Drink and all other liquid things pa≈øs into the Wind-pipe, as not being well clo≈øed by the ≈øtiff Epiglotis.
