Take Milk, ≈øix ounces; Yolk of an Egg; White-Sugar, three drams: Mingle them; let the Patient take often a ≈øpoonful or two.
Or,

Take Frankincen≈øe, Mirrhe, of each a ≈øcruple, Ea≈øtern Saffron, half a ≈øcruple; Juice of Liquoras, a dram and an half; Gum Tragaganth, two drams; Sugar, as much as ≈øufficeth to make them into Troches, always holding one of them in the Mouth, and ≈øwallowing them down.

I deem tho≈øe Anatomi≈øts to have committed a great Error, who have a≈øcribed this Malady to be an Inflamation of the Larinx; although I deny not, but that the Cartilages may be inflamed, and al≈øo corrupted; yet 'tis certain, that which they have ≈øet down, is not of the Cartilages, but of the neighbouring Glandules, and of the fle≈øhy parts of the Jaws; for it would not be ≈øo frequently cured, becau≈øe an Inflamation and Corruption of the Larinx I always e≈øteemed a mortal Di≈øea≈øe.

2. The Sword-like Cartilage of the Brea≈øt is oftner than Practitioners take notice of, unnaturally bent inward, from Humors flowing in too great quantity; and ≈øo inclining with the point inward, pre≈ø≈øeth the Stomach, from whence comes a diminution of the Appetite, a Vomiting of what is taken in, with a continual pain of the Stomach,
and a wa≈øting of the whole Body; 'tis ea≈øie for an Anatomi≈øt, by the touch to apprehend this Malady, and in the ≈øpace of few hours to cure it; for otherwi≈øe men are mi≈øerably troubled for many years.

'Tis corrected by a large-mouth'd Cupping-gla≈øs, outwardly applied upon the depre≈ø≈øed Cartilage, and being there fixt, let it remain, till breathing is hindred; then ≈øuddenly remove, and the Cartilage oftentimes at the fir≈øt time, returning again into its natural place; which if it appears not to do, the Chirurgeon mu≈øt repeat this Operation once or twice; then having embrocated the Part with Oyl of Ro≈øes, and Myrtles, apply this Plai≈øter to the Part, which mu≈øt remain there ≈øeveral days.

Take Bi≈øtort-Roots, Cypre≈øs-Nuts, of each a dram; Ma≈øtick, Frankincen≈øe, of each half a dram; Balau≈øtians, a ≈øcruple; Oyl of Nutmegs Expre≈øt, one dram and an half; Naval-Pitch, and Turpentine, of each enough to make it into a Plai≈øter.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of Ligaments.
div.p: A Ligament is a Similar, Spermatick, dry part, adhering firmly to the Bones, tying the parts of the Body mutually together.

Difference.] Some are Broad and Membranous, ≈øome Round and Nervous. 'Tis here to be ob≈øerved,
that the Names Membranous and Nervous, are much u≈øed both by Writers and Practitioners, and hath deceived many of them; for 'tis requi≈øite to know that here it hath regard only to their external form, not their internal e≈ø≈øence; for the Ligaments, both the Membranous and the Nervous are void of Sen≈øe, which they would not be, if they were compo≈øed of their true ≈øub≈øtance of Nerve or Membrane.
There is no Ligament hollow, if you except the ≈ølender Ligaments of the Womb; and are all de≈øtitute likewi≈øe of Sen≈øe of Motion, as from them≈øelves.
U≈øe is to connect the parts of the Body, e≈øpecially the Bones, and pre≈øerveth them from continual Luxation.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: 1. Ligaments hurt, by rea≈øon of their want of ≈øen≈øe; ≈øeldom draw other parts into con≈øent, and by the u≈øe of drying Medicines, are ea≈øily cured. I cannot but again in this place (taught by Experience) commend the Re≈øtaurative Powder, of which this is the De≈øcription.
Take Roots of Comfrey the greater, Aloes Succotrine, Calcis vivae, of each two ounces; Ma≈øtick, Mirrhe, Mummy, of each two drams; Precipitate, two ounces: Make it into a Powder.
Here diligently at the fir≈øt time is the weak heat of the Ligaments to be con≈øidered, ≈øeeing it may give occa≈øion to a copious collection of Humors, and other grievous Symptoms.

2. The Ligaments al≈øo are not ≈øeldom Relaxt: Yea, although the Ignorant do contradict, ≈øometimes
they are ≈øo much extended that they may give way to a Luxation, which the Sciatick pain hath more than once given us example of; in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, external Bleeding and Purging profit much; outwardly the Application of corroborating and di≈øcu≈ø≈øing Topicks: The following Plai≈øter is excellent.
Take Stiptick Plai≈øter of Crollius, an ounce; Oyl of Earth, of Tiles, of each a dram: Make it into a Plai≈øter to be ≈øpread upon Leather.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of Membranes.
div.p: A Membrane is a Similar, Spermatick Part, broad, ≈øoft, dilatable, white, inve≈øting the Parts, and carrying ≈øen≈øe to them.
Difference.] Some are very thin, others thick; ≈øome fle≈øhy, but for the mo≈øt part not.
The Parts which inve≈øt, are properly call'd Membranes; tho≈øe which contain the Humors, Tunicles; and tho≈øe which cover the Brain, Meninges.
It is endued with ≈øen≈øe from it≈øelf, for all Membranes are ≈øen≈øible; yea, the Nerves them≈øelves owe their ≈øen≈øe to the Membranous ≈øub≈øtance of them.
Membranes therefore only are the true Organs of feeling, they ≈øerving the Animal Spirits to this purpo≈øe.

U≈øe is, 1. To inve≈øt the Parts of the Body 2. To defend it from Injuries. 3. To keep them
united. 4. To ≈øtrengthen them. 5. To give them ≈øen≈øe. 6. To clo≈øe the Mouth of the Ve≈ø≈øels, that the Nutritious Blood be not carried too ≈øuddenly into the Part, or out of it, into the Vein it ≈øelf 7. To ≈øeparate the Parts.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: The Membranes being ≈øo very ≈øen≈øible, they cannot bear ≈øharp Medicines; they are not endowed with great quantity of Blood, whence when they ≈øuffer a ≈øolution of continuity, they are not ea≈øily united again. But I have ob≈øerved oft entimes that by the Mu≈øcles, and the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Quittour, they are joyned together, as in the Bladder it ≈øelf, who≈øe Wounds and Ulcers otherwi≈øe are e≈øteemed incurable.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Fibres.
div.p: A Fibre is a Similar, Spermatick Part, di≈øper≈øed through the Skin, Fle≈øh and Membranes, to make them the ≈øtronger, and being naturally di≈øtended, to contract again into the ≈øame manner.

Differences are, right, oblique and tran≈øver≈øe, and ≈øome round; the right attract, the oblique thru≈øt forth, tran≈øver≈øe retain, round con≈øtrain; but this they do not ≈øo by their own ≈øingular virtue, as by the common virtue of the Member which they ≈øerve, and from whom they have their ≈øen≈øe and nouri≈øhment, for of them≈øelves they are ≈øen≈øele≈øs.

U≈øe, is, to ≈øtrengthen the Membranes, Skin,
and Mu≈øcles, and when dilated, to reduce them into their natural ≈øtate.
Whether the Blood it ≈øelf hath Fibres, as many have delivered, and as it ≈øeems very probable to us, ≈øhall be explained in another place.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øideration.
div.p: The≈øe offer nothing worthy con≈øideration, except that, when they are wounded, the con≈øolidation of the Fle≈øh and Skin is the longer, and there is a greater ≈øtiffne≈øs of the Mu≈øcles about the place, and makes them difficulter to contract and extend. The Ductus of the Fibres is diligently to be ob≈øerved by them which are to make any curious Inci≈øion.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of Veins.
div.p: A Vein is a Similar, Spermatick, Membranous, long, hollow Part, every where joined by Ana≈øtomo≈øes to the Arteries, receiving the Blood, wanting further Concoction from them, and carrying it to the Heart and Liver.
Difference.] Veins of a four-fold condition are found in the Body.
1. Vena Cava. 2. Vena Porta. 3. Vena Pulmonalis. 4. Vena Lacteae.
Of the la≈øt of which, a more convenient occa≈øion will be offered to treat of in the following.

The Venae Cava and Porta take their beginning from the Liver. There are tho≈øe which would
have them come from the heart, from a weak Argument taken from unborn Embrio's. But where I find many Branches in≈øerted in the Liver, few or none in the Heart; yea, I have ob≈øerved, that it hath not entred into the Heart it ≈øelf, but only to be joined to its right Auricle: I rather embrace the old Opinion, willingly granting tho≈øe honours to the Liver that I think belongs to it.

That the Roots of the Vena Cava and Porta were united by mutual Ino≈øculations, the old Anatomi≈øts per≈øwaded them≈øelves; but the curious Inqui≈øition of the Moderns hath both found out and clearly demon≈øtrated, that they mutually touch one another, but not ≈øo united, that the Blood can pa≈øs out of one into the other; for the extremities of the fore≈øaid Ve≈ø≈øels, by means of the Parenchyma of the Liver, do ≈øo mutually con≈øent, that Milk or any liquid thing ca≈øt into the Vena Porta with a Syringe, finds an ea≈øie pa≈ø≈øage into the Vena Cava, without either an injury of the Veins or the Parenchyma. Concerning which, read Gli≈ø≈øon. Anatom. of the Liver, pag. 272.
Veins have only one Tunicle with many Valves within, e≈øpecially in the external Joints.
They are nouri≈øhed with Blood from the little Arteries, not that contained within them≈øelves.
They are endowed with feeling, both from them≈øelves, and ≈øometimes from the Nerves.
U≈øe is, to receive the Blood not ≈øufficiently elaborated from the Arteries, and return it to the Heart and Liver, there to be more perfectly concocted.
For the better Methods ≈øake in the following, we mu≈øt be forced to de≈øcribe all Veins here particularly, and divide them into their Branches.
Vena Cava taking its beginning in the Liver, as is before ≈øaid, is ≈øeparated into the a≈øcending Trunk, and de≈øcending.
The A≈øcending, which is the greater, perforates the Diaphragm, and is divided into four Branches, of the≈øe,
1. Phrenica, which di≈øper≈øeth it ≈øelf through the Diaphragma and Pericardium.

2. Coronaria, appropriated to the Ba≈øis of the Heart, proceeds from the Trunk it ≈øelf, after it hath penetrated the Pericardium, and inwardly united it ≈øelf by a large fle≈øhy Orifice to the right Auricle of the Heart.

3. Azygos, or ≈øine pari, coming from the right ≈øide of the ≈øame Trunk, when a≈øcending, it hath pa≈ø≈øed the upper part of the Pericardium, affording chief Branches to the eight lower Ribs, then about the fle≈øhy appendices of the Diaphragm, it enters the Cavity of the lower Belly, where, on the left ≈øide 'tis in≈øerted into the Emulgent Vein, on the right into the Trunk of the Cava.
4. Subclavia, from whom comes forth ≈øeveral Branches which go both upward and downward:
The Superiors are,
1. Mu≈øcula Superior.

2. Jugularis, externa & interna; that on both ≈øides (≈øometimes ≈øingle, ≈øometimes double) goes to the Neck, Head and Face; this to the thick Meninx of the Brain, to who≈øe third Sinus its greater Branch is united.
The Inferiors are,
1. Interco≈øtalis, ≈øerving the four upper Ribs, and their Interco≈øtal Mu≈øcles.
2. Mammaria, which is carried to the Brea≈øts.
3. Media≈øtina, which goes to the Media≈øtine and Thyme.
4. Cervicalis, which goes to the Neck.
5. Mu≈øcula inferior, which goes to the Mu≈øcles of the Neck.
6, 7. Thoracica, inferior, and ≈øuperior, which goes to the Mu≈øcles of the Brea≈øt.
The Subclavials being come out of the Brea≈øt, are called Axillares, then go to the Arms, where they are divided into 3 great branches, which are,
1. Cephalica, in the hand between the little Finger and its next; 'tis named Salvatella: Its Branches are variou≈øly mixt with the Branches of the Median.
2. Ba≈øilica, or Liver-Vein.
3. Mediana, which proceeds with other branches from the Ba≈øilica.
The de≈øcending Trunk, which is the le≈ø≈øer, and is undivided till it comes to the fourth Vertebra of the Loins, then it communicates,
1. Adip≈øo≈øa, to the Membranes of the Kidneys.
2. Emulgens, to the Kidneys them≈øelves.
3. Spermatica, to the Te≈øticles.
4. Lumbares, two, three or four, to the Loins, and to their Vertebra's.
Nearer to the Os Sacrum, it is ≈øeparated into two Branches called Illiaci. Before they go to the Feet; the Trunk it ≈øelf pre≈øents,
1. Mu≈øcula Superior, which goes to the Mu≈øcles of the Loins and Peritonaeum.
2. Sacra, ≈øometimes ≈øingle, ≈øometimes double to the Os ≈øacrum.
3. Mu≈øcula Media, to the Buttocks.
4. Hypoga≈øtria, to the Bladder and its Neck; to the Sphincter Ani, to the Penis, and to the neck of the Womb.
5. Epiga≈øtrica, to the Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen, and to the Peritonaeum.
6. Pudenda, to the privy Parts.
7. Mu≈øcula Inferior, to the joint of the Hips.
The Iliack Branches, as ≈øoon as they have left the Cavity of the Belly, are called Crurales.
From the≈øe proceed,
1. I≈øchiatica minor, which goes to the Skin, and Mu≈øcles of the Hip.
2. I≈øchiatica major, to the Hip, then to all the Toes.
3. Proplitea, to the Ham.
4. Suralis, to the Mu≈øcles of the Calf of the Leg.
5. Saphena, To the Knee, Ankle, and to the upper part of the Foot, and to the great Toe.

The Vena Cava, where it comes out of the Heart, receives three Valves, called Tricu≈øpidales, looking internally, for this purpo≈øe, that the Blood may freely enter into the Heart, but to hinder its return.
The U≈øe of the Vena Cava is, to receive the cruder Blood from the Arteries, and remit it to the Heart.

Vena Porta, much le≈ø≈øer and loo≈øer than the Vena Cava, ari≈øeth from the Umbilical Vein, and with many Roots is in≈øerted into the Liver; without the Liver, it is divided into Trunk and Branches, all which are di≈øtributed into ≈øeveral Parts contain'd in the lower Belly.
From the Trunk proceeds,
1. Ga≈øtroepiplois, which goes to the Caul and Stomach.
2. Inte≈øtinalis, to the inte≈øtine Duodenum.
3. Cy≈øticae Gemellae, to the Gall.
4. Ga≈øtrica minor, to the left ≈øide of the Stomach.
Then this Trunk is divided into two great branches, the Splenick and Me≈øenterick.
Ramus Splenicus, ≈øometimes joyning to the Sweet-bread, ≈øometimes pa≈ø≈øing through it, divides into four little Branches, as ≈øoon as it hath left it; which are the≈øe,

1. Vena Ga≈øtrica major, which goes to the Spleen, communicating from thence three or four ≈ømall Veins to the Stomach: The≈øe being blown up in living and dead Bodies, manife≈øtly declare, nothing at all can enter into the Cavity of the Stomach, & ≈øo by con≈øequence no Humor coming from the Spleen, as long ≈øince Learned Men have imagined, taught and writ, ≈øeeing they terminate in the Coats of the Stomach, and open not into the Cavity it ≈øelf.
2. Epiploica dextra. 3. Coronaria ≈øtomachi. 4. Epiploica ≈øini≈øtra.
Me≈øenterious ramus is al≈øo divided into four others; of the≈øe, the
1. Retains its old name, and is di≈øtributed with fourteen or more Branches through the Me≈øentery.
2. Vena Haemorrhoidalis, and goes to the Spleen, the Womb, and the right Inte≈øtine.
3. Vena Coecalis, to the blind Inte≈øtine.
4. Ramus Me≈øocolicus, and goes to the Inte≈øtine call'd Colon.
The U≈øe of the Vena Porta is, to take the Blood not ≈øufficiently elaborated, from the Arteries, and carry it to the Liver, for the perfecter concoction, and for the ≈øeparation of the Choler.

Venis pulmonalis (which the Ancients corruptly call'd Arteria veno≈øa, ≈øeeing that it hath but only one Tunicle, beats not of it ≈øelf, nor returns the
Blood) coming out of the left Ventricle of the Heart, with a wide Orifice goes to the Lungs, to receive the more imperfect Blood from the Pulmoniack Artery, and carries it to the Heart.
About its egre≈øs from the Heart‚ñ™ it hath two Miter-like Valves, hindring the regre≈øs of the Blood to the Lungs.
Its U≈øe is, to carry the Blood received from the Pulmoniack Artery, into the left Ventricle of the Heart.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: 1. We have in another place treated of the Wounds of Veins; we ≈øhall only add, that if the Bandage, by which you ≈øtay the bleednig, be bound too hard, it will ea≈øily induce a Gangrene.

2. We have admitted only four general Indications of Bleeding; to wit, for the Refrigeration, Imminution, Revul≈øion, and Derivation of the Blood; but ≈øpecial Di≈øea≈øes requiring one Vein to be cho≈øen before the other, which are the≈øe following; in a Delirium and great pain of the Head, the Vein of the Forehead or Praeparata, or Vena puppis, may be cut; ≈øometimes the Temporal or Saphena.
In an Inflamation of the Eyes, the Cephalica, and if you de≈øire to evacuate from the whole Body, the Ba≈øilica or Mediana.
In a Quin≈øie, the Ranina, which mu≈øt be but with a little Inci≈øion, ≈øeeing we cannot ≈øcarce by any means ≈øtop the Flux of Blood, and ≈øometimes al≈øo the External Jugular.
In a Pleuri≈øie, the Ba≈øilica of the affected, not oppo≈øite ≈øide; here is requi≈øite the greate≈øt Circum≈øpection; for under it lies the Tendons of the Mu≈øcle Biceps, and near it the Artery.
In anger, fear, or any Ca≈øualty, &c. the Mediana or Ba≈øilica.
In Chronick Di≈øea≈øes, and quartane Fevers, the Salvatella, e≈øpecially in the Full and New Moon.
In Women that lie in, and in ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the Men≈øes, the Saphena; In the Sciatica, the I≈øchiatica.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Arteries.

p.hi: AN Artery is a Similar, Spermatick, Membranous, round, cavous Part, joined every where to the Veins, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of its O≈øcultations, containing the Nutritious Blood with the Vital Spirit, carrying it to all the Parts of the Body.

div.p: Difference is two-fold, the great Artery or Aorta, and Pulmoniack.

The great Artery comes from the left Ventricle of the Heart; which except in the Brain and other ≈øofter parts, every where el≈øe con≈øi≈øts of a double Coat; the outermo≈øt of which is of the thickne≈øs of the Veins; but the inmo≈øt is five times thicker, le≈øt by continual pul≈øation about the hard and ≈øolid Parts, it might incur an incurable Rupture.
It receives three Valves, call'd Sigmoides, looking outwardly.

Coming out of the Ventricle of the Heart, with a great Orifice before it, perforates the Pericardium, it affords to the Heart it ≈øelf the Coronary Artery; when pa≈øt the Pericardium, it is divided
into the A≈øcending and De≈øcending Trunk.
The A≈øcending Trunk, which is the le≈ø≈øer, re≈øting upon the Wind-pipe, is ≈øeparated into the two Subclavials, from which, being yet within the Brea≈øt, proceeds,
1. Interco≈øtalis ≈øuperior, proper to the four upper Ribs.
2. Mammaria, to the Brea≈øts.
3. Cervicalis, to the Mu≈øcles of the Neck.
4. Carotis, externa & interna, proper to the Larinx, Tongue, Neck, Head and Brain.
When they have left the Thorax, they are called Axillares, and carry Nouri≈øhment to the outward part of the Brea≈øt.
1, 2. By the Thoracica ≈øuperior & inferior. 3. By the Scapularis. 4. By the Humeraria.
Then they approach the Arm, where they accompany the Branches of Vena Cava, and are call'd by the ≈øame name as they are.
The De≈øcending Trunk, which is the greater, being yet within the Brea≈øt, ≈øends,
1. The Interco≈øtalis ≈øuperior, to the eight lower Ribs.
2. The Phrenica, to the Diaphragm and Pericardium.
Then having perforated the Diaphragm, it communicates.
1. The Coeliaca, to the Stomach, from which proceeds the Splenica and Ga≈øtro Epiploica dextra.
2, 3. Me≈øenterica ≈øuperior & inferior, to the Me≈øentery.
4. Emulgens, to the Kidneys.
5. Spermatica, to the Te≈øticles.
6. Lumbaris, to the Loins.
7. Mu≈øcula ≈øuperior, to the Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen.
Then at length it is divided into the two Iliac Branches: About this Divi≈øion exhibiting,
1. Mu≈øcula ≈øuperior. 2. Epiga≈øtrica. 3. Hypoga≈øtrica. 4. Umbilicalis. 5. Pudenda.
Out of the Abdomen they change their names, and are call'd Crurales; and ≈øo they de≈øcend into the Feet, and all along accompanied with the Veins, from whom they borrow their Names.
U≈øe is, to carry the nutritious Blood with the Vital Spirit into all parts.

Arteria Pulmonalis, (which the Ancients did fal≈øly call Vena Arterio≈øa, ≈øeeing it hath Pul≈øation, is made up of a double Coat, and contains the Nutrious Blood) i≈ø≈øuing out of the left Ventriticle of the Heart, with a double Branch enters the Lungs, and is di≈øtributed through them by many little Branches, carrying to them the Nutritious Blood: And then what in the Blood is not ≈øufficiently concocted into the Pulmoniack Vein, by who≈øe means 'tis returned into the left Ventricle of the Heart.
It hath three Valves called Sigmoides, which look outward, le≈øt the Blood that having entred it, ≈øhould ≈ølide back again into the Ventricle of the Heart.

Its U≈øe is, to convey the Blood out of the right Ventricle of the Heart, into the Lungs, by which they are nouri≈øhed, and what remains above, then ≈øerves for their Nutriment, is brought back again by the Pulmoniack Vein, into the left Ventricle of the Heart.

Here it plea≈øeth the curious Ob≈øervers of Anatomy, to take notice of (be≈øides the eleven Valves which we have declared to be di≈øpo≈øed in the four already named Ve≈ø≈øels) that many others are
found in the Heart, which as yet want any certain name.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øideration.
div.p: In an Haemorrage of the No≈øe, the Blood flows from the Arteries, not Veins, which not only the colour of the Blood witne≈ø≈øeth, but al≈øo the great weakne≈øs which always follows ≈øuch a Flux: I u≈øe to ≈øtay it after this manner;

Fir≈øt, let a Vein be opened, then let there be applied in Men, to the Te≈øticles, in Women, to the Hypoga≈øtrium, a Linnen Cloth, four double, wet in cold water; or let the Face of the Patient be ≈øuddenly ≈øprinkled with cold Water: Internally, let there be exhibited now and then a ≈øpoonful of the following Mixture.

Take Plantain-water, two ounces and an half; Alexipharmick-water, half an ounce; Cinamon-water, three drams; Confection of Hyacinth, half a dram; Dragons Blood, Lapis Haematitis, of each fifteen grains; Julep of Ro≈øes, an ounce; Laudanum Opiat, two grains; Spirit of Vitriol, ≈øix drops: Mix them.
The following Water is al≈øo commended.
Take Lapis Prunella, half an ounce; Plantain-water, ≈øix ounces; let it be divided into three Do≈øes.

The manner of opening Arte ‚Ä¢ ies, delivered by the Ancients, is ≈øo dangerous and frightful, as that there is none of the Moderns but what di≈ølike it; yea, Arteriotomy hath been wholly rejected, had not the Diligence of their Po≈øterity found out other ways: That which I (with others) have
found always to be the be≈øt of them, I will here ≈øet down.

Chirurgeons were wont to tie a Bandage about the Neck; but ≈øeeing when it is hard bound, it is very trouble≈øome; it is better that the Ligature be made under the Arm-pits, which mu≈øt be ≈øo ≈øtraight, that the Jugular Veins, and Carotide Artery may appear both by ≈øwelling and touch; then let the Arteries be compre≈ø≈øed by the Thumb, a little below, where you intend to make the Inci≈øion; and being opened, (which mu≈øt be done by a ≈øteddy and ≈øtrong hand) take forth as much Blood as is ≈øufficient; which done, ≈øtrew A≈øtringent Powder upon the Wound; then put over it a double Linnen Cloth, with a Plate of Lead; then bind it up with a convenient Bandage, and within five or ≈øix days ≈øpace, it will be perfectly well.

In the Head-ach, Madne≈øs, Epilep≈øie, great Inflamations of the Eyes or Ears, the Arteries of the Forehead, Temples, or tho≈øe behind the Ears, are opened; as al≈øo the Arteria puppis, all of them being branches of the external Carotide.
In the Inflammations of the Liver and Diaphragm, the Artery between the Thumb and forefinger is opened; in palpitations of the Heart, either that, or the Saphena is to be opened.
Other Arteries are not to be opened, except a Bone lies under them, for fear of an Aneuri≈øm.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Nerves.
div.p: A Nerve is a Similar, Spermatick, Membranous, round, white, hollow part, ≈øerving for the carriage of the Animal Spirits to the Parts for Sen≈øe and Motion.

The Nerves take their Original from the Brain, and are divided within the Skull into eight Parts, without the Skull, to wit, tho≈øe that come out of the Spinal Marrow, into thirty Pares; ≈øeven of which proceed from the Vertebra's of the Back, five from the Vertebra's of the Loins, ≈øix from the Os Sacrum.
The eight Pare within the Skull, proceeding from the Brain, are,
1. Smelling pare, which adheres to the Mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes.
2. Optick pare, which is the greate≈øt, and united in the middle.
3. The pare that moves the Eyes.
4. The Ta≈øting pare.
5. The ≈øecond ta≈øting pare.
6. The hearing Pare.

7. Par vagum, which is ve≈øted with ≈øtrong Membranes; it de≈øcends through the Orifices of the Bone of the hinder part of the Head to the Throat, afterwards ≈øending Branches to the Neck of the Larinx, to the Mu≈øcles of the Tongue, and Os Hyodis; then is divided of each ≈øide into the external and internal Branch.

The right External Branch, having ≈øent ≈øome Branches to the Mu≈øcles of the Brea≈øt, makes the right recurrent Nerve; this contributes to the Voice, as al≈øo to the feeling in the Pleura, the Coat of the Lungs, the Pericardium, and to the upper Orifice of the Stomach, ≈øeeing all tho≈øe Parts obtain Branches from it.

The left external Branch con≈øtitutes the left recurrent Nerve, which goes to the ≈øame Parts, as we have declared the right doth; being brought to the ≈øaid Orifice of the Stomach, it is joined to the right recurrent, and ≈øo goes to the lower Orifice of the Stomach, and to the lower part of the Liver.
The right internal Branch ≈øends Branches to each interco≈øtal Mu≈øcle; then having perforated the Diaphragm, furni≈øheth all the parts of the lower Belly with a Nerve, ending about the Os Sacrum.
Of the left Internal Branch is the ≈øame Di≈øtribution.
8. The Part moving the Tongue.
The Nerves have a Cavity, but ≈øo little, not to be di≈øtingui≈øhed by the ≈øight, except in the Optick Nerves, and tho≈øe of the Pudendum.
U≈øe is, to carry the Animal Spirits for ≈øen≈øe and motion of the whole body.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: The Cure of wounded Nerves and Tendons is ≈øo like, as it hath been more than once the occa≈øion of Confu≈øion among the be≈øt Authors; therefore for the better di≈øtinction ≈øake,

1. The frequent contu≈øion of the Nerves by a Fall or Blow: the Skin having ≈øuffered a ≈øolution of continuity, there happens an Ulcer, and many
other Symptoms, from the afflux of Humors. It requires the ≈øame Cure we have propo≈øed in another place, of Wounds of the Nerves.

But if the contu≈øed Nerve be not bare, which may be di≈øcerned from the greater and more connual pain than is u≈øual, in a ≈øimple contu≈øion of the Fle≈øh, the greate≈øt care is, that the coagulated Blood be as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible re≈øolved; for if it ≈øhould ≈øuppurate, the Nerve ea≈øily would putrifie; therefore let there be applied a Cloth dipt in one or other of the following Oyls, warm to the affected Part.
Oyl of Ca≈øtor, Worms, Dill, Rue, Camomile, Ro≈øemary.
Or, let this Fomentation be applied very hot with Spunges.
Take our Ori≈øe Roots, two ounces; Leaves of Ro≈øemary, Marjoram, Hor≈øe-Mint, of each half a handful: Boil them in white Wine for a Fomentation.
Or let the following Plai≈øter be laid on:

Take Sow-bread Roots in Powder, two drams; Species Diambrae, one dram; Oyl of Ca≈øtor, three drams; Turpentine, a dram; Plai≈øter of Betony, on ounce; Virgins-Honey, as much as to make it according to Art into a Plai≈øter.
Oyl of Lavender is excellent in this Ca≈øe, if taken to the quantity of two drops, e≈øpecially where Convul≈øions happen.

2. The Nerves are not ≈øeldom ob≈øtructed with a pituitous and tough Humor, from whence a ≈øtuppor of the Part, and ≈øometimes al≈øo a ≈øtiffne≈øs; the≈øe Symptoms I u≈øed to remove after the following manner; the whole Body, if occa≈øion, being fir≈øt purged.
Take Gum Caranna, half an ounce; Galbanum; an ounce; Oyl of Euphorbium, a dram and an half: Make it into a Plai≈øter.
Or,
Take Mans-fat, Goo≈øe-Fat, of each an ounce‚ñ™ Oyl of Earth, three drams: Make it into a Liniment.
Let the Part affected be anointed with it Morning and Evening, then lay on the Stiptick Plai≈øter of Crollius, or of Ladanum or Diachilon with Gums.

You will ha≈øten the Cure, if you u≈øe Internal Corroboratives, which do wonderfully alter the Nerves, although the≈øe things properly belong to the Phy≈øician, yet I think it convenient to pre≈øcribe this Decoction of great efficacy, of which, let the Patient take three or four ounces twice a day.

Take Roots of Piony, Sea-holly, of each half an ounce; Orri≈øe, three drams; Leaves of Marjoram, Ro≈øemary, of each an handful; Flowers of the Lime tree, Lavender, and Lilly of the Valley, of each a pugil; the le≈ø≈øer Cardomomes, three drams; Nutmegs, a dram: Infu≈øe them ≈øix hours in a ≈øufficient quantity of White-Wine, afterwards boil them, and to a quart of the ≈øtrained Liquor, add three ounces of Syrup of Stoechas: Mix them.

There often happens through a Chronick Di≈øea≈øe, or from a Luxation or Fracture, a Contraction of the Member, which is not to be a≈øcribed to the Nerves, but Tendons. This is ea≈øily remedied by the u≈øe of Oyls and Ointments that have the property of mollifying the indurated Tendons, e≈øpecially if
there is to be u≈øed a daily extention, either by the Hands, Weights or In≈øtruments.
Take Oyl of Camomile, Olives, Foxes, of each half an ounce; compounded Ointment of Mar≈øhmallows, an ounce; Capons-grea≈øe, an ounce and an half. Make it into a Liniment.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Fle≈øh.

p.hi: THE Fle≈øh is a ≈øimilar, Bloody, Soft, Thick part, together with the Bones, to yield a ≈øtrengthening to the Body, and to cover the ≈øpermatick Parts.

div.p: Difference.] Fle≈øh is three fold.
1. Mu≈øculous. 2. Glandulous. 3. Vi≈øcerous.
Mu≈øculous is ≈øoft, red, and is properly call'd fle≈øh, and for the≈øe many ages hath come under the name of Mu≈øcles.

But yet a Mu≈øcle is not a Similar Part, but compounded of many others, to wit, Fibres, Tendons, Nerves, a Membrane, Veins, Arteries, that it might be a fitter in≈øtrument of voluntary motion, to which the Fibres, Tendons and Nerves do chiefly contribute.
It hath a Tendon in its begining and end, ≈øometimes round, ≈øometimes broad, ≈øometimes but one, ≈øometimes double.
Its end is in that place where the Tendons are greater and more.
Its Head, or beginning, where the Nerve is in≈øerted, the middle, where the fle≈øh ≈øwells out.

U≈øe is, to promote voluntary motion, which
is performed after a three-fold manner.
1. When the Contraction of the Mu≈øcle is ≈øo, that the end comes to the beginning, and then its Antagoni≈øt is quiet.
2. When the Motion is Tonick, ≈øo that being contracted, it remains for ≈øome time in the ≈øame condition.
3. When it relaxeth, ≈øo that it is re≈øtored into its former ≈øeat and quiet, by its Antagoni≈øt.

The Glandulous fle≈øh is white, thick and ≈øpungy, formed of ≈øeed (from whence it cannot properly be call'd fle≈øh) to this purpo≈øe ordained, 1. To prop up the Ve≈ø≈øels. 2. To receive the ≈øuperfluous Humidities; whence they are called the Emu ‚Ä¢
ctories of the noble Parts.

Some Anatomi≈øts make ≈øtrange diver≈øities of them, but it will appear to any one that diligently enquires into all the Glandules, that they differ not ≈øo much in ≈øub≈øtance, as in their U≈øe and Humor.

The Vi≈øcerous fle≈øh, or the Parenchemick is red, hard, convenient to prop the Ve≈ø≈øels, and to ≈øerve for many particular and various operations; this is the fle≈øh of the Lungs, Heart, Liver, Spleen, which ≈øhall be treated of in their places.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: The Mu≈øcles are ≈øubject to many Di≈øea≈øes, very many of which are of ≈øo little con≈øequence, that they ≈øhall not be numbred here; ≈øome we have declared in another place: the following require con≈øideration, oftentimes wonderfully exerci≈øing the patience and diligence of the Chirurgeon.

1. An Atrophy of the whole Body oftentimes comes from an Internal Cau≈øe: But if of the Finger,
Hand, Arm, Foot, for the mo≈øt part from an External Cau≈øe. Thus a Fracture, Luxation, Contu≈øion, Tumor, too hard Ligature, and the like, ≈øo vehemently compre≈ø≈øing the Veins and Arteries, that it hinders the free pa≈ø≈øage of the Blood to the Parts, upon which happens an Emacitation; for where the Ve≈ø≈øels are wholly divided or ≈øtopt, ≈øo that the lea≈øt quantity of Blood cannot be carried to the Parts, there follows not a Wa≈øting of the Part, but a Mortification; in this Ca≈øe the External Cau≈øes mu≈øt be removed: And care is to be taken that the Blood may again be carried to the Part: Here chafing the Part, and the u≈øe of Nettles (as many will) is good; the Chymi≈øts commend much Alumen Plumo≈øum; all hot Oyls likewi≈øe are here good; and this Oyntment is of excellent vertue.

Take fre≈øh tops of Savin, Juniper, Lovage, of each two handfuls; Camomile Flowers, Juniper-berries, of each two handfuls; Oyl of Bayes, White-Lillies, of each twelve ounces; Hogs-grea≈øe, three ounces; Dogs-grea≈øe, an ounce and half; Aqua vitae, two ounces; Boil them to the con≈øumption of the moi≈øture; then add to the expre≈øs'd Liquor, Oyl of Spike, three drams; Juniper, a dram; Mu≈øtard-≈øeed in Powder, half a an ounce; Roots of Pellitory of Spain, Long-Pepper powdred, of each two draws; Yellow wax as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into an Ointment.
Or,

Take Pulvis Amianti, three drams; Roots of Pellitory of Spain, a dram and half;
Ca≈øtor, Euphorbium, Oyl of Earth, of each two drams; Gum Ammoniacum, an ounce and half; Laudanum and Wax, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Plai≈øter.

2. The true rea≈øon of the generation of Wens, in my opinion, is this; the mouths of the Arteries appointed to carry nouri≈øhment to the Mu≈øcles, ≈øometimes are more opened than they ought to be, whether it be by Fall or Blow, or from an internal Cau≈øe, e≈øpecially in Plethorick People, and in Parts di≈øorderly moved, the native heat converts the extrava≈øated Blood into Fle≈øh: But ≈øeeing the Member requires not ≈øo great a quantity of nouri≈øhment, it increa≈øeth into a preternatural Swelling; and if this Blood be impure, Choler produceth Pain, Phlegm, Vi≈øcou≈øne≈øs, Melancholy, a Cartilaginous hardne≈øs; and 'tis to be attributed to the≈øe Humors, that this preternatural fle≈øh is more yellow, white or livid.

'Tis ≈øeldom included in a proper Tunicle, except where Phlegm is its greate≈øt Cau≈øe, and then tho≈øe Tumors are generally in the Neck: The Veins grow big, according to the increa≈øe of the Tumor, ≈øo that under the Skin they appear as thick as ones Thumb.
'Tis not in it ≈øelf malignant, yet by ill applications may be ea≈øily made ≈øo: Air is very hurtful, if the Tumor be expo≈øed to it.

For the mo≈øt part the be≈øt Remedies are here u≈øed to little purpo≈øe; on the contrary, the Tumor more and more increa≈øing. You cannot promi≈øe any Cure, except you take it away by a Thred, Knife, or both.

In the beginning, the Medicines that are to be applied, ought to be very a≈øtringent and repelling,
the Part is gently to be rouled, having applied to it, either a Plate of Lead, or a Diachalcitheos Plai≈øter, or of Frogs with Mercury, or the following:

Take Pomegranate-rinds, Bi≈øtort-roots, of each one dram; Scales of Iron, Quick-≈øilver, Burnt-Lead, of each two drams; Bole-armenick, Lapis Haematitis, of each a dram and half; Turpentine, Wax, as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into a Plai≈øter according to Art.
In the mean time, Purging, Bleeding, Scarification, and the Application of Leeches are not to be neglected. Sweating, al≈øo Watchings and Ab≈øtinence, profit very much.

But if the Tumor yields not to the≈øe Remedies, but daily increa≈øeth, Suppuratives are to be applied; but if the≈øe within few days effect nothing, and the Tumor continuing in the ≈øame ≈øtate, an actual Cautery may be u≈øed; which, let not the contrary Opinions either of Chirurgeons or ≈øtanders-by hinder; for by its u≈øe, the increa≈øe of the Tumor will be ≈øtayed for a long time; yea, ≈øometimes the Di≈øea≈øe will be wholly eradicated.

But if the Fle≈øh begins to repullulate again beyond expectation, the Surgeon ought not to defer to endeavour either by a Thred or Knife its extirpation; the Thred being ≈ømall and ≈øtrong, mu≈øt be twice wound about the neck of the Tumor, and tied with a double knot, which mu≈øt be ≈øtraightned the ≈øame day, and ≈øo every day until the Tumor be deprived of its colour, ≈øen≈øe and life, which is within ≈øeven or eight days; then 'tis to be taken off with a crooked Knife, which is very ea≈øie to perform, ≈øeeing neither any great pain or flux of Blood is to be feared: If the Thred be
wet in Mercurial or Ar≈øenick-water, it ha≈øtens the mortification of this Tumor: But in this Operation, a Phlegmatick Body is required; for in other Bodies pain and inflamation do ≈øo much afflict the Patient, that 'tis ≈øeldom that the Thred in a ≈øhort time ≈øhould take them off; yet the Chirurgeon may to le≈ø≈øen the Symptoms, and to cool, anoint with a Feather the part which the Thred toucheth, with white camphorated Ointment, of Ro≈øes, or the like, continually putting the Patients in mind how that others bear it more quietly.

But if you de≈øign to u≈øe a Knife only, the whole Tumor mu≈øt be endeavoured to be taken away, except you will con≈øume the remaining by Medicines, which is very rarely effected; be≈øides the Chirurgeon mu≈øt have a Care that he divides not the greater Ve≈ø≈øels, le≈øt there follows a Flux of Blood not to be ≈øtopped.
3. The Vi≈øcerous Fle≈øh belongs rather to the Phy≈øicians care, than the Chirurgeons.

4. Of the Glandulous Fle≈øh we have treated particularly in ≈øeveral places. In general 'tis to be noted, 1. That the Glandules are of a cold temperament, therefore require hot Medicines, but very ill ≈øuffers cold. 2. The Tunicle inve≈øting them, being eroded or divided, the Skin cannot be con≈øolidated, before the whole Glandule, together with its Tunicle, be con≈øumed with the Ulcer. 3. If Corro≈øive Medicines cure not the Ulcers of the Glandules, within the ≈øpace of few weeks, no hope remains of a ≈øound Cure, becau≈øe of the continual Flux of Humors: And this is the rea≈øon why we are for the mo≈øt part compelled to take them away by Inci≈øion.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the Skin.

p.hi: THe Skin is a ≈øimilar, ≈øpermatick part, having ≈øome Blood mixed with it, reddi≈øh, white, loo≈øe, inve≈øting the Body, and ≈øerving for feeling.

div.p: 'Tis covered by a Scarf-skin, for the greater defence, every where perforated with Pores, to give vent to the u≈øele≈øs Fumes and Vapors; endued likewi≈øe with manife≈øt Perforations, as are the Mouth, No≈øtrils, Ears, &c. who≈øe u≈øe is ≈øufficiently known.
It hath Cutaneous Veins and Arteries, as al≈øo Nerves.
Its U≈øe is, to cover the Body, as moreover it is the In≈øtrument of feeling.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øideration.
div.p: 1. The Skin being di≈øcoloured by the Jaundies, Freckles and other Spots, this Water renders again ≈ømooth and fair.

div.head: Co≈ømetick Water of Min≈øicht.
div.p:
Take white Frankincen≈øe, Sugar-Candy, of each two ounces; white Hermodactils, Florence-Orri≈øe, Venice-Borax, of each an ounce; Salt of Tartar, Burnt Ivory, Camphire, of each half an ounce; Flowers of white Lillies, of the white Water-Lillies, of the white Garden-Mallows, of each three handfuls; Virgin-Honey, three ounces; Goats-Milk, two quarts; Bean-flower-water,
and white Ro≈øe-water, of each a pint and half; white Lilly-water, and Solomons Seal-water, of each a pint; being mixt, let them be di≈øtilled in Balneo Mariae.
2. Scars remaining after the Small Pox, Wounds or Burns, we take away by the following Medicines if deep and great, fir≈øt, having u≈øed Exedents, then Sarcoticks.
Take Venice-Borax, three drams; Camphire, a ≈øcruple; Oxes-Gall, a dram; Oyl of Mirrhe, two drams; Capons-grea≈øe, half an ounce: Make it into a Liniment.
Or.

Take Powder of the Roots of Snake-weed, of Orri≈øe, of each three dams; Seeds of Melon blanch'd, of Raddi≈øhes, of each a dram; Burnt Egg≈øhels, half a dram; Common white Chalk, a dram and half; Frankincen≈øe, a dram; Sugar-Candy, three drams; Gum Tragaganth di≈ø≈øolved in Ro≈øe-water, an ounce; Goo≈øe-grea≈øe, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Liniment.

3. Scabs blemi≈øhing the Skin, are ≈øometimes moi≈øt, dry, ≈øpreading, eating, cru≈øty, malignant; this difference is of ≈øo ≈ømall con≈øideration, that generals being well known, 'tis not difficult to one that well weighs every thing, to proceed aright in particulars.

Seeing the Cau≈øe of this Di≈øea≈øe is a ≈øharp, cholerick, ≈øerous, ≈øalt Humor, mixt ≈øometimes with Phlegm, the often u≈øe of Purging, Sweating and Vomiting, of Bleeding, Scarification, Leeches, Natural and Artificial Baths, as al≈øo of cooling, drying Medicines, and tho≈øe that temper the acrimony of the Blood, Lotions and Unctions are here very profitable; an Example of each I here give.

div.head: A Purging Decoction.
div.p: Take Roots of A≈øparagus, Gra≈øs, Polypody, of each ≈øix drams; Liquoras, three drams; Leaves of Fumitory, Succory, of each an handful; Senna, an ounce and half; Rhubarb, half an ounce‚ñ™ Tamarinds, an ounce; Anifeeds, two drams: Cream of Tartar, three drams: let them infu≈øe 24 hours in a ≈øufficient quantity of Whey; then boil them, and to a pint and half of the ≈øtrained Liquor, add Syrup of Dianicum, three ounces: Make it into an Apozem. Do≈øe, three ounces.

div.head: A Vomit.
div.p: Take Oxy≈øaccharum Vomitivum, Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive with Senna, of each an ounce; Fumitory-water, as much as is ≈øufficient: Make it a draught.

div.head: A Sudorifick.
div.p: Take Flower of Brim≈øtone, Antimony Diaphoretick, Salt of Holy-Thi≈øtle, Sal Prunellae, of each a dram: Make it into a Powder, to be divided into ≈øix equal Do≈øes.

div.head: A Bath.
div.p: Take Roots of red Docks, Briony, of each ≈øix ounces; Leaves of Fumitory, ≈øix handfuls; Camomile Flowers, three handfuls; Bran, a pound; Brim≈øtone, two ounces; Nitre, an ounce; Alom, an ounce and half; common Salt, two ounces; Mix them.

In a grievous and rebellious Scab, the Powder
of Snakes is excellent; this is the Preparation of it: Take a Snake (in March, if po≈ø≈øible, before it hath laid its Eggs) the Head and tail being cut off, and the Skin ≈øtript off, all the inward Bowels (except Tongue, Heart and Liver) thrown away, let it dry in an Oven moderately warm, to a Powder: The Do≈øe from four grains to fifteen.
Vipers dried after the ≈øame manner, excel Snakes, and are commended in the Lepro≈øie it ≈øelf.

div.head: A Fomentation.
div.p: Take Burnt-Talk, an ounce and half; quick-Lime, two ounces; Litharge of Gold, half an ounce; Bole-armenick, an ounce; dry Tabacco-Leaves, three ounces; White-Wine, a pint; clear Water, a quart: Let them boil a little, and keep the ≈øtrained Liquor for u≈øe.

div.head: A Liniment.
div.p: Take Crude Brim≈øtone, two drams; Venice-Sope, a dram and half; prepared Nitre, half a dram; Litharge of Gold, two drams; Mercurius dulcis, a dram and an half; White Camphorated Ointment, an ounce; Oyl of Rhodium, eight drops: Make it into an Ointment.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Fat, Nails and Hair.
div.p: IT hath been long di≈øputed, whether the Fat, Hair and Nails ought to be accounted Parts of the Body, or Excrements. I neither think them Excrements, nor Parts properly ≈øo call'd.
Not Excrements, for they are Bodies, enjoying with the re≈øt Life and Nouri≈øhment, but not nouri≈øhing others, and are of ≈øingular u≈øe for the publick good.

They are not Parts properly ≈øo call'd, being de≈øtitute of any certain bounds, and have no particular operation: Fat nouri≈øheth in Famine; the Hair and Nails, without injury to the whole, may be cut off.

Adeps, or Fat, is a ≈øimilar, ≈øoft, white, in≈øen≈øible part, made to pre≈øerve the Natural Heat, to help Chylification, to facilitate Motion, to moi≈øten the Parts, and to nouri≈øh the Body in Famine.

p.hi: Hair is a ≈øimilar Part, produced by the wor≈øt part of the Blood, covering ≈øome Parts, and in ≈øome manner adorning them.

div.p: 'Tis outwardly four-≈øquare, inwardly hollow; the variety of Colour it owes to the Temperament & Age of Men, to the Con≈øtitution of the Air or Country.

The Nail is a ≈øimilar part, ≈øprung al≈øo from the impure≈øt part of the Blood, flexible, hard, defending the Fingers from external injuries, as al≈øo adorning them. Its Root is joyned to a Ligament,
and is very ≈øen≈øible by rea≈øon of the neighbouring Tendons.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: 1. Blood wholly, or in part de≈øtitute of Fat, is not much to be commended; for its abundance con≈øtitutes fle≈øhy, its unctiou≈øne≈øs, fat Bodies, as where but little fat, lean; this fatne≈øs of the Blood di≈øper≈øed into the parts of the Body, changeth into natural Fat more copiou≈øly in the cold parts, to wit, in the lower Belly, Brea≈øt, &c. than in the hot. The≈øe Signs may confirm our Opinion, as often as they are required from the Blood, after the opening of a Vein; for the upper part of the Blood, which is erroneou≈øly taken by many, to be the Phlegm of the Body, and ≈øo the vitious part, oftentimes is the very be≈øt of it: This may be di≈øtingui≈øhed by the Fire; for if it be fat, it will flame; if Phlegm, it u≈øeth to crackle; hence it comes to pa≈øs, that the Fat, when it is any ob≈øtruction in the Cure of an external Di≈øea≈øe, may be cut off without any pain, or other inconvenience.

2. The Nails are oftentimes ≈øubject to clefts, to be rough, and of ill colour; the Cau≈øe is a vicious Humor, or ≈øome External Accident; the≈øe may be cured by the often paring of the ≈øuperfluities, and the applying the following Plai≈øter.
Take Ro≈øin, half an ounce; Turpentine, Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, of each two drams: Goats-Suet, Green-Wax, of each five drams: Make it into a Plai≈øter acco ‚Ä¢ ding to Art.
Blood ≈øometimes remains coagulated under the Nails, which may be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed by this Plai≈øter.

Take Roots of Crow-foot, of Solomons Seal, red Mirrhe, of each a dram; Gum Sagapenum,
an ounce; Oyl of Nuts, a dram: Make it into a Plai≈øter.
For the falling off of the Nails, a Finger-≈øtall may be prepared of Green Wax, Laudanum and Amoniacum, &c.

3. The ≈øhedding of the Hair is a frequent evil; the cau≈øes of it, are Burning Fevers, old Head-aches, the Lepro≈øie, and the French Pox; and there is not to be expected any new in its room, before the Cau≈øe for ≈øome time hath been taken away; which being done, the following external Applications may be made u≈øe of.

Take Southern-wood, Maiden-hair, Mallows, Marjoram, of each one handful; Cummin, roots of Par≈øley, of Radi≈øhes, Storax Calamit, and liquid, red Mirrhe, of each five drams; Euphorbium, Cantharides, of each a dram; Gum Laudanum, three ounces; Oyl of white-Lillies, an ounce; Roman Nettle-≈øeeds, half an ounce: Infu≈øe them 36 hours in three quarts of fair Water, then di≈øtil them in Balneo Mariae.
Or,

Take Aloes, a dram; Agarick, Coloquintida, of each two drams; Rocket-≈øeeds, half an ounce; Salt of Camomile, two ≈øcruples; infu≈øe them twenty four Hours in fifteen ounces of White-Wine, and keep the ≈øtrained Liquor for your u≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the Generation of the Blood, and its Circulation.
div.p: WE have hitherto treated of the Similar Parts, properly and improperly ≈øo call'd; from whom are the Di≈ø≈øimilars compounded. The Blood ≈øerves to their Con≈øervation, as doth the Spirits to the Actions from thence proceeding; but how the Blood is generated in our Body, and how many Spirits are there found, is not as yet ≈øufficiently under≈øtood by us. In this thing Writers differ among them≈øelves, ≈øo that the very Truth ≈øeems to lie hid in the profounde≈øt darkne≈øs; yet the love and de≈øire of ≈øearching out the Truth exactly, gives me freedom to declare my Opinion, yet ≈øtill giving place to a better.

Sanguification I conceive to be performed after this manner: The harder Meat received in by the Mouth, chawed by the Teeth, and by the Spittle moi≈øtened, is in ≈øome manner prepared to be made Chyle.

This Spittle, from whence it hath its beginning, no man as I know of, hath rightly demon≈øtrated: Tho≈øe that derived it from the Veins and Arteries, it is upon this rea≈øon, becau≈øe they communicate ≈øeveral Branches to the Maxillerary Glandules, through which the late invented Ductus Salivales pa≈øs; and moreover, a Salivation rai≈øed by Art, ≈øeems to confirm this Opinion.

But how the Arteries and Nerves can ≈øeparate
≈øo great a quantity of Spittle, as we have often known to have been thrown forth in ≈øo ≈øhort a time, ≈øeems not po≈ø≈øible to me, I do rather derive it from the Stomach and Limphaducts, which I ≈øuppo≈øe to adhere to the Salivals, upon the following Rea≈øons.
1. As often as voluntary ≈øwallowing is de≈øigned, we ob≈øerve the Spittle to a≈øcend as it were from the Stomach into the Mouth it ≈øelf, e≈øpecially if the Meat be moi≈øtened by Drink.
2. The Tongue, Mouth and the whole Stomach have inwardly a common Tunicle.
3. The Meat in the Mouth, as in like manner in the Ventricle, ought to be mixt with Spittle.

4. It would be very trouble≈øome continually to drink in eating; for it is very ea≈øie for ≈øome time to keep the devoured Liquor in the Stomach, and then ≈øen≈øibly to communicate ≈øome part of it to the Mouth.
5. The Limphaducts are di≈øper≈øed through the whole Body, and they go both unto the Stomach and Tongue.

6. I judge no Humor to be thrown out of our Body, except by peculiar pa≈ø≈øages; and ≈øo for ≈øeveral rea≈øons, I think the Tears al≈øo to be ≈øhed though particular Channels, which a more accurate hand (whether mine or others) may ≈øometimes find out: Yea, the mo≈øt Noble Lewis Bills, the great Anatomi≈øt, atte≈øts to have already di≈øcover'd them and promi≈øeth to demon≈øtrate them in the Body, and in Figures to the Favourers of Truth.

If you enquire of me of what nature Spittle is, I an≈øwer, that it is Salt; yet 'tis not always nece≈ø≈øary that this ≈øaltne≈øs be perceived by the Tongue, which tho≈øe that Under≈øtand the Nature
of Artificial Salts, ≈øufficiently know: It is certain that there is ≈øome natural Salt in all Meats and Drinks; 'tis al≈øo certain, that Salt not only helps the commixing and concoction of the Meat, but al≈øo contributes much to the fermentation of the Humors.
The Ductus Salivales, which we have now made mention of, have but one ≈øtrong Tunicle, not unlike the Ureters, but that they are le≈ø≈øer.
Of each ≈øide one.

They take their Original, endued with many Roots, from a certain great Glandule, lying under the Tendon of the Mu≈øculus Diga≈øtricus, not far from the upper Part of the Jaw; then they run under the Tongue, above the great Nerve of our eighth Pare, to the more inward parts of the mouth, where, in the two ranine Glandules, near the bridle of the Tongue, they terminate; from whom being variou≈øly perforated, i≈ø≈øues out the Spittle into the Mouth; of which, the enquiring Reader may more largely ≈øatisfie his curio≈øity, out of the Writings of Gli≈ø≈øon and Van-Horn.

The Meat thus chewed by the Teeth, and prepared by the Mouth, through the Gullet, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of proper Mu≈øcles, is carried into the Stomach, which that it may the better keep it, it pre≈øently pur≈øeth it ≈øelf together, ≈øo that the upper Orifice is clo≈øe ≈øhut, but the lower not ≈øo ≈øtraight, that though very lightly pre≈ø≈øed, may there find pa≈ø≈øage.

The Meat received by the Stomach, and moi≈øtened by Spittle, Drink, and its own humidity, forthwith by the heat of the Stomach, begins to be concocted; the Order is not ob≈øerved here, which was in the eating of the Meat; yet in the beginning
I have ob≈øerved the Meat to be di≈øpo≈øed in the ≈øame order, as it was devoured by the Animal that was di≈ø≈øected; but afterwards the Stomack continually dige≈øting, fir≈øt ≈øends away that Meat which is of ea≈øie≈øt Dige≈øtion, to the Guts, and it doth not detain it, whil≈øt the other is al≈øo concocted, which Loo≈øne≈ø≈øes and Vomiting evidently enough declare, if you look into the Excrements.
The Meat being concocted, a≈ø≈øumes a whitene≈øs like to Cream, and this is called Chile.

The Chile out of the ≈øtomach through the Pylorus enters the Inte≈øtines, in which pa≈ø≈øage there is a notable Peri≈øtaltick motion: Out of this the Venae Lacteae ≈øuck what is u≈øeful to nouri≈øh the parts; and the unu≈øeful is ca≈øt out through the Belly: The Venae Lacteae con≈øi≈øt of one very thin Tunicle, but are endowed with ≈øeveral Valves, extended from the Liver towards the Glandules, they are di≈øtributed through all the Me≈øentery, and ≈øo are carried for the mo≈øt part to the ≈ømall Guts, e≈øpecially the Jejunum; but yet the great Guts are not altogether de≈øtitute of them, that none of the Nutriment may be lo≈øt.

From the Inte≈øtine, both the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels and the Chile contain'd in them, go to the three Glandules of the Chile, the greate≈øt of which is in the middle of the Me≈øentery, called by A≈øellius, Pancreas; the two le≈ø≈øer are call'd the Lumbar Glandules, ≈øituate near the left Kidney.
Each of the≈øe Glandules ≈øend forth a Branch, which joining above the left Kidney, con≈øtitutes a Ve≈ø≈øel called Vena Lactea, about the bigne≈øs of a great quill.

This great Lactean Vein, lying between the Arteria
aorta, and the Vertebra's of the Loins, cover'd with Fat, runs upwards, and above the Heart, a≈øcends by the Gullet, and ≈øo ha≈øtens to the left Subclavial Vein, where it ends in one, two or three branches; here a mo≈øt thin valve occurs at the very end of the Vein looking inwardly, that the Chyle might not return back again, or run further into the Arm; out of this Subclavial they de≈øcend by the a≈øcending Trunk of Vena Cava into the right Ventricle of the Heart, that there by the help of the heat, and natural quality, it may be changed into Blood.

Being converted into Blood, it pa≈ø≈øeth by the Pulmoniack Artery to the Lungs, which are by part of it nouri≈øhed, and the re≈øt of it goes through the Pulmoniack Vein to the left Ventricle of the Heart, that it may be more perfectly elaborated; thence by the great Artery is carried to all the parts of the Body, communicating to them nouri≈øhment for the pre≈øervation of Life.

The≈øe ways of Conveyance is di≈øplea≈øing to ≈øome, who would rather retain that by the Me≈øaraick veins known, and ≈øo greatly cried up by the Ancients, than admit of a new Truth; therefore they ≈øay that the Chile, together with the Blood, may by this way be mo≈øt conveniently carryed to the Liver, ≈øeeing that the Venal Blood is carried not from the Liver to the Guts (which was the fal≈øe Opinion of the Ancients) but from the Guts to the Liver, and ≈øo not here to be allowed a contrary motion of each Liquor, already ≈øufficiently known.

But in truth the≈øe Opinions they defend, rather by a probable Ratiocination, out of their old affection to the Liver, than that they can make it out by natural or demon≈øtrative Arguments, or an≈øwer the≈øe Queries following.
1. What is the u≈øe of the Lacteal Veins?
2. Why is their ri≈øe in the Guts?
3. Why the Valves are ≈øo placed, that they may hinder the regre≈øs of the Chile into the Guts.
4. Why do they all go together with the Chile to the Glandule of the Chile, and none of them to the Liver?
5. Why are the great Lacteal Veins joyned together?
6. For what end doth the Chile pa≈øs into the Subclavial Veins? All which can be made appear in the Body to the ≈øight.

That part of the Blood which is not altogether u≈øele≈øs, yet not fit for Nutrition, pa≈ø≈øeth out of the Arteries, ever joyned together by Ino≈øculations with the Veins, into the Vena Cava and Porta, and ≈øo by their means is brought again into the Liver and Heart, that it may be amended, and again concocted.
I do not only ≈øay that the Blood is carried by the Vena Cava into the Heart, but al≈øo by the Vena Porta into the Liver, which I prove by the≈øe Rea≈øons.

1. The Liver is the bigge≈øt of all the Vi≈øcera; not that I would infer its pre-eminence from its greatne≈øs (≈øee Chap. 2.) but I ≈øuppo≈øe Nature would never have created ≈øo great a Body, but for the performing of ≈øome extraordinary operation.

2. Its greate≈øt Vein, coming out with a large Orifice, forthwith goes to and enters the Heart. What nece≈ø≈øity is there for the Vena Cava to be di≈øtributed with ≈øuch numerous Branches through the Liver, and ≈øo pre≈øently to a≈øcend into the Heart; for indeed it ought to convey back the Blood not
amended. Its Trunk likewi≈øe, and that of the Arteria Aorta might a≈øcend directly up the Body to the Heart, without concerning it ≈øelf with the Liver, e≈øpecially when the Vena Porta, near the Liver, may al≈øo yield ≈øufficient ways for freeing all the Blood from Choler: It ought to receive the Blood concocted in the Liver, and convey the ≈øame to the Heart.

3. Its colour is red. I well know that it is ≈øometimes ob≈øerved to be white, pallid, yellow, green; but this colour is to be a≈øcribed to the Di≈øea≈øe, not to its natural Con≈øtitution; for in all Bodies perfectly ≈øound, it is found red.

What wonder is it, that the Liver being red, in weakne≈øs ≈øhould contract a whitene≈øs; doth not a red face grow pale, when the Body is affected with ≈øickne≈øs? How ea≈øily likewi≈øe that the Liver ≈øeparating the Choler, ≈øhould be died with a yellow or green colour? 'Tis al≈øo ob≈øerved in the fir≈øt xx or xxx days after conception, it is naturally white, neither becomes red before the maternal Blood (concerning which, ≈øome of the Moderns have far otherwi≈øe a≈øcribed) comes to the nouri≈øhment of the already formed parts, which is the ≈øame in all Spermatick parts, even in the Heart it ≈øelf: But will you conclude from hence, that this red colour only happens to the Liver, and is not more proper to it, than it is to the Mu≈øcles, which yet therefore do not make Blood? To this I an≈øwer, that the affluent Blood is ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary here, and ≈øo appropriated to the Liver, that without it it cannot be called a perfect Liver; but both the colour, ≈øub≈øtance and number of Ve≈ø≈øels are ≈øo difierent in a Mu≈øcle, and in the Liver, that in no wi≈øe the parts de≈øerve to be ≈øaid to be like one another; and what
ab≈øurdity is it to ≈øay; that a Mu≈øcle ≈øanguifies, when even the Heart it ≈øelf by the principal Anatomi≈øts and Philo≈øophers, is acknowledged a Mu≈øcle.

4. The Maternal Blood comes fir≈øt up the Umbilical Vein to the Liver, ere it goes to the Heart of the Infant: And the Valves and Ligatures evidently demon≈øtrate, that the Arterial Blood is carried by the Umbilick Arteries from the Child to the Womb, but the Venal by the Umbilick Vein from the Womb to the Child; but whether the Infant is nouri≈øhed by the Maternal Blood, or by an External Humor, like as a Chicken in the Egg, is to me all one; when 'tis evident, the Blood, which either coming from the Mother or Infant, pa≈ø≈øeth fir≈øt to the Liver, before it enters the Heart.
5. The Choler is ≈øeparated from the Blood in the Liver; for every one knows, that there can no ≈øeparation be made, without there be fir≈øt a Concoction.

From all the≈øe Arguments I cannot gather any thing, but that the returning Blood is carried by the Vena Porta to the Liver, that it may there be purified, and in ≈øome manner concocted, in which its operation, that the Blood may be rendred more perfect, 'tis carried to the Heart, e≈øpecially when by rea≈øon of its continual and nece≈ø≈øary Pul≈øation, the Blood cannot remain long in the Heart: and for this rea≈øon I judge, the whole Blood mu≈øt needs be moved about with a circular motion.
The Blood made in the Liver, as is declared but now in the eighth Chapter, enters the Vena Cava, and from thence into the Heart.
And thus the Royal Liver, at the ≈øame time, when Kings are taken away, may yet u≈øe a limited power, and may remain with honour in its own Kingdom.
But what ≈øhall we do with the Melancholick Spleen, which makes many laugh? It hath many accu≈øers, and not fewer excu≈øers.
1. It was never accounted by Hippocrates the Learned Greek, a receptacle of the Excrements; or is it any where to be found in him, that he call'd the Spleen another Liver.
2. The great number of Veins and Arteries, and ≈øo by con≈øequence the abundance of Vital Spirits, do not permit the Excrements to be collected here.
3. It hath not any convenient Cavity wherein the Melancholy, Faeculent Juice can be received.

4. And if you imagine that there is no nece≈ø≈øity here of a Cavity, its Parenchyma is too thick, and not porous enough, therefore unfit for the reception of ≈øo thick a Humor; which al≈øo is never naturally found in it.
5. It is too great a Bowel to perform ≈øo vile an Office.

6. In dead men, where Melancholine≈øs hath been the cau≈øe of their death, upon the examination of the Internal parts, there none of them le≈øs recede from its natural ≈øtate than the Spleen, the Heart only excepted, whom the Vital Spirits do ≈øo greatly defend, that it is le≈øs affected than other parts, which ≈øeldom happen to the Inte≈øtines, Kidneys, Gall and Bladder.

What is therefore its U≈øe? It elaborates the Acid Humor, which is very nece≈ø≈øary, but not
Excrementitious, and mingles it as a Ferment with the Blood, by which it becomes more perfect, and fitter for Circulation.

In my judgment the Salt of the Blood affords matter to this Humor, which it greatly requires that it may not be corrupted; but this Salt which proceeds from the Meat and drink, is never ≈øo pure, but that it hath need to be brought to a more perfect ≈øtate in our Body. But this is my Opinion.

The Supreme≈øt of the Kings is the Heart; to this are two others ≈øubject, the Liver and Spleen (I be≈øeech you give me leave to make u≈øe of this Similitude in favour of the Ancients) the Heart makes the Blood, the Liver repeats the Concoction, and ≈øeparates the Choler; the Spleen from its own Salt, by an innate vigor, produceth an Acid Humor, which as a Ferment by the Venal Splenic Branch, it mixeth with the Blood, to render it the perfecter, and the more fit for Circulation; if any Excrementitious part ≈øhould be there ≈øeparated, it is all by the Caeliack Artery, and the Haemorrhodal Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øent to the Guts.
If it appears to any one to be a contradictory, that by Salt a Humor ≈øhould be made Acid, we advi≈øe that per≈øon to ta≈øte ≈øome Spirit of Salt.

About ≈øixteen years ≈øince, the great Anatomi≈øt Franci≈øcus Sylvius put forth ≈øome particular things concerning the u≈øe of the Spleen; he was of opinion, that the Blood was not made in the Ventricles of the Heart, neither that it was carried from the Heart by the Arteries to all the parts of the Body, for nouri≈øhment-≈øake alone, but that it likewi≈øe underwent ≈øome other Mutation in the re≈øt of the Vi≈øcera's, particularly that the
Spleen further concocts the Arterial Blood, and brings it to a higher degree, yea that it more then perfects it, ≈øo that the Blood in a manner in this place a≈ø≈øumes the nature of Ferment, by who≈øe means in a ≈øhort time, a great quantity of Ma≈øs may become acid; in the ≈øame manner he affirms, that the Blood more and more concocted in the Spleen there receives ≈øtrength, by which it re≈øtores the returned and weakned Blood, and preparing together with it the Chile, that it may the ≈øooner be turned into Blood: The Rea≈øons which he produceth for it, are the≈øe:
1. The Spleen receives a much greater quantity of Blood from the Heart, than is nece≈ø≈øary, for its nouri≈øhment.

2. That it can be returned back again to the Heart, by no other way than by the Branches of the Vena Cava and Porta; for what hath hitherto been delivered of the ≈øhort Ve≈ø≈øel, are to be accounted but ridiculous Fictions, as may mo≈øt evidently be made appear in di≈ø≈øected Bodies.

3. Seeing this Blood is continually mix'd with the returned Blood and Chile in its pa≈ø≈øage to the Heart, it ought not to be an Excrement; for ≈øo the Noble Parts, and the whole Body would not be purged, but the more injured.
4. Chymi≈øtry hath long ≈øince taught us, that ≈øuch mutations happen daily in Nature.

The Remaining Part of the Blood unu≈øeful to the Body, therefore Excrementious, is thrown out through the Guts, Ureters, and Parts of the Skin, &c. concerning which it is not nece≈ø≈øary to add more here; but now we are forced to de≈øcribe tho≈øe new watry pa≈ø≈øages, which the ≈øtudious
in Anatomy have long and diligently inquired into. The watery pa≈ø≈øages, the Lymphatick Ve≈ø≈øels have their ri≈øe both from the Liver, and from the Joints, and receive the liquid Juice from the Arteries with which they corre≈øpond.

Tho≈øe which come from the Liver, embrace the Vena Porta, and ≈øo pa≈øs to the Mi≈øaraick Glandules of the Chile, as do tho≈øe al≈øo that a≈øcend from the Feet; thence they di≈øcharge their Water into the great Lacteal Vein, which as we have already declared, carries the Chile to the Heart.

Tho≈øe which proceed from the Arm, both lie above and under the Veins, until they come to the Subclavial Vein, which they enter about the ≈øame place; where the great Lacteal Vein doth, being furni≈øhed with a particular Valve ju≈øt at their entrance, and ≈øo altogether they carry the Water to the Heart.
This Water is Sweet, not being as Urine is, Salt.
The≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels con≈øi≈øt of a very thin Tunicle, whence they are ≈øoon broke.

U≈øe of them in my opinion, is to take the ≈øuperfluous Water from the Arteries, and carry it to the Glandules of the Chile, and Lacteal Vein, by which the Chile being made more Liquid, may the more conveniently be conveyed through the narrower pa≈ø≈øages, thence to return the ≈øame to the Arterial Blood, making it fitting to ≈øerve to the nutrition of the moi≈øt parts, and to the cooling and moi≈øtening of the hot.

But that it may the more clearly appear, in what manner I conceive, how what hath already been ≈øaid, is perform'd in our Body; ob≈øerve that the Meat is converted in the Stomach into Chile,
to which part of the Drink is mingled, this mixture is carried through the Glandules of the Chile, and the great Lacteal Vein into the Heart, where it is changed into Blood, which is by means of the Arteries to be conveyed through the whole Body; every part of this Blood nouri≈øheth tho≈øe parts which are of the like temperament with it ≈øelf; the Hot part of it nouri≈øheth the Hot; the Dry, the Dry; the Moi≈øt, the Moi≈øt, &c. that which is here not well concocted, mu≈øt be brought back again to be perfected. Why we ≈øay that the Veins are not ≈øufficient, and the pa≈ø≈øages not commodious enough to perform the ≈øame, who≈øe Office we know is to bring back to the Heart the Blood not ≈øufficiently concocted; the Rea≈øon is that the Water always remaining in the Ve≈ø≈øels, rendered the Blood too thin, ≈øo deprived it of its natural con≈øi≈øtence and ≈øtrength.

From all tho≈øe ≈øo clearly and di≈øtinctly laid down, it ≈øufficiently appears what the CIRCULATION OF THE BLOOD is, to wit, a continual motion of the Blood out of the Arteries into the Vena Cava and Porta to the Liver and Heart, that in them it may be fitted for the Nutrition and the life of the whole Body.
Out of the ≈øubtile≈øt part of the Blood are the SPIRITS produced, which are two-fold:
1. Vital, which begotten in the Heart, carry life to the parts of the Body.
2. Animal, who out of the Vitals elaborated in the Brain, impart Sen≈øe and Motion to the Body.
The Natural at the ≈øame time that the Circulation of the Blood was found out, vani≈øhed.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: 1. The Ductus Salivales, when the ≈øtring of the Tongue is to be cut, or the Ranine Vein to be opened, or any other Di≈øea≈øe of the Tongue that is to be cured by Manual Operation, warn you to have great care of tho≈øe little Glandules in which they end, that they might not be hurt with the Launcet, le≈øt there follow a continual ≈øpitting.

The great Glandule al≈øo of the Neck, from whence the≈øe Ductus's take their ri≈øe, when it is inflamed, admits not of the u≈øe of Mercury; for from hence a dangerous Salivation may very ea≈øily be rai≈øed.

2. The Lacteal Veins, either the greater or the le≈ø≈øer, are oftentimes from a Contu≈øion or Wound ≈øo greviou≈øly hurt, that they cannot carry the Chile to the Heart; and though the wound be cured with great diligence, care, and ≈øpeed, yet the Patient will fall into a Con≈øumption, whence follows Death inevitably: This Truth will defend Chirurgeons from many Calumnies.

In Children, and older People, is often perceiv'd an induration and inflamation of the Abdomen; the cau≈øe of which is the hardne≈øs of the Me≈øaraic Glandules, which allow not pa≈ø≈øage for the Chile to the great Lecteal Vein, except the very thinne≈øt of it; whence the fle≈øh of the Mu≈øcles wa≈øts, the Body becomes heavy and weary, and at length a Feaver, and a wa≈øting of the whole Body. This evil I u≈øe to remedy without any great trouble, with this External Liniment.

Take compound Oyntment of Mar≈øhmallows
Ointment of Sow-bread, of Martiaton, of each two drams; Oyl of white Lillies, of Camomile, of each three drams: Mix it into an Ointment.
Inwardly the following Troches are excellent, being continually u≈øed the whole time of the Cure.

Take prepared Steel, prepared Crabs-Eyes, of each a ≈øcruple; Vitriolated Tartar, half a dram; Sal Prunella, xvj. grains; Species Aromatici Ro≈øati, a ≈øcruple; white Sugar, two ounces: Make them into Troches according to Art.
In this ca≈øe Purging is not to be u≈øed, but with Ca≈ø≈øia, Cream of Tartar, and Laxative Syrups; for the Glandules will not bear ≈øtrong Purges.

3. The Blood taken out upon the opening a Vein, oftentimes after ≈øome few hours ≈øpace, appears very dry, and de≈øtitute of all Serum, which for the mo≈øt part is a≈øcrib'd to its too great Heat, and Adu≈øtion: but this Argument is very invalid for if the ≈øame day, the ≈øame, or another Vein be again opened, there will be found a great quantity of Serum in the Blood; therefore the true Cau≈øe is to be deduc'd from the Circulation of the Blood, but e≈øpecially in the Lymphatick Ve≈ø≈øels, which at that time draws the Serum and Humidity, and ≈øo leaves the Blood dry.
It very often al≈øo happens, that the Body becomes Tumid, Turgid and Languid, upon which the fearful Phy≈øitian forthwith pronounces nought but dangers.

When with the u≈øe of Internal and External Sudorificks, the Patient in a ≈øhort time may be cured: The Cau≈øe of this Di≈øea≈øe is not from the intemperature and debility of tho≈øe parts the Ancients call'd Noble; for it may ea≈øily be di≈øtingui≈øhed from the Drop≈øie, which the≈øe parts occa≈øion;
for although the ≈øick per≈øons are very dull and weary, yet are they not anxious, but breath free, and the Belly ≈øwells not much. In the Face, and Joynts e≈øpecially, is a watry Matter collected; but if the ≈øwell'd parts are compre≈ø≈øed by the Finger, we perceive much le≈øs Serum to be contained in the parts, than in a true Drop≈øie; from whence tho≈øe that under≈øtand not the true Cau≈øe, are wont to a≈øcribe this Inflammation to wind: But the Lymphatick Ve≈ø≈øels when compre≈øt, broke, or by any other way ob≈øtructed, ≈øo that the natural motion of the Lympha is hindred, occa≈øions this evil.

1. The Circulation of the Blood, requires all venomous and deprav'd Humors, which are thrown out either by Nature it ≈øelf, or that outwardly happen to the Body, at the very fir≈øt in≈øtant, forthwith to be expelled out of the Glandules and the Skin, by the means of attractive Medicines, le≈øt that the whole Blood in a very ≈øhort time be infected, and the Heart it ≈øelf oppre≈øt, and ≈øuffer under it: The which doth ≈øufficiently declare, how dangerous it is to open a Vein, and to purge in a Venereal and Pe≈øtilential Bubo, nay, in all venomous Wounds; as on the contrary, how nece≈ø≈øary it is to ca≈øt forth the offending matter; by the u≈øe of Sudorifick and Attracting Medicines: As moreover, how that the invention of the Circulation of the Blood, is of very great u≈øe in the Art of Phy≈øick.

div.head: CHAP. XV. The Divi≈øion of the Body.
div.p: MAn's Body is mo≈øt conveniently divided into the Venters, or Regions, and Joynts.
There are three Venters.
1. The Head, or the ≈øupream Region or Cavity, to it is joined the Neck, which is its prop.
2. The Thorax, Brea≈øt, or middle Region.
3. The Abdomen, lower Belly, or lower Region.
The Joynts are the two Arms, and the two Legs.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: We divide the Body after this manner, that it may be known what place each part of the Body ought to keep; to tho≈øe that read the following, every thing will become more manife≈øt.

But there is ≈øo great con≈øent of all the Parts, ≈øo great concord, that no part may be by it ≈øelf con≈øider'd, without a con≈øideration of the whole; therefore I think it nece≈ø≈øary, that in a few words the foundation of this mutual con≈øent be here declar'd.
1. In every part is required a natural temper; for the Liver being too hot, the Stomach too cold, the Brain too dry, &c. the whole Body mu≈øt be out of order.
2. A ≈øufficient number, for in the Hand, if the lea≈øt Bone, Tendon or Artery, &c. be wanting, forthwith its operation is injured.
3. A ju≈øt magnitude: one Foot greater than the other, cau≈øeth a trouble≈øome walking.
4. A Natural Figure, Softne≈øs, Thickne≈øs: yea, colour it ≈øelf.
5. A convenient Connection and ≈øight.
6. The pre≈øence of the Vital Spirits, which are brought to the Part by the Arteries.
7. The pre≈øence of the Animal Spirits, which are carried by the Nerves.
8. Outwardly the Skin, that covers the whole Body; Inwardly, the Dura Mater, the covering of the Brain, Palate, Tongue, Jaws, Brea≈øt and lower Belly, requires al≈øo a particular Con≈øideration.
9. It is likewi≈øe nece≈ø≈øary that the Nutriment be well concocted, naturally carried and receiv'd, that there may no defect be ob≈øerved in the Parts.
