div.head: The SECOND BOOK. OF THE HEAD.
CHAP. I. Of the Outward Parts of the Head.
div.p: THE Head, as Supream Lord, both of its own, and of a thou≈øand other Bodies, not only governs it ≈øelf, but others well, when formed with a healthy Con≈øtitution, and in≈øtructed with the knowledge of its own Office; but they live a mi≈øerable life, who≈øe Head is not ju≈øtly and with Art compo≈øed, and who neither enquire into, or know its Sub≈øtance or Figure.
Its Figure is Oval, the upper part is call'd Vertex, the fore-part Frons, the hinder-part Occip√∫t, the ≈øides Temples, the re≈øt is call'd the Face, and con≈øi≈øts of the following parts.
Fir≈øt appears the Skin, in ≈øeveral places endowed with Hair, but in all with a Scarf-skin.

Under this lies the Membrana Carno≈øa and Pericranium, which takes its ri≈øe from the Dura
Mater; and pa≈ø≈øing through the Sutures of the Skull, fir≈øt inve≈øts the Skull, then all the other Bones.
Anatomi≈øts that are very curious, make the Pericranium to be double; the outward retains the old name of Pericranium, the inward is called Perio≈øtium.
The Bones which lie under the≈øe Membranes, fir≈øt we divide into the Skull and Jaws, then into many other Bones.
The Skull is compo≈øed of eight Bones, joyned together by proper and common Sutures.
The proper Sutures are true or ≈øpurious.
The true are three.
1. The Coronal. 2. The Sagittal. 3. The Lambdoidal.
The Spurious are the two ≈øquamous Sutures of the temporal Bones.
The common are three likewi≈øe.
1. The Frontal. 2. The Sphoenoidal. 3. The Ethmoideal.
The Bones them≈øelves which have many perforations and cavities for the pa≈ø≈øage of the Air, of the Veins, Arteries and Nerves, are eight.
1. The Bones of the Fore-head, always in Children, ≈øometimes in old people, is divided ju≈øt to the root of the No≈øe by the ≈øagittal Suture.
2, 3. The Bones of the fore part of the Head, or Bregma.
4, 4. Temporal Bones, or Petro≈øa.
6. The Lambdoidal, or Bone of the hinder-part of the Head.
7. The Sphoenoidal, or Wedge like Bone.
8. The Ethmoideal Bone, or Cribro≈øum.

The Mu≈øcles of the Forehead are the two Attollentes;
Mu≈øcles of the hinder part of the Head, are the two Deprimentes.
The Jaws con≈øi≈øt of ≈øeveral Bones conjoined ≈øo by Harmony, that in old people they appear but as one; the one is called the upper, the other the lower Jaw.
The upper Jaw is compo≈øed of eleven Bones, of each ≈øide five, the odd eleventh is placed in the middle.
1, 2. Os Zygomaticum, or yoke-bone makes the lower part of the Orbite of the Eye, con≈øtituting with its Apophi≈øis the Os Jugale, or Zygoma.
3, 4. Os Lachrymale makes the internal corner of the Eye, having a large Orifice de≈øcending to the No≈øe.
5, 6. Os Maxillare, or Jaw-bone, particularly ≈øo called, which is the greate≈øt of all the Bones, which con≈øtitutes the Jaws.
7, 8. Os Na≈øi, or Bone of the No≈øe, which in its end hath five united Cartilages.
9, 10. Os Palati, or Bone of the Palate.
11. Vomer, A peculiar Bone above the Palate, which ≈øupporting the inter≈øtice of the No≈øe, and joined to it by Harmony.
The upper Jaw moves not but when the whole Head moves, therefore needs not proper Mu≈øcles.

The lower Jaw (which generally remains divided in the fore-part till the eighth year, and afterwards is ≈øo clo≈øly joined together, as it appears to be but one Bone) hath two Proce≈ø≈øes, and in them a Cavity, big enough to allow a convenient ≈øituation to the Veins, Arteries, and Nerves, from whence the Teeth receive their Nutriment and Sen≈øe: The Branches of the Nerves about the Chin, pa≈øs out again through a little Orifice‚ñ™ are
di≈øtributed into the Mu≈øcles of the Lips.

It is moved by ≈øix pair of Mu≈øcles, which are,
1. Pterygo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Internus. Attollentes.
2. Diga≈øtricus. Attollentes.
3. Latus, Deprimens.
4. Pterygoideus Externus, bringing them forward.
5. Ma≈ø≈øeter.
6. Mu≈øculus Temporalis.

This Mu≈øcle hath this peculiar to it ≈øelf, that it is covered by the Pericranium, by which the ≈øubjacent temporal Bones are altogether de≈øtitute of it, which is not ob≈øerv'd in any other part of the Body. But no man hitherto as I know of hath yet given the Rea≈øon of it; for what≈øoever hath been delivered by others concerning this, hath been ≈øo ≈ølight, that they give little ≈øatisfaction to the lovers of Truth. But of late, Job Mekeren an Experienced Chirurgion of this City, hath in an Epi≈øtle communicated ≈øomething particular relating to this matter, the ≈øub≈øtance whereof I here give you, until he put forth his Ob≈øervations (≈øome of which I have ≈øeen.)
TO Dr. PAUL BARBETTE Phy≈øician at Am≈øterdam.
SIR,
I Will truly declare to you my Opinion concerning the Que≈øtion I informed you I had moved in the company of ≈øome Phy≈øicians, which was, Why the Bones
which lie under the temporal Mu≈øcles, are not covered and inve≈øted by the Pericranium as are the other Bones.
On the 6th. of Janaury 1654, being commanded by the Honourable Senate of this City, to open the Head of PETER JACOBS, Brick layer, then was my Opinion, which I had been hitherto big withal, ≈øufficiently confirmed; for as ≈øoon as I had ob≈øerved a great depre≈ø≈øion in the upper part of the Skull, I al≈øo found a great quantity of coagulated Blood, which had part of it pa≈øt through the Ears, and part of it remained yet in the Cavity of the Ear; then being very de≈øirous to know the way by which this Blood had de≈øcended into the Cavity of the Ear; which, when I had diligently enquired into, I al≈øo di≈øcovered the rea≈øon and cau≈øe wherefore the Pericranium covers in this place the temporal Mu≈øcles, and not the Bone under them.
Fir≈øt, The Opinion and the An≈øwer (which the Honourable and Experienced Dr. TULPH Burgoma≈øter of Am≈øterdam, had given to the propounded Que≈øtion, to wit from whence this Blood ≈øhould come, which very often in Wounds of the Head flows out of the Ears?) I found to be true and rea≈øonable; for I perceived, as the Noble Con≈øul had affirmed to me, that the Blood from the upper part of the Head, did de≈øcend between the Skull and Pericranium, and ≈øo did enter the ≈øpace that is between the Os Parietale and Petro≈øum, and from thence to be as it was ≈øtrained through a Sieve into the Cavity of the Ear; afterwards in ≈øearching further, I found the Os Petro≈øum to be removed a great di≈øtance from the Os Parietale; ≈øo that in the place where the Bones did recede from each other, was a motion ob≈øerved, beginning at the Os Petro≈øum, and ending in the Os Parietale,
there where the Toothy unition in the Os Jugale in the inward part, which is covered with a Callus (as it ought to be in every Articulation) to hinder brui≈øing, is ob≈øerved.
And this being ≈øo, it may be concluded, that the Pericranium, if it had inve≈øted the Bone under the temporal Mu≈øcles, without all doubt it would have pa≈ø≈øed it ≈øelf between the Os Petro≈øum, whence from its moving and rubbing in eating, ≈øpeaking, or any other Motion, would haue always felt intollerable pain. Thus have you, Sir, what I thought (hoping to proceed further) the rea≈øon to the Que≈øtion propounded, &c.
Farewel.

This Opinion is indeed judicious, and very probable; for in dead Mens Skuls the upper Bone of the Temple is movable as is the lower; and in the Suture of the Zygomatick Bone, is a Cartilage found, which is nece≈ø≈øary in every Joynt; for I confe≈øs the motion is little, but greater would not be required than what ≈øufficeth to afford pa≈ø≈øage to the thick Humors, either from External or from Internal Cau≈øes, collected ≈øometimes in the Cavity of the Ear, by the which the Brain and Ears may be freed from many and various inconveniences: I hope time and diligence will give us greater light in this thing.
Each Jaw is armed with nece≈ø≈øary Weapons, which are called Teeth.
In Men, for the mo≈øt part thirty two; in Women, twenty eight.
Four are called Fore teeth, or Cutters.
Two Dog, or Eye-Teeth.
All the re≈øt are called Jaw-Teeth, or Grinders.
After the 20th, 40th, 80th. year, oftentimes comes forth with pain, two Teeth in the very furthe≈øt part of the Jaw, which ≈øome call the Teeth of Manners or Wi≈ødom, others the late Teeth.
Before we come to the other Mu≈øcles of the Head, we deem it nece≈ø≈øary to de≈øcribe ≈øome parts which are not as yet mentioned, that is, the Eye, Ear, No≈øe, Mouth.
The Eye with the Lids, to wit, the Membranous coverings before Cartilaginous and Hairy, defend from External Injuries; hath two Corners or Angles.
In each corner is a Glandule; that which is in the le≈ø≈øer External Corner, is great, white, hard; that in the greater External Corner, is le≈ø≈øer, ≈øoft, red, and covers the Punctum Lachrymale.
Four Tunicles contain the three Humors.
One of them, which comes from the Pericranium is likewi≈øe common to the Lids, and is called Conjunctiva or Adnata.
The other three are proper, and are thus reckoned.
1. Cornea, coming from the Dura Meninx.
2. Uvea, from the Pia Mater; this ≈øometimes dilating it ≈øelf, then again contracting it ≈øelf, con≈øtitutes the Pupil, ≈øhewing the many coloured Oval Circle, call'd the Iris.
3. Retina, from the Brain it ≈øelf, or rather from the Optick Nerve; which proceeding further, is changed into the Aranea.
To the≈øe three may be added a fourth, Vitrea, which is ill omited by many.
The Humors of the Eyes are,
1. The Aqueous. 2. The Chry≈øtalline. 3. The Vitrecus.
The ≈øecond pair of Nerves, or the Optick Nerve brings the Spirits for ≈øight; the third pair, or the Motorious, for Motion.
Branches of the Internal and External Carotide-Artery bring to it the Nutritious Blood; and the ≈øuperfluous is returned by the Internal and External Jugular Veins.
Fat and Mu≈øcles make up the re≈øt of the Eye.
The Fat ≈øerving to the Calefaction, Humectation and better motion, is here in great quantity, every where di≈øtributed between the Ve≈ø≈øels and the Mu≈øcles.
The Eye-lid hath four Mu≈øcles.
One ≈øtraight Mu≈øcle, three orbicular.
The Eye it ≈øelf hath ≈øix, of which four are ≈øtraight.

The outward Ear, or the Cartilaginous Auricle, is join'd to the Bone of the Temples.
It hath a very ≈øen≈øible Membrane, and behind it al≈øo ≈øome Glandules, to which the Head ≈øends the ≈øuperfluous humors.
Ve≈ø≈øels, it receives from the External and Internal Jugular and Carotide.
Nerves, from the ≈øecond pare of the Nerves of the Neck, as al≈øo from the ≈øix pare of the Nerves of the Brain.
Here is but little Fat; what little there is, is below the Lap; it receives four Mu≈øcles, of which, the three former are to it common with other parts, the fourth proper to it ≈øelf.
1. Antror≈øum ducens, which moveth it forward.
2. Retror≈øum ducens, which pulleth it backward.

The inward part of the Ear hath four Cavities for ≈øound; and for defence and ≈øtrength, as many Bones.
The Cavities are.

2. Tympanum. 3. Labyrnthus. 4. Cochlea.
The little Bones are of the ≈øame bigne≈øs in Children, as in older People; which are,

The Noble Lewis de Bils, the great Anatomi≈øt, in a particular Treati≈øe, ≈øhews, that the Os Petro≈øum (which hitherto by rea≈øon of its great thickne≈øs and ≈øolidne≈øs, was a va≈øt hindrance to tho≈øe that had a de≈øire to view the≈øe Bones of the Hearing in their natural ≈øituation) not to con≈øi≈øt of one only Bone, but to be made up of four, joined together by Harmony, which may very ea≈øily be ≈øeparated by „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .
Within are two Mu≈øcles, the one joined to the Meatus auditorius, the other to the Malleclus.

The No≈øe covered with a Scarf-skin, Skin, Mu≈øcles, and the Perio≈øtium, hath two Cavities ≈øeparated by a Cartilaginous Septum; each of the≈øe again is divided into that which a≈øcends to the Os Ethmoides; and into that which de≈øcends above the Palat, into the further part of the Mouth.
The ≈øides of it are called Pennae, Alae, or wings; the lower fle≈øhy part is called Columna, or the fle≈øhy Pillar.

In the in≈øide they are inve≈øted with a thin Membrane, which is very ≈øen≈øible, ari≈øing from the Dura Mater, which is as to the No≈øe, likewi≈øe common to the Mouth, Palat, Tongue, Larinx, Gullet, and to the Stomach it ≈øelf.
The Bones of which it is compounded, are many and ≈øpungy, replete with Caruncles, that the Snot might not voluntarily di≈øtil forth.

Arteries from the Carotide, bring nouri≈øhment to it; Veins from the Jugular, return the Blood that is not perfectly concocted. Nerves from the fir≈øt pare, according to our order, ≈øerve for the ≈ømelling, as do tho≈øe from the fifth pare, ≈øerve to the feeling.

1, 2. Deprimentes, depre≈ø≈øing the No≈øe.

The Mouth, the Gate of Air, Speech and Nouri≈øhment, hath two Lips, the parts of each
≈øide, call'd Cheeks, as that below is call'd the Chin.
The Lips have two Mu≈øcles common to the Jaw.

The Tongue (as a Sword-cutting out Honour either well or ill, as it is moved by pure or impure Spirits) behind, is fa≈øtned to the Larinx, Os Hyodis, to the Jaws, and to the Ton≈øils; before, to a certain Membranous and ≈øtrong Body, who≈øe extremity makes the String of the Tongue.

Os Hyodis, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Mu≈øcles and Ligaments, is tied to the ≈øharp proce≈øs of the temperal Bones, and to the Buckler-like Cartilage of the Larinx; it is compo≈øed of five united Bones; the middlemo≈øt of the≈øe, which is the greate≈øt, call'd the Ba≈øis of the Tongue, hath two Cartilaginous Productions, which often degenerate into Bones.

All the≈øe are the outward parts of the Head, which is either ≈øolely moved by its own proper Mu≈øcles, or together with them likewi≈øe with the Mu≈øcles of the Neck; the≈øe ≈øhall be treated of hereafter. The proper Mu≈øcles are.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: Very many, as well Internal, as External Di≈øea≈øes, take their ri≈øe from the Head, which is is not improperly compared to a Hou≈øe-roof that receives the vapours of the whole Hou≈øe; which afterwards being changed into a Catharre, di≈øtils upon the inferiour parts, creating a Pain, and Pal≈øie in the Joynts; an inflamation in the Eyes and Jawes, &c. a ≈øhortne≈øs of breathing in the Brea≈øt, and in the Stomach a depraved Chylification; in the Guts a loo≈øene≈øs, &c. ≈øome of the External Di≈øea≈øes ≈øhall here be con≈øidered by us, the Internal belong to the con≈øideration of the Phy≈øician.

1. There is often in the Head Porago, Achor, or Fav ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ s, which is a cru≈øted Scab, happening as well in old as young people; the≈øe Scurffs are oftentimes very thick, ≈øometimes accompanied with moi≈øture, which cau≈øeth great itching and a very ill ≈ømell.

The Cure] In this ca≈øe are generally u≈øed, ≈øtrong Purging, Bleeding, Sweating, Salivation, Unctions, pulling out of the Hairs: But without u≈øing
any of the≈øe Remedies, I have often cured this Di≈øea≈øe, only with this Decoction.

Take A≈øhes, (which are call'd by the Dutch Weida≈øch, in Engli≈øh Pot-a≈øhes,) with White-Wine, make a Lixivium of a moderate Acrimony, in a quart of which, boil the Leaves of Marjorum, Southern-wood, of each two handfuls; of Maiden-hair, a handful and half; Ro≈øe leaves three pugils: Make a Fomentation.

With this let the head be wa≈øhed twice or thrice a week warm; then dry it well with hot Linnen Clothes, and in a few weeks ≈øpace, the Patient with thus doing, will be cured: You may likewi≈øe ≈øometimes u≈øe gentle Purging Medicines.

2. In a Hydrocephalus, and great Cathars, an I≈ø≈øue with great ≈øucce≈øs may be made in the Nape of the Neck, becau≈øe the Cavities of the Dura Mater are thereabouts joyned to the Jugular Veins; e≈øpecially in Children, in whom very often the Sutures do too much gape.
3. Fat things hurt the Head, becau≈øe it is not covered with many Mu≈øcles.

4. In the Skull ≈øometimes a rough matter is collected in ≈øeveral places, which if not remov'd by tho≈øe Medicines that purge Phlegm, and outward di≈øcu≈ø≈øives, in proce≈øs of time acquire a very great hardne≈øs, which ≈øtill increa≈øing, grow into a perfect Horn, not to be cured, but by Chirurgery.

5. Upon the Skull likewi≈øe comes other Ab≈øce≈ø≈øes, which although they may belong to a Steatoma, Atheroma, or Melicerides, yet in the Head e≈øpecially they are call'd Te≈øtudo, Talpa, Natta. The≈øe give little hope of Cure, where the Bone is much corrupted;
otherwi≈øe they may be taken away by a Thred, or what is better, by a Knife, when they reject other Remedies. The manner of taking them away by a Knife, is this; the Skin being divided in form of a Cro≈øs, the Bladder is to be taken out, then the Pericranium being ≈øeparated, the Cranium is to be ≈øcraped with a Ra≈øpatory, till you come to the ≈øound part, then ≈øprinkle upon it ≈øome A≈øtringent powder, and let the Skin forthwith be con≈øolidated again; which if it be too loo≈øe, a little part of it may be taken away, which is very ≈øeldom nece≈ø≈øary to be done, when it may be clo≈øed enough in the time of the Cure.

6. If the Sutures of the Skull are too open, they bring a weakne≈øs upon the Brain; if they are too ≈øtraightly united, they cau≈øe the pain of the Head. Experienc'd Chirurgions affirm, that it is as ≈øafe to u≈øe the Trepan in the very Sutures them≈øelves, as any other part of the Head.

7. The Mu≈øcles of the Head occa≈øioning nothing differing from other Mu≈øcles, except upon a Wound, or Contu≈øion of the temperal Mu≈øcle, a Convul≈øion ea≈øily follows; neither ought it to be tran≈øver≈øly divided, le≈øt there happen a di≈øtortion of the Mouth.

8. The Teeth, ≈øeeing they neither are furni≈øhed with Membranes, nor Nerves, are altogether in≈øen≈øible; but they which attribute the pain to tho≈øe Membranes which cover the Alveolus, it ought to be a≈øcribed to many Nerves that are di≈øtributed through them; yet the Cau≈øes in this Ca≈øe are various, and mu≈øt be well di≈øtingui≈øhed, to wit, 1. a hot Di≈øtemperature, 2. a cold di≈øtemperature, 3. a ≈øharp humor, 4. a ≈øolution of continuity.

In a hot di≈øtemper, Bleeding, and Purging is very nece≈ø≈øary; apply Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes to the Neck and Shoulders; let the Head be purged with Errhins: In the beginning, this Water being held in the Mouth, profits much.

Take the Roots of Tormentil an ounce; Leaves of Vervain, a handful and a half; Flowers of Balau≈øtians, two Pugils; Cypre≈øs Nuts, two drams; red-Saunders, three drams; Scales of Iron, one dram; Vitriol, two ≈øcruples; Ro≈øe-Vinegar, two ounces. Let them boil in a ≈øufficient quantity of Red-wine, to a pint and half; keep it for your u≈øe.
The Flux being ≈øtayed, we di≈øcu≈øs the remaining with the following Decoction.

Take the Roots of Bi≈øtort, three drams; of Flower-de-luce, two drams; Leaves of Sage, Hy≈øop, of each half a handful; Galls, a dram; Frankincen≈øe, Sandarach, of each two drams; Juniper-Berries, an ounce: Boil them in Red-Wine.

In a cold Di≈øtemperature, the Patient mu≈øt avoid all cold potable Medicaments, yea the very Air it ≈øelf, tho≈øe Medicines that purge Phlegm profit, Bleeding hurt. The following Medicine which is of great vertue may be held in the Mouth.

div.head: My Spirit for the Tooth-ach.
div.p:
Take ≈øhavings of Guaiacum, four ounces; Seeds of Stave≈øacre, Pomgranate-rinds, Galls, White-Frankincen≈øe, of each an ounce; Crude Opium, red flowers of Poppy, Camphore, White-Ginger, Cloves, Long-Pepper, of each half an ounce,
Leaves of Sage, Ar≈ømart, Tobacco, Hor≈øe mint, of each one handful; Roots of Henbane, Pellitory of Spain, Mandrake, Hounds tongue, Nettles the le≈øs, of each an ounce and half: Let them infu≈øe fourteen days in a ≈øufficient quantity of Spirit of Wine, then di≈øtil it in Balneo Mariae.

A ≈øharp Humor falling upon the Teeth, is cured almo≈øt in the ≈øame manner as a hot di≈øtemperatur; but if tho≈øe Remedies are not ≈øufficient, the following Mixture is to be u≈øed in a Spoon, which is not only of great virtue in this, but in all the other kinds of Tooth ach.

Take water of Plantane, an ounce and half; of Ro≈øes, Mint, of each an handful; Alexipharmick water, half an ounce; Cinamon-water, two drams; Julip of Ro≈øes, or Syrup of Red Poppies, an ounce; Laudanum Opiatum, three grains. Mix them.
In ≈øolution of continuity, and rottenne≈øs of the Teeth, it is be≈øt to pull them out.

In the Breeding of Teeth in Children, the pain may be mitigated with fre≈øh-butter and Virgins-Honey, or with a Decoction of the Brains of a Hare or Coney in Ale; but in a long pain it is very convenient to cut the Gum, to give pa≈ø≈øage to the Tooth.

9. From the Blood and mixt Humors ari≈øeth the Ophthalmia, ≈øometimes true, ≈øometimes ≈øpurious, ≈øometimes ≈øeizing on one Tunicle of the Eye, ≈øometimes on more; that which happens only in the great corner of the Eye, is call'd Aegylops; the white of the Eye may be vexed with little Bladders called Phlyctenae, which being broke, there follows an Ulceration, except ≈øtayed, corrupting the whole Eye.

But if this Ulcer ≈øeizeth only the Caruncle, & that the Punctum Lachrymale afterwards grows callous, it becomes a Fi≈øtula Lachrymalis. If the≈øe Di≈øea≈øes yield not to the≈øe Remedies propo≈øed in our Chirurgery, others are to be made u≈øe of; Phlectenae are ≈øoon removed by the following Powder.
Take white Sugar-Candy, prepared Tutty, of each half an ounce; red Coral prepared, Camphore, white Vitriol, Saccharum Saturni, of each two ≈øcruples: Mix them, and make them into a Powder.
A beginning Ulcer of the Eye requires fir≈øt mundifying, afterwards con≈øolidating Medicines.

div.head: A Mundifying Medicine.
div.p: Take Mirrhe, 15. grains; Aloes, ≈øix grains;
Sugar-Candy, one dram; the yolk of an Egg, Goats-milk, three ounces: Mix them.

div.head: A Con≈øolidating Medicament.
div.p: Take red Coral prepared, burnt Harts horn, Sarcocol of each a ≈øcruple; Dragons Blood, half a ≈øcruple; burnt-Lead, a ≈øcruple; Starch, half a dram; Crocus Metallorum, half a ≈øcruple; Gum Tragaganth di≈ø≈øolved in Ro≈øe-water, a dram; Hor≈øe-tail-water, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Collyrium.

If the Punct√ºm Lachrymale, in the great Glandule of the Eye be callous, and from the continual Flux of Humors, degenerates into a Fi≈øtula, fir≈øt, the Callo≈øity is to be removed, before the other accidents will cea≈øe, for which the following are u≈øed by us; the Phlegm and Spirit of Vitriol, burnt
Alom, blew Vitriol, Verdigreece, Mercury water, Aqua Fortis, Unguentum Aegyptiacum; but the be≈øt of all is Unguentum Fu≈øcum of Felix Wurtz, boil'd to the con≈øi≈øtence of a Suppo≈øitory, and put into the Fi≈øtula.
The Callo≈øity being taken away, the Ulcer may be cured by the following Medicine.

Take Roots of Flower-de-luce, round Birthwort, Bark of Frankincen≈øe, of each dram and half; Mirrhe, Ma≈øtick, Sarcocols, Aloes, Cadmia Fo≈ø≈øilis, of each a dram; Honey, as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into an Ointment.

If the Os Lachrymale, or Zygomaticum be foul, the Skin being divided, an actual or potential Cautery mu≈øt be applied, that the Caries may be removed, otherwi≈øe it is impo≈ø≈øible to cure the Fi≈øtula, that not taken away.

10. The pain of the Ears proceeds from a cold or hot di≈øtemperature, or from a ≈øolution of continuity, which oftentimes an Ulcer follows; for a cold di≈øtemperature, and what accompanies it, the Wind, be≈øides the common and particular Medicines, outwardly may be applied this with very good ≈øucce≈øs.
Take Oyl of Rue, Henbane, of each half a dram; of di≈øtilled Marjoram, half a ≈øcruple; Ca≈øtor, ≈øix grains; Ea≈øtern-Saffron, four grains: Mix them.

The Smoke of Tobacco blown through the bole of a Pipe put into the Ear, hath done good to many for the pain of the Ears, and for Deafne≈øs; oftentimes al≈øo a decoction of Cloves in Red Wine, hath profited, if two or three drops of it be in≈øtill'd warm into the Ear, and the Ear afterwards be ≈øtopt with one of the boil'd Cloves.
Two drops of the following Spirit, Morning and Evening dropt into the Ear, is excellent.

div.head: My Spirit for the Ears.
div.p: Take Ants-Eggs, No 100, Ca≈øtor, Pulp of Coloquintida, Marjoram, Savin, Wormwood, Rue, a handful; Seeds of Cummin, Ani≈øe, Fennel, Caraways, of each three drams; Bay-berry-husks pull'd off, Juniper-berries, of each half an once; Pomegranate-rinds, ≈øix drams; Roots of black Hellebore, round Cyprus, Raddi≈øhes, Sow-bread, of each an ounce; middle-≈øiz'd Onions, No vij. bitter Almonds, two ounces: Infu≈øe them 14 days in a ≈øufficient quantity of rectified Spirit of Wine, then di≈øtil them in Balneo Mariae.
In a hot di≈øtemperature, fir≈øt we ought to divert the Flux of humors by Bleeding, Purging, Scarifications, Gli≈øters, &c. then the following Medicines by Cotton inbibed, we may put into the Ear.
Take womans-Milk, two ounces; Whites of Eggs well beaten, half an ounce; Oriental Saffron, half a ≈øcruple; Goo≈øe-grea≈øe di≈ø≈øolved, two drams; Crude Opium, five grains: Mix them.
Or,
Take Oyl of Violets, ≈øweet Almonds, Ro≈øe-Vinegar, of each an ounce; Philonium Romanum, two drams; Ea≈øtern Saffron, half a ≈øcruple: boil them, and ≈øtrain them for your u≈øe.
Or,

Take Roots of Mar≈øh-mallows, an ounce; leaves of Mallows, of Mandrake, of each one handful;
Heads of Poppy, No. ij. flowers of Dill, Camomile, of each two handfuls; Lin≈øeed, three drams; boil them in Cows-Milk for a Fomentation.
The Flux and pain being cea≈øed, what yet remains, may be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed by tho≈øe Remedies but now ≈øet down in a pain from a cold di≈øtemperature.
Where the Inflamation Apo≈øtumates, which we under≈øtand by a Feveri≈øh Pul≈øe, and by the continual increa≈øing, we mu≈øt a≈ø≈øi≈øt Nature by ≈øuppurating Medicines.
Take Unguentum Ba≈øilicon, two drams; Oyl of Lin≈øeed, three drams: Mix them.
Or,
Take Goo≈øe grea≈øe, Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, of white Lillies, of each two drams: Mix them.
Or,

Take Roots of white Lillies, an ounce and half; a large Onion roa≈øted in the Embers, and beaten together; add to them the Meal of Mar≈øh-mallows, half an ounce; Lin≈øeed, ≈øix drams; fre≈øh-Butter, an ounce and half; Oyl of Camomile, & Lin≈øeed, of each half an ounce; Saffron, half a dram; Make it into a Poultice.

The Apo≈øtume being broke, the Ulcer is fir≈øt to be mundified; for which purpo≈øe are convenient Honey of Ro≈øes, of Centaury, the juice of Smallage, Fennel, Bete, Onions, Leeks, Decoction of Agarick, Lupins, Urine, Lye, Oxes-gall, Unguentum Aegyptiacum.
Then mu≈øt be u≈øed tho≈øe Medicines that may dry and con≈øolidate the Ulcer.

Take Roots of round Birthwort half a dram; of Flowerdeluce, a ≈øcruple; wa≈øh'd Ceru≈øe, prepared
Tutty, of each a dram; Mirrhe, Sarcocols, Litharge of Gold, of each two ≈øcruples; artificial Cinabar, half a dram; Scales of Iron, a ≈øcruple; Honey of Ro≈øes, as much as is ≈øufficient: Make it into an Ointment.
Where Worms come in an Ulcer from an impure matter, the following are convenient to kill them.
The juice of Wormwood, Centaury, Ar≈ømart, a decoction of Coloquintida, of white Hellebore, Ox-gall, Oyl of Wormwood, of bitter Almonds, &c.
Or,
Take Aloes, Mirrhe, of each two drams; Coloquintida, half a dram; tops of Wormwood, half a handful: Boil them in white Wine for an injection.

11. The No≈øe as well as the Ear is ≈øubject to inflamation, which pre≈øently in the beginning we are forced to remedy by the Medicaments formerly mentioned in an inflamation, le≈øt otherways its Cartilages ≈øhould become carious, which may cau≈øe a great deformity.

Sometimes a Tumour call'd a Polypus, ≈øeizeth the inward Cavity of it, occa≈øioned from impure and pituitous Blood; which is two-fold: for it either re≈øembles a Tent or Pellet, and is call'd by the general name Sarcoma, or it ≈øpreads it ≈øelf with many ≈ømall branches into the inward parts of the Mouth, or into the external parts of the No≈øe, & is in ≈øpecie call'd a Polypus; that which it of a whiti≈øh colour, not painful and ≈øoft, is ea≈øily cur'd; but that more difficultly, which is very red; never that which is livid, black or ≈øtinking; being touched, it turns into a Cancer, and over≈øpreads the whole Face.
The Cure of it is performed by Medicaments by a Thred, or by a Knife; in the beginning tho≈øe Medicines that are dry and a≈øtringent are mo≈øt convenient.

Take Pomegranate-rinds, flowers of Balau≈øtians, of each a dram; Cadmia Fo≈ø≈øilis, two drams; Crude Antimony, Crocus Martis, of each half a dram; Ma≈øtick, Mirrhe, Load≈øtone, Litharge, of each a dram: Make them into fine Powder.
The≈øe effecting nothing, Exedents are to be us'd.
Take burnt Alom, Bole-Armenick, Balau≈øtians, of each three drams: Make them into a Powder.
Another ≈øtronger.
Take Vitriol, half an ounce; Alom, Pomegranate-rinds, Galls, of each two drams; red Mirrhe, burnt Birthwort, of each a dram: Make them into a Powder.
Another yet ≈øtronger.
Take Vitriol, four ounces; Alom, Verdigreece, of each half an ounce; Vinegar, ≈øix ounces: Calcine them in a luted Ve≈ø≈øel.
Another, very effectual.
Take red and yellow Ar≈ønick, Alom, Galls, of each half an ounce: Make them into fine Powder
I have ≈øeen tho≈øe Tumors totally eradicated by the water wherein Mercury ≈øublimate is boiled.
But they ≈øeldom are cured by Medicine; for the mo≈øt part we u≈øe here an In≈øtrument de≈øcribed by S ‚Ä¢ nnertus and Aquapendens.

It may al≈øo be drawn forth with a pair of Forceps;
they may al≈øo be removed by a Thred (if it can be conveniently put about it) what remains may be cured by application of the Medicines but now mentioned.

12. The Mouth is inflamed upon many Cau≈øes; the chief are, 1. The heat of the Blood. 2. The acrimony and ≈øaltne≈øs of the Spittle. 3. A Rheum from the Head; generally there follows little Bli≈øters, and an Ulceration, which not being carefully looked after, turns to a Gangrene, e≈øpecially in Children after the ≈ømall Pox and Mea≈øles; in this ca≈øe, be≈øides the common Means, this is excellent.
Take Felix Wurtz his brown Ointment, two drams; Honey of Ro≈øes, an ounce and half; Spirit of Vitriol, half a ≈øcruple: Mix them.
13. Under the Tongue happens a Rannula or Baetrachios, a Tumor which is more frequently produced from Phlegm, than from any other part of the Blood; and it is often cured by this Powder.

Take Pepper, Ginger, of each a dram; Sal Gemmae, and common Salt, of each two ≈øcruples; wild Marjoram, Calamint, Ori≈øe-roots, Hermodactils, of each half a dram; Ma≈øtick, a ≈øcruple: Make it into a Powder.

Strew it often upon the Tumor, which if it goes not away, open it in one or more places, that the moi≈øture may come forth, and apply Honey of Ro≈øes to the Wound; ≈øome in this ca≈øe u≈øe an actual Cautery, but I rather approve of a Launcet.
14. For the Corruption of the Gums, this Powder is good.

Take Roots of Comfrey, Pomegranate-rinds,
of each a dram; Frankincen≈øe, Mirrhe, white Vitriol, of each half a dram; burnt Vitriol, a ≈øcruple: Make it into a Powder.
15. Epulis, a Tumor of the Gums mu≈øt be ≈øuddenly taken away by a Thred or Knife, le≈øt it ≈øhould turn into a Cancer.

16. For the taking off an ulcerated and rotten Uvula, Bartholine hath de≈øcribed an excellent In≈øtrument in his Anatomical Ob≈øervations; but it may be conveniently enough cut off with a pair of Sci≈ø≈øers, and the Bleeding may be ≈øtopt with Cyprus Vitriol, Unguentum Aegyptiacum, or the like, is ≈øufficient to perfect a Cure. Fabritius Hildanus judiciou≈øly took it away by the help of a Thred, which is to be imitated by them who fear an Inci≈øion.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the internal Parts of the Head.
div.p: NOw we approach Palas's Tower, which is ≈øometimes empty, and ≈øometimes fill'd with Folly; wherein, if an ill mind, be, as it were, a familiar Inhabitant, Virtue mu≈øt prudently look to it ≈øelf; but yet let it continue its Dominion, whil≈øt its Enemy in the mean time lurking in ≈øome corner, ≈øhall no where be at quiet.
Before we can enter into it, and look into the Brain, there are two Curtains to be drawn open, the Pia and Dura Mater.

The Dura Mater in the out≈øide rougher than in the in≈øide, encompa≈ø≈øeth the Brain very loo≈øly, le≈øt
its Arbitrary Motion ≈øhould be hindred, dividing the ≈øame by the help of certain foldings, which is call'd Falx, into the right and left part, and al≈øo ≈øeparating it from the Cerebellum. In this Falx are always found four Cavities, ≈øometimes ≈øeven; in which many of the branches of the Carotide-Arteries are in≈øerted, afterwards joining with the Jugular Veins.
The≈øe Cavities have the u≈øe and ≈øub≈øtance of Veins, ≈øo that they may not unproperly be reckoned among the Veins.

The Pia Mater is more ≈øen≈øible, & hath more Arteries than the Dura, which doth not only inve≈øt the whole Brains, but al≈øo enters the winding every where; which, for this cau≈øe may more ea≈øily be ≈øeparated.
We do divide the Brain into three Parts, which are, 1. The Brain it ≈øelf. 2. The Spinal Marrow. 3. The Cerebellum, or little Brain.

The Brain is of an A≈øhy colour, and of a ≈øofter ≈øub≈øtance than Marrow (which is both whiter and ≈øolider) whence al≈øo it was wont to be call'd Rind; it receives ≈øeveral Branches from the Carotide-Artery, and is de≈øtitute both of Nerves and Sen≈øe.
It hath divers turnings and windings, which fold in deeply, e≈øpecially tho≈øe in the fore-part of the Head, where the great Fi≈ø≈øure divides the Brain outwardly even to the Marrow.
The Marrow is the Mother of all Nerves; within the Skull 'tis call'd the Marrow of the Brain; but without it is termed the Spinal Marrow.
The Cerebellum, or little Brain, is more of an A≈øh-colour than White, receives Arteries from the Cervicalis and Carotide; yet there are fewer branches here than in the Brain, as being much le≈øs.
It hath no windings, but is made up as it were of ≈øeveral thin plates lying one upon another.
The≈øe being thus con≈øidered, the Anatomi≈øt takes off ≈øome part of the Brain with a Knife, & forthwith the Corpus Callo≈øum, and the Fornix joyning to it, come in view.
Under the≈øe laterally lie two great Ventricles, in figure re≈øembling a Hor≈øe-hoof, which the Septum Lucidum di≈øtingui≈øheth into the right and left, or into the fir≈øt and ≈øecond.
In them is contained the Rete-Mirabile, or Plexus Choroides, con≈øi≈øting of many little Glandules, compo≈øed from the branches of the temporal Artery, twi≈øted together in form of a Net.
In the fore-part the≈øe Ventricles are united, and make a third.

In this third Ventricle are two Cavities; the fir≈øt of them runs to the Infundibulum, and to the Glandula Pituitaria, the other to the fourth Ventricle contained in the Cerebellum; above this Ventricle are ob≈øerved four round Bodies, which are call'd Te≈øtes and Nates, to which joyns the Glandula Pinealis, which is fal≈øly call'd by ≈øome the ≈øeat of the Soul‚ñ™ Of late the famous Sylvius hath demon≈øtrated it not to re≈øide in the Ventricles, but without them; by whom al≈øo it is e≈øteem'd but a Glandule: and that with more rea≈øon, becau≈øe that both he and I have found in it not ≈øeldom two or three Stones, but ≈øometimes four, which we yet keep by us.

The Bodies being removed, eight pair of Nerves appear, which we have already treated of; on the fore-part of whom joyns the Rete Mirabile of Galen, which is a complication of the Cervical and Carotide-Arteries.
After the≈øe, the Cerebellum comes in view, like a double Globe, in the mid≈øt of which is the Proce≈ø≈øus vermiformis, and Pons Varolii, under it lies the fourth Ventricle.
La≈øt of all, the Spinal Marrow ≈øhews it ≈øelf, divided in its beginning into two Parts, not unlike a Writing-Pen, which de≈øcending down the Back, imparts its branches over the whole Body.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: 1. In Wounds of the Dura Mater, two Symptoms render their Cure very trouble≈øome, to wit, a Flux of Blood and extream Pain; if the Skill be not ≈øufficiently open, without any delay the Trepan is to be applied on the Part affected, and forthwith the extrava≈øated and grumous Blood being di≈øcharged, let this Ointment be applied.
Take Manna of Frankincen≈øe, two drams; Aloes, one dram; Mirrhe, a dram and half; the ≈øofte≈øt Hares hair, half a ≈øcruple; white of an Egg, as much as ≈øufficieth to make it into a Liniment.
The Powder is al≈øo very u≈øeful, that is de≈øcribed in the Chapter of particular Wounds, in the ≈øecond Part of this Chirurgery.
To mitigate the pain, Oyl of Ro≈øes, Violets and Myrtles u≈øed warm, as al≈øo the warm Blood of a Hen or Pigeon, &c. is very much commended.
The Flux of Blood and the Pain being cea≈øed, the following Medicines are to be u≈øed, which are not to be left off, unle≈øs the Matter begins to flow too plentifully.
Take Oyl of Turpentine, two ounces; Spirit of Wine, Syrup of Wormwood, of each an ounce: Mix them.
But if a Gangrene or Putrefaction ≈øhould happen, the following Liniment is of great u≈øe.

Take Sarcocols, Mirrhe, Aloes, of each a dram: Syrup of Wormwood, Honey of Ro≈øes, of each two drams; Ung. Aegyptiacum, two drams and an half; Aq. vitae, an ounce and half; White-Wine, an ounce: Let them boil gently, then ≈øtrain them.

Neither do I apprehend any danger is to be feared in the taking off part of this Membrane when putrifi'd, ≈øo that you can come at it with a pair of Sci≈ø≈øers, and that the Sinus or Pia Mater be not hurt.

2. When the Pia Mater is likewi≈øe affected, the Chirurgion mu≈øt ab≈øtain from all Oyls, although they be drying, le≈øt a Corruption of the ≈øoft Brain be caus'd: Drying Cephalick powders are very convenient to be u≈øed here. But ≈øeeing that the≈øe Wounds for the mo≈øt part are Mortal, I ≈øhall ≈øay no more of them.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Neck.
div.p: THe Neck under the Scarf-skin, Skin, and fle≈øhy Membrane, and the common and proper Membrane of the Mu≈øcles, hath of each ≈øide four Mu≈øcles.
Of the≈øe, the Longus and Scalenus bend it.
Tran≈øver≈øalis and Spinatus draw it back of each ≈øide.
It hath five Veins, Cervicalis, Mu≈øcula Superior and Inferior, Carotis, Interna and Externa.
And as many Arteries, Cervicalis, Mu≈øcula Superior & Inferior, Carotis Interna & Externa.
It hath Nerves from the Par Vagum, and the Spinal Marrow.
In the fore-part of it, are many Glandules, which are greater in Women than in Men.

Under the≈øe the Larinx, the Organ of the ≈øound lies, compo≈øed of five Cartilages, which are,
1. Thyroides, or Buckler-like.
2. Crycoides, or Annular.
3. Arytenoides.
4. Glottis.
5. Epiglottis.

It is moved by ≈øix pair of Mu≈øcles, which are,
1. Hyothyrodaei, the pair that lift up the Larinx.
2. Bronchii, the pair that pull it down.
3. Cricothiroidaei antici, the pair that dilate.
4. Cricothiroidaei laterales, pur≈øing it together.
5. Thyro-arythenoidaei, that open it.
6. Arythenoidaei, Sphincters that clo≈øe it.
After the≈øe, the Almonds or Pari≈øthima (by ≈øome call'd Ton≈øils) offer them≈øelves; then the Pharynx, to which appertain ≈øeven Mu≈øcles, by who≈øe a≈ø≈øi≈øtance the Meat and Drink are ≈øwallowed.
1, 2, Sphenopharyngaei, which rai≈øe up the Pharinx.
3, 4. Cephalopharyngaei, moving it inward.
5, 6. Stylopharyngaei, dilating it.
7. Con≈øtrinctor or ≈øphynctor, which clo≈øeth the Gullet.
The back-part of the Neck hath ≈øeven Vertebra's, the proce≈ø≈øes of ≈øome of which are perforated, to give pa≈ø≈øage to the Ve≈ø≈øels that carry the Blood into the Brain.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: 1. We have already ≈øufficiently treated of the Cure of Scrophulas or the Kings Evil; I will only give you here the Oyl of Langius, who≈øe Virtues are very excellent, not only in the Kings Evil, but al≈øo in malignant and ≈øordid Ulcers, if it be carefully u≈øed.

Take Oyl of Philo≈øophers or Brick, half a pound; Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, Gum Arabick, Turpentine, of each three drams; pound them togather, & di≈øtil them in an Alembick; then add to the di≈øtillation Salt of Holm-Oak, two drams; and di≈øtil it again, and re≈øerve the di≈øtillation in a Gla≈øs for u≈øe.
In the room of the Salt of Holm-Oak, which grows not in Holland, Sal Gemmae may ≈øerve in≈øtead of it.

2. In a Hernia gutturis, or Bronchocele, ≈øeldom Medicaments effect any thing, when for the mo≈øt part the Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe (to wit, preternatural Phlegm mixt with Wind) is contained in a peculiar Bladder, and the Tumor lies under the Mu≈øcles, having its Original not from the Glandules, but from the A≈øpera Arteria, or Wind-pipe; yet in the beginning, the following do good.

Take Roots of Ireos, Galangal, of each a dram and half; Penny-royal, Savory, Rupture-wort, of each a dram; Seeds of Fennel, Anni≈øe, of each a dram; Par≈øly-≈øeeds, half a dram; Long-Pepper, Spikenard, Nutmegs, Cinamon, of each two drams Mirrhe, half a dram; Burnt-Alom, half an ounce; White Sugar, three ounces: Make it into a fine Powder.
Let the Patient take of this Powder each Morning a dram and half in White Wine.

Take Gum Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Bdellium, di≈ø≈øolved in Vinegar, of each an ounce; powder of Orri≈øe-roots, two drams; Mu≈øtard and Nettle-≈øeeds, of each a dram; Pulp of Coloquintida, Ea≈øtern Saffron, of each a ≈øcruple; Sal Gemmae, Alom, of each a dram; Naval-Pitch, ≈øix drams; Ro≈øin of the Pine, an ounce: Make it into a Plai≈øter.

The≈øe Medicines effecting nothing, after this manner the Tumor may be taken away. Fir≈øt, Take up the Skin, and divide it long-ways; then it being ≈øeparate of each ≈øide to the bottom, from the Tumor, take out the Bladder, whole if po≈ø≈øible; for if any part of it be left behind, the little Artery which brings nouri≈øhment to the Tumor, mu≈øt be divided; le≈øt it increa≈øe a new. Then let the Part affected be wa≈øhed with Vinegar, wherein a little Salt and Nitre hath been di≈ø≈øolved; for the Flux of Blood is not in this ca≈øe at all con≈øiderable; La≈øtly, Bring the Lips of the Wound together with a ≈øtitching Pla≈øter, it being not nece≈ø≈øary to u≈øe a Needle here.
Of the Angina and luxation of the Vertebra's of the Neck, we have ≈øpoken of in their places.

div.head: The THIRD BOOK Of the Thorax or Brea≈øt.
CHAP. I. Of the External Parts of the Brea≈øt.
div.p: THe middle Region of the Body, who≈øe upper part is call'd the Shoulders, fore-part the Brea≈øt, hinder-part, the Back; under proper and common Teguments, hath proper and common Mu≈øcles.
The common are tho≈øe of the lower Belly and Scapula's; tho≈øe we have ≈øhewn already; the≈øe are four.
1. Serratus Anticus minor, which brings the Scapula forward.
2. Trape≈øius, or Cucullaris, which moves it upward, and obliquely backward.
3. Romboides, which moves it obliquely downwards.
4. Levator.
The proper Mu≈øcles of the Thorax are twelve,
1. Subclavius or Exten≈øor.
2. Serratus Anticus major, or the inferior rai≈øer up the Ribs.
3. Serratus po≈øticus ≈øuperior, or the ≈øuperior ri≈øer up of the Ribs.
4. Serratus po≈øticus inferior, or the depre≈ø≈øor of the Ribs.
5. Sacrolumbus, which draws the Brea≈øt together.
6. Triangularis, which likewi≈øe draws the Brea≈øt together.
Under the≈øe Mu≈øcles lie the Brea≈øts, in both Sexes abounding with quantity of Fat, and in the Female with many Glandules.
The Back and Loins (who≈øe Mu≈øcles in this place we are forced to de≈øcribe) have four pair of Mu≈øcles.
1. Quadratus, or the flexor of the Vertebra's.
2. Longi≈ø≈øimus, or fir≈øt extender of the Vertebra's.
3. Sacrum, or the ≈øecond extender.
4. Semi≈øpinatum, or the rai≈øer up of the Back.
After the Mu≈øclers, follow the Collar-bones, the Shoulder-blades, the Brea≈øt-bone, the Ribs, and the Vertebra's; of the Veins, Arteries and Nerves we have formerly treated.
The Clavicles, or Collar-Bones, being ≈øpungy bones, are joyned to the upper proce≈øs of the Shoulder-blade, by ≈øtrong Ligaments and movable Cartilages.
The Scapula or Shoulder-Blade is a broad and thin Bone, lying upon the out≈øide of the Ribs, furni≈øhed with two Ligaments, three proce≈ø≈øes, and five appendices.

The Sternum, or Brea≈øt Bone being di≈øtingui≈øhed in Infants, by ≈øeven or eight lines, and by three or four in old people, is very ≈øpungy, and
hath in its lower part a Cartilage, call'd Cartilago en≈øiformis or mucronata.

The Ribs in each Sex are twelve; the ≈øeven uppermo≈øt, which are the true, are joyned with a double Tubercle to the Vertebra's, but with a Cartilage to the Sternum, are hard and round; the five lowermo≈øt, which are the Ba≈øtard-Ribs, are le≈ø≈øer, ≈øofter and ≈øhorter, having Cartilages about the Os Sternum, but not touching it.

Between the≈øe Ribs on each ≈øide, are Mu≈øcles found, which are call'd Interco≈øtals, eleven within, and as many without; ≈øo that in all there are forty four, the Fibres here are placed cro≈øs-wi≈øe.
In the Cavity of each Rib, formed in the lower part of it, re≈øides a Vein, Artery and Nerve, which extend them≈øelves into the middle of the fore≈øaid Mu≈øcles.
The Vertebra's of the Back are for the mo≈øt part accounted twelve, and have nothing con≈øiderable.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: I omit here divers operations, having already treated largely enough of them before.

What now offers it ≈øelf, is a Fi≈øtula of the Brea≈øt, of a more difficult cure in that, than in any other part, by rea≈øon of the continual motion of the Mu≈øcles; therefore 'tis highly nece≈ø≈øary to di≈øtingui≈øh the≈øe Fi≈øtula's; for the oblique do very hardly admit of any Cure: Tho≈øe that perforate the Brea≈øt, are not ea≈øily made whole again; tho≈øe that have their ri≈øe from between the Pleura and the Mu≈øcles, the matter
falls down; whence it comes to pa≈øs, that afterwards it is difficultly di≈øcharged; therefore in this ca≈øe there nece≈ø≈øarily is a ≈øhort breathing, and a ≈ølower motion of the Brea≈øt: The Callous is to be removed by the ≈øame Remedies we have ≈øet down in the Chapter of Fi≈øtula's, and ≈øo ≈øometimes the Pleura, and the fle≈øh of the Mu≈øcles unite again; but if the≈øe effect nothing, let the Chirurgeon put a little crooked Silver-pipe into the Fi≈øtula, ≈øo that the end of it may touch the bottom, through which let him pa≈øs a Needle fitted with Silk, an≈øwering to the crookedne≈øs of the Pipe, which being done, let him with the Needle perforate the Skin, then the Needle being drawn through, let both ends of the Thred be tied together, and the Thred every day be anointed with ≈øome Exedent Medicines, and the Callo≈øity being taken away, let the Ulcer be skinned. The In≈øtruments which are u≈øed in this ca≈øe, are de≈øcribed in Tab. 38. Figure 5. of Scultetus, of the old Edition.

The Brea≈øts of Women often in tho≈øe that give ≈øuck, from the great quantity of Milk, wax hard and painful, and by the Dutch is called Drop; which affect may be cured in one days ≈øpace, with compound Ointment of Mar≈øhmallows, the watry matter being ≈øuckt out by a Woman or Whelp: but this di≈øcharge being neglected or delayed, every day the Brea≈øt grows harder and harder, nay, becomes enflamed; then Bleeding, Purging, Sweating is requi≈øite: Outwardly this Catapla≈øm may be applied.

Take meal of Mar≈øhmallows, of Fenugreek, of each an ounce; Flowers of Elders, Camomile,
of each an handful; red Ro≈øes, two pugils; Crums of cour≈øe Bread‚ñ™ an ounce and half: Boil them in Ale, adding to them of Ro≈øe-Vinegar, an ounce. Make a Catapla≈øm.
The Flux of Humors and Pain being cea≈øed, the remaining may be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed by the following Catapla≈øm.

Take Meal of Beans, of Lin≈øeed and Fenugreek-≈øeed, of each an ounce; Cummin-≈øeed, three drams; boil them in Wine, adding to it compound Ointment of Mar≈øhmallows, Oyl of Camomile, of each half an ounce: Make it into a Catapla≈øm.
When it begins to apo≈øtumate, Maturatives are to be u≈øed.

Take Leaves of Mallows, Mar≈øhmallows‚ñ™ of each a handful; Powder of Lin≈øeed, an ounce; of Fenugreek-≈øeed, an ounce and half; Leaven, half an ounce; boil them in Milk, adding to them ∆≤nguentum Ba≈øilicon, an ounce; Saffron, a ≈øcruple: Make it into a Catapla≈øm.

The Tumor being ≈øuppurated, mu≈øt be opened with a Cau≈øtick; or, what is better, with a Launcet, and put a Tent into it, dipt in common Bal≈øom of Brim≈øtone until the end of the Cure; laying upon the Brea≈øt Empla≈øtrum Dia≈øulphuris Bulandi.

3. A Gibbo≈øity ari≈øeth from the ≈øpine of the Back, when the Vertebra's are removed outwardly, or of one ≈øide, from their natural place; which is occa≈øioned ≈øometimes by an External Cau≈øe, ≈øome by an Internal, e≈øpecially when ≈øome pituitous Humor is collected about them; this Humor mu≈øt be taken away by di≈øcu≈ø≈øive Oyl; and Plai≈øters, before what is ≈øtarted out,
can by a Steel-compre≈øs, fitted to the Body of the Patient, be reduced: This reduction is not ≈øo much performed by the Compre≈øs, as it is by the Emollient quality of the Iron: For this rea≈øon, it is nece≈ø≈øary that the Patient, though cured, for a year or more after, u≈øe another Bandage, that the ≈øoft Bones may not again ≈øtart out.

It is here likewi≈øe to be ob≈øerved, that in the middle of the Back, about the ≈øeventh Vertebra, with great ≈øucce≈øs may an I≈ø≈øue be made, to intercept Rheums flowing to the Hip, Kidneys, Feet, &c.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Internal Parts of the Thorax.
div.p: THe Brea≈øt now comes to be opened, that we may view the Fountain of Life, which the Cele≈øtial Truth affirms to con≈øi≈øt in the Blood; for what rea≈øon is it therefore that the Sovereign Sanguification is not attributed to the Heart, where every where, and by all, it is call'd the Original of Life.

Within, the Brea≈øt is inve≈øted by the Pleura, which is afterward doubled, and at length quadrupled, extending it ≈øelf from the Vertebra's to the Sternum, and then it is called Media≈øtinum, dividing the Lungs and Thorax.
Near to the Throat there adheres to the Media≈øtinum, a Glandulous Body call'd Thymus.

The Lungs drawing in the Air, & ≈øo cooling the Heart, is furni≈øhed to this purpo≈øe with a Trachea,
A≈øpera Arteria, or Wind-pipe; this lies upon the Gullet, and con≈øi≈øts of Cartilaginous Rings, and a double Membrane.
The outermo≈øt of the≈øe Membranes which is the thinner, ari≈øeth from the Pleura; the innermo≈øt, which is the thicker, from the Dura Mater.
The annulary Cartilages are joyned together with Ligaments, and make not a perfect Circle, as being de≈øtitute of a fourth part that lies upon the Gullet.
The Wind-pipe di≈øtributes Branches through the whole Lungs, which are ≈øtrong enough, but not at all Cartaliginous.
The Lungs them≈øelves covered with a thin, porous Tunicle, con≈øi≈øt of a ≈øoft, red, ≈øpongy ≈øub≈øtance.
In the fore-part they adhere to the Sternum; in the back-part to the Vertebra's, filling the greate≈øt part of the Brea≈øt.
It hath ≈øeven le≈ø≈øer Ve≈ø≈øels, of which we ≈øhall ≈øpeak in their places.

The Heart, the Work-hou≈øe of the Blood, the Fountain and Origin of Life, as the Sacred Writ it ≈øelf al≈øo witne≈ø≈øeth, is included in a certain Ca≈øe, call'd by Anatomi≈øts, Pericardium: It con≈øi≈øts of two Membranes, the outermo≈øt comes from the Media≈øtinum; the innermo≈øt from the Ve≈ø≈øels of the Heart; it contains a clear watry Liquor, void of all Acrimony, which we no longer doubt of to be brought from the Ductus's of the Limpha.
The Heart it ≈øelf con≈øi≈øts of a fle≈øhy, ≈øerene and hard ≈øub≈øtance, which is inve≈øted with a proper Tunicle, furni≈øhed with Fibres of all ≈øorts, and like a Mu≈øcle is continually moved.
It is placed in the middle of the Brea≈øt, but the point of it inclines ≈øometimes to the left ≈øide.
In Figure it is like to a Pine-Apple, having in its upper part two Auricles or little Ears, which alwayes beat before the Heart it ≈øelf.

In old people, the right Auricle is bigger than the left, which in Infants is the contrary; in the throwing forth of the Blood, the Auricles, as well as the Heart it ≈øelf, are pur≈øt together, and dilated as often as they take in the Blood; and this Con≈øtriction and Dilation makes the Pul≈øe.
For the concoction, reception and throwing forth of the Blood, it hath two Cavities, and four Ve≈ø≈øels.

The Cavities are di≈øtingui≈øhed by a fle≈øhy Divi≈øion, in which I could not yet find any way appointed for the motion of the Blood out of the right Ventricle into the left, although many Anatomi≈øts do certainly affirm it.

The≈øe Cavities are divided into the right and left; the right, which is the greater, receives the Vena Cava, and Arteria pulmonalis, or Vena Arterio≈øa; the left, which is the lea≈øt, receives the Arteria aorta, or great Artery, and Vena pulmonalis, or Arteria veno≈øa.
Of the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels, as al≈øo of the Nerves, and Chylous pa≈ø≈øages, or the Thoracick lacteal Veins, we have treated of in the fir≈øt Book.
Under the Wind-pipe in the Cavity of the Brea≈øt, lies the Oe≈øophagus or Gullet, re≈øting upon the Vertebra's.

About the fifth Vertebra of the Back, it inclines a little to the right ≈øide, that it may give way to the Arteria aorta, unto the eleventh
Vertebra; thence with a ≈øtraight Ductus it pa≈ø≈øeth the Diaphragm into the lower Belly.

It con≈øi≈øts of a double Membrane; the outermo≈øt is fle≈øhy, having ≈øtreight and round Fibres, the innermo≈øt tran≈øver≈øe and oblique: Many add to the≈øe a third from the Peritonaeum, and rightly in my opinion.

The Diaphragm, in nature of a Fan, ≈øerving to re≈øpiration, divides the Thorax from the Abdomen, and adheres to all the Ba≈øtard-Ribs, to the Cartilage of the Brea≈øt-bone about the Vertebra's, ≈øending two fle≈øhy Proce≈ø≈øes to the lower parts.
Its edges round about are fle≈øhy, variou≈øly movable like a Mu≈øcle, but its Center Membranous and very ≈øen≈øible.

It hath three perforations, 1. In the middle of it, through which the Vena Cava pa≈ø≈øeth. 2. In the left ≈øide, through which the Gullet, with the adjacent Nerves. 3. About the Vertebra's, for the pa≈ø≈øage of the Arteria aorta, with the Vena azygos.

It receives more Nerves than any other part of the Body from the Collar-Bones to the Feet, which ari≈øe not only out of the Brain, from the Parvagum, but al≈øo from the Spinal Marrow, and from the fifth and ≈øixth Vertebra of the Neck. Of the other Ve≈ø≈øels we have already treated.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p:
The Pleura is not only ≈øubject to Inflammation, upon which follows a Pleuri≈øie, an Empiema, and Impo≈øtumation; but al≈øo a certain pain, which a ≈øalt Humor produceth: This may
be di≈øtingui≈øhed from a Pleuri≈øie, becau≈øe here is a dry Cough, yet no Fever, al≈øo free breathing enough. I have u≈øed to remove this by Bleeding and Sweating, and if you fear a Pleuri≈øie, apply outwardly this Plai≈øter.

Take Marrow out of an Oxes-bone, Ducks-grea≈øe, of each three ounces; the Mu≈ø≈øilage of Mar≈øhmallows, Lin≈øeed, Fenugreek-≈øeed, of an ounce; Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, of each half an ounce; Oyl of Nuci≈øta expre≈øt, two drams; yellow Wax, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Plai≈øter.

2. Media≈øtinum, hath not ≈øo great a Cavity in Man, as in Dogs and other creatures; yet it happens ≈øometimes that a purulent matter de≈øcends between the two Membranes of it, which can by means be evacuated by the Lungs; therefore we are forced to perforate the Sternum with a Trepan, that ≈øo through the made Orifice, by the u≈øe of Tents, Spunges and other In≈øtruments, the Matter may be di≈øcharged.

3. In that kind of Quin≈øey, which we above call Cynanche, where the Patient is almo≈øt ≈øuffocated, we remedy by Laringotomia, or opening the Wind-pipe; the Di≈øea≈øe it ≈øelf is far more dangerous than this Operation; therefore it would be well if it was oftener practi≈øed; neverthele≈øs there is required a diligent con≈øideration, that the other parts, to wit, the Lungs, Pleura, Gullet, &c. be not al≈øo enflamed, or already full of matter, which may fru≈øtrate your labour, & afford cau≈øe of ≈øcandal; but every thing being well weighed, the Operation is to be performed in this manner; Let the Head be a little bent backwards, that the Wind-pipe may
the more plainly appear, and the annulary Cartilages recede the further the one from the other; then divide the Skin according to the length of the Larinx unto the hollow, and let a ≈øtander-by with his Fingers pluck open the Skin of each ≈øide, that the Chirurgeon may ≈øee the two long Mu≈øcles, Sterno hyoidei, which he mu≈øt remove a little a≈øunder either with a Knife of Wood or Bone; then the Larinx appearing, he mu≈øt make his Inci≈øion with a Launcet, in the middle between the third and fourth annulary Cartilage, taking great care that he hurt not the Cartilages them≈øelves; upon the Breaths coming forth, take out the Knife, and put a Silver Pipe into the Wound, which mu≈øt not be ≈øo long as to reach the hinder part of the Wind-pipe, le≈øt it cau≈øe a continual Cough; the danger of ≈øuffocation being over, which for the mo≈øt part happens to be about the third or fourth day, or at lea≈øt ought then to be, the Pipe mu≈øt be taken forth, and the Wound is to be cured in the ordinary manner according to Art, from which it differs not.

4. 'Tis no new thing for Worms to generate in the Pericardium, which, except kill'd, corrode the very Heart it ≈øelf. They may be de≈øtroyed with a Decoction of Scordium, Wormwood, Centaury, &c. drunk twice or thrice a day.
Concerning the Wounds of the Lungs, Heart and Diaphragm, ≈øee our Chirurgery. A Wound of the Gullet is cured after the ≈øame manner as that of the Stomach.
