div.head: The FOURTH BOOK. Of the Lower Belly.
CHAP. I. Of the External Parts of this Belly.
div.p: THE lower Cavity, properly call'd the Belly, is divided into three parts; of which,
1. Is the Epiga≈øtrium, each ≈øide of which is call'd Hypochondria.
2. The Region of the Navel who≈øe ≈øides are call'd Ilium.
3. Hypoga≈øtrium, the ≈øides of which are the Groins.
The lower hairy part is call'd Pubes.
The Abdomen under common Teguments, hath ten Mu≈øcles, of each ≈øide five, very nece≈ø≈øary for the exclu≈øion of the gro≈ø≈øer Excrements contained in the Guts; they are the≈øe.
1. Obliquely de≈øcending, which in the upper part, the Navel; in the lower, in Man, the proce≈øs of the Peritonaeum; In Woman, the long Ligaments of the Womb perforates.
2. The Oblique a≈øcending.
3. The Recti, or ≈øtraight.
4. The Pyramidal.
5. The Trar≈øver≈øe.
In the middle of the Abdomen, between the two ≈øtraight Mu≈øcles, ari≈øeth the Linea Alba, or White-Line, from the meeting of the broad Tendons of the other thin Mu≈øcles, which is very ≈øen≈øible.

Of the Veins, Arteries & Nerves, both of the outward and inward parts of the lower Belly, we have already treated of in the fir≈øt Book; as likewi≈øe ≈øomething of the Bones. But the more curious Examiner meets withal, fir≈øt, five Vertebra's of the Loins, which are very full of holes, and greater and thicker than all the re≈øt.
Next to them follows the Os Sacrum, which is triangular; in old people being only of one Bone, but in young, con≈øi≈øting of five or ≈øix.
To this is joyned the Os Coccygis, bent in Women more outward, in Men more inward.
On the ≈øides of the Os Sacrum is the Os Innominatum, or Coxae, con≈øi≈øting of three Bones joyned together with a Cartilage. Of the≈øe,
1. Is the Os Ilium, much thicker in Women than in Men.
2. Os Pudis, more ea≈øily ≈øeparable in the fore-part in Women than in Men.
3. Os I≈øchion, or Coxae, furni≈øhed with a large Cavity, which is call'd Acetabulum or Pixis, appointed to receive the head of the Thigh-Bone.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øideration.
div.p:
The outward Divi≈øion of the Lower Belly, plainly declares what Internal Parts may be affected: In the right Hypochondrium, the Liver is
≈øituated, extending it ≈øelf beyond the Ba≈øtard-Ribs two fingers breadth, to the Sword-like Cartilage of the Sternum.

In the middle lies the Stomach, extending it ≈øelf to the ≈øofter parts of this Belly, ≈øo that it reacheth four fingers breadth beyond the Ba≈øtard-Ribs; Beyond the ≈øoft places near the Kidneys lies the Spleen.
In the middle of the ∆≤mbilical Region, and about it lies the Small Gut, which being wounded, is mo≈øt dangerous.

In the right ≈øide, about the Kidney, the Gut Colon takes its ri≈øe, tran≈øver≈øly running between the Stomach and Navel to the left Kidney, where winding downwards, and becoming narrower, is the frequent receptacle of Wind, and whence long pain and great ten≈øion, which is unde≈øervedly attributed to the Spleen on the other ≈øide, the Inte≈øtine re≈øts upon the Me≈øentery, as doth the Stomach upon the Pancreas.
In the middle of the Hypoga≈øtrium, are the Bladder and Womb placed, and under them the Inte≈øtinum rectum.
On the Side lie the Spermatick Ve≈ø≈øels, and the Glandules, in which both benign and malignant Buboes are produced.

But all the≈øe Parts cannot be wounded, except the Peritonaeum and Omentum be fir≈øt perforated, yet in many men the Omentum de≈øcends not below the Navel; and contrariwi≈øe in others, it reacheth to the Os Pubis it ≈øelf.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Internal Parts of the Abdomen.
div.p: THe fir≈øt of the Internal Parts is the Peritonaeum, comprehending all the others, before and behind, above and below.
It is a double Membrane; its ri≈øe is rather deduced from the membranous quality of the Soul, than from the Meninges of the Brain.
It is joyned to the Diaphragm, and to the fir≈øt and third Vertebra of the Loins.
It is thicker in Women from the Navel to the Privy Parts, and therefore ≈øtronger, terminating about the Os pubis.

In Men it is thicker from the Navel to the Diaphragm, and after it hath received the Spermatick Ve≈ø≈øels, as in a Sheath, it ≈øends them through the outer Membrane to the Te≈øticles, where it con≈øtitutes their fir≈øt Coat. Between the foldings of this Peritonaeum, lie four ∆≤mbilical Ve≈ø≈øels.
1. The ∆≤mbilical Vein.
2, 3. The two ∆≤mbilical Arteries.
4. ∆≤rachus, coming from the Navel, which is nothing el≈øe but an indurated knot of the afore≈øaid Ve≈ø≈øels.

In Infants the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels are open, in old people altogether clo≈øed, and turned into Ligaments: Yet I could never by any means ob≈øerve in Abortives of ≈øix, ≈øeven or eight months, the ∆≤rachum pervious into the Bladder; for neither Probe nor Wind would pa≈øs.
The Umbilical Vein goes to the Liver, the ∆≤rachus to the Bladder, both the Umbilical Arteries to the Iliack Branches of the great Artery.
The Omentum or Caul, keeping the Stomach and Inte≈øtines warm, is very fat and double; yet it con≈øi≈øts of very thin Coats, which are perforated with many little holes.
It takes its ri≈øe from the Peritonaeum, under which it al≈øo lies, for the mo≈øt part extending it ≈øelf as far as the Gut Colon, and ≈øometimes as far as to the Os Pubis.

The Stomach, the Work-hou≈øe of the Chyle, is compo≈øed of three Tunicles; the outwardmo≈øt is common from the Peritonaeum, the innermo≈øt from the Dura Meninx, the middlemo≈øt is proper to it ≈øelf; the fir≈øt is the thicke≈øt, the middlemo≈øt fle≈øhy, and the innermo≈øt wrinkled.
It hath Fibres of all ≈øorts, inwardly cru≈øted over with ≈øpungy fle≈øh.
It is ≈øituated in the middle of the Hypoga≈øtrium re≈øting upon the Vertebra's of the Loins; its left Orifice is called Os, or Stomachus; its right Orifice Pylorus.

The Guts are joyned to the Stomach, which convey the Chyle, and expel the Excrements; they are almo≈øt of the ≈øame ≈øub≈øtance with the Stomach, and are all divided very well into the thick and thin.
The thin Guts are,
1. The Duodenum, in which the Ve≈øica Fellea, with the Ductus Coledochus, and the new Ductus Pancreaticus are in≈øerted.
2. Jejunum, in which are more Lacteal Veins than in any of the re≈øt.
3. Ileon, which is the longe≈øt of all.
The thick Guts are,
1. Coecum, with its worm-like appendix.
2. Colon, with two outward Ligaments, and one internal Valve.
3. Rectum, with the two Mu≈øcles, Ani levatores, and with one Sphincter all the≈øe Guts are joyned together by the help of the Me≈øentery, and al≈øo to the Vertebra's of the Loins.

The Me≈øentery con≈øi≈øts of a double ≈øtrong Membrane, with many Glandules between each Membrane, which are ≈øo very ≈ømall, that they can ≈øcarce be perceived by the Eye; but commonly after a long ≈øickne≈øs, three excepted, they ≈øhew them≈øelves, and are greater than their natural con≈øtitution, long, white and hard.

The greate≈øt of them is ≈øeated in the mid≈øt of the Me≈øentery, which being pre≈øt, yields Milky juice, ≈øometimes thicker, otherwhile thinner, which is nothing but Chyle, as likewi≈øe do the other two, which for the mo≈øt part are in the left ≈øide, under the Emulgent Vein, above the Mu≈øcle P≈øoas, not far from the Vertebra's of the Loins.

As the≈øe Glandules receive many Lacteal Veins, ≈øo each of them again produceth a Branch, which forthwith being joyned together, make the Thoracick Lacteal Vein, which a≈øcending, as hath already been declared, carries the Chyle to the Heart.

The Pancreas or Sweet-bread, lies under the Stomach like a Pillow, joyned to the Gut Duodenum, into the which the late invented pa≈ø≈øage, from the Author, call'd Ductus Wyr≈øungianus, penetrates; in this is often Choler found, but never Blood.
The Spleen, which perfects the Blood, contains an Acid humor, which it ≈øends not to the Stomach by the Va≈øa brevia, but to the Liver by the Ramus Splenicus.
It con≈øi≈øts of a rare ≈øub≈øtance, covered with a proper Tunicle, not proceeding from the Peritonaeum.
It is of a darki≈øh red colour.

It joyns to the bottom of the Stomach by the means of the ≈øhort ve≈ø≈øels, and to the Ba≈øtard Ribs, and left Kidney, to the Caul & Peritonaeum, and to the fle≈øhy part of the Diaphragm, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Carnous Fibres.
There is no Bowel abounds with ≈øo many Arteries as the Spleen, except the Brain.
The Nerves, which it receives from our ≈øeventh pair, are di≈øtributed through its Tunicle, rather than through its Parenchyma.
It is not placed in the fore, but back-part of the left ≈øide, near the left Kedney, lying upon the Ba≈øtard Ribs and Vertebra's, which is to be well ob≈øerved.
The Liver, the In≈øtrument of Blood, Mother of the great Veins, is ≈øituate in the right Hypocondrium, and covers a great part of the Stomach.
It is divided (as it were) into two parts, by the Umbilical Vein, which after-birth ≈øerves it for a Ligament.
It is a great, thick and hard Body, of a red colour.
It is fa≈øtened to the Diaphragm by two Ligaments from the Peritonaeum, and to the Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen by the Umbilicial Vein.
Some few Arteries it receives from Coeliaca, and ≈øerveral Nerves from the Spinal Marrow, and from our ≈øeventh pair.

In the right ≈øide of it, underneath, is in≈øerted the Ve≈øicula Fellis, or Gall, with the Porus Biliarius; the branches of both together with the branches of the Vena Porta, are comprehended in a certain common Bladder, call'd by Gli≈ø≈øon, Cap≈øula; the≈øe branches of the Ve≈øica Fellis & Ductus Colydochus, or Biliarius, being detained in the Liver, are di≈øper≈øed through its whole Parenchyma, every where included in the above-named Cap≈øula, wch is red, about the thickne≈øs of an Artery, taking its Original, as it appears, from the Peritionaeum.
The External Branches being joyned, perforate the Gut Duodenum, taking two little Arteries from the Coeliaca, and Veins from the Vena Porta, call'd Gemelle, together with the Bladder it ≈øelf.
The Kidneys, which depurate the Blood, con≈øi≈øt of a peculiar hard fle≈øh, inve≈øted with a proper Tunicle,
Outwardly they are encompa≈ø≈øed with Fat, and with a large, loo≈øe Coat from the Peritonaeum.
They lie upon the Mu≈øcles of the Loins (yet the left is higher than the right) within the folding of the Peritonaeum.

And above the Kidneys are two hollowed Glandules, called Renaes ≈øuccenturiati, or Cap≈øulae atribilariae; the≈øe are furni≈øhed with Branches from the Emulgent Veins and Arteries, and with Nerves from the Par vagum.
The Kidney being opened, appear the nine Carunculae pupillares, through which the Serum di≈øtils into the Pelvis, to be carried through the Ureters into the Bladder.

The Ureters or the Urinary pa≈ø≈øage, whil≈øt
within the Kidneys them≈øelves, is very large, but when come from them, is very narrow; it is furni≈øhed all along with two Coats, the innermo≈øt is proper, the outer common from the Peritonaeum.

Within the duplicature of the Peritonaeum, it de≈øcends downward upon the Mu≈øcles of the Loins to the Bladder, into who≈øe Neck it is in≈øerted; then it a≈øcends upwards between the Membranes, where it perforates the innermo≈øt Coat; and through the ≈øame hole, together with the Ureter of the other ≈øide, enters the Bladder, which is ≈øo very little, & ≈øo ≈øtraightly clo≈øed, that there needs not here any Valve to hinder the return back again of the Urine.
Ve≈øicae ∆≤rinaria, or Bladder con≈øi≈øts likewi≈øe of two Membranes, the External is thick and fle≈øhy, the innermo≈øt not.
It is ≈øeated between the Duplicature of the Peritonaeum, in the Cavity of the Hypoga≈øtrium, which is commonly call'd Pelvis.
In Women it is joined before by its Neck to the Vagina uteri.

The Neck of the Bladder is very fle≈øhy, and by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Fibra's, like a Sphincter it opens and clo≈øeth the Bladder; in men it is longer, narrower, and more crooked; in Women, ≈øhorter, wider, and ≈øtraighter.
The Ve≈ø≈øels that bring Blood to the Bladder, are the branches of the Hypoga≈øtrick Ve≈ø≈øels; it receives many Nerves from the ≈øeventh pare, and from the Os Sacrum.
The Spermatick Ve≈ø≈øels yet remain, which wonderfully vary according to the diver≈øity of the Sex.
In Men the Spermatick Veins and Arteries fir≈øt appear, of each ≈øide one, which ≈øerve for the bringing of the Blood to the Te≈øticles for its preparation.
The right Spermatick Vein comes from the de≈øcending Trunk of the Vena Cava, the left from the left Emulgent, and both the Arteries from the great Artery.

The≈øe four Ve≈ø≈øels being very crooked, and covered by the Ureters, pa≈øs to the Te≈øticles; but before they come to them: near, and in the proce≈øs of the Peritonaeum, are united by ≈øeveral ino≈øculations, and joining them≈øelves with the Nerves, make one Body, which is call'd Pampiniforme.
The Te≈øticle, or Stones them≈øelves, the Organs of Seed, have each a Mu≈øcle, call'd Crema≈øter, they have two common Tunicles; and three proper.
The common are,
1. That wrinkled Pur≈øe which is call'd the Scrotum, to wit, the Skin which is thinner and ≈øofter than in other parts.
2. Dartos, to wit, the Carno≈øa Membrana, which hath many Ve≈ø≈øels.
The proper are,
1. Elytroides, ari≈øing from the proce≈øs of the Peritonaeum.
2. Erithroides, from the Mu≈øcle Crema≈øter.
3. Albuginea, from the Spermatick Ve≈ø≈øels.
The ≈øub≈øtance of the Te≈øticles is white, ≈øoft, thin, ≈øomething like to the Glandules.
Upon them with a tran≈øver≈øe ≈øituation lies the Corpus vermiforme, which ≈øen≈øibly becoming narrower, con≈øtitutes the Vas ejaculatorium, which is Epididymis, or Para≈øtata.
Vas ejaculatorium, is white and hollow like to the Ureters, which carries the Seed about the neck of the Bladder into the Ve≈øiculae ≈øeminales, where it is kept till a convenient time.
Proceeding a little further, before, you ≈øhall find two great Glandules, in which, an Oily Liquor is contained, to mitigate the acrimony of the Urine, the≈øe are called Pro≈øtatae.
At la≈øt comes the Penis or Yard, appointed for the evacuating of the Seed and Urine.
Its Sub≈øtance is peculiar to it ≈øelf, the like being not in the whole Body.
It hath no Scarf-skin, and is de≈øtitute of Fat, even in the mo≈øt fat Bodies.
It is covered with a loo≈øe Skin, which is double, and makes the Praeputium, and covers the Glans, to which it is tied by means of the Froenum or Bridle.
Under the Skin and fle≈øhy Membrane, lie the Ve≈ø≈øels above de≈øcribed.
Near to the≈øe are the four Mu≈øcles, which are the two Erectores, and the two Ejaculatores; under the Mu≈øcles, are two Nervous Bodies, which make the greate≈øt part of the Yard.
By their fungou≈øne≈øs, rendring it either ≈øtiff or flacid. In the lowe≈øt part of the Penis appears,
The ∆≤rethra, or pa≈ø≈øage for the Urine, con≈øi≈øting of two Coats, the innermo≈øt is very thin and ≈øen≈øible, the outermo≈øt thick and fle≈øhy.

In Women, the Spermatick parts in this, differ from Mens, that they are ≈øhorter and le≈øs, and by a wreathing and winding approach the Te≈øticles; likewi≈øe they communicate ≈øeveral Branches to the Uterine Tubes, and to the Womb it ≈øelf.
The ≈øofter Stones are placed on the ≈øides of the Womb, qualified to elaborate the Seed; they are covered with only one Coat, and that is proper.
They have no Para≈øtats. The Te≈øticles inwardly are full of little Bladders, which both contain the Seed, and by means of the Tubes conveigh it to the Womb.
The≈øe Tubes joyn to the Womb of each ≈øide, and to the Te≈øticles but only of one ≈øide.
The≈øe have a Cavity con≈øi≈øting of a double coat, which al≈øo contains ≈øome little Bladders, in which many will have the Seed to be further perfected.
The Womb, the receptacle both of the Seed and Child, is ≈øituate in the middle of the Hypoga≈øtrium, call'd Pelvis, between the ≈øtraight Gut and the Bladder.
It hath two ≈øtrong and thick Coats the fir≈øt, which comes from the Peritonaeum, the other is proper, and between both many fle≈øhy Fibres.
It is conveniently divided into the Fundus or Botton, the Orifice and the Neck.

The Fundus, the Globous part of the Womb, hath four Ligaments; the two uppermo≈øt are broad and membranous. which are joyned to the Os Ilium, the two lowermo≈øt are red and round, and pervious to the Clitoris, thence like a Goo≈øe-foot, de≈øtitute altogether of their hollowne≈øs, they ≈øpread them≈øelves upon the forepart of the Thigh.

The Ori≈øice of the Womb, which at one time can very ≈øtraightly clo≈øe it ≈øelf together, yet at another is very dilatable, hath in its lower
part a Tubercle or knotty ≈øub≈øtance, as al≈øo many little holes.

The Cervix or Neck of the Womb, appointed to receive the Penis, is very much wrinkled within, and almo≈øt eight inches long. To the Di≈ø≈øector comes fir≈øt in view the Meatus ∆≤rinarius, or the pa≈ø≈øage for the Urine, which is ≈øhort and ≈øtraight, then in this Cavity is the Clitoris ≈øeated, which is ≈øomething in ≈øoftne≈øs or hardne≈øs re≈øembling to a Mans Yard.

To this joyns the Hymen, perforated in the mid≈øt for the pa≈ø≈øage of the Urine and Cour≈øes, to which joyn four Caruncles, call'd Myrtiformes; then follows the Alae, Nymphae or wings which defend it, and the hairy Lips.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: 1. The Coats of the Peritonaeum grow very thick in Hydropick per≈øons, nay in proce≈øs of time they acquire a Cartilaginous hardne≈øs, which is very nece≈ø≈øary to be known; in a Paracenthe≈øis or opening of the Abdomen, there oftentimes ≈øuddenly follows a watry ≈øwelling in the Cod.

After a Paracenthe≈øis made by the formerly de≈øcribed In≈øtrument; the rea≈øon of it and the pa≈ø≈øage are true, that the Water by little and little ≈øinks down above the proce≈øs of the Peritonaeum, in the ≈øpace between the Peritonaeum and the right Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen.

2. Sometimes between the fouldings of the Caul is Wind detained, the cau≈øe of long continued pain, which brings along with it fear al≈øo of a future ab≈øce≈øs. In this ca≈øe, be≈øides
Sudorificks, we u≈øe di≈øcu≈ø≈øing Oyls and Plai≈øters. In the ≈øame folding is Water al≈øo ≈øometimes included, which promi≈øeth no certain hope of Cure.
Steatoma's and other Ab≈øce≈ø≈øes are often generated in the Caul, by rea≈øon of its great quantity of Fat, and its many Glandules, which are very difficultly cured.

3. The Guts, which move them≈øelves variou≈øly like to Worms, ≈øometimes they fall inwardly into one another, e≈øpecially when afflicted with great pain; in this ca≈øe the Excrements cannot pa≈øs to the Fundament: this Malady is call'd Mi≈øerere mei, or the Iliack Pa≈ø≈øion; ordinary means effecting nothing, a great Cupping-gla≈øs without Scarification, is often to be applied to the Part affected, and taken off again; but whether it is not better to divide the Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen and the Peritonaeum, and draw out with the Fingers the fallen-in Gut, than to ≈øuffer the Patient inevitably to die.

4. The Me≈øentery, from it ≈øelf, and al≈øo from the great number of the Glandules is ≈øubject to Inflammation, Tumors, ∆≤lcers, and to Corruption. The≈øe Di≈øea≈øes, ≈øeeing they are very difficultly di≈øtingui≈øhed from others, require an experienced Phy≈øitian; we llkewi≈øe ≈øpeak the ≈øame of the Sweet-bread, and of the Spleen: Yet in the mean time, I will communicate to you this Plai≈øter, who≈øe virtues I have often experienced in the Cure of the Tumor of the ≈øaid Parts.

Take Gum Caranna, Ammoniacum, of each a dram; Quick≈øilver kill'd with Turpentine,
half an ounce: Make it into a Plai≈øter.

5. The Ligaments of the Liver, which joyns it to the Diaphragm, and to the Sword-like Cartilage, are often ≈øo much relaxt, that the Liver de≈øcends to the Region of the Navel; this we remedy with this Plai≈øter.
Take Roots of Bi≈øtort, three ounces; Bole-Armenick, two drams; Cummin-≈øeeds, a dram; Gum Galbanum, an ounce; Ol. Nuci≈øtae expre≈øt, a dram: Make it according to Art into a Plai≈øter.
Moreover the Liver is not freed from Inflammations, ∆≤lcers, nay not from Gangrene it ≈øelf.
6. The Gall may be broke from an extream Cough; a Stone al≈øo, nay ≈øometimes many, are generated in it.
I was la≈øt year with a certain Scot, who in the ≈øpace of four weeks voided two hundred Stones and more by Stool, and was cured only by the u≈øe of the following purging Con≈øerve.
Take Electuary of the juyce of Ro≈øes, an ounce; Powder of Jalop, a dram; Spirit of Salt, a ≈øcruple: Make it into a Con≈øerve. Let him take each day or each other day the quantity of a Nutmeg.
7. For Wounds and ∆≤lcers of the Kidneys, our Chirurgery furni≈øheth you with ≈øufficient Medicines.

The ∆≤reters are al≈øo ≈øubject to Exulcerations, but are cured by the ≈øame means, which are proper in ∆≤lcers of the Kidneys: If they are broke either by a great Stone, or other Cau≈øe, the Di≈øea≈øe is accounted incurable.

8. Be≈øides Stones, Worms al≈øo are generated in the Bladder, which may be expelled by Diureticks
mixt with tho≈øe things that kill Worms.

Take Aqua Antinephritica, an ounce; Water of gra≈øs, two ounces; Spirit of Salt, ≈øix drops; Corallin, a ≈øcruple; Syrup of Wormwood, an ounce; Mix them. Let the Patient take one half in the Morning, the other in the Evening.
This injection al≈øo is covenient, it bringing them forth in a ≈øhort time.
Take Holy-Thi≈øtle-water, ≈øix ounces; Mirrhe, Aloes di≈ø≈øolved in Spirit of Wine, of each a ≈øcruple; Honey of Centaury, half an ounce: Mix them.
9. The Te≈øticles may as well as the other parts be inflamed; where, be≈øides the general means, the≈øe outwardly are convenient: In the beginning let this Catapla≈øm be applied.

Take Powder of Red-Ro≈øes, Myrtles, Balau≈øtians, of each two drams; Barley-Meal, two ounces and an half; Oyl of Ro≈øes, Elder-Vinegar, of each an ounce; Red Wine, as much as is ≈øufficient to make it into a Poultice.

div.head: In a vehement pain.
div.p: Take Meal of Linced, Barley and Fenugreek, of each an ounce; Leaves of Henbane, a handful; Mallows, half a handful; Hogs-grea≈øe, an ounce; Oyl of Poppy-≈øeeds, an ounce and half; Milk, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Catapla≈øm.

If after the Inflammation an Ulcer follows, let the Chirurgeon a≈ø≈øi≈øt Nature with Suppuratives; the following Plai≈øter is excellent to mollifie, ea≈øe pain, and to ≈øuppurate, which is
al≈øo very good in any other Tumor.

div.head: Empla≈øtrum Filii Zachariae.
div.p: Take Yellow-wax, Oxes-marrow, Hens and Ducks-grea≈øe, of each a pound; the Mu≈ø≈øilage of Lin≈øeed, Mar≈øhmallows, Fenugreek, of each four ounces; Oyl of Lin≈øeed, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Plai≈øter.

The matter being come to ≈øuppuration, mu≈øt be di≈øcharged, which the Chirurgeon may do with a Launcet; for I cannot commend to him here a potential Cautery, from which I have ob≈øerved very ill ≈øucce≈øs: Let the Orifice be little, and penetrate only the Tunicles, For in this ca≈øe although the matter be good, neverthele≈øs the di≈øea≈øe is dangerous, and ea≈øily degenerates into a Cancer or Gangrene, which cannot be taken away more conveniently than with a Knife, and mu≈øt be done at the fir≈øt appearance of it; then let the Chirurgeon endeavour to cure the Ulcer as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, after the following manner; let the Part be defended from all cold, and continually corroborated by Medicines, that the natural heat may be pre≈øerved in it: This Lotion u≈øed warm, is good.

Take Flowers of Balau≈øtians, Red-ro≈øes, Myrtles, of each two pugils; Aloes, a dram; Franckincen≈øe, two ≈øcruples; Plantane-water, three ounces; Red-wine, as much as ≈øufficeth: Boil them, and ≈øtrain them.
This being u≈øed, apply the following Ointment, putting over it a Plai≈øter or Catapla≈øm moderately di≈øcu≈ø≈øing.

Take prepared Tutty, Ceru≈øe wa≈øht, of each two drams; Red-lead, Litharge of Gold, of each a dram; Sarcocols, three drams; Burnt-lead, two drams; ∆≤nguentum Apo≈øtolorum, half an ounce; Oyl and Wax, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into an Ointment.
10. If the Yard be wounded, for the mo≈øt part it is mortal: This Ointment is very excellent.

Take wa≈øht Ceru≈øe, three drams; Mirrhe, Litharge, of each a dram and half; Sarcocols, prepared Tutty, of each a dram; Tragaganth, two drams; Oyl of Ro≈øes, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into an Ointment.

An Inflammation of it is cured in the ≈øame manner as an inflammation of other ≈øen≈øible parts; but if an External ∆≤lcer ≈øhould happen, the Cure mu≈øt be performed both by Internal and External Medicines, le≈øt it contracts a Malignity, and degenerates into a Sphacelus.

Take Litharge, half an ounce; Burnt-lead, three drams; prepared Tutty, two drams; Aloes, a dram and half; Pine-bark dried, four ≈øcruples; Lapis Haematitis, a dram; Seeds of Dill burnt, of Gourds burnt, of each two ≈øcruples; Oyl of Ro≈øes, Quick≈øilver, of each three drams; Wax, as much as ≈øufficeth to make an Ointment.
But if it yields not to this by rea≈øon of its foulne≈øs,
Take Verdigreece, half a dram; Water of Plantane and Ro≈øes, of each two ounces; White-wine, four ounces; Spirit of Wine, an ounce: Mix them, and boil them a little.
To this may be added, Mercury precipitate, if there be occa≈øion.
A Sphacelus in this ca≈øe, hath no certainer cure than extirpation in part, or wholly, le≈øt the mi≈øchief creep inwardly, and kills the Patient.

How the Internal ∆≤lcers of the Yard ought to be cured, we have ≈øet down in the Chapter of particular ∆≤lcers: But in this we may de≈øcribe this Medicine, by the u≈øe of which a Cancerous Yard was cured.

div.head: An ∆≤nguent of Peter Baierus.
div.p: Take the juice of the tops of Bramble, Stalks of Ro≈øes, Vinegar, of each two ounces‚ñ™ Franckincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, of each three drams; Litharge of Gold, an ounce; Sack, four ounces; Juice of Hou≈øleek, three ounces; Aqua vitae, four ounces: Verdigreece, two ounces and half; Vitriol, Burnt-alom, of each a dram and half; Camphire, a dram; Oyl of Ro≈øes, four ounces: Powder tho≈øe things that are to be powdred, very fine, and being ≈øearched, let them boil all together upon a gentle fire, except the Camphire, which is to be put in at the end, to the con≈øumption of the Juices, then add the Wax, and make it into an Ointment.
11. The Spermatick Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øometimes in Women, are ≈øo greatly ob≈øtructed, that together with the Te≈øticles in the ≈øide of Hypoga≈øtrium, they ≈øwell to the bigne≈øs of ones Fi≈øt.

12. In the Tubes of the Womb, the Womans Seed is ≈øometimes corrupted, from which ari≈øe grievous Symptoms; the Cour≈øes being for ≈øome Months ob≈øtructed, oftentimes there
follows a Drop≈øie; the Water here collected, we have ob≈øerved in dead Bodies that have been opened, to flow directly through the Tubes into the Duplicature of the Peritonaeum.

13. The Womb, from the preternatural afflux of Blood, is often inflamed, e≈øpecially in lying-in Women, and in tho≈øe who≈øe Cour≈øes flow di≈øorderly, this Inflammation oftentimes is changed into an Ab≈øce≈øs, if negligently handled; who≈øe Cure belongs to the Phy≈øitian: But a Sphacelus is incurable. For what the Ancients relate concerning the extirpation of the Womb, to wit, that it may all be taken off without any great danger, is to be reckoned among≈øt their other Errors; but whether this Animal in living Creatures, this nece≈ø≈øary part, joyning to ≈øo many other parts, and furni≈øhed with ≈øuch abundance of Arteries, may be cut out without danger of Life? The ≈øame thing I believe hath hapned to them in this ca≈øe, as hath hapned in the de≈øcribing and curing the falling down of the Womb, who here and there have taken the extended Tunicles of the Vagina ∆≤teri for the Womb it ≈øelf; for I ea≈øily grant the≈øe Tunicles may without any great danger be taken away: But I truly e≈øteem a Sphacelus of the whole Womb to cau≈øe certain death.

14. The Neck of the Womb is ≈øubject to Haemorrhoids in the ≈øame manner as the ≈øtraight Gut is; the≈øe flowing, may be di≈øtingui≈øhed from the Cour≈øes by the≈øe following ≈øigns; in the flowing of the Cour≈øes, we can ob≈øerve no Branches of the Ve≈ø≈øels in the Neck of the Womb, they come out of the Womb it
≈øelf, and they cau≈øe no pain, except in the Hypoga≈øtrium; the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels by which the Evacuation is made, are the Hypoga≈øtrick and Spermatick Arteries; but the Haemorrhoids are the Branches of Vena pudenda, they may be known both by the ≈øight and feeling, and there is no pain but in the privy part it ≈øelf: They ought to be treated in the ≈øame manner as the other Haemorrhoids are; to ea≈øe pain, this Ointment is excellent.
Take Mu≈ø≈øilages of the Seed of Quinces, Mar≈øhmallows, of each half an ounce; Saffron, Oyl of Ro≈øes, Hens-grea≈øe, of each a dram; the Yolk of an Egg‚ñ™ Make it into an Ointment.
This Mixture is excellent.
Take Litharge of Gold, wa≈øht Oeru≈øe, burnt-Lead, of each a ≈øcruple; Pur≈ølane-water, five ounces: Mix them.
Let the Haemorrhoids be wa≈øht with it, and let a Linnen Cloth dipt in it be applied to the Part affected.

div.head: The FIFTH BOOK. Of the Joynts.
CHAP. I. Of the Hand.
div.p: UNder the name of the Hand, we comprehend al≈øo the Arm, who≈øe Teguments, both proper and common, as al≈øo its Ve≈ø≈øels, are already ≈øufficiently de≈øcribed.
It is commonly divided into three parts.
The Shoulder, or upper part of the Arm, con≈øi≈øts of one Bone, and nine Mu≈øcles.
The Mu≈øcles are,
1, 2. Deltoides, and Supra ≈øpinatus, which two rai≈øe it upward.
3, 4. Ani≈øcalptor, Lati≈ø≈øimus, and Rotundus major, which two pull it downward.
5, 6. Pectoralis & Perforatus, or Coracoidaeus, which two draw it forward.

7, 8, 9. Infra-≈øpinatus, Rotundus minor, and
Immer≈øus, or Sub≈øcapularis; which three move it backward.
By the≈øe three la≈øt moving together, the Arm is as it were turned about, and obliquely outwardly rai≈øed up.

The Bone is great and long, its Head or upper extremity is inve≈øted with a Cartilage, Membranous Ligament, and four Tendons, and furni≈øhed with a particular Cavity, in which the Tendon of the Mu≈øcle Triceps lies.
The Lower Extremity is like unto a Pulley, which permits the Cubit to be bent very much inwardly, but not to extend beyond the right Line.
The Cubit con≈øi≈øts of two Bones, which are by proper Mu≈øcles properly moved, which although out of order, we are forced to ≈øet down in this place.
The Lower Bone, which is greater and longer than the other, is call'd ∆≤lnae; in its upper extremity are two triangular proce≈ø≈øes ob≈øerved, which are call'd Ro≈øtra or Glandes.
The Lower Extremity ends with a round Knob, to which is joyned a ≈øharp Proce≈øs, which is call'd Styloides.
It is moved by four Mu≈øcles, of which two are Flexors.
Two Exten≈øors.

The upper Bone, which is le≈øs and ≈øhorter, is call'd Radius, or the le≈ø≈øer Focil, it is received in the upper part by the ∆≤lna, in the lower part
it receives the ∆≤lna, in the middle they are a little di≈øtant from one another, which ≈øpace is yet fill'd with a thin Ligament.
It is al≈øo moved by four Mu≈øcles, whereof two are Pronatores, or pullers down.
The other two are Supinatores, or rai≈øers up.
Some add to the≈øe two other Mu≈øcles, but they are very ≈øeldom found, and diver≈øly de≈øcribed.
The Hand is divided into three parts, the Carpus, or Wri≈øt, the Metacarpus, or the di≈øtance between the Wri≈øt and Fingers; and the Fingers them≈øelves.
The Carpus hath four Mu≈øcles.
Two Flexors, the Cubitaeus, and the Radiaeus internus.
Two Exten≈øors, the Cubitaeus, and Radiaeus externus.

Under the≈øe lie eight little Bones, as yet without name, which are in the fir≈øt years Cartilaginous and ≈øoft, but afterwards become harder; they are tied and joyned together with ≈øtrong Ligaments.
The Metacarpus hath two Mu≈øcles, call'd Palmares, longus & brevis.
And four Bones fa≈øtened to the Carpus by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Cartilaginous Ligaments.
The Fingers con≈øi≈øt of fifteen Bones, which as yet have no certain names given them, and fourteen Mu≈øcles; whereof,
Two are Flexors, ≈øublimis & profundus.
Two Exten≈øors.
Four Adductors, Lumbricales.
Six Abductors, or Intero≈ø≈øei. Three are External, and as many Internal.
Be≈øides the≈øe, the Thumb and Little Finger have a particular Flexor and Exten≈øor.
The≈øe are be≈øides to be con≈øidered in the Hand,
1. The Armilla Membrano≈øa, which is a round Ligament, comprehending the many Tendons of the Hand, as it was in a Circle, ea≈øily divi≈øible into many others.
2. Vagina Membrano≈øa, which hold in the Tendons contained in the Hand.
3. Fi≈ø≈øura oblonga, framed in each Tendon, for the pa≈ø≈øage of the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles moving the third Joynt; this ≈øerves in nature of a Pully.
4. O≈ø≈øa Se≈øamoidea.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: 1. The Shoulder oftentimes is broken or put out of joynt, but is oftner afflicted with a Cathar and Gout. In a cold Gout, I never found any thing more efficacious than the Stiptick Plai≈øter of Crollius, mixt with Oyl of Bricks or Philo≈øophers; as al≈øo the following Plai≈øter.

Take Naval-Pitch, Colophony, of each three ounces; Mu≈ø≈øilages, of Mar≈øhmallow-roots, two ounces and an half; Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Ma≈øtick, Mirrhe, Frankincen≈øe, of each an ounce and half; Propoleos, Mi≈øletoe of the Oak, round Birthwort, burnt Bra≈øs, yellow-Wax, Turpentine, of each three ounces;
Oyl of Earth, two ounces; Make it into a Plai≈øter according to Art.
In a hot Cathar, or the like Gout, I have always found this Fomentation of ≈øingular u≈øe.

Take Vitriol, white and green, of each half an ounce; prepared Nitre, ≈øix drams; Crude Alom, one dram; Mirrhe, two drams: Opium, a dram; White-Wine, half a pint; rectified Spirit of Wine ten drams: Elder-Vinegar, three ounces: Mix them for a Fomentation.
Under the Arm-pits, Veneral Buboes appear as well as in the Groins.

2. Often tough Phlegm ≈øeizeth upon the Joynt of the Shoulder and Elbow, from whence comes a ≈øtiffne≈øs. I have learnt by experience to e≈øteem much in this ca≈øe of Bal≈øom of Peru, as al≈øo of the following Ointment.

Take Fox-grea≈øe, and Rams-grea≈øe, Fre≈øh-Butter, of each two ounces; Oyl of Earthworms, an ounce; rectified Spirit of Wine, four ounces; boil them to the con≈øumption of the Spirit of wine, then add Oyl of Ro≈øemary, of Amber, of each three drams; of Tiles, or of the Philo≈øophers, two drams: Mix them, and make it into an Ointment.
One or more of the little Bones of the Carpus oftentimes are di≈ølocated, which, if not pre≈øently reduced, becomes an incurable evil.
A Ganglion is here very frequent, be≈øides the Cathar and Gout, who≈øe cure we have but ju≈øt now taught.

4. In the Metacarpus and Fingers, both above and below meet many Tendons, which are ea≈øily injured in Wounds and Ulcers, which is carefully to be ob≈øerved, le≈øt a Pal≈øie follow:
In which no other Medicines are needful, than what we have already in the foregoing declared: But the≈øe are chiefly to be con≈øidered of; 1. That the Bandage is not to be bound too hard. 2. You mu≈øt not put in the Probe too deep, nor too often. 3. The Hand and Fingers are to be placed upright, not depending. 4. The≈øe Parts are ea≈øily affected with a Sphacelus, which the≈øe ≈øigns certainly denounce: When there is no matter in due time; the Lips in the beginning are dry, or yield a little thin moi≈øture; the heat, pul≈øation, and redne≈øs is greater here, than in the fle≈øhy parts; afterwards the Lips are turned in, and become livid, and at length black. In this ca≈øe, all tho≈øe Medicines are to be applied that may put a ≈øtop to the Gangrene, and as formerly we have ≈øet down.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Foot.
div.p: THe Foot is al≈øo divided into three parts, to wit, into the Thigh Leg, and Lower Foot.
The Thigh hath but one Bone, to who≈øe motion ≈øerves fourteen Mu≈øcles.
Two Flexors, P≈øoas and Illiacus.
Three Exten≈øors, Glutaeus Major, Medius and Minimus.
Three Adductors, Triceps.
Six Abductors, Quadragemini & obturatoris duo.
The Abductors and Adductores working together, rowl about the Thigh.
The Thigh-Bone is the greate≈øt of all the Bones of the Body, outwardly it buncheth forth, and is a little bended inwardly, and ≈øo de≈øcends internally oblique to the Knee.
It hath three Proce≈ø≈øes, ea≈øily ≈øeparable in Infants.

The Leg con≈øi≈øts of two Bones; the greater of which, is in the in≈øide, and is called Tibia, or the greater focile; the le≈ø≈øer, which is in the out≈øide, is call'd Fibula, or the le≈ø≈øer Focile; both very much re≈øembling the Bones of the Cubit; they are a little di≈øtant one from the other, but are tied together by a Ligament.
It is moved by eleven Mu≈øcles, which are,
Four Exten≈øors, Rectus, Crureus, Va≈øti duo.
Four Flexors, Biceps, Semimembrano≈øus, Seminervo≈øus, Gracilis.
Two Adductors, Longus and Poplitous.
One Abductor, Fa≈øcialis.
Between the Thigh and Leg lies the Patella or Knee-pan, in Infants Cartilaginous, in old people, hard and ≈øtrong, placed on the out≈øide of the Joynt.
The Foot is divided into three parts, the Tar≈øus, Metatar≈øus, and Toes.
The Tar≈øus is moved by ≈øix Mu≈øcles, viz.
Two Flevors, Tibiaeus anticus & Peronaeus.
Four Exten≈øors, Biceps, two Gemelli, and Sole ‚Ä¢ s, to which many add a fifth, Tibeaeus po≈øticus.

Three of the≈øe Exten≈øors from one very ≈øtrong Tendon, which is called Cordia Hipocra
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a.

It is made up of ≈øeven Bones, which are,
1. Talus, or A≈øtragalus.
2. Calx, or Os Calcis,
3. Os Naviculare, or Cimbiforme.
4. Os Te≈ø≈øerae, or Cuboides.
5, 6, 7. O≈ø≈øa tria Cuneiformia, or Shpaenoidea.
The Metatar≈øus con≈øi≈øts of five Bones.
The Toes have fourteen Bones; for the great Toe hath but two Joynts.
The Matacarpus hath no Mu≈øcles, except Plantaris, which is not unlike Palmaris.
The Mu≈øcles of the Toes are ≈øeventeen, to wit,
Two Flexors.
One Exten≈øor of the four Toes, for which u≈øe 'tis furni≈øhed with a fourfold Tendon.
Four Adductors or Lumbricales.
Ten Abductors, or Intero≈ø≈øei.
To the great Toe are peculiar,
One Flexor.
One Exten≈øor.
Two Adductors.
One Abductor.

Here al≈øo, as in the Hand, are ob≈øerved the O≈ø≈øa ≈øe≈ø≈øamoidea, which are always placed between the full grown Joynts, partly that they may corroborate the Joynts, partly that they may defend the tender Joynts; in old people they are alwayes numbred from ten to twenty, never in Children.

div.head: Chirurgical Con≈øiderations.
div.p: The Foot in its natural con≈øtitution, as al≈øo in its Di≈øea≈øes, hath many things agreeing with the Hand, therefore it would be ≈øuperfluous to repeat them over again.

1. Con≈øiderable here is the Sciatick pain, cau≈øed from a ≈øharp Humor gathered in the Joynt, where the Thigh-bone joyns with the Os I≈øchium; when the Ligament tying the≈øe Bones together, is from ≈øuch an Humor relaxed, the Bone recedes from the natural places, and brings upon that part a lamene≈øs: If the Bone or Cartilage be corroded, and the Ve≈ø≈øels compre≈øt, there follows an Atrophy of the Legs, and ≈øometimes of the whole Body.

2. Tumors in the Knee, are very dangerous and hard of Cure, by rea≈øon of the firmne≈øs of Mu≈øcles, the great number of Ligaments, Tendons, and Bones, and the cold and dry nature of the parts, not being of force ≈øufficient to di≈ø≈øipate the moi≈øture; therefore 'tis mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to a≈ø≈øi≈øt it with warm Medicines as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible; and if any ≈øigns of Suppuration appear, forthwith let it be opened, le≈øt otherwi≈øe the Patient becomes lame, the Part wa≈øtes, and at la≈øt happens death it ≈øelf. Upon the opening of the Ab≈øce≈øs, for the mo≈øt part there follows a gleet of ≈øome Humor, which renders the Cure very difficult: For this I commend the often prai≈øed Re≈øtorative Powder.
3. A great Tendon is in≈øerted in the Calcaneus, or Bone of the Heel, which being wounded, or much contu≈øed, brings Convul≈øions, and death it ≈øelf.

About this place comes Kibes, who≈øe cau≈øe is inten≈øe cold or heat with drine≈øs: Here fir≈øt are ob≈øerved Fi≈ø≈øures in the Skin, then follows an Ulceration: All fat things and Plai≈øters profit here, e≈øpecially the following.

Take Powder of Galls, of round Birthwort, of each half a dram, red Lead, a dram; Mercury ≈øublimate, ≈øix grains; Litharge, Mirrhe, of each a dram and half; Camphire, a ≈øcruple; Franckincen≈øe, two drams; green Wax, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into a Plai≈øter.
In the room of green Wax, you may take the Fat of Deer, or of Rams.
4. The Fingers or Toes being frozen, mu≈øt be rubb'd with Snow, or with a brui≈øed frozen Turnep; then this following Plai≈øter is much commended.
Take Hogs-grea≈øe; fre≈øh Oyl of Olives, of each an ounce; white Wax, two ounces: boil them a little, and make a Plai≈øter.

5. I≈ø≈øues are often made in the Joynts; we have formerly declared the place: In the Arms, between the Mu≈øcle Deltois and Biceps; in the Thigh two fingers breadth above the Knee in the in≈øide; in the Leg, the uppermo≈øt, two fingers breadth below the Knee; the lowermo≈øt, two fingers or three above the Ankle. That you may make the≈øe I≈ø≈øues without pain, in≈øtead of a Conclu≈øion, take this Cau≈øtick, which works without pain; which is al≈øo very much to be commended in ≈øordid and cancerous Ulcers, and in Excre≈øcencies.

Take Crude Brim≈øtone, white Ar≈ønick, Crude Antimony, of each two ounces; the Brim≈øtone being melted by a gentle fire, and
≈øtirred about with a Spatula, add the Ar≈ønick and Antimony powdred, and mix them whil≈øt they are incorporated with the Brim≈øtone, and look red. Afterwards,
Take of this Mixture, an ounce; Caput mortuum, of Vitriol, half an ounce: Mix them, and make a Powder; let it be wa≈øht ≈øix times in Spirit of wine, and dried for your u≈øe.

THE Plague is a Di≈øea≈øe who≈øe nature is not to be comprehended by us; the Cau≈øe thereof ≈øeems to proceed from a Spirituous and Infectious Vapour, which is powerful enough to make a ≈øudden di≈ø≈øolution of the con≈øi≈øtence of the Blood, by which means the Heart is deprived both of ≈øtrength and life.

I do a≈ø≈øert that the Nature of it is not to be comprehended by us, as well becau≈øe it is a Puni≈øhment inflicted on us by the immediate hand of Almighty God, who vouch≈øafes not that his Incomprehen≈øible Wi≈ødom and E≈ø≈øence (which is ≈øometimes faintly de≈øcribed to us) ≈øhould be narrowly pryed into by his creatures; as al≈øo that it is in it ≈øelf ≈øo mutable, that if we ≈øhould ≈øeriou≈øly recollect our ≈øelves, and recount the ≈øeveral Pe≈øtilences wherewith all former Ages have been vi≈øited; we ≈øhall not thereby be able to in≈øtance in two of that whole number which have agreed with each other in all circum≈øtances: From whence we may ea≈øily infer, that in
the Cure of this Di≈øea≈øe, an Experienced Phy≈øician may much more ≈øafely follow the Dictates of his own Rea≈øon, than adhire ≈øtrictly to the Method & Pre≈øcriptions of others. For although it doth ≈øometimes by the more remarkable ≈øymptoms ≈øufficiently evidence it ≈øelf, yet we cannot likely di≈øcover its Nature and E≈ø≈øence, although we ≈øhould the mo≈øt indu≈øtriou≈øly attempt it.

But that we may cautiou≈øly enquire into it, we mu≈øt know that it is ≈øometimes not accompanied by any Fever: And it is nece≈ø≈øary that what Phy≈øician ≈øoever is ignorant of this ≈øhould either by peru≈øing good Authors, or his own Experience, acquaint him≈øelf throughly with it. I have been ≈øent for to ≈øeveral Patients my ≈øelf, who although they appeared otherwi≈øe in good health, not refu≈øing their meat, nor di≈øturb'd in their ≈øleep, have neverthele≈øs had Buboes ari≈øing in their Groin, on their Neck, under their Armpits, or behind their Ears, which have apparently di≈øcovered a greater Malignity than could be di≈øcerned in tho≈øe Buboes, which in other per≈øons have been attended by a violent Fever: And many hereupon who have been incredulous, and lightly regarded the cautions which I have given them upon this account, have with great danger to them≈øelves experimented, that as ≈øoon as tho≈øe Buboes have ≈øunk down, the Pe≈øtilential Symptoms which have appear'd, have been very dreadful, and much more dangerous than in tho≈øe that have carefully u≈øed the means pre≈øcribed to them, who have been al≈øo much more ea≈øily and ≈øpeedily cured than the other.
Sometimes the Plague is accompanied with a Fever; and again, there are ≈øome Pe≈øtilent Fevers without the Plague.

To di≈øtingui≈øh this Fever from the Plague, I u≈øed to ob≈øerve, that they that are ≈øeized with it, complain of pain in their Head and Stomach, which ≈øometimes is di≈øper≈øed over the whole Body; ≈øometimes it confines it ≈øelf to the Arm-pits; the Neck, the Parts behind the Ears, or to the Groin. To outward appearance, there is not the lea≈øt ≈øwelling. If the Patient by ≈øuch means as is requi≈øite be provoked to ≈øweat at the beginning of the Di≈øea≈øe, the pain utterly cea≈øeth, and in a few dayes he will be perfectly re≈øtored to his health, the Di≈øea≈øe not having at all di≈øcovered it ≈øelf‚ñ™ by any outward Symptoms. Why ≈øuch a Fever ≈øhould be accounted a Species of the Plague, I ≈øee no rea≈øon; But there is no one but will confe≈øs it to have ≈øeized on that Body on which Buboes, Carbuncles, and Spots do outwardly appear.

The cau≈øe of the Plague is either Internal or External; but unto which ≈øoever we impute it, it is nece≈ø≈øary to conclude, that there is in it a power of di≈ø≈øolving the natural Con≈øi≈øtence of the Blood, and depriving the whole Body of its ≈øtrength.

As to the Inward Cau≈øe, which is Meat and Drink, it is evident to all, that it cannot produce in any Body what≈øoever ≈øo great & ≈øudden a change; but it is mo≈øt certain, that by a long & continued cour≈øe of bad Diet, the Blood may by degrees be after ≈øuch a manner di≈ø≈øolved, weakned, and corrupted, that ≈øome part of it a≈ø≈øuming to it ≈øelf a malignant quality; a man
may be ≈øurprized by a ≈øudden Di≈øea≈øe, & ≈øometimes be deprived of life it ≈øelf; which hath been ob≈øerved in ≈øick per≈øons at ≈øeveral times, when there hath been no contagion in the place, nor any ≈øu≈øpected, who have been troubled with perfect Buboes, and other Symptoms of the Plague, much more intolerable than others have been at any time when the Air hath been infected.

As to the outward Cau≈øes, every one confe≈ø≈øeth that there are ≈øuch; but their Nature is known but to few: The Chymi≈øts, who are able by the force of Fire di≈øtinctly to ≈øeparate the Parts of ≈øimple Drugs, endeavour to find the Original of the Contagion in a Volatile Salt, which ≈øuddenly di≈ø≈øolves the fixed Salt of the Blood; which hath indeed ≈øome appearance of truth, though it will not be reli≈øhed by all men.
If you enquire into the Cau≈øe hereof from others, their an≈øwer will be various, but mo≈øt of them very idle and impertinent.

It hath by ≈øome been thought probable that a Plague might proceed from the Heavens; they affirming that the Stars do actuate the Subluminary Bodies, both by the influence of their Light, and by ≈øeveral other qualities inherent in, and peculiar unto them. But the Conjectors rai≈øed from hence, are very uncertain, and the foundation of them un≈øecure. We are not ignorant of the Fopperies of A≈øtrology, and of the vanity of tho≈øe Predictions, which have no other Foundation than the ≈øeveral Cour≈øes, the Conjunction and Oppo≈øition of the Stars; which are all ≈øo frivolous, that we cannot think it worth our labour to refute them.

We acknowledge that the Air may be ≈øeveral ways corrupted; from whence the Vapors which have been received from the Earth, are ≈øent down again among≈øt us, which like Fire may inkindle our Blood, Corrupt waters, Carca≈ø≈øes either not at all buried, or el≈øe ≈øhallowly interred; the South-wind, which may be ≈øuppo≈øed to promote the Putrefaction; Men already infected, & ≈øucce≈ø≈øively imparting the Contagion to the ≈øound, & by that means ≈øpreading the Venom through the Bodies of Men, & the Air it≈øelf.

This Pe≈øtilential Infection may likewi≈øe for a long time lie couched and concealed in Straw or Stubble, among≈øt Garments, Hangings, and the Furniture of Beds; which we have ≈øometimes ob≈øerved ≈øtrangely to impart their Malignity to tho≈øe that have handled them, or approached unto them.
But all the≈øe things only inform us of the means by which this Pe≈øtilential Poy≈øon is conveyed unto us; but no one hath as yet declared what it is, and wherein its Nature doth properly con≈øi≈øt.

The Symptoms of it are the≈øe. The ≈øick per≈øons are ≈øeized with a ≈øhivering all over their Body, which is pre≈øently followed with an inward heat, which is oft-times very inten≈øe, yet without any great thir≈øt; ≈øomtimes the thir≈øt is exce≈ø≈øive, & the Fever moderate. But whether the heat of the Fever be great or ≈ømall, it is mo≈øt commonly accompanied with a dryne≈øs of the Tongue, & an Urine of the ≈øame con≈øtitution which you might expect from a man in perfect health: They are taken ≈øometimes with a great drow≈øine≈øs, ≈øometimes with a Dilirium, or with
an exce≈ø≈øive pain in the Head; & in this ca≈øe, the white of the Eyes appeareth of a Saffron-colour, & they are more wakeful than is con≈øi≈øtent with their ea≈øe & quiet: great pain at the Heart, the Pul≈øe ≈øeems ≈ømall, if not at fir≈øt when you touch it lightly (for then it oftentimes appears to beat high) yet at lea≈øt when you pre≈øs it clo≈øely with your Fingers. The ≈øtrength fails in the beginning of the Di≈øea≈øe, & decrea≈øeth much more vi≈øibly than in the mo≈øt burning Fever, which hath no Malignity attending it. Some are taken with a Diarrhaea, which can by no means be ≈øtopt: Others bleed much at the No≈øe, the Eyes, the Ears, or Mouth; ≈øome at the Yard or Womb. Some are troubled with a continual Vomiting, others with a Nau≈øeou≈øne≈øs. On ≈øome Bodies there appear red or purple ≈øpots; & on others Buboes behind their Ears, on their Neck, under their Chin, in the Groin, and under the Arm-pits: In ≈øome there break forth red Wheals or Pu≈øhes; in others white Bladders, or Carbuncles. And where≈øoever the≈øe Bladders, Buboes, Carbuncles, &c. do appear, they are a mo≈øt certain ≈øign of the Plague, although the bigne≈øs of them may be incon≈øiderable; e≈øpecially if they either accompany, or are Con≈øequents of a Fever.

As to the Progno≈øticks, we mu≈øt con≈øider, that the Plague is a very treacherous Di≈øea≈øe, and whil≈øt it flatters us mo≈øt, it intends us the greate≈øt mi≈øchief. A Bubo is le≈øs dangerous than a Carbuncle, and a Carbuncle than the Spots, which very ≈øeldom portend le≈øs than pre≈øent death where≈øoever they are di≈øplay'd.

A Bubo behind the Ears, on the Neck, or
under the Arm-pits, is more dangerous than that in the Groin.

Carbuncles on the Hands and Feet, may by ≈øome be thought le≈øs pernicious, becau≈øe they are more remote from the Heart; but ≈øince they happen among≈øt many Nerves and Tendons, they are more to be feared than tho≈øe which appear in other parts of the Body which are better covered with fle≈øh.
A Carbuncle ari≈øing after a Bubo, is a ≈øign of Death. If a Bubo or Carbuncle appear before the Fever, there is le≈øs danger than if they follow it at a di≈øtance, and ari≈øe ≈ølowly.
A blew Circle encompa≈ø≈øing the Bubo the ≈øecond day after its appearance, is a ≈øign of Death.
If a Bubo ≈øuddenly di≈øappears, the ≈øtate of the Patient is dangerous, unle≈øs Nature di≈øpatcheth the Malignant Humour to ≈øome other Part.

Thus we have often ob≈øerved, that upon the retreat of that Morbifick Matter which hath cau≈øed a Bubo in the Groin, there hath appeared a Gangrene in the Foot, and on the ≈øame ≈øide which was before affected, and many have by that means e≈øcaped.
If a Cupping-gla≈øs applied to the Patient, rai≈øeth no Bli≈øter, we may rea≈øonably conclude his condition to be de≈øperate.

It is an infallible ≈øign of Death, if after Cauterization, or the application of a Cupping-gla≈øs, the Carbuncle abates not in 12 or 24 hours, as likewi≈øe if there is no moi≈øture proceeding from it; but if a Bladder appears, or any ≈øeparation of the matter be made

A Carbuncle which ≈øeems to have a little tail, or pu≈øh at the end of it, is very dangerous, as are likewi≈øe tho≈øe which look white; which, unle≈øs the Fever doth very much abate, are certain forerunners of Death.

If the Patient that hath a Bubo in his Neck, or behind his Ears, be troubled with a pain in his Throat, and a difficulty in ≈øwallowing, and no con≈øiderable Inflammation appear, we have always found it a certain Rule, that in this ca≈øe he outlives not 12 or 15 hours.

Sleep more ≈øound than ordinary, Diliriums, waking often in the night, inflammation of the Eyes, pain at the Heart, a trembling and convul≈øion of the Joynts, are all very dangerous Symptoms, but do not always portend Death.
A great Fever without a pain at the Heart, is not ≈øo dangerous as a le≈ø≈øer, which is accompanied with that Symptom.

If by the admini≈øtration of Sudorificks, Sweat is not provoked, the Patient u≈øually mi≈øcarrieth.

A Flux of Blood was heretofore held dangerous in all Plagues; but in our Age, all that can either bleed at the No≈øe, or have their Men≈øtrua's, come off ≈øafe: We have no pre≈øident of any that have pi≈ø≈øed Blood; but a Di≈ø≈øentery is the ≈øign of an approaching Death.
It is very certain, although it but ≈øeldom happens, that incurable Carbuncles do break out about the Eyes, No≈øe & Stomach, & even amid≈øt the Entrails them≈øelves.
If they ≈øeize on the Bladder, they become mortal to the Patient, and put him to exce≈ø≈øive pain.

I can in≈øtance only in one, who after he had for 30 hours or more been troubled with the Spots, at length, after exceeding great pain, accompanied with a Delirium, he voided fir≈øt, Blood and after that, a purulent matter through his Yard, by which means he was re≈øtored to his health; I conjectured that there was a Carbuncle in the ca≈øe, which ≈øeized not on the Membranous part of the Bladder, but on the Neck thereof.
As to the Cure; Blood-letting is very prejudicial to tho≈øe that already have the Plague, and dangerous to ≈øuch that would prevent it.

The Poi≈øon oftentimes lies hid within the B ‚Ä¢ dy for ≈øome dayes, weeks, or months, before ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ di≈øcovers it ≈øelf by ≈øeizing on the conveyances of the Blood. Wherefore I would advi≈øe you ≈øeriou≈øly to con≈øider, if by opening a Vein, you invite it immediately to the Heart, whether the diminution of Blood, Spirits and Strength, which is effected by this means, be not the Cau≈øe why the Heart is ≈øuffocated and deprived of that vigour which it ≈øhould make u≈øe of to repul≈øe the Enemy. I confe≈øs ≈øome Experienced Phy≈øitians of good credit, have reported, that in hot Countries there is no better means for re≈øtoring a Patient vi≈øited with the Plague, unto his health, than that of opening a Vein, provided it be done cautiou≈øly, and at the beginning of the Di≈øea≈øe; but who≈øoever have attempted it in colder Climates, have quickly learnt by experience, that it ought to be forborn.

Purging, which is oftentimes very nece≈ø≈øary in other gentle Di≈øea≈øes, is excluded by the Malignity of this. But every one is not quick-≈øighted enough to di≈øcern when it is requi≈øite to be done, and when to be forborn: Moreover, it is evident, that in a Malignant Di≈øea≈øe, the Phy≈øick which is admini≈øtred to a Patient, ought to be more mild and gentle than at other times; for be≈øides that the Body cannot then bear ≈øtrong purgations, a Dy≈øentery is oftentimes the con≈øequence of them. I have when I have been fully per≈øwaded that there was no Malignity in the Di≈øea≈øe‚ñ™ oftentimes u≈øed this, or ≈øome ≈øuch like Potion with good ≈øucce≈øs, viz.

Take Rhubarb, a dram and half; Senna, two drams; Cream of Tartar, a dram; Scorzonera-Roots, half an ounce; Ani≈øeeds, half a dram; Boil them in Holy-Thi≈øtle-Water, and to three ounces of the ≈øtrained Liquor, and Syrup of Succory, with Rhubarb, ≈øix drams; Spirit of Salt, a little; Confection of Alkermes, a ≈øcrupel: Make it into a Potion.

I never adventured to pre≈øcribe any thing Purgative to ≈øuch as have been taken with the Plague, before the fourteenth day, at which time the Fever and the other Symptoms of the Di≈øea≈øe would be abated. There are ≈øome who have attempted it while the Carbuncles remain purulent, and before the Bubo is perfectly cured.
But I dare not advi≈øe any one to follow that Method, what≈øoever Remedies they admini≈øter at the ≈øame time, which may be intended ≈øpecifically again≈øt the Plague.

But if it happen that the Patient for ≈øeveral
days be very co≈øtive, and troubled with a pain at his heart, and hopes to be relieved by Purgation,

It is to be con≈øidered, that the Venom of the Di≈øea≈øe, and not the Co≈øtivene≈øs is the cau≈øe of the pain at the Heart; it is therefore mo≈øt requi≈øite to make u≈øe of Sudorificks, to corroborate the Heart, and not to concern your ≈øelf for the co≈øtivene≈øs of the Body: but if you de≈øire to open it a little, it is better to make u≈øe of a Suppo≈øitory than a Gly≈øter, which is not altogether ≈øo ≈øafe, but hath been prejudicial to many on this occa≈øion: and to others it hath done but little good, and not at all oppo≈øed the Malignity of the Di≈øea≈øe: But to ≈øuch as will not take this advi≈øe, which hath been very confirmed by experience and ≈øeveral good Rea≈øons, and will ≈øtill per≈øi≈øt to make u≈øe of Gly≈øters, it is fit however that they forbear to pre≈øcribe Scammony as an Ingredient, e≈øpecially to Women in the time of their Flowers.

Juleps are in this ca≈øe very nece≈ø≈øary; but all per≈øons may not make u≈øe of them, nor any at all times. I am never wont to pre≈øcribe them without joyning with them ≈øome Sudorificks (which will appear hereafter) and this I take to be the ≈øafe≈øt cour≈øe; for if the ≈øick per≈øon ≈øhould make u≈øe of ≈øuch things only as refrigerate while he ≈øweats freely, the Sweat would oftentimes ≈øtrike inward, and the Venom would be conveyed to the Heart, from whence would follow ≈øudden Death.

There is no means more requi≈øite than that of Diaphoreticks and Cordials, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that are acid, which produce ≈øuch effects as are
certain, and therefore the more laudable; for they rectifie the Ma≈øs of Blood, and free it from the venom which infects it. They di≈ø≈øolve the pituitous Matter which is lodged in the Stomach and the Entrails, and correct the Choler, which in this Di≈øea≈øe is the cau≈øe of much mi≈øchief. Neverthele≈øs the ≈øeveral di≈øgui≈øes of this Di≈øea≈øe, and the vanity of the Symptoms which attend it, do require that they ≈øhould be often changed; ≈øince when the Di≈øea≈øe is more gentle, tho≈øe things are not to be u≈øed, which would do good ≈øervice in an accute one.

div.head: Our Prophylactick Water.
div.p: Take Roots of Angelica, Zedoary, of each an ounce; Roots of Butter-Bur, two ounces; Leaves of Rhue, four ounces; Leaves of Balm, Scabious, Marrigold-Flowers, of each two ounces; unripe Walnuts ≈øliced, two pound; fre≈øh Citrons ≈øliced, a pound: let them be all brui≈øed together, then poure upon them ≈øix quarts of the be≈øt Wine-Vinegar di≈øtilled by it ≈øelf in a Gla≈øs-Cucurbit in Sand.

div.head: The Symptomes of the Plague.
div.p:
THey are many, and very various, but mo≈øt of them are accompanied with ≈øome others; which when the former are cured, the latter are very ea≈øily removed. We therefore think it very needle≈øs to give an account of
them all in this place, it will be ≈øufficient to in≈øtance in the chief of them, among≈øt which, we in the fir≈øt place encounter with.
A Fever: Of ≈øuch a Nature, that it admits not of any purging, or letting of Blood, which the Experience of ≈øeveral hath ≈øufficiently confirmed.

The Sudorificks before pre≈øcribed are no le≈øs u≈øeful for this Sympton, than for the Plague it ≈øelf; but the Fever and great drine≈øs of the Tongue, requiring ≈øuch things as refrigerate, they are not to be admini≈øtred, except they are mixed with Sudorificks, as we have ≈øhewn before.

Take Water of Borage, Sorrel, of each two ounces; our Prophylactick Water‚ñ™ an ounce and an half; Juice of ≈øowre Oranges fre≈øh Citrons, of each two drams; Julep of Ro≈øes, as much as will make it conveniently ≈øweet; Oriental Bezoar, fifteen grains: Mix them.

Or,

Prunella, two ≈øcruples; or Spirit of Salt, as much as is ≈øufficient: Mix them.

Take Borage-water, three ounces; Holy-Thi≈øtle-water, a pint; Ro≈øe-water, an ounce; Lozenges of Sugar pearl'd, an ounce; Amber-greece, two grains; Musk, a grain; Juice of Citrons, as much as ≈øufficeth: Mingle them.

We≈øop-Ale, or ≈øome ≈øuch like, which is well boyl'd, may here be very u≈øeful, e≈øpecially if ≈øome Nutmeg ≈øcrap'd, or a piece of calcin'd Harts-horn be tied up & ≈øteeped in it. Nor need we fear any mi≈øchief from exceeding either in the quantity or the frequent repeating of it; but we mu≈øt take heed that it be not given cold, le≈øt Gripings, Flux, and a pain at the Heart, & ≈øuch like Maladies ≈øhould be cau≈øed thereby.

To ≈øuch who have weak ≈øtomachs, & a pain at their heart, I do u≈øe to give the liberty, when their Fever abates, to drink Mo≈øel, or Rheni≈øh-wine with Sugar, & the juice of Limons, provided that they take it in a moderate quantity: But I believe they do err very much, who pre≈øcribe to their Patients, whil≈øt the Fever continues ≈øtill very high, ≈øome ≈øort of French Wine, either alone by it ≈øelf, or mixt with their Sudorificks.

That Oriental Stone, call'd Lapis Porcinus, or Pedro Porco, is of very great u≈øe, if it be ≈øteeped for a while in your ordinary Drink; for it ≈øtrongly provokes Sweat, and very much refre≈øheth the Heart.

though it be very hard, yet every time it is infu≈øed, it abates ≈øomewhat of its quantity, which is di≈øcoverable by the Tincture which it imparts to the Liquor. Let Sweat be thereby provoked, and let it be the care of the Attendants, that after the fir≈øt or ≈øecond day, the Patient may be kept from ≈øleep, if it be found that he hath ≈øtrength to bear it.

I have ≈øometimes in this ca≈øe (though contrary to Cu≈øtom) given it ≈øparingly, when I have found the ≈øick per≈øon not to ≈øleep in the fir≈øt, ≈øecond or third days: But when he hath waked for ≈øix or ≈øeven days together, and found a great decay of ≈øtrength, this following Pre≈øcription, taken every quarter of an hour by a ≈øpoonful, till ≈øleep hath ≈øeized on him, hath afforded great relief, and the ≈øleep produced thereby, hath been undi≈øturbed, and of long continuance.

Before I come to the u≈øe of Opiat Laudanum,
I endeavour to ea≈øe the pain of the Head by the≈øe following, viz. by applying Ground-Ivy brui≈øed to the nape of the Neck, and to the ≈øoles of the Feet, and palms of the Hands; this, or ≈øome ≈øuch like Compo≈øition.

The≈øe (If they are not the Cau≈øe of the Vomiting and Hiccough, may be ea≈øily removed by a ≈øpoonful of this following Preparation, taken cold every quarter of an hour.

Another Symptom of the Plague is a great Flux which is u≈øually a ≈øign that Death approacheth; but when the ≈øick per≈øon hath not voided meer blood, nor any thing of a bloody ≈øub≈øtance, I have ≈øometimes found the≈øe following Pre≈øcriptions to be ≈øucce≈øsful.

Let him ab≈øtain from all things that are either acid or ≈øalt; which except in this ca≈øe, are of great u≈øe in the Plague; and likewi≈øe from drinking much: But if his thir≈øt be ≈øo exceeding great, that he cannot bear it, let him take one, two or three ≈øpoonfuls of this following Mixture.

And thus much may ≈øuffice to have been ≈øpoken concerning the inward Symptoms of the Plague; the outward are three, the Spots, call'd Petechiae, the Bubo, and the Carbuncle.

The Bubo, I am wont to deal with after this manner following. div.head: The Magnetick Ar≈øenical Plai≈øter.
div.p: Take Crude Antimony, yellow Brim≈øtone, white Ar≈øenick, of each two ounces.

When you have beat them very ≈ømall, let them be put into a Viol covered in Sand, to which you mu≈øt apply fire till they are all melted, & appear to be of a dark red colour; when
it is cool, it may be taken out of the Ve≈ø≈øel, and this is that which they call the Ar≈øenical Magnet, and hath not in it any thing of Poy≈øon, as it may be ea≈øily experimented upon Dogs afterwards.

Take Gum Sagapenum, Ammoniacum, Galbanum, of the Ar≈øenical Magnet, of each three drams; Turpentine of the Larch-tree, Wax, of each half an ounce; Oyl of Amber, two drams; Dulcified Earth of Vitriol, a dram.

Let the Gums be di≈ø≈øolved in the ≈øtronge≈øt Wine-Vinegar, and ≈øtrained through a Linnen Cloth, let them after that be boiled up to their former con≈øi≈øtence, then melt the Wax and the Turpentine together by them≈øelves, & when you have taken them off from the fire, ≈øtir them well till you have brought them to the con≈øi≈øtence of an Ointment; then add to them the Gums beforementioned, & the Ar≈øenical Magnet, together with the Earth of Vitriol, and Oyl of Amber, & you will have that plai≈øter which is mo≈øt effectual for drawing forth all ≈øorts of Poy≈øon.

I have found the virtue of this Plai≈øter to be ≈øuch, that if it be applied to tho≈øe parts where the Skin is ≈øomewhat hard, it leaves not the lea≈øt ≈øign of a Scar, and yet doth ≈øo plentifully draw forth the malignant Humor, that a Bubo of the bigne≈øs of a Walnut, will in the ≈øpace of 5 or 6 days be utterly taken away; but becau≈øe it doth not always ≈øo ≈øuddenly produce this Effect, it is often very nece≈ø≈øary to rai≈øe a Bli≈øter for evacuation of the Humors. And it is ob≈øervable, that in ≈øome ≈øtrong Bodies it cau≈øeth no E≈øcar at all, unle≈øs when the Bli≈øter hath corroded,

Take Virgins-Honey, Ducks-gree≈øe, of each an ounce; Soot, ≈øix drams; Turpentine, an ounce; Yolks of two Eggs, Treacle, three drams; Oyl of Scorpions, as much as ≈øufficeth to make it into an Ointment.

But if the Tumor is not ≈øufficiently abated when the fir≈øt Cru≈øt is taken off by the Ar≈øenical Magnetick Plai≈øter, it is requi≈øite that you create a ≈øecond or third, and then proceed as before.

div.p: Take Gum Galbanum, an ounce; Ammoniacum, two drams, Oppoponax, three drams; yellow Wax, twenty ounces; Oyl of Olives, 24 ounces; Litharge of Gold, 17 ounces; Olibanum, two ounces: Mirrhe, Frankincen≈øe, of each ten drams; Verdigreece, long Birthwort, Ma≈øtick, of each an ounce; Bdellium, Load≈øtone, of each two ounces: Make it according to Art into a Plai≈øter.

If the Bubo is too protuberant, or cleaves to the Tendon, a Ve≈øicatory is too weak; but an actual Cautery is not ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary: it will be therefore be≈øt to make u≈øe of a potential one, and among tho≈øe ≈øeveral wherewith I have been acquainted, I know not any one that is more corro≈øive, and yet cau≈øeth le≈øs pain than this following.

None but ≈øuch as are unskilful, make u≈øe of the Plai≈øter of Frogs and Mercury; for it driveth the Venom inward, and threatneth much danger to the ≈øick per≈øon; wherein we are confirmed both by the Writings of Ancient Authors, and by our own experience.

div.head: The Carbuncle.
div.p:
Called by the Greeks Anthrax (for it is to no purpo≈øe to in≈øert any nice di≈øtinction between
them) ≈øhews it ≈øelf in ≈øeveral ≈øhapes; but the Symptoms of it are many times very fallible: It is ea≈øie to conclude of it when ever it di≈øcovers it ≈øelf by a little Pu≈øh of a dark Purple Colour, with an Inflammation round about it; but often appears with a White Pu≈øh without any con≈øiderable prominency, which ≈øeems to contain a ≈øort of purulent Matter that portends no mi≈øchief; but if you ≈øqueeze it, you will find it dry and very hard, and it eats very deep into the Skin underneath it.

Sometimes there appears one ≈øingle Bladder filled with Limpid Matter, which if it be not opened in the ≈øpace of 24 hours, it grows black, and upon its di≈ø≈øection ≈øends forth two or three drops of black Blood.

Otherwhiles, ≈øeveral little white Bli≈øters di≈øcover them≈øelves. If the≈øe grow hard underneath, and are accompanied with a Fever and Inflammation, there is no que≈øtion but that they are Malignant; and I know not why they may not be reckoned in the number of Carbuncles, e≈øpecially ≈øince they are wont to di≈øpatch a man in as ≈øhort a time as the purple ones; and they are to be dealt with after the ≈øame manner, if we expect that our endeavours ≈øhould ≈øucceed.

To the Cure of it, it is requi≈øite that the Suppuration ≈øhould with all diligence be promoted, and thereby the danger prevented of the Infection di≈øper≈øing it ≈øelf. And for this purpo≈øe I have found nothing more effectual than an actual Cautery; which hath al≈øo been approved of by ≈øeveral Chirurgeons; but there are ≈øome who apprehending it to be too cruel
a Remedy, do upon that account reject it, and choo≈øe rather a Potential Cau≈øtick, or ≈øome Medicines whereby Bli≈øters may be rai≈øed: Both which I my ≈øelf likewi≈øe have made u≈øe of, when it hath not been allowed that we ≈øhould u≈øe other means, and when I have hoped that the≈øe might be ≈øufficiently efficacious. For a Phy≈øitian is often con≈øtrained to comply with the Humor of ≈øuch as are conver≈øant about the ≈øick Per≈øon, and will pretend to know much, although it be many times to the prejudice of his Patient.
They that approve not of any of the forementioned Remedies, may make u≈øe of the Magnetical Ar≈øenick Plai≈øter, which in this ca≈øe we have found to be of great virtue.
For the ≈øeparation of the Scar, tho≈øe means which we mentioned in treating of the Bubo, are very nece≈ø≈øary: Many have very much commended this following Poultice.

Take Roots of Comfrey the greater dried, two drams; Mar≈øhmallow Roots dried, half an ounce; Leaves of Scordium dried, two drams; Meal of Lin≈øeed and Wheat, of each half an ounce; make them into fine Powder, poure upon them clean water as much as is ≈øufficient; let them boil a little, that the Mucilages may be di≈ø≈øolved, and till it comes to the con≈øi≈øtence of a thick Poultice; then add of Honey, Turpentine, and ∆≤ng. Apo≈øtolorum, of each, three drams; Ba≈øilicon, Tar, of each two drams; the Yolk of an Egg; Ea≈øtern Saffron, a ≈øcruple: Mix, and if you plea≈øe, you may add two drams of Treacle.

div.head: Pre≈øervatives again≈øt the PLAGUE.
div.p: IT is the Doctrine of the Devil to teach that the u≈øe of all Means is to be neglected; who once ≈øpake to our Saviour, and endeavoured to per≈øwade him to ca≈øt him≈øelf headlong from the top of the Temple, becau≈øe they need no other ≈øecurity, whom God ≈øupporteth by his mighty Hand: but he that hath given us Life and Health, requires that we ≈øhould make u≈øe of ≈øome helps for the con≈øervation of both; and therefore if you take my advice, I would wi≈øh you to ob≈øerve the Rules following.
Among≈øt which, in the fir≈øt place is challenged, and that de≈øervedly, fervent Prayer.

Flight is very allowable to Chri≈øtians, if it be con≈øi≈øtent with their quality and condition of Life; but let tho≈øe that make u≈øe of this, not depend too much upon it, but remember that it is not po≈ø≈øible to fly beyond the reach of the Omnipotent.
