Sleep and Watching, exerci≈øe of the Body, and the u≈øe of Women, if immoderate, are very hurtful.
Co≈øtivene≈øs is prejudicial, but not ≈øo much as a great loo≈øne≈øs.
Sadne≈øs, Fear and Anger will make very ≈øtrange alterations in the Blood; he who knows how to moderate tho≈øe Pa≈ø≈øions, is mo≈øt prudent.

div.head: I.
div.p: A Young Man aged twenty two years, being lately returned from the Ea≈øt-Indies, on the 21 of July, 1655. in the Evening was ≈øuddenly taken with a great pain in his Head, and a ≈øhivering through his whole Body, having that day received much injury from the Water and Air; the day following he became exceedingly delirous, ≈øo that he could not by four men be kept in his Bed.

The Plague at that time raged very much in the next Town, which was very populous: but there had as yet appeared no Symptoms of it in this of ours: We met with no outward ≈øigns of any Malignity, nor did tho≈øe within appear ≈øo con≈øiderable, as to forbid the breathing of a Vein, which the Delirium did very much pre≈øs us upon: I therefore pre≈øcribed a Cordial Mixture, which might al≈øo be Sudorifick; whereof 2 ≈øpoonfuls was to be taken each quarter of an hour, and after the ≈øpace of one hour a Vein to be opened in the right Arm, and ≈øeven ounces of Blood to be taken from thence: I had more than once before made trial of this Mixture in a Pleuri≈øie, which was accompanied with Spots: The De≈øcription of it is as followeth.

Take Waters of Borage, Holy-Thi≈øtle, Bawm, of each an ounce; Alexipharmick Water, an
ounce and half; Cinamon-water, half an ounce; Confection of Alkermes without Amber-greece and Musk, a dram and half; Syrup of the juyce of Citrons, an ounce‚ñ™ Mix them.

The mixture was taken, and a Vein opened, and ≈øuch things as we thought fitting applyed to the Temples, the Neck, and the Soals of the Feet, but all was not ≈øufficient to overcome the Malignity of the Di≈øea≈øe, for he dyed that night.

div.head: II.
div.p:
A Man and his Wife on the 5th of July, were both taken with Buboes in their Groin; She was very drow≈øie, Feveri≈øh, and Anxious, but by the u≈øe of Sudorificks and drawing Plai≈øters, ≈øhe was by the 10th day following re≈øtored to perfect health. He was ≈øeized on by a pain in the Head, and a ≈ømall Delirium which continued till the 5th day, on which he was taken with a great fit of Bleeding, which with ≈øome intermi≈ø≈øion continued for two days, this according to the opinon of all Practical Phy≈øicians was to be judged very dangerous. But when I con≈øidered that his ≈øtrength was not at all hereby impaired, but on the other≈øide, the pain in the Head and the Fever abated, nor did the Bubo ≈øtrike inward; I ca≈øt away fear, and concluded that the Judgments of men by time and experience might be much corrected. I therefore thought it not the be≈øt cour≈øe to continue here the u≈øe of Sudorificks, but rather to ≈øtrengthen the Heart, and to incra≈ø≈øate the Blood, and thereby to ≈øtop the Flux of it. To which purpo≈øe I pre≈øcribed
this which followeth, to be taken by a ≈øpoonful at a time.

Take Water of Ro≈øes and Plantane, of each four ounces; Cinamon-water, ≈øix drams; Dragons-Blood, red Coral prepared, of each a ≈øcruple; Confection of Hyacinth, a dram; Spirit of Salt, eight drops; Syrup of Barberies an ounce and half: Mix them.
Upon the taking of this, the Bleeding and the Delirium both cea≈øed; and thereupon the Patient grew well, the Bubo continuing for ten weeks after.

div.head: III.
div.p: A Maid on the 4th of September, was taken with a Fever, a pain at the Heart, and in the Head, and with a Bubo, which broke out about the inward part of the bending of the left Arm, and ≈øeized on the Tendon of the Mu≈øcle Biceps; from hence proceeded a very acute pain, not only in that part where the Bubo appeared, but al≈øo about the Armpits by con≈øent of parts, although there was no ≈øwelling, which thereabouts appeared. I gave her this Sudorifick forthwith.

Take Dia≈øcordium of Fraca≈øtorius, four ≈øcruples; Sal Prunella, a ≈øcruple; Alexipharmick-water, an ounce and half; and Holy-Thi≈øtle-water, as much as is ≈øufficient; Syrup of Limons, half an ounce: Mix it for a draught.
To the Bubo I applied the Divine Plai≈øter.
The Sweat came plentifully, but the pain of her Arm, a Delirium, and continual watchings, after the u≈øe of ≈øeveral other things, forced us to u≈øe this Landanum Opiat.

Take Bawm-water, an ounce; Holy-Thi≈øtle-water,
an ounce and half; Alexipharmick-water, an ounce; Confection of Hyacinth, a dram; Julep of Ro≈øes, ten drams; Laudanum Opiat, two grains: Mix them.

Of this ≈øhe took every half hour one or two ≈øpoonfuls; and although it cau≈øed Sweat, yet it procured no Sleep. The Chirurgeon for variety, made u≈øe of his Pe≈øtilential Plai≈øter; but neither was the pain hereby remitted: we were therefore forced at length to apply this following to break it.
Take of un≈ølack'd Lime, of Black-Sope, as much as ≈øufficeth.

By the help whereof the Fever very much abated, though the pain continued as before; but yet in the ≈øpace of 10 or 12 days it utterly left her; but the Bubo remained open for ≈øix weeks after, for the whole Glandule was con≈øumed by the Ulcer, & ≈øome part of it which was corrupted, was nece≈ø≈øarily to be ≈øeparated from the other. In the mean while, we had great cau≈øe to fear that the putrefaction had pierced deeper, becau≈øe the Ulcer was deep, and the ≈øides of it callous, and a ≈øerous matter came from it; but by the ble≈ø≈øing of God the Cure ≈øucceeded according to our wi≈øh.

div.head: IV.
div.p: A Book≈øeller in May was very much troubled with two Biles, whereof one broke out on his Buttock, the other on the Scrotum. To remove the cau≈øe hereof, and to abate the Tumor, I pre≈øcribed this following Laxative Apozem to be taken two or three days together.

Take Tamarinds, an ounce; Cream of Tartar,
two drams; Senna, 6 drams; Rhubarb 2 drams and an half; Ani≈øeeds, a dram and half; boil them in Whey, and to a pint of the ≈øtrained Liquor, add two ounces of Syrup of Succory with Rhubarb: Make it into an Apozem.
To the Swelling I applied the Plai≈øter Diachilon with Gums, by the means whereof they were wholly removed.

The ≈øame per≈øon the 26th of Augu≈øt (at which time the Plague raged here very much) was taken with a Bubo in his Groin, which, when after inqui≈øition made (that I might ≈øatisfie the curio≈øity of him and his Wife) I had declared to be Pe≈øtilential, it was ≈øtrange to ≈øee what terrour ≈øeized upon them both, but I quickly cau≈øed them to chear up again, by letting them know that the Life was not at all in danger; for the Man in all other re≈øpects was very well, he eat, drank, and ≈ølept well, had no Fever nor pain at his Heart; neverthele≈øs I gave him Sudorificks more than once; and the Chirurgeon drew a Bli≈øter, and afterwards applied Plai≈øters and drawing Poultices, whereby in the ≈øpace of four weeks the Bubo was wholly di≈ø≈øipated without any Suppuration.

div.head: V.
div.p: A young Emdener of 26 years old, on the 12th of Aug. fell into a continual Fever, accompanied with drow≈øine≈øs, trembling of the Lips, blackne≈øs and drine≈øs of the Tongue, all malignant ≈øigns; but I re≈øtored him again by the 30th of the ≈øame Month: to effect which I pre≈øcribed him a Sudorifick, Morning and Evening, and for his ordinary Drink, this Julep.
Take Holy-Thi≈øtle-water, a pint; Alexipharmick-water, 2 ounces; Julep of Ro≈øes, 2 ounces & half; Spirit of Salt, eight drops: Mix them.
On the 3d day there was Spots di≈øcovered all over his Body, nor was his drow≈øine≈øs or the trembling of his Lips abated, but he vomited not at all. I gave him this Sudorifick.

Take Salt of Scordium, of Holy-Thi≈øtle, of each a ≈øcruple; Antimony Diaphoretick, half a ≈øcruple; Crabs-Eyes bru≈øed, twelve grains; our Prophylactick-water, Mint-water, and Syrup of the juyce of Holy-Thi≈øtle, of each an ounce: Mix it for a Draught.
By the u≈øe hereof the Fever abated very much, and on the eight day I found that he had a Thru≈øh; for the ≈øeparation whereof, I pre≈øcribed this Mixture to be taken by ≈øpoonfuls.
Take the juyce of the greater Hou≈øleek, half an ounce; Water of Self-heal, of Pur≈ølane, of each an ounce and half; the yolk of one Egg, Syrup of Violets compound, ≈øix drams: Mix them.

This being twice or thrice reiterated, and making u≈øe at the ≈øame time of a Lohoch of the Syrup of Pur≈ølane and Violets, by means hereof the Thru≈øh was removed, and the Fever cured without either Purging or letting Blood.

div.head: VI.
div.p:
I was ≈øent for on the 18th of Augu≈øt to a Woman great with child, which was taken with a great drow≈øine≈øs, and had a Pe≈øtilential Bubo brake forth in her Groin, but ≈øhe had ≈øcarcely any Fever; her Eyes looked well, and her Tongue was moi≈øt, and ≈øhe ≈øeemed
very heart-whole, ≈øhe had now gone ≈øeven months, & on the night following ≈øhe was delivered, which I concluded to be a certain ≈øign of Death, and found it true; for on the next day about ten of the Clock ≈øhe departed.

The Husband of this Woman fell ≈øick the ≈øame day, he was delirous, his Eyes ≈øparkled, his Tongue was dry, all which I noted for very ill ≈øigns, his Fever was but ≈ømall, but the pain at his Heart very great, his Urine like that of men well in health. After having taken two Sudorificks, he began to come to him≈øelf, his Tongue was ob≈øerved to be moi≈øt, and a Bubo appeared in his Groin, and a Carbuncle on his Back, which on the next day had three or four more joyned to it. The≈øe Symptoms promi≈øed good ≈øucce≈øs, but it happened otherwi≈øe; for as ≈øoon as he ≈øaw his Wife dead, he was ≈øo altered, that the Bubo ≈øtriking inward, and the Sweat ≈øtopping, the 3d day after he died.
An old Woman related to him, had a Carbuncle without a Fever, and by our u≈øual way of proceeding, was cured in nine days.

div.head: VII.
div.p:
A Midwife which went trembling and un≈øteady, gave me occa≈øion from thence to ≈øu≈øpect ≈øome extraordinary weakne≈øs in her, or a Delirium: nor was I mi≈øtaken; for when I came to feel how languidly her Pul≈øe beat, I found it evident; but yet I could di≈øcover no outward Symptom: neverthele≈øs the drine≈øs of the Tongue, the difficulty of Breathing, and ≈øuch other ≈øigns did di≈øcover that ≈øome Malignity was concealed within; at length upon
enquiry, ≈øhe told us that ≈øhe had a pu≈øh upon her right Thigh, which, upon ≈øearch, we found to be a Carbuncle of the breadth of a Shilling. She would not grant that ≈øhe had any Bubo in her Groin (which neverthele≈øs I doubted not of) nor ≈øuffer the Chirurgeon to ≈øearch. He gave her what was requi≈øite to be applied outwardly, & I pre≈øcribed her a Sudorifick; after two days ≈øhe recovered her ≈øtrength & became of a right mind, & the 3d day ≈øeemed to be perfectly well; but on the Evening of that day all was changed, ≈øhe became re≈øtle≈øs and almo≈øt di≈øtracted, and died that night.

She had taken before I was ≈øent for, Manna with Cream of Tartar, and after that, Tamarinds, all which doing no good, but the Di≈øea≈øe ≈øtill encrea≈øing upon her, ≈øhe conjecturing that there was ≈øome Malignity in it, took an ounce of Plague-Water; which, though it were much weaker than the Malignity required, yet ≈øhe took it for two dayes by my advice; but on the third (what≈øoever I per≈øwaded to the contrary) ≈øhe changed all her Linnen, even to her Head-cloaths, and drank Whey in which Tamarinds had been boiled, from whence proceeded her ≈øudden change for the wor≈øe, and upon that her Death; and the≈øe are the effects of ≈øelf-conceitedne≈øs.

div.head: VIII.
div.p:
Helena van Wyngaerden, a Servant of mine, on the fir≈øt day had ≈øome ≈ølight Symptoms of the Di≈øea≈øe, the next ≈øhe was taken with Vomiting, a pain in the Head, and at her Heart, e≈øpecially when ≈øhe endeavoured to ri≈øe from
her Bed, her Eyes look'd red, but her Tongue was well enough, and her Fever was but ≈ømall; a few dayes before, without my knowledge, ≈øhe had been at an hou≈øe that was vi≈øited; I gave her pre≈øently a Sudorifick; whereupon, the third day after a Bubo appeared in the left Groin; I continued the u≈øe of Sudorificks, and the Chirurgeon took care of the Bubo, by which means, within a fortnight ≈øhe perfectly recovered, and went again about her bu≈øine≈øs.

div.head: IX.
div.p: The Daughter of N. Domer, on the ≈øecond of September, complained of a great pain in her head, and at her Heart, and her Tongue grew black and dry. The fir≈øt and ≈øecond day we put her into a Sweat, and on the third, ≈øhe told us that ≈øhe was perfectly well; her Tongue became moi≈øt, her Pain, her Fever & Anxiety left her; neverthele≈øs I per≈øwaded her to continue the Sudorificks, but ≈øhe aro≈øe and ate and drank, went abroad, and after that ≈ølept well all night; but in the morning the former Symptoms returned, and in the evening of the ≈øame day there appeared Spots, and the next morning ≈øhe died.

div.head: X.
div.p:
N. N. had lain very ill for ≈øix dayes, at what time I was ≈øent for to him on the twentieth of Augu≈øt, he began to be light-headed, his Tongue became black and dry, and he had a great anxiety at his Heart, his Eyes were fixed, his Hands trembled, and a great Carbuncle di≈øcovered it ≈øelf on his Cheek, who≈øe Tail reached to his very Chin, which was al≈øo hard and
much ≈øwelled. It ≈øeem'd to threaten a much greater increa≈øe; for it was very dry, & much inflamed, and not circum≈øcribed within any bounds. To this was added a pain in the Throat (which Symptom I conjectured to be mortal) and a very inten≈øe Fever. This de≈øperate ca≈øe put us in mind of de≈øperate Remedies; wherefore being guided by my ow Rea≈øon and Experience, and per≈øwaded by the Authority of the mo≈øt Eminent Phy≈øitians, both Ancient and Modern, I boldly recommended to him an actual Cautery, which was pre≈øently applied by the Chirurgeon, without any great pain to the Patient: This Operation was perform'd in the Morning at ten of the Clock, and between 4 and 5 in the Afternoon it appear ‚Ä¢ d purulent, and the Cru≈øt began to be ≈øeparated, nor did the Core of it creep any further; all which effects, I know not from what means they could have been expected be≈øides this. In the mean while he ≈øweat plentifully, and all things gave his Friends to hope that he would again recover; but I was of another mind, as knowing well the nature of this treacherous Di≈øea≈øe. The ≈øame Evening he took another Sudorifick, and ≈ølept quietly enough all night. On the 21 day the Cheek that was affected, di≈øcovered on it ≈øome moi≈øture, the Fever continued as it was: Between his forefinger and his middle one there brake forth a very painful Carbuncle, which affected the whole Arm. To this there was applied another actual Cautery without any great alteration di≈øcerned in the Patient; then we pre≈øcribed him a Julep which might cau≈øe Sweat, & ≈øome food that was nouri≈øhing, but no
Sweat appear'd, & the affected places being drier than the re≈øt, fore-boded an ill event. At 9 in the Morning another Chirurgeon was ≈øent for, who approved of what≈øoever we had done in this ca≈øe; at midnight he fell into an high Delirium ‚ñ™ ≈øo that he could not be held in his Bed by tho≈øe which attended; about morning he betook him≈øelf to re≈øt, & in one hour after departed: Some of his Friends accu≈øed me of being negligent, which ingratitude I can the better bear; ≈øince I am con≈øcious to my ≈øelf, and give thanks to God for it, that I omitted nothing which the Rules of Art required to be done.

div.head: XI.
div.p: The Wife of Cornelius Jan≈øon being fifty years old, was after ≈øhe had been ≈øick two dayes troubled with a Bubo in her Groin, and a great anxiety of Heart; but the Fever was but ≈ømall: Her Eyes (which I do much ob≈øerve in all ≈øick per≈øons (look'd very well; as ≈øoon as ≈øhe ≈øweat, ≈øhe began to confe≈øs her ≈øelf better, her anxiety was pre≈øently removed, and her Fever al≈øo after few days: The Bubo (a Bli≈øter being fir≈øt drawn (was dre≈ø≈øed by a Chirurgeon with the Magnetical Ar≈øenick Plai≈øter: She fell ≈øick on the eighteenth of September, and her Son on the 23d, who was taken with a pain in his Head, and refu≈øing all Medicines, died within three dayes, but ≈øhe recovered.

div.head: XII.
div.p:
Everard Te≈ø≈øalear, a Vintner, was taken on the 28th of September, with a chilne≈øs all over him, and then with a very great heat, his anxiety was great, and his breathing difficult,
accompanied with nau≈øeating, a pain in the Head, a trembling of the Hands, a burning of the Eyes, and an intolerable pain on the right ≈øide of the Groin, yet without an apparent ≈øwelling. I gave in my Opinion that he was taken with a Pe≈øtilential Fever, and pre≈øcribed ≈øome Remedies for that purpo≈øe; after the fir≈øt Sudorifick, the pain in the Head and Groin abated, and the Vomiting was ≈øtopped; after the ≈øecond, the pain became tolerable; and by the fourth, it was wholly taken away, and the Feaver cured: Being ≈øo ≈øuddenly re≈øtored, he believed not that there was any Malignity in it, and went abroad forthwith; which I did very much di≈øallow, accu≈øing him of unthankfulne≈øs to God, and foretelling that he was to ≈øuffer ≈øomewhat more ≈øevere, becau≈øe I could ea≈øily perceive his Health and Strength not to be confirmed, and that there was need of a further cour≈øe of Phy≈øick to ≈øettle it. He ≈øtill refu≈øed to hearken to me, till on the day following he was attaqued by the ≈øame Enemy, and his Wife al≈øo; he fir≈øt complained of a pain in his Groin, and then of a Bubo, which Symptoms confirmed the truth of what I had foretold, and cau≈øed him to repent when it was too late: The fear of Death made him now de≈øirous of repeating the Sudorificks, by means whereof, through the Divine a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, they were both cured in nine dayes, though the Bubo continued on the Woman for a Month after.

div.head: XIII.
div.p:
Albert N. on the ≈øecond of October, was taken with a great pain at the Heart, his Pul≈øe was
not to be di≈øcerned by a gentle touch, his Countenance was like one in an Agony, he was extream prone to Vomit and to Sleep; but he was pretty well in his Sen≈øes, his Eyes were not inflamed, his Tongue moi≈øt, the Fever but ≈ømall, and the Thir≈øt not great: The Vomiting was pre≈øently relieved by the u≈øe of tho≈øe things which we have mentioned in their proper place; but the Sweat came but ≈ølowly: whereupon I gave him the next day a more powerful Sudorifick, whereof we found very notable effects, but his thir≈øt by that means being increa≈øed, made him drink a great quantity of Beer, whereby the vomiting returned, and becau≈øe he complained of a pain in his Belly, we were afraid of a Diarhaea; wherefore in≈øtead of Beer, we gave him this following Mixture by Spoonfuls.
Take Ro≈øe-water, two ounces; Holy-Thi≈øtle-water, four ounces; Mint-water, an ounce; Cinamon-water, three drams; our Prophylactick-Water, an ounce and half; Syrup of Myrtles, two ounces: Mix them.
And in the Evening he took this Sudorifick.
Take Confection of Hyacinth, a ≈øcruple; Treacle, Dia≈øcordium, of each two ≈øcruples; Salt of Coral, fifteen grains; our Prophylactick-Water, ten drams: Mix it for a draught.

The night after pa≈ø≈øed quietly, the Vomiting cea≈øed; the third day after there was a Carbuncle di≈øcovered on the in≈øide of the left No≈øtril: We applied to it our Divine Plai≈øter, and inwardly we gave Sudorificks, and ≈øuch things as
might refrigerate; on the 4th day his No≈øe was ob≈øerved to be cold, and to look of a purple colour, the Carbuncle extending it ≈øelf to the Proce≈ø≈øus Mammiformis; the Pul≈øe beat low and unequal, neverthele≈øs he took another Sudorofick, but without ≈øucce≈øs; for about Noon many mortal ≈øigns di≈øcovered them≈øelves; and although he was all along of a ≈øound mind, yet after two hours he departed.

div.head: XIV.
div.p: The Wife of John N. Chirurgeon, in September was ≈øuddenly taken with a Fever, with drow≈øine≈øs and anxiety of heart. I pre≈øcribed this Sudorifick.

Take Dia≈øcordium of Fraca≈øtorius; a dram; Confection of Hyacinth, Lapis Prunellae, Salt of Scordium, of each a ≈øcruple; our Prophylactick Water, an ounce; Betony Water, as much as ≈øufficeth; Syrup of the juyce of Holy-Thi≈øtle, half an ounce: Mix it for a draught.
It produced no Sweat, which was an ill Omen: The next day therefore ≈øhe took this which is ≈øomewhat ≈øtronger.
Take Treacle, Dia≈øcordium, of each a dram & half; our Prophylactick Water, an ounce and half; Salt of Holy-Thi≈øtle, a ≈øcruple; Syrup of Limons, ≈øix drams: Mix it for a Potion.
And this al≈øo effected nothing: For variety ≈øake in the Evening I gave her this following.
Take Salt of Wormwood, Scordium, Prunella, Antimony Diaphoretick, of each a ≈øcruple; Syrup of the Juice of Holy-Thi≈øtle, an ounce; Our Prophylactick Water, two ounces: Mix it for a Draught.
By the help whereof ≈øhe began to ≈øweat, & the Fever to abate, together with the anxiety; but the third day after the Spots appear'd, which carried her off immediately.

Her Husband, after eight days, beginning to vi≈øit his Patients again, came about eight in the morning to one that was ≈øick, when ≈øitting down on a Stool, he was ≈øuddenly ≈øo taken, that he could not ri≈øe again; about Noon, by the help of his Son and his Man, he went home, where taking his Bed, he was pre≈øently ≈øeized with a great drow≈øine≈øs, which I call'd a Coma; becau≈øe whatever I did or ≈øaid to him, I could not get two words from him; I pre≈øently pre≈øcribed him a Cly≈øter, and this Ointment for his Head.
Take Oil of Marjoram, a ≈øcruple; Oil of Rue, a dram; of Amber rectified, a ≈øcruple; Ro≈øemary, half a ≈øcruple: Mix them.
I advi≈øed al≈øo that they ≈øhould endeavour to make him ≈øneeze by putting Tobacco to his No≈øe, and give him inwardly ≈øome of this Mixture.
Take Anti-Epileptick water, of our Porphylactick water, of Betony and Ro≈øewater, Syrup of Stoechas, of each an ounce.

The Cly≈øter came from him without any effect, and Tobacco did no good; he took a little of the Mixture; and about evening I pre≈øcribed him another Cly≈øter, and this Sneezing-Powder following, was blown up his No≈øtrils with a Quill.
Take the flower of Lillies of the Valley, Leaves of Marjoram, of each half a ≈øcruple; white Hellebore, three grains: Make them into fine Powder.

By the help hereof he ≈øneezed 3 or 4 times, and a purulent Matter came from him at his Mouth, but a greater quantity of it went down his Throat; be≈øides which, there remained a great deal of it in his Mouth, which we could ea≈øily ≈øqueeze forth by pre≈ø≈øing his Cheeks. The≈øe were ≈øufficient ≈øigns of an Ab≈øce≈ø≈øus in the Brain, and con≈øequently of certain Death, e≈øpecially when we could not perceive that his Sen≈øes returned to him, not that he was any other way reliev'd, but on the contrary, his voice quite failed him, and he began to rattle in the Throat; nor was I deceived in my conjecture; for in a ≈øhort ≈øpace he died.

Four of his Children, and a Maid-≈øervant followed him; his Man was cured of a Bubo under his Arm-pit by drawing a Bli≈øter, and by applying ≈øome drawing Medicines. His elde≈øt Daughter and younge≈øt Son ≈øtill ≈øurvived: He had a Fever, but was not very ≈øick; but ≈øhe was handled more ≈øeverely: She had a Thru≈øh appeared on the eighth day, which took off not only the Fever, but the whole Di≈øea≈øe; and thus of ten in Family, but three e≈øcaped. You have here an account of the true Signs and Effects of Malignity, which none but ≈øuch as are po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd with the Spirit of contradiction, can deny to be Contagious.

div.head: A De≈øcription of a LANCET, FOR The more ≈øecure Letting of BLOOD,

argument.p:
FOra≈ømuch as it hath been thought convenient by ≈øeveral good Chirurgeons, to contrive a ≈øafe way of Blood-letting, for the benefit of young Beginners in that Profe≈ø≈øion; and whereas Dr. LOWER of late, in his Treati≈øe of the Heart, hath di≈øcovered a plain and ≈øecure way of Bleeding, and given a figure of the Lancet, which he commends for that
purpo≈øe, I have been advi≈øed, for the publick Good, to tran≈ølate what he hath written, and likewi≈øe give the figure of the Lancet, and de≈øcription of the U≈øe of it, as it is printed in the 166 page of the la≈øt and true≈øt Edition of his Book, Printed at Am≈øterdam 1671. in the Author's own words.

div.p: HOw great Ebullition ≈øometimes happens in the Blood, in what ve≈ø≈øels, and with what ≈øwift motion it is ca≈øt about every where through the Body, and if an Artery be opened how quickly, and with what force it breaks out, it hath been hitherto treated of in the foregoing Di≈øcour≈øe; by which it appears, how nece≈ø≈øary ≈øometimes Blood-letting is, to dimini≈øh its Quantity, or to ≈øtop its Career, and how dangerous the Admini≈øtration of it is, if it be performed by a rude and unskilful hand.

For it often happening, either by want of skill, or common practice of Bleeding, (which makes the Mind fearful, and con≈øequently the Hand trembling and uncertain) that an Artery is opened, or a Nerve or Tendon cut or prick'd, whence follows Swellings, Pains, Inflammations, Gangrenes or Convul≈øions, which put the member in danger of being cut off, or render'd u≈øele≈øs, I thought it might not be beyond the ≈øcope of my Treati≈øe, if, by way of Appendix,
I ≈øhould ≈øhew by what means and In≈øtrument any Vein might be ≈øafely and ≈øecurely opened, (if it ≈øwell upon a Ligature (though it have an Artery, Nerve or Tendon immediately under it.

Fora≈ømuch therefore as never any harm happens in Blood-letting, unle≈øs a Vein be prick'd through or ≈ølipping a≈øide, the Lancet be put too deep into the part, the Fabrick of this Lancet is ≈øuch, and ought to be ≈øo put into the Vein, as both may be ea≈øily prevented.

For the Lancet is ≈øo contrived, that it is not cutting on each ≈øide, unle≈øs it be near the point, but is purpo≈øely blunt, and made round on the lower ≈øide, which is to be applied next to the skin, that it may more ea≈øily ≈ølide over it, as it appears by the following Table, in which.
a the Lancet.
b the place where the upper edge of the Lancet ends in a plain.

c where the under edge of the Lancet ends, the re≈øt of the under part being poli≈øh'd round, and thick, (but not made thicker than the upper plain part) that it may not grate or tear the skin (upon which it mu≈øt be applied) by its compre≈ø≈øion.
Which figure of the Lancet differs nothing from a common ordinary Lancet, but that the under edge of it is blunted almo≈øt to the point.

The way of u≈øing it is only this, that the Member being tied, and the Vein ≈øwelling, the
Lancet mu≈øt be applied as near to it as po≈ø≈øible, but ≈øo that the Lancet may be depre≈øs'd as much as may be; then the Point of it being directed upwards, it mu≈øt be gently, and by an oblique tran≈øver≈øe Inci≈øion be put into the Vein: which if ≈øo directed, neither can the Vein avoid the point of the Lancet, or the parts underneath be any way offended. Which way of Blooding, as it is mo≈øt ea≈øie, ≈øo it will never prove unhappy to any one, though but meanly skilful.

And though I do not write this to Phy≈øicians and Chirurgeons, who are expert and frequently exerci≈øed in bleeding; yet having ≈øeen many peoples health and life endangered, either by ill Blood-letting, or becau≈øe a good Chirurgeon could not timely be called in by Phy≈øicians, who mo≈øt commonly forbear the Practice of it, therefore I have devi≈øed this figure of a Lancet, that they may more ≈øecurely and confidently u≈øe it.

div.head: CISTA MILITARIS, OR, A Military Che≈øt, Furni≈øhed either for Sea or Land, with convenient Medicines and In≈øtruments.
div.p:
WHil≈øt I was in the Low Countries in the year 1612. in the City of
‚Ä¢ orsk, I was entertained with great kindne≈øs by that Noble and Valiant Gentleman, Alexander de Schweichel, Governour of the Place and Works, who among≈øt the other things worthy ≈øeeing, ≈øhewed me the Military Che≈øt of the mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious Heroe, Maurice, Prince of Orange, &c. wherein not onely Medicines and In≈øtruments, but al≈øo Linnen, Rowlers, and other Nece≈ø≈øaries were prepared, and di≈øpo≈øed all in order in a Room, but not as then put into the Che≈øts, which were fitly contrived for that purpo≈øe, becau≈øe that the Garri≈øon-Souldiers might be
≈øupplied with what they needed for their healths; and al≈øo that the Medicines that were wanting or decayed, might be forthwith renewed: an evident ≈øign, and great demon≈øtration of the Piety, Prudence, and Care of this Prince towards his Souldiers. This Che≈øt, as often as nece≈ø≈øity required march'd with the Camp, and in the greate≈øt and mo≈øt dangerous occa≈øions the Souldiers were for the pre≈øent ≈øuccoured, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted from it. Then afterwards they were carried to the next Cities, where they were taken care of by Phy≈øicians and Chirurgeons, appointed and paid by the States: and if by chance any Souldier lo≈øt a Limb, or was lame, he was relieved, and had an Annual Pen≈øion from the States. This Pious and Chri≈øtian Con≈øtitution made the Souldiers de≈øpi≈øe all dangers, and incouraged them to be both valiant and daring.

Therefore that Generals may under≈øtand what things are mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to furni≈øh a Che≈øt with, I thought good to ≈øet down both the principal Medicaments, and In≈øtruments, that a Chirurgeon, following the Camp or Sea, ought to be provided with; and if there ≈øhould be occa≈øion for any others, he may furni≈øh him≈øelf at the next Shop he comes at.

The Che≈øt ought to be ≈øo divided into Partitions and Cla≈ø≈øes, that all confu≈øion and intermixing of Medicines may be avoided, and the Virtue and Propriety of each pre≈øerved. To this purpo≈øe I have divided it into twenty Cla≈ø≈øes.

The fir≈øt contains purging Simples, which mu≈øt be put up in Leather-bags, except Manna
and Ca≈ø≈øia extracted, which may more conveniently be kept in Galli-pots. Tho≈øe Bags again are to be put into other larger, and writ upon in great Characters, Purging Simples.
In the ≈øecond Cla≈ø≈øis are contained Purging Electuaries, which are to be kept in Galli-pots, writ upon, Purging Compounds: and ≈øo of the re≈øt.

Syrups, and di≈øtill'd Waters, are to be put into double Gla≈ø≈øes, clo≈øe cork'd, and tied down with Bladders. They mu≈øt be ≈øo plac'd, that they may not move, and ≈øo break each other, and their cells lined with Baiz.
Pills are to be wrapt up in white leather, rubb'd fir≈øt with oyl of ≈øweet Almonds.
Cordial Powders and Electuaries, being put into leather bags, are to be ≈øo plac'd in a ≈øeparate cla≈ø≈øis, that they may not mix with the Purgers.
Roots, Herbs, Flowers, and Seeds are likewi≈øe to be kept in Bags of Leather or Linnen, and to be ≈øo di≈øtributed, that in the fir≈øt Cla≈ø≈øis the Roots, ≈øecond Herbs, &c.

Oyls, and common Bal≈øams, in Gla≈øs-bottles, with ≈øcrewed Pewter-heads; but the pretious Chymical Oyls, as of Cinnamon, Cloves, Maces, Nutmegs, &c. ought to be pre≈øerv'd in double Gla≈ø≈øes well ≈øtopt with Cork, and waxt. The Bal≈øams likewi≈øe of the≈øe are to be kept in Gla≈ø≈øes, or Silver.
∆≤nguents, and Fats are be≈øt kept in Galli-pots, or of Pewter, well tied down with Paper and Leather. And Turpentine ≈øo likewi≈øe.
Plai≈øters, Gums, Wax, the Sewet of Bears, Cows, Goats, and the like, which are of a ≈øolid con≈øi≈øtence, are to be put in Bladders wrapt afterwards in Paper.

Metals, and ≈øubterraneous Medicaments, as Vitriol, Allum, Letharge, Bole, &c. as al≈øo Meals, mu≈øt be put into Leather-bags: but prepared Tutia, Seif Album, O≈øtiocolla, and the like, which are to be u≈øed in Colliriums, or given inwardly, are to be wrapt up in Paper, and put into Leather-bags, and plac'd among≈øt the Cordials. Let all the Bags be tied clo≈øe, and written upon in great Letters, to prevent confu≈øion.

Ar≈ønick, Orpiment, crude Mercury, ≈øublimate, proecipitate, cau≈øtick‚ñ™ Minium Troches, Spirit of Vitriol, Aqua fortis, and the like corro≈øive Medicines, are not to be plac'd in the Che≈øt, le≈øt the Gla≈øs, or what other things they are contained in, break, and ≈øo ≈øpoil and prejudice the other Medicines, and withal endanger the lives of the ≈øick; therefore to prevent this, it is more convenient to keep them in ≈øome Box or Che≈øt apart by them≈øelves.

The In≈øtruments are to be pre≈øerv'd in this manner. Tho≈øe that are for cutting, and edged, as Ra≈øors, Sci≈ø≈øors, Inci≈øion-Knives, &c. are to be kept in Ca≈øes, the re≈øt are wrapt in Paper, or rather in Flannel.
The≈øe being thus prepared and in readine≈øs, you mu≈øt take a Catalogue of all‚ñ™ that you may pre≈øently, and without trouble, find them when you have occa≈øion for them.

As your Che≈øt is divided into cla≈ø≈øes, after the ≈øame manner it is nece≈ø≈øary to write your Catalogue; and as often as any Simple & Compound Medicine is wanting, mark it on the Margin of the Catalogue, that you may ≈øupply its defect.
All which, kind Reader, I thought good to advi≈øe: the Cla≈ø≈øes following now in order.

div.p: Be≈øides the above recited Medicines, it is al≈øo mo≈øt requi≈øite, that a Chirurgeon ≈øhould be furni≈øhed with nece≈ø≈øary In≈øtruments, without which he cannot perform his duty as he ought. They may be divided into two ≈øorts, ≈øome to be fitted for a Box, which he ought continually to carry about him in his Pocket; the≈øe ought to be made ≈ømall and little, that they may neither load him, nor afright the Patient: the others are to be kept in the Che≈øt, whil≈øt occa≈øion calls for their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. I never vi≈øited my Patients without a Box of In≈øtruments in my Pocket, in the which were contained the following:

A pair of Forceps for the ≈øame u≈øe.
Needles, to ≈øtitch up great Wounds, which are to be of different Sizes, ≈øome great, others ≈ømall, &c.

A ≈øtitching Quill, which is u≈øed in ≈øtitching Wounds: it ought to be of that length, as to contain the Needles within its hollowne≈øs. Wounds of the Fle≈øhy parts only are to be ≈øtitcht, nervous parts in no wi≈øe. In wounds of the face I never u≈øe Needle, but that which is called the dry ≈øtitch.
Spatula's, great and little.
Speculum oris, one end of which, in affects of the Jaws, and Throat, is to depre≈øs the tongue, the other to ≈øcrape it.
A Burrus quill, to ≈øprinkle Powders upon Wounds or Ulcers.
A Hook, ≈øingle at one end, and two at the other.
A Hone, to ≈øet the Inci≈øion-Knives, Lancets, &c.

I had all the≈øe In≈øtruments, and many more, made me by a skilful Arti≈øt in Silver, which I u≈øed only within the Town, Patients being le≈øs afraid of them than of Iron: but at Sea and at Camps it is not ≈øo ≈øafe for a Chirurgeon to have them of Silver, therefore they may be very conveniently made of Iron or Steel, except the Probes, which ought to be made of Lead, Copper, or Latin.

The≈øe In≈øtruments a Chirurgeon ought always to have about him, as al≈øo a Salvatory with ≈øix divi≈øions, which ought to be furni≈øh'd
1. with unguentum Ba≈øilicon, 2. with ung. Aureum, 3. Apo≈øtolorum, 4. Nutritum, 5. Album Rha≈øis, the 6. with Rubrum Ex≈øiccativum, or de Minio: it ought to be made of Horn, or ≈øome ≈øolid wood, as Ebony, Guajacum, or Box, for Unguents are better pre≈øerved in wood, than in Silver, Copper, &c. It is al≈øo requi≈øite that he hath about him in a Pewter Bottle ≈øome oyl of Ro≈øes, to anoint any wounded part, it ea≈øeth pain, &c. as al≈øo another pot with a dige≈øtive.
Thus much for the In≈øtruments, which a Chirurgeon ought to wear about him; now follow the others, and fir≈øt of tho≈øe that are us'd about the Head.
1. Trepans, by which the Skull is perforated in great Contu≈øions, to give pa≈ø≈øage to extrava≈øated and concreted blood collected in the head.
2. Levatories, to rai≈øe the depre≈ø≈øed skull.
3. Scalpra's, to ≈øcrape the carious skull.
4. A great Speculum oris, by which the Tongue, in great inflammations of the Jaws and Throat, is depre≈øs'd.
5. Another ≈øpeculum oris, to force open the Mouth, which, as I have ≈øeen ≈øometimes in ≈øpa≈ømus's, to be ≈øo clo≈øe ≈øhut, that a drop of Broth could not be poured in.
6. Several In≈øtruments to draw Teeth.

7. And becau≈øe ≈øometimes in eating, a fi≈øh-bone or the like is fixt in the Throat, and ≈øo would ≈øuffocate the per≈øon, therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary for a Chirurgeon to have in his Che≈øt ≈øuch an In≈øtrument, as I have de≈øcribed in the 36 Ob≈øervation of the fir≈øt Century: but if
he hath it not at hand, let him forthwith make fa≈øt a piece of Spunge to the end of a Catheter, and thru≈øt it down the Throat.

8. In≈øtruments to draw forth Bullets from Gun≈øhot-wounds, of which there are divers ≈øet down by Authors. I e≈øteem that the mo≈øt convenient, who≈øe De≈øcription you may ≈øee in the 88. Ob≈ø. of the fir≈øt Century.
9. A great Saw, for amputating great Members.

10. A little Saw for the di≈ømembring Fingers, and Toes; it not becoming a Rational Chirurgeon to ≈øeparate them with Chi≈ø≈øels, as I have more largely ≈øhewn in my Treati≈øe of a Gangrene, &c. chap. 17.
11. Becau≈øe in amputating, the greater part of Chirurgeons u≈øe a Knife, it is convenient to have one well ≈øet, and ≈øtrongly fixt in a Handle.
12. A crooked Knife: its De≈øcription ≈øee in the above named book of a Gangrene.

13. I, in the taking off of Members, in≈øtead of a Knife, u≈øe a Cautery, made in fa≈øhion of a Knife, well edged, and red hot: its de≈øcription is in the above named Treati≈øe. He ought likewi≈øe to have ready other Cauteries, ≈øome larger, others le≈ø≈øer; ≈øome ≈øharp, others round, which may be u≈øed to ≈øtop the flux of Blood after Amputation, or other great and dangerous Hemorages.

14. And becau≈øe Souldiers, from their debaucheries and impure copulation, are oftentimes troubled with the running of the Reins, Carbuncles, and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of ∆≤rine, it is nece≈ø≈øary a Chirurgeon ≈øhould be provided with Catheters and Syrenges.

15. For the reducing of Broken Bones, and Di≈ølocations there are ≈øeveral In≈øtruments, both by Hippocrates, Ortha≈øius, and other Authors, ≈øet down; but I have always found in my practice the In≈øtrument of Ambro≈øe Parey, which is with a Pulley, the mo≈øt convenient; e≈øpecially if you join to it the Girdle and Remora, as in the 86. Ob≈øervation of the fifth Century: it is not only the mo≈øt convenient, but mo≈øt u≈øeful In≈øtrument for all Fractures and Di≈ølocations, except of the Fingers, Ribs, and Mandibles (which are ≈øet by the hand alone; it is al≈øo little, and therefore not trouble≈øome to carry about one.

16. A Chirurgeon ought al≈øo to be provided with Splints of ≈øeveral bigne≈ø≈øes, ≈øome little, others big, according to the qualities of the members broken, which ought to be made of thin pieces of Wood, or of Scabbards.

He mu≈øt be provided likewi≈øe with Mortars, Sives, Skillets to boyl Catapla≈øms in, and al≈øo to mix up Oyntments; and with Gly≈øter-pipes, who≈øe u≈øe in Angina's, wounds of the Head, Fevers, &c. are very u≈øeful.

The De≈øcription and Cuts of the In≈øtruments are given by Ambro≈øe Parey, Joh. Andreas √† Cruce; but becau≈øe this ≈øhould be a compleat Treati≈øe of Chirurgery, there is added to it ≈øeveral Copper-plates of the mo≈øt u≈øeful In≈øtruments for almo≈øt all operations, but e≈øpecially of all tho≈øe that relate any way to the operations mentioned in this Book.

div.head: CLASSIS XX. Linnen Rowlers, and the like.
div.p: THE Che≈øt cannot be perfectly furni≈øhed, if Linnen, and the benefit received from it, in the application of Medicines, be wanting; for what profit Medicaments, though the mo≈øt excellent, without Linnen? e≈øpecially in great and dangerous fluxes of Blood, fractures and di≈ølocations of the Bones, and in other accidents, where there is danger in delay; therefore you mu≈øt have always in readine≈øs Rowlers, both large, narrow, and middle-≈øized, Linnen cloaths doubled, which we call Compre≈ø≈øors, or Boul≈øter-pledgets of Tow.
Lint, which we u≈øe to apply Medicaments upon, and to keep the lips of the Wounds a≈øunder, that they unite not again.

Tents al≈øo of Lint, of prepared Spunges‚ñ™ Gentian roots, and the like, which are to be of ≈øeveral ≈øizes, ≈øome big, ≈øome little, &c. they ought to be prepared at lea≈øure hours, that they may be ready when occa≈øion requires.
He mu≈øt have al≈øo Spunges, and Oxe-bladders, which are nece≈ø≈øary to tye down Pots and Gla≈ø≈øes, and al≈øo u≈øed in Amputation.

If a Sea or Land-Chirurgeon be furni≈øhed with the above recited things, and have about him both faithful and expert Servants, he will be able to give a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to a whole Fleet or Army, and pre≈øerve infinites from death.

Candid Reader, I have been ≈øomewhat prolix in the ≈øetting down the Medicaments, and
other things, by rea≈øon I de≈øigned to de≈øcribe a mo≈øt perfect, and every way compleat furni≈øhed Che≈øt; but if thou art to furni≈øh one at thy one particular charge, thou may≈øt ≈øelect out of them the mo≈øt u≈øeful and nece≈ø≈øary Medicaments; but be ≈øure likewi≈øe that it be ≈øo provided both with Medicaments and In≈øtruments, that out of it, when occa≈øion requires, thou may≈øt be able to a≈ø≈øi≈øt and relieve the Sick; for what thou art imployed about here, is neither Bea≈øt, nor Pretious Stones, but Man, for whom the Son of God ≈øhed his pretious blood upon the Cro≈øs: therefore if any thing be neglected, it mu≈øt be an≈øwered before the Almighty, to whom an account of all our Actions mu≈øt be render'd.

div.head: A BODY OF MILITARY MEDICINES EXPERIMENTED.
CHAP. I. Concerning the Morals of a Souldier.
div.p:
WHereas the Old Philo≈øophers wi≈øhed to every one MENTEM SANAM IN CORPORE SANO, a Sound Mind in a Sound Body; con≈øidering how much it conduceth to the Health of the Body to have the Mind free from Vice and Vexation: It will behove a Souldier, as much at lea≈øt as any man, to endeavour after that Soundne≈øs and Integrity of con≈øcience, which may in≈øpire him with true Fortitude, undi≈øturbed from the troubles and anxieties accompanying Impiety and Inju≈øtice. To this end, he ought,
in the fir≈øt place, be con≈øtant in paying his Duties to Almighty God, by ≈øerving Him in publick and private, by imploring the Divine protection and ble≈ø≈øing in all his Ju≈øt undertakings, and by returning his humble acknowledgments for every good ≈øucce≈øs. Next, he ought to ≈øerve his Prince faithfully to the be≈øt of his skill and power, to obey his Officers readily, and to do to all others, as he would be done to, if he were in their condition.

div.head: CHAP. II. What care a Souldier is to take of his Body.
div.p:
THe Mind being thus taken care of, thou art to advi≈øe with a skilful Phy≈øician concerning thy Body, whether it be not nece≈ø≈øary to purge it, the better to ≈øecure thy ≈øelf from Agues and Fevers. Then furni≈øh thy ≈øelf with ≈øome Mithridate or Treacle, to u≈øe it again≈øt Infection; taking of it in the morning fa≈øting, again≈øt the ill Air, the quantity of a Ha≈øel-Nut. Take al≈øo with thee a quantity of Zedoary, Angelica, Imperatoria or Ma≈øterwort, and Carlina; of which thou ≈øhalt do well, now and then to eat ≈øome for the pre≈øervation of thy ≈øtrength, and again≈øt the corruption of the Air. But e≈øpecially keep thy Head and Feet warm, by the neglect of which thou mai≈øt ca≈øt thy ≈øelf into great danger. Take heed of ≈øurcharging the ≈øtomach, which is to prepare and to convey the nouri≈øhment
for the whole body, and re≈øtrain as much as thou can≈øt thy appetite, there being nothing more hurtful to health, than when that is irregular and extravagant.
Gird thy ≈øelf well, that thy body may be clo≈øe, and ≈øo be ≈øecured from receiving mi≈øchief in leaping, falling, ≈øtorming, &c. and thy bowels from being put out of their place.

Take al≈øo with thee out of the Apothecary's ≈øhop a powder, called Pulvis ≈øolutivus de Tribus, which is not dear. Of this, when thou neede≈øt purging, take the weight of a ducat or a little more, according to thy con≈øtitution, in warm fle≈øh-broath or the like, early in the morning fa≈øting; ≈øo ordering the matter, that that day thou mai≈øt keep thy ≈øelf warm in thy quarter. Fa≈øt two hours after the taking of it, and then eat warm meat. The ≈øame be done with Pulvis Sena Montagnana, and Pulvis ≈øolutivus de Tartaro.

If thou be troubled with Corns on thy feet, apply to them every day fre≈øh lard, and continue this, till by the fatne≈øs of the lard they grow ≈øoft; and then they will fall off from the very roots without pain.

To free or ≈øecure thy ≈øelf from Vermin, take a good quantity of Wormwood, and the inner cuttings of hor≈øe-hoofs, cut out by the Farriers when they ≈øhooe hor≈øes; boyl the≈øe both together in half lye and half water, and ≈øo put thy ≈øhirt into it, and afterwards dry it in the Air, without wa≈øhing it out any other way, and not a Low≈øe will come into it. This Experiment is found approved among≈øt the old German Souldiers; and although there
≈øhould be a Low≈øe in thy ≈øhirt, it would not ≈øtay there.

If thy feet be moi≈øt and ≈øweaty, (which is very trouble≈øome not only to thy ≈øelf, but to others al≈øo,) take the filings of Bra≈øs, which are ≈øometimes u≈øed for du≈øt to dry moi≈øt writings with, and put ≈øome of it into thy ≈øocks, and walk upon it. Refre≈øh this every other or third day, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øoon be freed of that inconvenience: Nor be thou troubled, that it makes, as it will do, thy feet look greeni≈øh; for there is no hurt at all in that, ≈øince you are not like to put them in your cap.

Take al≈øo with thee ≈øome Stags or Bucks-grea≈øe, to make u≈øe of in ca≈øe thou ≈øhould≈øt be galled any where in riding, or going on foot. Anoint the part therewith at the fire-≈øide, and it will ≈øoon be healed.
To prevent Ru≈øt, draw thy Sword through the fat of a Goo≈øe or a Capon, or grea≈øe thy Arms therewith.

Take care to have always about thee a hard cru≈øt of Rye-bread; for if thou art dry, and de≈øtitute of water, wine or beer, to quench thy thir≈øt, chew ≈øome of this dry cru≈øt, and it will moi≈øten thy mouth, and con≈øiderably abate thy thir≈øt. The ≈øame may be done with a Leaden-bullet, rolled to and fro in the mouth, Lead being cooling.

It hath been pre≈øcribed above, to take with thee the Herbs Imperatoria and Carlina. Of this be mindful; for if it ≈øhould happen, that thou ≈øhould≈øt be obliged to ≈øtand ≈øome hours in battel or in the field, take a piece of it in thy mouth for hunger, thir≈øt, and refre≈øhment,
and thou ≈øhalt find, it will keep thee a good while from faintne≈øs. But woe to thy fellows, if they want it; for they will certainly faint, unle≈øs thou be ≈øo kind as to give them a ≈øhare in thy provi≈øion.

In the be≈øt Apothecary-≈øhops may be found a root, called Co≈øtus, ≈øomewhat like Cinnamon; which hath the ≈øame effect. And if others ≈øhould eat Onions, others drink Brandy, and I only hold in my mouth of this root the bigne≈øs of half a Pea; I ≈øhould keep in breath a good while longer than they. But take notice, that this, I ≈øpeak of, is not the common Co≈øtus, which hitherto hath been ≈øold for the true in common ≈øhops; but that which comes to us from the Indies.

If thou art a Hor≈øe-man, take a good quantity of Bay-≈øalt, a little Brim≈øtone, Clove, and Ginger, and mingle with it ≈øome of the powder of the two above-≈øaid herbs, Imperatoria and Carlina, and give it to thy Hor≈øe, or in ca≈øe of want of Provender let him have of it upon his bit, or give him ≈øome upon a ≈ølice of bread, and it will make him ≈øtrong and vigorous.

If thou art to ride in a German Saddle, the two hind-knobs whereof are wont only to be ≈øtuffed out with ≈øtraw or hor≈øe-hair; get thee made two Tin-flasks with good ≈øcrews, fitted for tho≈øe places. In one of them carry Brandy, in the other Vinegar. The Brandy will ≈øerve thee in cold nights, and fre≈øh mornings; and and 'twill be good al≈øo for thy hor≈øe, giving him a little of it upon bread. The Vinegar will be of u≈øe to thee for the heat of the day,
wa≈øhing thy mouth with it, as al≈øo ≈øpirting a little of it into thy hor≈øes mouth. Be≈øides mingling it with water, it will afford thee a good cooling drink.

If it he very cold, put ≈øome of that hor≈øe-hair, that is wont to be curried out of their mains and tails, into thy Boots. I never received on ≈øuch occa≈øions more warmth from any thing, e≈øpecially keeping my ≈øelf dry. A Hares-skin is al≈øo good for this purpo≈øe, making ≈øocks of it; but if it grow wet, 'tis naught.

Gather of the Wheel-grea≈øe that runs out at the nave of the Wheels, and would el≈øe be lo≈øt, which hath taken in ≈øome of the ≈øub≈øtance of the Iron that is about the Axel-tree, witne≈øs its blackne≈øs: This is a good Ointment for Hor≈øes.

When thou come≈øt into the field, and art to lye abroad, look out for ≈øome ri≈øing ground, that the Rain, which may po≈ø≈øibly fall, may run away from thee: And avoid as much as is po≈ø≈øible. Vallies, Mari≈øhes, Ditches, Meadows, and the like low and moi≈øt places.

Be≈øides, ob≈øerve the Air, and put up thy Tent towards the Ea≈øt; which quarter though it be cool, yet 'tis whol≈øom. But le≈øt it ≈øhould be too cool, order it ≈øo, that thou may≈øt enjoy that wind, which comes from between the Ea≈øt and South, as being one of the whol≈øome≈øt of all Airs, and temperate, the South-air qualifying the ≈øharpne≈øs of the Ea≈øtern. Beware of the We≈øtern wind, e≈øpecially that which blows from between the South and We≈øt. The Air of Mid-night is whol≈øome
enough and dry, but ≈øharp and piercing. Believe it, a Souldier is much concern'd in the Air; nor hath Hippocrates without cau≈øe written a whole Book De Aere, Aquis & Locis, to teach, how the Air, Water, and Places are to be di≈øcerned and cho≈øen.

Moreover, look about thee for good clear Water, ≈øuch as grows warm and cool again ≈øooner than other waters; and ob≈øerve this mark for my ≈øake. I know water, that will not boyl Pea≈øe, Vetches, Stock-fi≈øh, Flounders, &c. In ≈øome Springs Iron is turn'd into Bra≈øs, and great care is to be had in the choice of water for drinking.

But if thou can≈øt not have Spring-water, but art nece≈ø≈øitated to u≈øe Pit or Ditch-water; have a care not to drink it without ≈øtraining, lea≈øt thou ≈øhould≈øt ≈øwallow Frog or Snake-≈øpawn. For I have known and had in my cure a Countrey-man, who voided, though not at once but at different times, two hundred fifty and five Frogs, and of them many in my own hou≈øe, in the pre≈øence of divers Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Secular Per≈øons; and ≈øome of the bigge≈øt of them, being dried, are ≈øtill to be ≈øeen in the Repo≈øitoy of Mantua, as al≈øo in that of Mr. Philip Hainhofer at Au≈øpurg. And there is a Cook in the Ho≈øpital of We≈ø≈øenburg or Landsberg, who, (as appeared by the event) had drunk the Spawn of Serpents, out of which were bred divers Serpents in his Body, ≈øome of which he voided by vertue of the Medicine he took, among≈øt which there was one of the length of a Bavarian Ell. The Man hath been ≈øince in good health, and continues in his ≈øervice to this day.

Wherefore it will behove you to ≈øpread your handkerchief over the Ditch-water, and ≈øo drink through it; or if you take any of it up un≈øtrain'd, quench fir≈øt a red-hot Stone or Iron in it, whereby the noxious quality will be de≈øtroyed. Or, if you lye ≈øtill, and can get any Oyl of Vitriol, let ≈øome drops of that fall into it, and you need not then fear any corruption or poy≈øon in ≈øuch water. Otherwi≈øe, if time will permit, let it boil up and cool again, and put a cru≈øt of bread into it, and you may drink of it ≈øafely.
Tho≈øe Waters that run out of ≈øtony hills and from under rocks, are the be≈øt; to which may be reckon'd tho≈øe Springs, that flow from high places, and purge them≈øelves in clear ≈øand and pebles.

If thou meet with Beer or Wine, take heed of exce≈øs; and forbear drinking New beer that hath not yet done working, or is not ≈øome days old, becau≈øe new beer cau≈øeth the Strangury. And in ca≈øe this ≈øhould trouble thee, take a handful of Hay-blo≈ø≈øoms, boyl them in water, and Urine over it, drawing into thy body the warm ≈øteam thereof, and anointing thy Navel ≈øeveral times with warm ≈øuet.

If thou art hot, and can≈øt not forbear drinking, make water fir≈øt; then wa≈øh thy mouth, and cool the arteries on both thy temples, and tho≈øe of both thy wri≈øts, and then drinking will hurt thee le≈øs.

If you chance to drink whil≈øt you are hot, (which is ≈øo dangerous a thing that ≈øome have dyed within 24 hours after it; others have fallen into con≈øumptive Coughs, others been
troubled with Pains in their ≈øides and with Impo≈øtumes, &c.) then take of the leaves of Bellis or Dai≈øy, which grows in all meadows and pa≈øture-grounds, and is green both winter and ≈øummer, and wa≈øh them clean, and dre≈øs them like a Salad with Oyl, Vinegar and a little Salt, and forthwith eat thereof; and it helps immediately, as I know by much Experience. But this mu≈øt be u≈øed pre≈øently, the ≈øooner the better. I can ≈øay with truth, that in all my Practice of Phy≈øick for above 20 years I have not met with any Experiment of ≈øo quick an Operation from any herb, as from this. But here I mu≈øt note, that I have always u≈øed the Red Dai≈øy, and have not tryed the other ≈øorts; though I am apt to believe, the others may have the like effect. You mu≈øt not eat the Flowers, but only the Leaves. This Experiment ≈øhould be put up on all po≈øts every where, for the good of Courriers, Mowers, and other labouring Men, that are wont to drink plentifully when they are hot, and thereby ≈øpoil them≈øelves in great numbers.

But to proceed; as thou art to beware of exce≈øs of drinking at all times, ≈øo thou art e≈øpecially to forbear when thou art to ≈øtand Sentinel, le≈øt thou ≈øhould fall a ≈øleep; whereby thou may≈øt lo≈øe thy life, at lea≈øt, thy place and thy preferment for ever.
Neither be fond of Gaming at dice, tables, &c. whence are occa≈øioned quarrels, mi≈øtru≈øts, deceit, ≈øwearing, and what not?

Avoid al≈øo the company of ba≈øe women, le≈øt thou ≈øhould≈øt be con≈øtrained to undergo the Mercurial Salivation, and with it a very lean
Diet, of thin broth, water-gruel, barley-broth, prunes, roa≈øted apples, and ≈øuch like, without any fle≈øh-meat at all.

div.head: CHAP. III. Concerning the Phy≈øicians and Chirurgeons in an Army.
div.p: EVery Army ought to be well provided with one or more able Phy≈øicians, ≈øuch as are not only expert in the cure of inward Di≈øea≈øes, but al≈øo under≈øtanding in outward Ca≈øes, as Wounds, Burnings, Luxations. Di≈ølocations, Ery≈øipelas's or St. Antony's Fires, &c.

The≈øe Phy≈øicians ought to be no Young≈øters, that are lately come from Schools and Univerver≈øities, knowing only in Controver≈øies and Di≈øputations, but ≈øuch as are expert in the Cure of Di≈øea≈øes, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as are mo≈øt frequent in Armies. They are al≈øo to be Men of good nature, great hone≈øty and conde≈øcen≈øion, willing to take pains with the poor as well as the rich. Phy≈øicians thus qualified may ≈øo gain the hearts of the Souldiers, that the≈øe will love and honour them as if they were their Parents.

Likewi≈øe the Chirurgeons ought to be learn'd, di≈øcreet, and affable, ≈øuch as have been long vers'd, and experienc'd, in all the operations of Chirurgery, that can di≈øtingui≈øh well of Di≈øea≈øes, and with prudence make their judgments thereon: They ought al≈øo to be diligent, and careful of tho≈øe committed to their charge,
and very knowing in all manner of outward applications, as Unguents, Plai≈øters, Pulments, Lenitives, Stiptiques, Attractives, Dige≈øtives, Cau≈øticks, E≈øcharotiques, as al≈øo their Mollifying, Di≈ø≈øipating, Repelling, Suppurating and Mundifying, &c. Medicines. They ought to be skilful in di≈øcerning them, and withal in knowing well the ca≈øes and times where and when to u≈øe them, They are to be very careful in ob≈øerving the beginning, middle and end of Ulcers, Wounds, &c. ≈øince it often may be impertinent and even hurtful too, to u≈øe that in the beginning, that may be pertinent and beneficial in the mid≈øt of the cure, and the like.
An able and dextrous Chirurgeon is a great Trea≈øure in an Army, and cannot be enough valued, e≈øpecially if he con≈øult in all dangerous ca≈øes with an under≈øtanding Phy≈øitian.
The≈øe two, Phy≈øitians and Chirurgeons, are to be intimate friends together, a≈ø≈øi≈øting one another without envy and pride, for the better relief and the greater ≈øafety of their Patients.

'Tis very nece≈ø≈øary, both the≈øe ≈øhould go abroad and travel before they undertake to practi≈øe, thereby to acquire experience, and to learn al≈øo to conver≈øe with the more di≈øcretion and gentlene≈øs with all ≈øorts of humors. And when they come to practi≈øe, the Chirurgeons ought to advi≈øe with Phy≈øitians, who are but lame Doctors, if they be not skilled in Chirurgery; ≈øince this is the third part of Phy≈øick, from which it can and ought not to
be ≈øeparated, being an integral part thereof. It is recorded in hi≈øtory, that above 2000 years ≈øince, Podalyrius and Machaon, Sons to E≈øculapius, went both with Agamemnon in the Expedition for Troja, and there purcha≈øed great honour by their practi≈øe not ≈øo much of Phy≈øick as Chirurgery.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of Fevers, Hungarian Di≈øtempers, Spotted Fevers, and other Pe≈øtilential Di≈øea≈øes, as al≈øo of Hereditary Maladies, together with their Remedies.
div.p: 'TIs known ≈øeldom to fail, that in an army there reigneth ≈øome Di≈øea≈øe or other, according to the nature and con≈øtitution of the Country, Air, and Diet. The rea≈øons are;

Fir≈øt, that among≈øt ≈øo great a number of Men, rai≈øed from ≈øo many different places, there are to be found Men of very different tempers and con≈øtitutions, ≈øound and un≈øound; and among≈øt the latter, ≈øome that are ≈øcabby, others ≈øcorbutical, others labouring under venereal Di≈øea≈øes, many inclined to dangerous and infectious Fevers, &c. all which a Phy≈øitian mu≈øt have a watchful eye upon, and endeavour to prevent their ≈øpreading.

Secondly, that Souldiers in an Army want conveniences wherewith to take due care of their health; but are often con≈øtrain'd to expo≈øe them≈øelves and ≈øleep in the open Air
on moi≈øt ground, the vapours whereof penetrate into their bodies; and they are carele≈øs or want oppertunities of expelling them out again by ≈øweat. Whence is cau≈øed an inward putrefaction in the blood and humours, which ≈øometimes proceeds ≈øo far, as to a≈ø≈øume a venemous nature, and to break out into ≈øpots, tumors, bubo's, carbuncles, &c.

Thirdly, that Souldiers commonly keep an irregular diet. Sometimes they have plenty and do ≈øupperabound; at other times they have nothing; and then being very hungry, when they come again to a place of plenty, they over-feed and ≈øurfeit; whence are bred crudities in the Stomach, and corruption, which cau≈øeth malignant Fevers in abundance. Be≈øides, they often feed upon Meat that is unwhol≈øom, as ≈øtinking Veni≈øon, rotten Chee≈øe mu≈øty Bread, &c. which cannot but occa≈øion many Di≈øea≈øes. And when they come to places, where Fruit abounds, as Apples, Pears, Plums, Melons, Cherries, Grapes, &c. they over-eat them≈øelves, and thereby cau≈øe Gripings in the Guts, Diarrhaea's, &c.

La≈øtly, ≈øometimes the Air is corrupted, e≈øpecially after a great Battel, and ≈ølaughter of Men that remain unburied; whereby the Air being tainted infects the living that take it in. Which is often made wor≈øe by the exhalations of low and moori≈øh ground, and by thick Fogs.

The≈øe are the general Cau≈øes of the common Di≈øtempers reigning in Armies; again≈øt which thou art to arm thy ≈øelf accordingly. Fir≈øt then be careful in thy Diet; eat not
greedily and indi≈øcreetly every thing that comes to hand; and though it be good, yet eat and drink not too plentifully of it, but re≈øtrain thy appetite, con≈øidering how de≈øtructive every exce≈øs may be to thy health.

If thou can≈øt and ha≈øt no aver≈øion from it, drink every Morning of thy own ∆≤rine, which prevents corruption in the Stomach, opens ob≈øtructions in the Liver, Spleen, Me≈øaraic Veins; which if not removed, there will follow Fevers, the Yellow Jaundice, Swellings, and difficulty of breathing. If thou art aver≈øe from doing ≈øo, eat ≈øome Bread and Butter with Rue on it; or, if it be not hot weather, take in the morning the quantity of a Ha≈øel-nut of Mithridate or Treacle; or infu≈øe in Brandy, or rather in Spirit of Juniper-berries, ≈øome Zedoary, Angelica, and a little Citron-peels, and drink a ≈øpoonful of it in the Morning.

When the Air is corrupted, and there be at hand a Goat, rub thy ≈øelf at him, and let not the ≈øtrong ≈ømell keep thee from it. Al≈øo put Quick≈øilver in an empty Ha≈øel-nut, clo≈øed up with Spani≈øh Wax, and hang it about thy neck; or the Zenechton prepared of Ar≈øenic, (after the manner by and by to be de≈øcribed) ≈øowed up in thin Leather; for if it ≈øhould touch the bare skin, it would cau≈øe Bli≈øters and do harm. This Zenechton is a Plai≈øter, out of which are cut pieces of the bigne≈øs of a Dollar, which are carried about the Neck, and hang down near the Heart; keeping good a whole year. And when the infection is pa≈øt, this Zenechton being reduced to Powder, will
yet ≈øerve to kill Rats and Mice with. It is to be thus prepar'd,

Take of Yellow and White Ar≈øenic, of each an ounce, or ¬æ of an ounce; of gummi Tragacanth ¬Ω an ounce; put this gummi in Ro≈øe-water or in common water over night, and it will yield a ≈ølimy Water. Then beat thy Ar≈øenic in a Mortar, and put ≈øo much of this gummed Water to it, as is nece≈ø≈øary to reduce it to a Pa≈øte having the con≈øi≈øtence of Dough; work it well and round it, and then cut off a ≈ølice of the bigne≈øs of a Dollar, ≈øomewhat thicker; let this ≈ølice dry in the Air, and ≈øow it in a piece of thin Leather (well-dre≈ø≈øed Dogs-skin is the be≈øt for this purpo≈øe;) carry this about thy Neck ≈øo as to let it hang down upon, and to touch the place of thy Heart. Some mix with it a proportion of the Powder of dried Toads, which I have done my ≈øelf, it being e≈øteem'd more powerful. Some carry about their Necks dried Spiders; Theophra≈øtus commends Celondine, Leaves and Root, carried about the Neck.

Remember al≈øo to burn frequently Juniper-wood before thy Tent; though all ordinary fires clean≈øe the Air: Upon which account Hippocrates advi≈øed great fires to be made in Greece at the time of a great Plague, which was thought to have been remov'd by that means. Some burn only a few Chips of Juniper-roots, or ≈øome of the Berries of that ≈øhrub, which is as effectual.

If the≈øe means cannot be had, burn ≈øome Gunpowder, ordering it like a Train; this purifieth the Air likewi≈øe. And the volleys
of ≈øhot made mornings and evenings in a Camp, conduce very much to the di≈øpelling of Mi≈øt, and qualifying raw weather.
Frankincen≈øe al≈øo, Ma≈øtick, and ≈øuch other Perfumes as dry and clear the Air, may be very u≈øefully burnt; and even a Scholars Perfume made of wa≈øte Paper is not to be de≈øpi≈øed.

If thou can≈øt get Rue, ≈ømell often to it: And remember me for this general hint, to take good notice of all Herbs that are green Winter and Summer, and which are not eaten by Hor≈øes or Cattel; for they are endow'd with excellent virtues for the good of Man, and therefore made to grow at all ≈øea≈øons of the year.

When the Air is pe≈øtilential, or breeding any Epidemical Di≈øea≈øe, then wa≈øh thy face with Vinegar every morning. If thou can≈øt get Acetum of Rue, Elder-flowers, Lavender, Ro≈øes, Marigold-flowers, 'tis the better. Or, if you have the conveniency, prepare the following Acetum: Take Rue, Elder-flowers, Burnet-roots, white Dittany, Carlina, of each equal quantity; a few Orange or Citron-peels, (of which the latter are the better of the two,) and a little Camphire, and ≈øome Walnut-kernels (the fre≈øher the better,) leaving the bitter skins upon them; put all the≈øe into common Vinegar, and with this infu≈øion moi≈øten every morning thy Temples, Mouth and No≈øtrils, and the beating Arteries of both thy Wri≈øts; taking down a good ≈øpoonful of it, and thou ha≈øt a good pre≈øervative.

If it be cold weather, take Angelica-roots, Zedoaria, white Dittany, ≈øome dried Citron-peels,
and a little Camphir, infu≈øe them all in Brandy, e≈øpecially in ≈øuch as is made out of Wormwood or Juniper-berries. Of this Liquor drink in the morning a ≈øpoonful. But if thou be of a hot con≈øtitution, then content thy ≈øelf with the former Acetum, in which you may mix a little Treacle.

Some advi≈øe to take fa≈øting ≈øome of the Juice of Marigold, fre≈øhly expre≈øs'd out of the Flower and Leaves, as a good pre≈øervative again≈øt the Infection. This I have not tried; but I have often in ≈øuch ca≈øes u≈øed the Acetum of Marigold-flowers, e≈øpecially for a Cordial and Sudorifick, and, I think, with very good ≈øucce≈øs.

Or make an Electuary of Rue and Juniper-berries, of each equal quantity, adding thereto a double quantity of Walnuts, with their bitter skin on them, ≈øome Figs, a little Treacle, and a little Saffron; beat them together in a Mortar, and pour on them, whil≈øt thou art beating, as much Rue-vinegar as will reduce it to a thick Puls or Electuary: Of this take the bigne≈øs of a Ha≈øel-Nut or two, fa≈øting.

Take the Roots of the greater Burrdock, and tho≈øe of Celondine, both well cleared, and the Bark of A≈øh; infu≈øe them twenty four hours in half White-wine, and half Rue-vinegar; then di≈øtil it, and in the di≈øtilled water mix a little Brim≈øtone-oyl, to render it a little ≈øowri≈øh. Of this take two ≈øpoonfuls in the morning for a pre≈øervative. But if any be already infected with the Plague, let him take of the ≈øame ≈øix or eight ≈øpoonfuls at a time, and ≈øweat upon it, it being a very ≈øudorifick
Liquor, which, under the name of Aqua Bardana compo≈øita, hath been u≈øed by me and my Collegues in Ho≈øpitals and other places with very great ≈øucce≈øs. You may mix ≈øome Mithridate with it, if you plea≈øe.

El≈øe take Carlina, Imperatoria, Serpentaria, Valerian, Saxifrage, Tormentil, Gentian, Angelica and Zedoaria, all cut ≈ømall; infu≈øe them in Brandy, and drink of it a ≈øpoonful in the morning for a pre≈øervative; but if thou ha≈øt the Contagion, take two ≈øpoonfuls, to ≈øweat upon it, in ca≈øe the Pe≈øtilential Poi≈øon be not yet broken out, and the Patients Tongue not dry; but if it be, content thy ≈øelf with the newly pre≈øcribed Acetum, as being more ≈øafe, and an Inflammation being to be feared from the Brandy.

Hold Zedoar, Angelica, Lovage or Imperatoria, in thy mouth; but if thou be ≈øubject to the Head-ach, then cut it fir≈øt ≈ømall, and infu≈øe it in Vinegar, and let it ≈øtand infu≈øed for the ≈øpace of 24 hours; then take it out again, dry it, and u≈øe it as pre≈øcribed above.

Among≈øt the good Pre≈øervatives reckon this al≈øo: Take Garden-rue, beat it into a mortar, pour Vinegar on it, and ≈øtrain all through a cloth; mix ≈øome Treacle with it, ≈øet it by in a gla≈øs, and take of it in the morning half a ≈øpoonful or a whole. Put a little Camphir to it, if you will have it ≈øtronger.
Or put Camphir in Worm-wood-wine, and drink a good draught of it every morning

When I ≈øerved in times of great mortality, I infu≈øed in Wine Carduus benedictus, Wormwood,
Scordium, Dictamne of Creet, Burnet-roots, and Citron-peels, and after I had taken every morning a good me≈øs of ≈øouri≈øh broth, I drank after it a good gla≈øs of this infu≈øion. As long as the herbs retain a bitterne≈øs, fre≈øh wine may be infu≈øed upon them.
Infu≈øe al≈øo white and well clean≈øed Garlick in Acetum made of Rue, and take of it a ≈øpoonful or two in the morning.

In the Apothecary-≈øhops are Pills, call'd Pe≈øtilential Pills: Among the≈øe cau≈øe a little Camphir to be mixt, and of it let Pills be made; of which take at once three or four every week, taking them in a ≈øpoonful of White-wine, an hour before ≈øupper. The≈øe prevent all inward putrefaction, and keep off all infection, nor do they ≈øuffer any collection, of morbifique matter within thee, though they purge not, but only keep the body ≈øoluble. They are made up of Aloe Myrrhe and Saffron. Formerly I have printed a whole Book of ≈øuch Pills, which I call'd Maroco≈øtinas in Latin; where I have de≈øcribed their vertues at large.

For the Rich may ≈øerve what follows; Take Terra Sigillata, Bolus Armenus, Pulvis Alexipharmacus, or Bezoardicum Nicolai, or the Cordiales Alexandrini Benedicti; item Species de Hyacintho, Aqua Stapediana, Acetum Theriacale, or the Red Hungarian Powder; all the≈øe ≈øerving not only to pre≈øerve, but al≈øo to recover, by Gods ble≈ø≈øing.
Provide out of the Apothecaries-≈øhops Pa≈øtils of the extract of Angelica or Zedoaria; take one or two of them in thy mouth every morning, and there let them melt down.

Keep thy body clean every way; be chearful; avoid ra≈øhne≈øs; nor be affraid, con≈øidering that many have been infected by fear, terrour, and melancholy. Chear thy ≈øelf up now and then with a gla≈øs of good and ≈øincere Wine, but not to exce≈øs. Never fa≈øting, nor never full. One that is empty will ≈øoon be caught with this di≈øtemper, e≈øpecially if he live among≈øt infected people. If he do, let him drink a good draught of Wormwood-wine, Juniper-berry-wine, Ro≈øemary, Sage, or Zedoar-wine; which may keep thee from many dangers. But remember, not to drink more of it than will chear thee up and revive thy Spirits. At lea≈øt, drink a little Wine with Camphir and Vinegar, kindling the Camphir and letting it burn in the Wine, ≈øo as to let it ≈øink into it; for if it burn on the top, it will there remain ≈øwimming: And if the Wine be skinned over with it, kindle it again till it be quite burnt out. Take of Camphir for one draught, the quantity of a pea≈øe; but if thou be ≈øubject to the Head-ach, then Camphir will not agree with thee.

In ca≈øe that any come to be infected, he is forthwith to be ≈øeparated from the ≈øound, and to be laid to bed, ≈øo as his head and ≈øhoulders may lye ≈øomewhat high; by which means he will be le≈øs ≈øubject to faintne≈øs. Then let him pre≈øently take ≈øome Sudorifick Medicine, to make him ≈øweat; for if the poy≈øon be not ≈øpeedily driven from the heart, the Patient is lo≈øt. You are al≈øo to take great care, that this Di≈øtemper prevail not, and to endeavour to di≈øcover it before the Patient be quite di≈øabled:
For, as ≈øoon as any begins to droop, grows melancholy, faint and feeble in his limbs, ≈øo as that he is hardly able to hold up his head, drawing his breath with difficulty, letting his head fall to and fro, lo≈øing his ≈øtomach, growing yellowi≈øh about his eyes, with the apples of his eyes ≈øtanding out, finding head-ach, interrupted heats and colds; as ≈øoon, I ≈øay, as the≈øe ≈øymptoms appear in times of the Plague, Spotted Fevers, Hungarian Di≈øea≈øe, &c. you may then look to it by times; fora≈ømuch as ≈øuch Patients, that are already infected, go often about until the ≈øixth or eighth day, as I have known my ≈øelf, until the lurking poy≈øon of the heart has got the prevalency; and then the poor Patient is quite ca≈øt down, and often dyes in very few days, and even in a few hours. Wherefore thou art not to ≈øtay, till the ≈øwellings and boils appear behind the ears, under the arms, &c. or till the Carbuncles, Bubo's, and the like, break out; but thou art immediately to make u≈øe of the be≈øt Medicines, thou can≈øt be Ma≈øter of, to drive out the poy≈øon, if thou wilt ≈øave thy life. I never found any thing, that was con≈øiderable, done in the Plague, by means of Purging and Bleeding; but rather on the contrary, all tho≈øe that had Spots, if they were Purged or let Blood, ≈øoon after died. However, I will pre≈øcribe nothing magi≈øterially to any man; let every one endeavour to do, what he can give a good account of. I have, together with my Collegues, treated many hundreds in our Ho≈øpitals infected with the Plague, without ever opening a Vein, and
