yet we have by Gods ble≈ø≈øing recovered near 600 per≈øons, be≈øides tho≈øe that by the ≈øame mercy we have cured in their ≈øeveral Hou≈øes.

Now to procure ≈øweat in the very beginning, take the quantity of two Ha≈øel-nuts of Treacle, di≈ø≈øolve it in common Vinegar; but if thou can≈øt have a cordial Acetum, made of Ro≈øemary, Lavender, Elder-blo≈ø≈øoms, Rue, Ro≈øes, or Elder-berries, u≈øe it much rather, and give it the Patient to ≈øweat.

Or take the roots of Celondine, boyl them in Vinegar, and di≈ø≈øolve ≈øome Treacle in it: Or take Carduus benedictus, Rue, Peta≈øites or Butter-burr, a little Angelica, Zedoaria, or Saxifrage-roots, boyl them together in half White-wine, and half Vinegar, or only Water, di≈ø≈øolve a little Treacle or Mithridate in it, and let the Patient take it warm, to make him ≈øweat.
Mithridate hath the like virtue with Treacle, yet neither of them are ≈øafe to take for Women with Child, old Per≈øons and young Children.
You may al≈øo make u≈øe to good purpo≈øe of the Saxon-powder, taking of it the weight of a Ducat in Caduus benedictus, Scabius, or Sorrel-water; which Powder is thus to be prepared:

Take Valerian half an ounce; Celondine, or Nettel-roots, of each one ounce; Polypody, Althaea, (or Marchmallow,) wild Angelica, of each two ounces; of garden Angelica, four ounces; of the rind of Laureola, (or Lowry,) an ounce and an half: The≈øe roots are to be dug up in their be≈øt ≈øtrength, viz. between the middle of Augu≈øt and the middle of September, and being
clean≈øed, they are to be cut ≈ømall, and then put in a glazed pot, pouring a ≈øharp Vinegar upon it, ≈øo as to cover it two inches high. Then lute on the cover with a lute made of whites of Eggs and Flower; let all be boiled upon a gentle fire; then pour off the liquor, and dry the roots, and reduce them to powder, mixing with it ≈øome 26 berries of Herbe Paris, (or One-Berrie (which look like Pepper-corns, very good again≈øt poi≈øon; and thus the powder is made. This herb grows in ≈øhadowed and moderately moi≈øt places; I have found of it ≈øeveral times in Ko≈øhinger-wood near Ingol≈øtad: It hath four leaves on one ≈øtalk, and one berry on the top. An herb belonging to the family of Solanum's or Night ≈øhades; whence the leaves of it do very much cool Inflammations, e≈øpecially tho≈øe of the Eyes, when laid upon them.

Take notice of Sorrel, brui≈øe ≈øome of it and pour Vinegar on't, (the Rue acetum is the be≈øt,) and ≈øtrain the juice through a cloth; put into it a little powder of Angelica, about the weight of half a Ducat; or of the root of Dictam, or of Butter-burr, or a little Treacle or Mithridate, and give it to ≈øweat.

On this occa≈øion of mentioning Dictam, I mu≈øt add, that in our Countrey there grows only the white Dictam, which is, among others, an excellent Antidote, but you mu≈øt take of it the double quantity and weight to that of Creta. You may boil of the root of half an ounce in half White-wine and half Vinegar, or, in≈øtead of the Wine, in Carduus benedictus water; and drink of the Decoction warm, and
put your ≈øelf to ≈øweat; or take of the powder of it a drachm and an half in warm broth with a little Vinegar, for the ≈øame purpo≈øe.

The Dictam of Creta hath hairy leaves and purpureous blo≈ø≈øoms, and is u≈øed in the prepation of Treacle. This herb by its odour drives away Serpents. The wild Goats being hurt by any Arrows eat this herb, and 'tis ≈øaid, that by this means the Arrows fall out of the wound. This perhaps hath no other ground than that of the Poet Virgil, affirming that Venus with this herb healed her Son Aeneas when wounded in the War. His words are Aeneid. 12.
Hic Venus indigno nati concu≈ø≈øa dolore;
Dictamnum genitrix Cretaea carpit ab Ida,
Puberibus caulem foliis & flore comantem
Purpureo, non illa feris incognita Capris
Gramina, cum tergo volucres hae≈øere ≈øagittae.

About this time came in the Hungarian Infection, which was a Di≈øea≈øe that bred ≈øuch a a putrefaction in the bodies of Men, that even when they were near death, they fell a vomiting but that with ≈øuch a ≈øtench, that no body could endure it. Here tho≈øe Medicines do well, that pre≈øerve the body from putrefaction; for the Plague, Spotted Fevers, and the Hungarian Di≈øtemper, proceed all from inward corruption. And of them, the Plague attacks the Spirits re≈øiding in the Heart, and ≈øo killeth very quickly; whereas Spotted Fevers have their ≈øeat in
the Blood, and therefore do la≈øt twelve, fourteen, and ≈øometimes twenty days before they kill. But the Hungarian Di≈øea≈øe is ≈øeated chiefly in the putrified Phlegm of the Head and Brains; whence tho≈øe that labour under it, are tormented with great and maniacal head-ach.

But though the≈øe three Di≈øea≈øes have their ri≈øe from one and the ≈øame cau≈øe (Putrefaction,) and are to be cured by the ≈øame remedies; yet is therein required the di≈øcretion of a prudent Phy≈øitian, for the ordering and pre≈øcribing of Medicines according to circum≈øtances.

Take a drachm of Zedoary, give it pulveri≈øed to the Patient in Acetum of Rue, or Elder, or Marrigold flowers, or even in common Vinegar: Let him ≈øweat upon it. 'Tis good again≈øt all ≈øorts of venom, and cau≈øeth a ≈øweet breath, as re≈øi≈øting inward corruption.

In the Apothecary Shops you find an Electuary, called Dia≈øcordium, found by that famous Phy≈øician Hieronymus Fraca≈øtorius. It is like to Treacle and Mithridate; only 'tis red from ≈øome Ingredients giving it that colour. This may be u≈øed with ≈øafety by Women with Child, young Children and all ≈øorts of Per≈øons, whereas, as was ≈øaid above, Treacle and Mithridate may not. It is made chiefly of Scordium or Water-Germander, which hath the ≈ømell of Leek when brui≈øed.
Galen in his fir≈øt Book De Antidotis, Chap. 12. writeth, that when in a great Battel ≈øome ≈ølain Bodies chanced to fall upon this Herb, they rotted not as far as they were touched by this Herb.
The ≈øaid Fraca≈øtorius did compound this his Dia≈øcordium out of this Herb Scordium, Tormentil, Serpentaria, Gentian, Bole Armeniac and Terra Sigillata, and ≈øuch like Ingredients.

It is chiefly to be u≈øed in the hot Di≈øea≈øes of the Head; which I have done many a hundred times. Take of it the weight of about two ducats in common Vinegar, or in Elder-water, or rather in the expre≈ø≈øed Juyce of fre≈øh Sorrel, and ≈øweat upon it. 'Tis very good e≈øpecially in the Hungarian Sickne≈øs and other venomous and infectious Di≈øea≈øes. To young People you may give a le≈ø≈øer quantity, and proportionably you are to le≈ø≈øen the Do≈øe for Women with Child or in Child bed, and little Children.
Be≈øides take notice of the Powder of Doctor He≈ø≈øius, which hath been u≈øed with great benefit, and is thus prepared.

Take a drachm of Sugar-candy, a quarter of an ounce of pulveri≈øed Ginger, and a drachm of Camphir; reduce all to a fine Powder; give of it to the infected Patient the weight of a drachm in Vinegar mingled with the Water of Marigold flowers, Scabious or Sorrel, and ≈øweat upon it. If you have none of the≈øe Waters, then look that the Vinegar be not too ≈øharp, and to that end dilute it with ≈øome Wine and Water. Mean time, though in this ca≈øe I highly value Camphir, yet in ≈øtead of Ginger I would u≈øe Zedoary, Saxifrage, Carlina or Imperatoria, or the true Peta≈øites or Butter-burr.

Again, Brim≈øtone is none of the meane≈øt Remedies in the≈øe infectious ca≈øes; for it pre≈øerves
the Body from Putrefaction. Wherefore take of the noble Flowers of Sulphur a quarter of an ounce, being ≈øublimed from Colcothar; add to it one ≈øcruple of Camphir, an ounce of the Spirit or Oyl of Cyprian or Venetian Turpentine. Put all this into a Gla≈øshead, lute it well and put it upon hot Sand or A≈øhes, whereby the Oyl of Turpentine will come to open the Brim≈øtone, and produce a red colour like a Ruby, or at lea≈øt as yellow as a high-colour'd Hyacinth. Of this give ≈øome to the Patient three or four times, mingled with a little Treacle, or in Sorrel, Cardobenedictus, or Scabious-water. This Bal≈øom is excellent al≈øo in ≈øore Brea≈øts that are growing purulent, taken in warm broth, or in a good Wound-drink. But this mu≈øt be in ca≈øes of no great heat or inflammation, in which it would be dangerous.

Among≈øt all the Remedies, which ≈øerve again≈øt Infectious Di≈øea≈øes, that of Henricus Stapedius, to be found in my Book de Pe≈øtilentia, is an excellent one, and perhaps the be≈øt for curing as well as pre≈øerving; of which half a ≈øpoonful being taken fa≈øting, is able to keep a Man well for twelve hours or more: But if any be already infected, he mu≈øt take of it at any time immediately, to the quantity of a ≈øpoonful and an half, or two ≈øpoonfuls, for ≈øweating. Which is to be repeated every eighteen or twenty four hours, to make the Patient ≈øweat, till he recover, or till the Pe≈øtilential Boyls and Carbuncles break out behind the Ears, under the Arms, or el≈øewhere. This Water, though it be ≈øomewhat
dear, yet its vertue countervails its price. The older it grows the more vertue it hath.

Many have a≈øcribed great efficacy to the Blood of Animals: Thus old Democritus, (witne≈øs Galen,) prepared an Electuary of ≈øuch Blood, called Diathaemat√¥n. Some e≈øteem much the Blood of Storks, becau≈øe they eat Toads and Snakes; others value the Blood of Hens, becau≈øe they eat Spiders and other venomous In≈øects. I ≈øhould e≈øteem mo≈øt the Fle≈øh or Blood of Badgers; which is to be dried in the ≈øhade, and that done, you mu≈øt mix with it Saffron, Camphir, and ≈øome or other of the Anti-pe≈øtilential Roots, as of Angelica, Zedoaria, or the like, together with a little live Brim≈øtone to the quantity of a ducat; which is to be taken in Acetuni of Rue, or Marigold-flowers, or Walnuts, and in ca≈øe of want of the≈øe, in common Vinegar: Upon which the Patient is to ≈øweat. If thou art a good Hu≈øband, have ready a good Acetum of Rue, Walnut-kernels and Marigold-flowers, taking the greater quantity of Rue; and as you u≈øe it, fill it up again with Acetum of Elder-berries.

The Rich do u≈øe for their Phy≈øick in the time of the Plague, the red Hungarian, as al≈øo the Imperial red and gray Powder, Bezoar, Harts-horn, Antidotum Matthioli, Terra Sigillata, Bole Armeniack, Scorzonera and Contrayerva, Species de Gemmis, Diamargariton de Hyacintho, and other high Medicines, of which I have largely di≈øcour≈øed in my above-cited Book De Po≈øtilentia. But I, though I have u≈øed ≈øuch Remedies among the Rich, yet I content my ≈øelf commonly with the plainer
and mo≈øt common Medicines, of which I have more knowledge and experience.
The Pickle of Ebulus or Walwort, (alias Dane-wort, or Dwarf-elder,) which is of kin to Elder; as al≈øo the Pickle of Juniper-berries, are al≈øo of great u≈øe in this ca≈øe.
The Phy≈øicians of Ausburg made great u≈øe, in the year 1572. of the red Imperial Powder; the compo≈øition of which is in the Augu≈øtan Di≈øpen≈øatory at large, as al≈øo in my Book de Pe≈øte.

The≈øe are the ≈øeveral means to provoke ≈øweat, which I e≈øteem to be of great efficacy for that purpo≈øe upon a ≈øudden. And though Souldiers have not the conveniency of a Bed for ≈øweating, when they are in a march, and often cannot put off their Cloaths for many nights together; yet let them u≈øe ≈øuch ≈øudorifick means: for, though they cannot ≈øweat outright, yet they may fall into a dampi≈øh moi≈øture, which if it ≈øtrike not in again, may prove as good as a ≈øweat. Yet in this ca≈øe he mu≈øt turn his Shirt: Quod non facit ≈øudor, prae≈øtat id tenuis udor.

But here is to be noted, that 'tis not enough, once only to give a ≈øudorifick Medicine to an infected Body; con≈øidering that the venom, like a raging Sea, is to≈ø≈øed to and fro every way. And though it ≈øhould ≈øeem to thee, as if by thy approved Antidote thou had≈øt overcome the Di≈øea≈øe, the ≈øymptoms of it excepted, yet thou art not to tru≈øt in this ca≈øe; for I my ≈øelf have been ≈øometimes deceived, and hard put to it to make good what by confidence I had omitted. Wherefore you mu≈øt not tru≈øt
to the once taking a ≈øudorifick Potion or Powder, becau≈øe ≈øuch malign and lurking Di≈øea≈øes, that keep no ≈øtitch, do indeed fly the fir≈øt time from thy Medicament, and hide them≈øelves under it, but they are wont ≈øuddenly to re-appear. Wherefore you mu≈øt repeat the Antidotes, that were fir≈øt admini≈øtred to you, for the time of 16, 18, 20, or 24 hours, according to circum≈øtances, and ≈øo long and often, till you judge your ≈øick Brothers or Friends Heart ≈øecured from the infectious Venom.

When the ≈øweating is over, thou mu≈øt then refre≈øh thy Patient, fir≈øt by drying him well, and next by giving him a little Vinegar to ta≈øte in a ≈øpoon. The Rich may afford ≈øome ≈ølices of Citron, of which Theopompus Chius writeth, that the Tyrant Clearchus Heracleota, who lived in Pontus, having poi≈øoned many People, the vertue of Citron was at length found out, of which a ≈ølice being eaten proved an effectual Antidote again≈øt it. The ≈øame vertue may be found in a ≈ølice of a common Apple; and the Syrupus de Pomis is one of the Cordials of our ≈øhops.

But the thir≈øt, that u≈øes to follow upon ≈øweating, will not be quenched with ≈øo ≈ømall a matter; wherefore take three parts of water, one part of Vinegar, and, if the Patient be not too hot, one part of Wine, mixing ≈øome Sugar therewith, and of this let him drink a good draught, and it will cool and refre≈øh him.

Be≈øides, take ≈øome of the guts of Hens, and ≈øome ≈ølices of Radi≈øh, ≈øprinkle them with
Vinegar and Salt, and bind them to the ≈øoles of his feet; this will draw away the heat. But let not the Radi≈øh lye too long upon them, becau≈øe it will give a ≈øtink that may increa≈øe the head-ach, wherewith the People that have the Plague are commonly troubled enough without provoking it. Moreover you will do well to tye about his wri≈øts ≈øome Rue beaten with Vinegar. Anoint his Loyns and Back-bone with the Unguent of Ro≈øes, or with fre≈øh Butter; but if there appear any Spots, forbear to anoint him, le≈øt they ≈øhould be driven in.

You will do well to have Epithemata of good things about you, as of Ro≈øe water and Elder-vinegar, to lay over the Heart; with which mix ≈øome Camphir. But if you find any thing of Specks, &c. broke out, you mu≈øt u≈øe no wet thing.

Anoint his Heart with Oyl of Scorpions, take the Oyl of Sea-blo≈ø≈øoms and of tho≈øe Earth-worms that appear after rain, of each ≈øix ounces, of St Johns-wort Oyl two ounces, of fre≈øh Elder-blo≈ø≈øoms and Rue, each a handful and an half, of the Acetum, of Marigold-flowers and Ro≈øes, each about three ounces, of live Spiders forty five: Boil all the≈øe together, till the Vinegar be ≈øo qualified, that when 'tis thrown into the fire, it cau≈øe no cracking there. Then ≈øtrain it, and in this ≈øtrained Oyl put a matter of five and twenty Spiders more, of the bigge≈øt ≈øort, and add to it of Camphir di≈ø≈øolved in the Spirit of Ro≈øes half a drachm; let it ≈øtand in Balneo Mariae or upon hot embers for twelve hours, and then
put to it of Treacle and Mithridate, of each half an ounce, and let them work together. With this Oyl anoint the eight Pul≈øes, viz. both Temples, behind both Ears, both Hands, and both Knees, as al≈øo the Heart. And this is an excellent Succedaneum to Scorpion-oyl, much u≈øed by the Germans.

Be≈øides, you mu≈øt refre≈øh and ≈øtrengthen the Patient with convenient Meat and Drink; I mean with good Fle≈øh or Barley-broath, with a little Vinegar in it to make it ≈øavoury to him who will have appetite to little el≈øe, till he have ≈øhaken off this venomous Di≈øtemper; which when he hath done, his ≈øtomach will be ≈øo keen, that you will find work enough to keep him from ≈øurfeiting.

Be al≈øo careful to keep thy Patients Body open; if he be ob≈øtructed, u≈øe a Cli≈øter, or take Butter or Hogs-grea≈øe, mixing a little Salt with it, or, if it be to be gotten, a little Micetrickles, and put it into his bowels. Phy≈øick at the mouth for this purpo≈øe is not always ≈øafe: When the Patient is di≈øcharged of the venom, a little liquor of ≈øtew'd Prunes with ≈øome Senna-leaves in it will do well for opening the body. Some fre≈øh Butter eaten in the morning, or melted in warm Broath, and taken down, is wont al≈øo to keep the body ≈øoluble.

The Drink of the≈øe Patients may be, Water with ≈øome Bread ≈øoaked in it; or take of ≈øuch Water, wherein Bread hath been ≈øoaked, one quart, and a little Vinegar, with two or three ≈øpoonfuls of Kitchin-≈øugar, mingling it well together. If you have no Sugar, u≈øe ≈øuch Water
with Vinegar alone: This affords good Drink in malignant Fevers. Among the Romans it was drunk by the Souldiers, under the name of Po≈øca.

You may al≈øo take a handful of well cleaned Plantain-roots, and boil them up in three quarts of Water, and then decant the Water, which though it be ≈øomewhat bitter, yet 'tis very good in Fevers, and a good Drink in hot Di≈øtempers.

If you have Oyl of Vitriol, let a few drops of it fall into clear Water, mingling it well; and you will have a factitious Sawer-brun or Acidula. But u≈øe no Metalline Ve≈ø≈øel for this purpo≈øe. With this kind of Water many People have been ≈øerved in all ≈øorts of Fevers; the Oyl of Vitriol, in ≈øuch Di≈øtempers, if rightly u≈øed, being very beneficial.

But if a Man ≈øhould have with it any Pulmonick Di≈øea≈øe, in that ca≈øe he mu≈øt forbear acid things, and u≈øe Liquorice, and content him≈øelf with Pti≈øane. Nor is it at all good to u≈øe acids in Pe≈øtilential Pleuri≈øies.

And ≈øince on this occa≈øion we mention this ca≈øe, and we having above given warning, not ea≈øily to blood in Pe≈øtilential Di≈øea≈øes; yet may Venae-≈øection be ≈øometimes, upon good con≈øideration, u≈øed in that Pleuri≈øie, provided it be done in the very beginning, and the Patient be ≈øtrong and full of Blood. Yet this is not to le≈ø≈øen the blood, but only to give it vent; but before bleeding the Patient is to ≈øweat by taking ≈øome of the above ≈øpecified Antidotes.

If the Patient have violent Head-ach, lay on his head Vine-leaves or fre≈øh Cabbage-leaves;
and, if you have no Alabla≈øter-≈øalve, take two parts of Vinegar, and one part of Oyl of Olives (the Sea-blo≈ø≈øoms Oyl, and Elder-Vinegar were better;) dip long rags of linnen therein, and having well ≈øqueez'd them again, lay them lukewarm over the face and temples. Even Vinegar alone is good. Of ≈øuch Applications you may make many, of Acetum of Ro≈øes, Elder-blo≈ø≈øoms, and the like, with a little Camphir. The expre≈ø≈øed Milk of Peaches is al≈øo very effectual in this ca≈øe.

If at the going off of this Di≈øtemper, a hot defluxion ≈øhould fall into the Eyes, take Camphir and infu≈øe it in water, and often moi≈øten the Eyes therewith; and if it ≈øhould be cold and windy weather, you will do well to keep your ≈øelf out of the open Air, and not to let this water dry up in your Eyes in the cold wind.

In ca≈øe of having lo≈øt thy hearing, take of thy own Urine, and with it wa≈øh thy Ears within, but withal dry them very well, becau≈øe that moi≈øture is very noxious to the Ears: And it often happens, that after the Hungarian Sickne≈øs People grow deaf or hard of hearing. Others put the water of Carduus-benedictus di≈øtilled with Wine into the Ears, or the Oyl of bitter Almonds.

If thy Throat ≈øwell, or the Palate of thy Mouth be fallen down, gargarize thy Throat with warm Milk, wherein Figgs have been boil'd, or ≈øweetned with Sugar. The Flowers of Phyllirea or Mock-privet, which grows in the Hedges, boiled, and u≈øed for a gargari≈øm, heals al≈øo a ≈øore Throat. The ≈øame doth the
middle rind of Oxyacantha or Haw-thorn, if boiled, with a little Allom di≈ø≈øolved in the Decoction. If you have the Juice of Mulberries, mix a little Honey of Ro≈øes with it, and often take a little thereof. The Roots of Sloes boiled in red Wine, and the Mouth often wa≈øhed therewith, is al≈øo very good.
If thou ha≈øt the Squinancy, boil Scabious in Meath, and drink thereof warm, when ≈øtrain'd. Beat Turnips and fry them in Butter or Oyl, and clap them in a cloth round about thy Neck.
If thou ca≈øt up blood, take Mou≈øe-ear, Ground-Ivy, Cumfrey; boil them in half Wine and half Water, or in Meat, and Drink often of it. But if the Plague reign not, open fir≈øt a Vein.

For a violent Cough, boil white Turnips, well clean≈øed in common water; throw away this fir≈øt water, pour on other water, and in it let the Turnips boil till they grow ≈øoft. Strain this water, ≈øweeten it with Sugar, or infu≈øe in it Liquorice cut ≈ømall; and drink of it mornings and evenings warm. Or make a Decoction of St. Johns bread, and drink it, ab≈øtaining from all four and ≈øalt things.

The bleeding at the No≈øe is al≈øo incident to per≈øons infected; which is no good ≈øign, though in ≈øound per≈øons it often frees from the Headach and cools the Liver. If this bleeding be too violent, clap Ice-cold water about the Patients Neck, or let him put his Pudenda in cold Vinegar.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Inflammation of the Tongue, its ri≈øe, and concomitants, together with the Remedies.
div.p: WHen the Tongue is inflamed, the whole Oe≈øophagus or Wea≈øand is inflamed al≈øo, and this from beneath upward, becau≈øe the inward fire ≈øends up its ≈ømoak all along, as it were, that chimney, which like ≈øoot ≈øticks to it, drying and blackning the ≈øame.

But there is another Inflammation, much more dangerous, which taking its ri≈øe about the Heart, and therefore is call'd the Inflammation of the Heart, which proceeds from the great inflammation of the orifice of the Stomach, ≈øituate near the heart, in which is in≈øerted the ≈øixth pair of Nerves, which maketh the ≈øaid orifice very ≈øen≈øible of any pain. This part being ≈øeized by ≈øo great an inflammation, which is venomous withal, it mu≈øt in a manner harden, and ≈øhrink; and this heat is of that extent that, the inner Membrane of the Stomach & that of the Tongue being one and the ≈øame, what befalls the Stomach, the Tongue mu≈øt needs be ≈øen≈øible of it. Whence it comes to pa≈øs, that if the Gall overflows and pa≈ø≈øeth into the Stomach, the Tongue pre≈øently finds the bitterne≈øs of it: or if the Stomach be full of ≈ølime or foul, or the like, the Tongue is ≈øoon affected therewith.

There is another kind of Inflammation, by the Latins called Prunella alba. This is of the ≈øame kind with the re≈øt, but not of the ≈øame degree; for 'tis not of ≈øo dry a nature, as the others are, but commonly is moi≈øt, yet overlays all the Gums, the Throat, and the Wea≈øand with ≈øuch a tough white ≈ølime, like a kind of Leather, and ≈øo covers the Almonds with the ≈øame, that ≈øometimes it can hardly be removed even with In≈øtruments. The Tongue is as if it were cru≈øted over with dough, the Gums like an Oven that by the heat of fire is burnt white, the Almonds cover'd as 'twere with white leather, and the Palate of the Mouth likewi≈øe. And in this ca≈øe if the Patient will ≈øpeak, he lalls and ≈øtutters, his Tongue being burthen'd with a load of ≈ølime; or, if he make his Tongue wagg, the ≈ølime ≈øpins out like a thred, and ≈øo invades the Teeth as if they were laid over with varni≈øh. And when this varni≈øh on the Teeth grows black (as I have often ob≈øerv'd it to do) and drieth on them, 'tis a mortal ≈øign; of which Hyppocrates ≈øaith, Quibus in febribus livores circumdentes na≈øcuntur, his fortes fiunt febres, 4. Aph. 53.

The≈øe are the three ≈øorts of Inflammation; for which let us now ≈øeek out the Remedies, beginning from the la≈øt, the White. This is not to be ma≈øter'd by gargari≈øins alone, but the hand mu≈øt be employed al≈øo. Take therefore Cotton-wooll, or Flax, and wind it about a ≈øtick or rod, and dip this in Vinegar, and rake his Throat and Gums therewith, yet taking care not to make it raw; let him gargari≈øe between, and wa≈øh well his Mouth
with Water and Vinegar, or Mul-berry-juyce. Privet that grows in the hedges, or the middle rind of Haw-thorn, boiled in Water and a little Vinegar, then ≈øtrained, with a little Sal-armoniack put into it, is in this ca≈øe an excellent gargari≈øm; but if there be bli≈øters upon the Tongue, or el≈øewhere, then take in≈øtead of Sal-armoniack a little unburnt Allom, and mix it therewith. If you can have the Juyce of Turnips, or the Juyce of fre≈øh Hou≈øe-leek, di≈ø≈øolve therein al≈øo a little Sal-armoniack, and u≈øe it to wet the ≈øtick, wherewith thou clean≈øe≈øt the Throat of the Patient; dipping it often therein, and carrying it about the ∆≤ vula or Palate of the Mouth; and you will ≈øee lumps come away as big as Pea≈øe. The skin is under this Prunella alba fair and red, but tender. Whil≈øt thou art clean≈øing the Patients Mouth, let him often gargari≈øe with the Waters above-≈øpecified, and he will clear his Mouth of the loo≈øen'd lumps. If thou can≈øt get Mulberry-juyce mixt with Honey of Ro≈øes, the Mouth will heal the better; for upon this ≈øort of Inflammation there u≈øually follows a Putrefaction of the Mouth; and in ca≈øe thou perceive≈øt any ≈øuch thing, take Wood-≈øorrel, and the above ≈øaid rind of Haw-thorn, make a Decoction of it, and put in it a little Allom, and often gargari≈øe with it. Clean thy Teeth from the ≈ølime with Water well ≈øharpned with Vitriol.

The common Inflammation of the Mouth may be cured with frequent wa≈øhing of the Mouth, taking a gargari≈øm made of Hou≈øe-leek, Lettice, Night-≈øhade, or Self-heal Water,
mixing a little Honey of Ro≈øes and Mulberry-juyce with it. Of this gargari≈øm the Patient is al≈øo to ≈øwallow a little, thereby to moi≈øten the Throat.

Some take Hou≈øe-leek, and beat it, and put to a pound of it half an ounce of Sal-armoniack, mixing it well together. And ≈øo they put it for ≈øome days in an earthen pot gla≈øed under ground; then they di≈øtill of it a Water in Balneo or in Sand: Which is excellent both to drink and to gargari≈øe, though the Sal-armoniack make it a little unplea≈øant.

But there is nothing better to allay this Inflammation than Niter; which is ≈øo well known among≈øt Souldiers, that they are wont to give one another Gunpowder to drink, which Powder performs this effect not upon the account of the Coals or Brim≈øtone, but the Saltpeter.
For this cau≈øe Experienced Phy≈øitians and Chirurgeons endeavour to purifie Niter for this u≈øe, that it may have the greater effect; and this they do in manner following:

They take of the pure≈øt Niter they can get, as much as they think fit; they beat it to a fine powder, and melt it in a large Crucible, & whil≈øt it boils up and foameth, they pour into it a little powdered Sulphur, and ≈øo let it boil together, till the blew Sulphur-flame cea≈øeth; then they ca≈øt in more fre≈øh Sulphur: Which they repeat often, and then pour out the Niter into an earthen ve≈ø≈øel gla≈øed, making Lozenges of it, of which they put one pulveri≈øed into a quart of limpid water, and ≈øo give the Patient to drink of it as much as he
needs to quench his thir≈øt. Or they give of this purified Niter to their Patients, labouring under this Inflammation, the quantity of a ducat or half a ducat weight in Broath, or in Pti≈øan, till they find the Tongue cleared of its ≈ølime.

The u≈øe of Salt-petre thus prepared removeth al≈øo the Inflammation of the Heart, e≈øpecially if it be melted upon Lead, and then proceeded with as before. For Lead is a con≈øiderable cooler, of which cooling quality the Niter, whil≈øt it is melting upon it, taketh in not a little. Let then your Lead melt, and when 'tis melted, di≈ø≈øolve the Niter upon it, and then, to purifie it, ca≈øt ≈øome Brim≈øtone into it, as was ≈øaid above, till it be clean≈øed from all impurity; and then give of it to thy Patient two or three times a day, according as need ≈øhall require.

Otherwi≈øe, take live Crafi≈øhes and fre≈øh Hou≈øleek, beat them together in a Mortar, ≈øqueeze out the Juyce, with it mix a little Sal-Armoniack, or a pretty deal of thy prepared Niter; make a Potion of it, and give of it even cold to thy Patient, repeating this ≈øeveral times, every eight or ten hours once, according as you ≈øhall ≈øee occa≈øion.

Or, take fre≈øh Lard, (if it be ≈øalted, draw it through hot Water to un≈øalt it,) and cut a ≈ølice of it two fingers large, and of the thickne≈øs of a knives back; put this into the Mouth of thy Patient, it is an excellent Remedy again≈øt this Inflammation; of which I ≈øhall give the rea≈øon hereafter. I have ≈øeen wonders done with it. But if thy Patient do rave, then fa≈øten this ≈ølice of Lard with a Thred and Needle to his
Shirt or Doublet, le≈øt he ≈øwallow it. Or take fre≈øh Butter, and put it in cold Water, and of it give thy Patient at a time the quantity of a Ha≈øel-nut to hold it upon his Tongue, and let it melt there; which will keep the Tongue always moi≈øt. And if thou work among this Butter ≈øome of thy prepared Niter, it hath a wonderful effect, though the ta≈øte be not plea≈øant.

I promi≈øed above to explain the Rea≈øon of the Cure of the≈øe Inflammations. When you take a Gargari≈øm of the Waters of Night-≈øhade, Wood-≈øorrel, Knot-gra≈øs, Endive, Hou≈øleek, and the like, mingled with Vinegar, you do well, but this is not enough; the rea≈øon is: If you wet a piece of Leather, you make it indeed limber, but when it comes to be dry, it grows hard and ≈øhrinks, except you grea≈øe it over with ≈øome fatty matter, and then it will remain ≈ømooth. So it is with the Tongue; though it be made clean with Gargari≈øms, yet will it become again rough and untoward, unle≈øs ≈øome fatne≈øs be u≈øed: For which cau≈øe I have directed to u≈øe Lard, or Butter mixt with Niter.

If the Almonds be ≈øwelled, thou mu≈øt ab≈øtain from all ≈øowre things, and prepare a Gargari≈øm of Figgs, St. Johns Bread, Mallows-flowers, Liquorice, Elder-canes, mixing with it ≈øome Ro≈øe-honey, or Juyce of Walnuts, or the Rob Diamorom, gargling often with it, ≈øeeing that this ≈øymptom is a dangerous thing; for when the Throat ≈øwells of it, few Patients do e≈øcape death, e≈øpecially if it be a Pe≈øtilential Squinancy. And in ca≈øe there appear any Tumor
outwardly, take fine Flower, Milk and Saffron, making a Pul≈øe of it; and, to keep it from growing hard, mix with it Althea-≈øalve, or Hounds-tongue-≈øalve, the Oyl of blew Violets, Mullein, white Lillies, Camomile, or the like, adding a little Oyl of Scorpions to it, and applying this outwardly.

Make al≈øo a Scraper of Alder-wood, if it may be had; if not, other wood will ≈øerve, though Alder be be≈øt. Throw it into cold Water, and let it lye there, u≈øing it as often as there is need; yet take heed of making thy Tongue ≈øore or raw.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of Fevers, Belly-aches, Tumors of the Belly, Yellow-Jaundi≈øe, and Di≈øtempers of the Liver.
div.p: IN Camps there is nothing more frequent than Fevers of the Stomach, ari≈øing from ill Dyet, which Souldiers are often put to for want of better, eating what they can get, Chee≈øe, Herbs, Fle≈øh half boiled, ≈øtale and mu≈øty Bread, and the like. Hence is gather'd a morbifick matter in the Stomach, which cau≈øeth putrefaction, and con≈øequently Stomach-fevers.

In this ca≈øe thou art fir≈øt to purge: And for that purpo≈øe make u≈øe of the Pulvis ≈øolutivus de tribus, recommended above, taking the weight of a Ducat, or a Ducat and an half, in warm
Broath, and fa≈øting two or three hours after it. Or fetch from the Apothecary of the Tabulatum Diaturbith cum Rhubarbaro, or the Diaphoenicon in tabulis, taking half an ounce at a time, and keeping thy Chamber. Or, infu≈øe Sena-leaves in Wormwood-wine, and drink a ≈ømall gla≈øs-ful of it an hour before thy breakfa≈øt: This will al≈øo ≈øerve very well, e≈øpecially if ≈øome Carduus benedictus have al≈øo been fermented in the Wormwood-wine.

If thou art troubled with Gripings or Inflation of the Belly, take of Zedoar, or Angelica-roots, or Orange-peels, cut them ≈ømall, and take at a time the weight of a Ducat in hot Broath. If the Inflation be much, take in the morning the quantity of a Ha≈øel-nut of Mithridate, fa≈øting an hour after it; and if the pains of thy Belly prevail, make a Decoction of Wormwood in Wine, and drink of it as hot as thou can≈øt; this will allay the pains, and give thee ≈øome ≈øtools. Mean time ab≈øtain from raw Fruit, and Beer, Milk, Herbs, and ≈øuch like.

If thou art ≈øwollen, take half a drachm of Rubarb, and about the ≈øame quantity or a little le≈øs of Mechocan; reduce it to powder, and take it in Wormwood-wine, or warm Broath, in the morning fa≈øting, and eat nothing within an hour or two after. Be careful to take down ≈øome Treacle in the morning fa≈øting; but you are fir≈øt to be purged. Otherwi≈øe make a Decoction of the Roots of Elecampane and Pimpernel, or Swallow-wort, in Wine, and drink a warm draught of it mornings; it will provoke Urine. If thou can≈øt bear among≈øt it
Wormwood, Carduus benedictus, or Centory, add them in the Decoction, and it is a good potion for the Liver.

An Herb, call'd by the Latins Euphatorium Avicennae, in Engli≈øh (I think) Common Hemp-Agrimony, hath a great operation in ≈øwelled People, drinking of the Decoction thereof, made in Wine. Be≈øides, u≈øe in this ca≈øe Par≈øley and Smallage-roots in thy meat. Boil Hor≈øe-radi≈øh, and drink of the Decoction warm in the morning. Thy ordinary drink is to be a water, in which hath been boiled a good quantity of Cummin, Annis or Fennel. You may al≈øo now and then drink a little Wine, ≈øwelled people having no great heat in them.

From the≈øe ob≈øtructions of the Liver and Me≈øaraic Veins comes difficulty of Breathing and a dry Cough, which occa≈øions the Inflation of the Belly, and helps to entertain the crudities and indige≈øtions: Mean time there u≈øeth to follow upon this the Yellow Jaundi≈øe. For this, take the Roots of Cyclamen or Sow-bread, reduce them to powder, and take the weight of half a ducat in Meath, or Wine mixt with a little Honey, ≈øweating upon it; and you ≈øhall find your ≈øheets di≈øcoloured of a yellowi≈øh colour. In the ≈øame manner make u≈øe of the ≈øeed of Aquileja, or Columbine. I have reduced the≈øe three to powder, and mixt them together, and given of it the weight of a ducat to ≈øweat; which hath proved very ≈øucce≈øsful. Orange-peels u≈øed in like manner, do al≈øo much good in this ca≈øe. The bitter Centory boiled in Meath, and a good draught drank of it warm in the morning, is al≈øo very good. Likewi≈øe a Decoction
of the white Hore-hound and Chicory-roots is al≈øo u≈øed to good purpo≈øe in this ca≈øe. The≈øe things expel al≈øo Worms, if any do lodge within thee; for which may al≈øo be u≈øed the Souldiers Pills of Aloe, called Maroco≈øtinae. In this ca≈øe Vinegar of Squills is al≈øo an excellent remedy, taking of it in the morning early a ≈øpoonful, two or three, and exerci≈øing after it. It will open the Brea≈øt, and make you expectorate phlegm and ≈ølime in abundance.

If you be troubled with Wind and Gripings of the Guts, be careful to have your Body ≈øoluble. Boil Calamus, cut ≈ømall, in Broath, drink of it hot, putting a little Angelica, or Ma≈øterwort. Do this mornings and evenings, and beware of drinking cold, and ab≈øtain from all Milk, keeping your ≈øelf very warm, e≈øpecially about the Feet, which you will do well to bathe with a Decoction made of A≈øarabacca, Camomile, wild Trefoil, wild Marjerom, wild Thyme, putting a little Salt into it. For your drink, boil Cummin, Annis or Fennel in Water, and now and then a gla≈øs of Wine may do well.

The≈øe Gripings may al≈øo be cured with drinking very bitter Wormwood-wine, as hot as you can endure it. This is al≈øo opening. If you boil Elecampane and Orange-peels with the Wormwood, it will have the greater effect. And if you add to it Allium Sylve≈øtre (Crow-Garlick) you have an excellent Medicine for this purpo≈øe. This I have u≈øed my ≈øelf, and found pre≈øent relief from it, when in a very hard Winter upon a Journey I was taken with the≈øe Gripings. 'Tis indeed a very unplea≈øant potion, exceeding bitter, e≈øpecially being to be drunk
hot; but the good effects will make amends for that. If the pains ≈øhould not cea≈øe after all this, mix with it the quantity of a Ha≈øel-nut of Treacle or Mithridate, and ≈øo drink it off together.

If you can get Malva≈øy, mix a little Oyl of Olives with it, and drink of it warm. Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds would be better, one half of that and the other of Malva≈øy; though the≈øe things perhaps will not ≈øo ea≈øily be had in a Camp. Fre≈øh Butter may ≈øerve in≈øtead of Oyl.

El≈øe make a Decoction of Juniper-berries, or Laurel-berries, and Elecampane in ≈øtrong Wine, and drink a good draught of it mornings and evenings. Or reduce the Herb Carduus benedictus to powder, and drink its weight of a ducat in warm Malva≈øy or other ≈øtrong Wine; it will remove the Gripings, e≈øpecially if you mix with it a little Zedoary pulveri≈øed.
For your Meat, take Larks, if they chance to be in ≈øea≈øon, draw them, and fill their bellies with Garlick, and ≈øo ro≈øt and eat them.
Make a Decoction of Burnet, or of Ma≈øterwort, and Laurel berries, in Beer, ≈øtrain it, and melt a little Butter in it, adding a little Pepper, and ≈øo drink of it hot.

For an outward Application, take the Oyl of Rue and Wormwood, dip Cotton into it, and put it warm to thy Navil. Or beat Onions, and fry them in Dill or Camomile-Oyl, wrap it up in a linnen Cloth, and apply it to thy Belly, where the pain is mo≈øt violent, refre≈øhing it often.

The Oyl of Laurel-berries, mixing a little Juniper-berry-oyl or Nutmeg-oyl with it, may be u≈øed with great benefit, anointing the Navil therewith, and afterwards put to the Navil a warm dry bag filled with Bran and Camomile-blo≈ø≈øoms. Or fry Cow-dung in the Oyl of Dill, or of Camomile, or of white Lillies, and apply it thus to thy Navil, keeping thy ≈øelf, and e≈øpecially thy Leggs, very warm.

If you perceive any Hydropical Di≈øtemper in you, make a Decoction of Wormwood and Juniper-berries in Wine, drink every morning a warm draught of it fa≈øting. You may al≈øo to very good purpo≈øe boil with it Swallow-wort, Burnet, or Succory-roots, adding al≈øo to it ≈øome Annis or Fennel≈øeed. But it will be requi≈øite fir≈øt of all to purge with Mechoacan and Rhubarb; and now and then to repeat this purgation. Ab≈øtain from Milk, Beer, Fruit, and all raw and ob≈øtructing food. If you knew how to u≈øe Elder, you would have an excellent Purge to free your Body from the Hydropical water, becau≈øe the Juyce of the Roots of Elder purgeth Hydropical Per≈øons exceedingly: But 'tis not ≈øo ≈øafe to u≈øe it, unle≈øs you do it with great caution, becau≈øe a very little of it taken inwardly purgeth both by ≈øtool and vomit, like Antimony. Half a nut≈øhel full may ≈øuffice. The like effect you'l find in Elder-buds boiled, and then dre≈ø≈øed with Oyl and Vinegar like a Salad, eating a very little of it. But I advi≈øe you not to u≈øe too much of it; el≈øe it will ca≈øt you into great faintne≈øs. The juyce of the Roots of blew Lillies hath the like vertue, but is likewi≈øe to be u≈øed with great di≈øcretion.

Otherwi≈øe take Earth-worms, and having wa≈øh'd them clean in Wine, reduce them to powder, and take of it for ≈øome mornings the weight of half a drachm in warm Broath or Wine, mixing a little Rhubarb with it.

The Swelling of your Leggs may be removed by heating ≈øome Tiles and ≈øprinkling them with Wine, and clapping them about your Leggs to make them ≈øweat. For a ≈øwelled Groin, take warm Milk, wherein Calamus Aromaticus hath been boiled, and ≈øweeten it well with Sugar, and apply it.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of all ≈øorts of Fluxes; as al≈øo the Tena≈ømus, or vain endeavour of going to ≈øtool; and the Haemorrhoid or Piles, and Mari≈øca's or ≈øore Fundaments.
div.p: IN Wars and Camps, Bloody and other Fluxes are very frequent, cau≈øed by an irregular and ill dyet; and the≈øe Di≈øtempers, e≈øpecially the Bloody Flux, carry away abundance of Men. Where it is to be noted, that the Bloody Flux is infectious, and very catching.

Commmon Fluxes and Loo≈øene≈ø≈øes may ea≈øily be cured. Among≈øt other Remedies, take burnt Harts-horn, and take it often in Broath; or pulveri≈øe Medlar-kernels, and take of the powder in Broath likewi≈øe. Al≈øo an Electuary made of Quinces and Sloes will cure them. The ≈øame does Nutmeg, and the
Roots of Tormentil, Snakeweed, or the Roots of Cinquefoil, baked in Eggs, and eaten. Likewi≈øe the Seed of Dock, broad Plantain; item Terra Sigillata, or Bolus Armenus, and Wheaten-bread coming hot out of the oven, and dipt in red Wine, and eaten. Again, Ma≈øtick pulveri≈øed, and put into Almon-milk, red Wine, or Broath, the weight of a drachm, is good for ≈øuch a Loo≈øene≈øs e≈øpecially as comes from indige≈øtion; adding a little Nutmeg or Galingal to it. Oaken-leaves al≈øo, or the Rinds of Pear-trees, with a little Mace boiled in Wine, and drunk, cureth common Fluxes. Again, Bur≈øa Pa≈øtoris (Shepherds-Pur≈øe) boiled in Steel-water with a little Coriander, and drunk, is al≈øo very good; and ≈øo are Crafi≈øhes boiled in Vinegar, and the ≈øcales beaten to powder, taking a drachm of it mornings and evenings, either in red Wine or in Broath wherein in red-hot Steel hath been ≈øeveral times quenched. Hawes al≈øo boiled, and made into a thick Electuary, and ≈øtrained, is beneficial, if taken in the morning fa≈øting, and an hour or ≈øo before ≈øupper, the quantity of a Walnut.

Be≈øides, take new Milk with its Cream on it, quench therein divers times red-hot Pebble-≈øtones, ≈øo that the Milk may grow hot of it; then mix with it two or three well-beaten Yolks of Eggs, two ounces of Sugar, melting in it an ounce and an half of the Suet of a Deer or Stagg, and about half an ounce of Albumgraecum, u≈øing it for a Cly≈øter, which clean≈øeth and healeth the Guts, and allays the ≈øharpne≈øs of the Blood and other corro≈øive humors, that annoy the Bowels.

But take heed of not ≈øtopping too ≈øuddenly the Bloody Flux, or any other Laske; for if you do, the annoyance will remain in the Body, and cau≈øe Impo≈øtumes, Difficulty of breathing, and other dangerous Di≈øtempers. Wherefore con≈øult with thy ≈øtrength, and if that be con≈øiderable, make not too much ha≈øt; yet keep a bridle upon it, ≈øo as to be able to ≈øtop it when there is need. Mean time, if it be without a Fever or heat, you may do much with new Milk, drinking it al≈øo mornings and evenings warm, ≈øome red-hot Stones having been quenched therein, and ≈øome Sugar mixed with it, to prevent curdling in your Stomach. This Medicine was known to the famous Grecian Phy≈øicians, Aetius, Alexander Trallianus, and Galenus him≈øelf, l. 10. de Simpl. Med. facult. If you add a little Albumgraecum to it, 'twill be the better. I have my ≈øelf done much good with thus prepared Milk, but then there mu≈øt be no Fever; which if there be, you'l ea≈øily perceive it by a great thir≈øt, quick pul≈øe, hot hands, and little ≈øleep &c. For bloody Fluxes are not wont to be accompanied with ≈øhaking Fevers, but only with hot fits, which ≈øpend more of the Patients ≈øtrength in an hour, than ≈øhaking Agues in ≈øeveral days; which is to be well heeded.
Eggs boiled hard in Vinegar, and given to the Patient, that is troubled either with the Bloody or any other Flux, it will be ≈øtopped.

The Roots of Tormentil, or of Snake-weed pulveri≈øed, and this powder drunk in a convenient vehicle, the weight of a drachm, is
one of the mo≈øt approved remedies again≈øt the≈øe Fluxes; Tormentil-roots being very powerful not only to ≈øtop them, but al≈øo to take away their catching malignity.
The Mo≈øs that grows on wild Ro≈øe-≈øhrubs, reduced to powder, and taken in Wine, wherein have been boiled the husks of Acrons, is an approved remedy in this ca≈øe.
Scrape red Lead or Rudle, ≈øuch as Carpenters mark their lines with, put it into Wine or Broath, wherein hath been boil'd the broader kind of Plantain and Tormentil-roots; or take it in an Egg.

Hares-blood dried, and taken inwardly, is al≈øo a tried Medicine in this Di≈øtemper. Item, open a new-laid Egg, take out the white, and fill it up with Nutmeg, or the pulveri≈øed root of Tormentil, or of Snake-weed, and give it the Patient to eat; or put into it ≈øome pulveri≈øed Blood-≈øtone, and it will do good.

I have u≈øed with good ≈øucce≈øs the Seed of the broader Plantain, gro≈øly beaten, and ro≈øted in an Egg, again≈øt the Flux; and I know it al≈øo to have been beneficially u≈øed again≈øt the Bloody Flux.
Take of Mummy, a little Ma≈øtick, Bol-Armeniack, Sanguis Dracon ‚Ä¢ , mix them together, and make a powder of them, and take of it in a convenient Liquor, the weight of a dram, once or twice a day.
Take Rye-bi≈øcuit, and boil it in Water with Coriander, and the roots of Tormentil or of Cranes-bill; quench ≈øome Steel in it once or twice, and give of it to the Patient to drink.
Make a Decoction of Shepherds-pur≈øe and Meadow-≈øweet, in Water and Wine, and now and then drink of it.

Burn live Crafi≈øhes in an earthen Pipkin well-clo≈øed, until they be ≈øo burnt as to be reduced to powder; of which give to the Patient mornings and evenings a Thimble-full or two in a convenient Liquor.

A dried Liver of a ≈øucking Lamb, or of any other ≈øuch Animal, is very good in this ca≈øe, provided ≈øuch a Liver, before 'tis dried, be boiled in Vinegar. Let the Patient take a drachm of it twice a day. Al≈øo the Blood of a Lamb, or of a Hind, both dried, will have here a good effect.

Take a Pigeon, Wood-cock, or Patridge, and having drawn any of them, fill them with Ma≈øtick and a little Nutmeg, and ≈øo ro≈øt them on a Spit, and whil≈øt they are ro≈øting, ba≈øte them with red Wine, and ≈øo let them ro≈øt till they grow ≈øo hard as will make them pulverable; then reduce them or any of them to powder, and take a ≈øpoonful of it at a time in warm Broath.

The highe≈øt Experiment in this ca≈øe is Crocus Martis, taken in the Juyce of the broader kind of Plantain, or in a Pul≈øe of red Beans, or Rice-broath; the do≈øe is half a dram. But when the pain is very great, you may then add to it ≈øome opiat Medicine, as of the Trochi≈øques de Garabe, or one only grain of Laudanum Opiatum. And give the Patient now and then a little new-made Treacle, or mix with it a few grains of the Confection of Archigenes; for of ≈øuch Medicaments a Field-Apotheque is not wont to be de≈øtitute.

For the Patients ordinary drink, boil water, and in it Coriander, dried Sloes, dried ≈ølices of Quinces, burnt Harts-horn, Ma≈øtick, Nutmeg, or any one of the≈øe; putting to it ≈øome of the roots of Snake-weed, Tormentil, or ≈øuch like ad≈øtringent roots. Of this water the Patient may drink according as his nece≈ø≈øity ≈øhall require.

The red Juyce of Quinces, boiled up without Sugar, is al≈øo much to be commended in this ca≈øe, for ≈øtrengthening the bowels, two or three ≈øpoonfuls of it being taken at a time, and that twice a day.

In many places a drink is made of Sloes, Pilo≈øella or Mou≈øe-ear, and Juniper-berries, infu≈øing them all in common water, and letting them ferment together. This yields a plea≈øant acid drink, allaying the violence of the Flux, and quenching thir≈øt withal.
The Rich may make Granat or Quince-wine. But I have here undertaken to deliver ≈øuch things, as are parable and cheap for the poor common Souldier.

I am ≈øorry, that in the Field there is no conveniency of admini≈øtring Cly≈øters: For, though I pre≈øcribe none without great nece≈ø≈øity; yet Cly≈øters being of great benefit in Di≈øea≈øes of the bowels; they being to them like Plai≈øters, I cannot but recommend in this Di≈øtemper Cly≈øters of Milk, wherein Pebble-≈øtones have been ≈øeveral times quenched, mixing a little of the melted Suet of a Stag or Hind, without any Oyl or other fat. I remember, I had once a Patient of quality, that had about an hundred ≈øtools within twenty four hours, who by the u≈øe of ≈øuch Cly≈øters, once or twice applied,
was fully re≈øtored. The cau≈øe whereof is, that the Milk wa≈øhes the bowels, and clears them of the ≈øharp humors that annoy them; moreover, it is healing and repairing, by rea≈øon of the Pebbles quenched therein. The Sugar is ab≈øter≈øive, and helps to clean the injured places. The Fat ≈øticks to the parts annoyed, to defend them from being further hurt by the ≈øub≈øequent humors, which running down over it, can find no ≈øtay there, and con≈øequently cau≈øe no more hurt to tho≈øe parts.

Yet mu≈øt you not put in any grea≈øie Fat, or any Oyl of Olives, becau≈øe they hinder healing; and all Oyl, except that of Lin≈øeed, Poppies, Hemp and Almonds, is very ≈øharp; and you will find, that if any drop of Oyl of Olives ≈øhould chance to fall into your Eye, no Juyce of Oranges or Limons is ≈øo ≈øtrong as to exceed the acrimony of that Oyl. But of this Oyl more will be ≈øaid in the next Chapter, to which I therefore refer you. If you would have your Cly≈øter yet milder and more ≈øanative, you may beat a yolk or two of new-laid Eggs, and mix them with it; though I have contented my ≈øelf with the Ingredients before mention'd, and found great benefit thereby. El≈øe you may in this ca≈øe u≈øe for a Cly≈øter the Cremor hordei, mixt with yolks of Eggs beaten in it; which is al≈øo very good to wa≈øh out the bowels.

Here is no conveniency of making much u≈øe of Apothecary-≈øhops; el≈øe many things might be pre≈øcribed to lay upon the belly and the navil, as al≈øo divers fermentations, and ≈øtomachical Unguents. You may therefore content
your ≈øelf with tho≈øe plain and ea≈øily parable means, already deliver'd, and be thankful to God for them.

But then you are al≈øo to think upon means to obviate Symptoms of this Di≈øtemper, and particularly Drought, which is wont very much to torment people in this Di≈øea≈øe. 'Tis true, Acid things do quench thir≈øt, but they cannot be u≈øed boldly, and therefore you mu≈øt u≈øe them with great di≈øcretion and warine≈øs. And as for ≈øweet things, they u≈øually increa≈øe thir≈øt, and do ea≈øily corrupt, and turn into gall. Wherefore give to the Patient pre≈øerved Currans; or if fre≈øh ones be in ≈øea≈øon, mix a quantity of them with Honey or Sugar, and give him of it to eat upon white-Bread and Butter. Or plump dried Black-cherries, or dried Dama≈øcene-prunes‚ñ™ in half Wine and half Water, and let him hold & ≈øqueeze them in his mouth. Or, if you can, mingle ≈øome Almond-milk with Chalybeat-water, and let him drink thereof; and this is both meat and drink. Or let him drink water, wherein Coriander and roots of Tormentil have been boiled. Or boil in water dried ≈ølices of Quinces, roots of Bi≈øtorta or Snake-weed, and burnt Harts-horn, put into it a to≈øted cru≈øt of Rye-bread rubb'd with Nutmeg, but let it not lye in it above a quarter of an hour, le≈øt the water ≈øhould thicken and become vi≈øcous. Marmelat al≈øo of Quinces, Black-cherries, and Sloes is proper in this ca≈øe, giving the Patient a ≈ølice of it to hold upon his tongue, and ≈øo to ≈øwallow it down.

Further, you mu≈øt learn how to remedy a Tena≈ømus, which is more irk≈øome to the Patient,
and, occa≈øions more trouble to the Phy≈øitian, than the Bloody-flux it ≈øelf, ≈øince it night and day painfully provokes the poor Patient to go to ≈øtool, and yet to no purpo≈øe. For this I have u≈øed many remedies, but found almo≈øt nothing more beneficial, than Fomentations of this nature following: Take Potentilla (wild Tan≈øie Silver-weed) Knot-gra≈øs, Mullein, and Oak-leaves, of each as much as you plea≈øe, put them into two linnen bags, and let them boil in Smiths-water, wherein much Iron hath been quenched: Squeeze out the≈øe bags between two boards, and let them be held alternately to the anus, as hot as can be endured. Black Pitch, ≈øuch as is found on Larch and Fir-trees, put upon a heated fire-≈øhovel, and the fundament held over it, is al≈øo a good remedy; & ≈øo is Turpentine, u≈øed after the ≈øame manner.

Again, take a black well-burnt Brick out of the hearth, heat it thoroughly, and wet it with ≈øharp Vinegar, and wrap it about with a linnen cloth, and let the Patient ≈øit on it as hot as he can endure it. This was the Experiment and Remedy of old Aetius; but he reduced the Brick to powder, and by boiling it in Vinegar, reduced it to a pul≈øe, and ≈øo put it into a linnen rag, and applied it to the fundament. You may chu≈øe which you plea≈øe of the two.

Milk-Cly≈øters, ≈øuch as above pre≈øcribed, would al≈øo be good, but that 'tis not ≈øafe with Cly≈øter-pipes to vex the anus, which is already ≈øore enough. Yet you may give a Suppo≈øitory of Deers-≈øuet mixt with ≈øome Oyl of Mullein. And the grey Diapompholox, or the white Camphire-unguent,
or the like, mixt with it, would not be improper in this ca≈øe.

If there be a Falling down of the fundament, then let it often take in the fumes of the above-mention'd Herbs, adding to them the beaten ≈øtalks of Sloe-≈øhrubs, and tho≈øe of red Ro≈øes, as al≈øo Mou≈øe-ear, and Mug-wort. The outer bark of Elder, and of Shepherds-pur≈øe, doth al≈øo well with it. But above all things keep the Patient warm, and let by no means any of the above≈øaid ≈øteams grow cold on the ≈øore part.

Make al≈øo a Decoction of Garlick, and pour it hot into your clo≈øe-≈øtool, let the Patient ≈øit upon it, to receive the hot ≈øteams. Be≈øides, put ≈øome burnt Harts-horn in a linnen cloth, and ≈øo ≈øtrew it upon the fundament, by little and little to drew it up. Or heat an Oaken-board very well, and cover it over with Stags-≈øuet, and let the Patient ≈øit upon it whil≈øt 'tis hot. Put Colophonium or the Ro≈øin of Pinetree upon a heated Iron, and let the Patient by holding his fundament over it take in the ≈øteams thereof, Anoint al≈øo the part with Butter, in which Onions have been boiled; and ≈øtrew upon it Album-graecum very finely pulveri≈øed. You may al≈øo make a Salve of Ceru≈øe, Bol-Armeniack, Dragons-blood, Stags-≈øuet, Blood-≈øtone, Oyl of Myrrh, or Butter in which fir≈øt hath been boiled broad Plantain, Mullein, or wild Tan≈øie Silver-weed; and with this anoint the fundament.

As for the Mari≈øca's, which do torment Men e≈øpecially, they may be cured with Oyl of Eggs, Salve of red Hounds-tongue, as al≈øo with
the ∆≤nguentum Populeum, or with Butter ≈øtirr'd up and down in a Leaden Mortar, till it turn grey or blacki≈øh, Let the Patient drink al≈øo of Scrophularia or Fig-wort, infu≈øed in his drink, this being a ≈øpecifick for that evil. Al≈øo the Oyl of Mullein, Elder-blo≈ø≈øoms, Water-lilly, and White-lillies, is an excellent remedy for it, a rag dipped therein being laid upon the part affected. To u≈øe ≈øcarifying on the lower part of the back-bone, is al≈øo very good, though it be very painful.

If the Hoemorrhoid-vein bleed in a convenient time, and do not overbleed, it is an exceeding good thing, and pre≈øerves from many Di≈øea≈øes, as the Inflammation of the Lungs, Stitches of the ≈øides, the Lepro≈øie, Melancholly, Quartans, and the like. If the ≈øame vein ≈øhould bleed in one that is mad, or di≈øturbed in his mind, or in one that is troubled with the Inflammation of the Kindneys, the≈øe Di≈øtempers would thereby be allayed. But if it ≈øhould bleed too often & too violently, it weakens much, cau≈øeth a pale colour and the Drop≈øie. My Collegues and I have often open'd it by Leeches, and thereby found great benefit. But in ca≈øe it ≈øhould exceed in bleeding, you mu≈øt deal with it as you do with the Bloody Flux, and give to the Patient Terra Sigillata, Bol-Armeniack, burnt Harts-horn, and the like ad≈øtringent things. If you can get ≈øome teeth of the Hippo-potamus, ra≈øp it into powder, and drink ≈øome of it in red or white wine; it ≈øtops all bleeding, of the no≈øe, mouth, guts, fundament, hoemorrhoids, the matrix, e≈øpecially the bleeding of Women after delivery.
Here is al≈øo very u≈øeful the expre≈øs'd Juyce of Plantain, Shepherds-pur≈øe, and of the tender leaves of Ra≈ø-berries, or Brambles, infu≈øed in wine and drunk.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of Pe≈øtilential Boyls, ∆≤lcers, Carbuncles and other venomous Sores.
div.p: ABove I have pre≈øcribed ≈øome, both Pre≈øervative and Curative, Medicines again≈øt the Plague, re≈øerving for this place the Chirurgical means, to be u≈øed again≈øt that Di≈øtemper, thinking it be≈øt to di≈øcour≈øe of them together in a place apart.

Concerning then the Pe≈øtilential Bubo's and Sores, that ri≈øe behind the Ears, under the Arms, and about the Groin, the Cure of them con≈øi≈øts chiefly in this, that they be ripen'd with ≈øpeed; for which end are to be employed meer emollient and ≈øuppurating things. Yet are you to know to di≈øtingui≈øh between Boyls, there being ≈øome of them that are not venomous, e≈øpecially in young people; and they may be hereby di≈øcerned, that at the touch they cau≈øe no pain, whereas the Pe≈øtilential ones are very painful; which are al≈øo di≈øcover'd by the accompanying venomous Fever, and other pernicious Symptoms. And of the≈øe latter great care mu≈øt be had to bring them out, and to a ≈øpeedy maturation, becau≈øe tho≈øe that lye deep are very dangerous.

Some there have been, that have u≈øed Scarification, and even Ve≈øicatories, thereby thinking to fetch out the venom. Others have pierced the Sores through, about a hands breadth beneath the Sores, putting the root of black Helebore into them, thereby to draw out the venomous matter. But ≈øuch means have rather irritated the evil, cau≈øed great pains, and put the Patient to greater danger.

Wherefore I judge nothing ≈øafer and better, than, as I was intimating, to u≈øe Emollients. Take then of the common Diachylon, and lay it upon the invenom'd Boyls; and be≈øides make a pul≈øe of the≈øe herbs, viz. of Camomile, Mallows, Melilot, Dill, Line-≈øeed, Fenu-greek, Althaea, the roots of White Lillies, as al≈øo ≈øalve of Althaea, Oyl of Camomile and Lillies, mixing a little Saffron with it, and ≈øome Oyl of Scorpions. Of this pul≈øe make ≈øome warm and lay it over the Diachylon upon the Sore.

Or, boil Wheaten-bread in the broath of Mallows and Camomile, till it grow ≈øoft, then ≈øaffron it over, and mix March-mallows-≈øalve with it, and lay it on. Or make a Plai≈øter of Figgs and ro≈øted Onions; or, make a pul≈øe of Bread-leaven, Honey, yolks of Eggs, and the juyce of Onions, adding a little Turpentine to it, and ≈øo lay it on.

If the meer common Diachylon be not ≈øufficient, u≈øe the Plai≈øter Diachylon cum gummis or de Mucilaginibus, or mix a Melilot-plai≈øter with the common Diachylon, make a pul≈øe of it with Oyl of Lillies, mixing a little Oyl of Scorpions with it, and ≈øo lay it on.

In laying on of Treacle, I have this con≈øideration, that Treacle, hinders putrefaction, which is the thing here mo≈øt of all de≈øired, becau≈øe all maturation, which here is a reducing the Sore to ≈øuppuration, is a kind of putrefaction.

Here al≈øo the Plai≈øter call'd Ba≈øilicon is of good u≈øe; likewi≈øe the Ceratum Oe≈øipum Philagrii and Me≈øuae, which Cerata are made of Gummi Ammoniac, Bdellium, Turpentine, liquid Styrax, Goo≈øe-grea≈øe, Marrow of Cows-bones and Oe≈øipum, and a little Saffron. Some take a dried Toad, and lay it upon the boyl, to draw out the venom.

Now when the Sores are ≈øoftned and ripe, and yet break not of them≈øelves, they are to be opened with a lancet; and if you have to do with Per≈øons ≈øo delicate that they cannot endure a lancet, you may make u≈øe of the Lapis Septicus or Corro≈øive-≈øtone, which opens without pain, but is more ≈ølow. Mean time beware of opening the Sores too ≈øoon; for then they will turn to a hard ≈øwelling, which the Patient will not wear off whil≈øt he liveth.

There are al≈øo ≈øome Plague-≈øores that never break, but wear away by ≈øweat. Yet if they ≈øhould leave behind ≈øome hardne≈øs, you may, when the danger is pa≈øt and the ≈øickne≈øs overcome, make u≈øe of ≈øome fomentations of Melilot, Camomile, March-mallows, Mullein and ≈øuch like: You may al≈øo take of the Gum, call'd Tacamahaca, and mix with it a Plai≈øter of Melilot or Diachylon, and lay it on.

The Sores being open'd; they mu≈øt be kept open with ≈ømall pellets, (called by the Germans,
Quellmai≈ø≈øeln,) dipt in a Salve made for this purpo≈øe out of fre≈øh Butter, Yolks of Eggs, and Turpentine, well mixt together cold.

But it happens ≈øometimes, that ≈øuch Bubo's, by rea≈øon of the venomous matter, do eat in, or grow fi≈øtulous, or make matter-baggs, in which the matter ≈øettles. In this ca≈øe you mu≈øt u≈øe the ∆≤nguentum fu≈øcum, Apo≈øtolicum, or the Aegyptiacum: Or make the following water, to be ≈øquirted into ≈øuch Sores; namely of Celondine, Scordium or Water-germander, Carduus-benedictus, Centory, or the like Herbs, together with Tormentil and Whitlow-gra≈øs; all boiled in wine. If the Sores be very ill, you may boil with it ≈øome quick Brim≈øtone, and Myrrh, and if need be, mix with it a little fine Verdigrea≈øe. Or, take Honey four ounces and an half, a quarter of an ounce of Aloes Epatica, a dram of Salt, an ounce and a half of Scordium, mix all well together, and keep it for u≈øe; and when you have occa≈øion for any of it, then di≈ø≈øolve it in wine, and fpirt it in. Mean time, enlarge the opening of the Boyls with the afore≈øaid Pellets, that ≈øo the matter may have vent enough, and come away without any impediment.

The Unguent of ∆≤ly≈ø≈øes Aldrovandus is al≈øo very good, for the clearing of ≈øuch Sores; and 'tis made of Oyl of Ro≈øes, the Juyce of broad Plantain, ≈øharp-pointed Dock, Centory, and Night-≈øhade, with a little Litharge, burnt Lead, and prepared Camphir. In≈øtead of the Juyce of Night-≈øhade, you may take that of Cumfry.

As for the Sores call'd Anthraces, and tho≈øe they call Carbuncles, great care mu≈øt be taken to break them ≈øoon, and to heal them ≈ølowly, that ≈øo the poy≈øonous matter may all come away. They ripen and break ≈øoone≈øt by fatty (but not hot) Plai≈øters and Unguents; e≈øpecially ≈øuch as are made of Butter, Leaven, Yolks of Eggs, and Honey; or if you mix together Turpentine, ∆≤nguentum Populeum, or Ro≈øe-≈øalve mixt with Yolks of Eggs, or the ∆≤nguentum Anodynum mixt with the Ointment of Hounds-tongue, and laid on it. It mu≈øt be often refre≈øhed, becau≈øe ≈øuch hot Sores and Ulcers, before they break, do ≈øo draw, wa≈øte, and, as 'twere, lick up tho≈øe fatne≈ø≈øes, that ≈øometimes of the Plai≈øters, that have lain on them, there remains nothing but the bare ragg. The Empla≈øtrum Ba≈øilicon, or the common yellow drawing Plai≈øter, is here the mo≈øt u≈øeful.

You mu≈øt al≈øo ≈øurround the Anthrax with good defen≈øives; for if it invade the neighbouring part never ≈øo little, it will ≈øoon make a large halo or circle, which will at length ≈øeparate from the ≈øound, and fall away like an E≈øcarre. For ≈øuch defen≈øives make u≈øe of Album Camphoratum, or the ∆≤nguentum de Liquiritia, known by our people under the name of Dr. Mindererus his Licori≈øh ointment. Item the ∆≤nguentum de Lithargyro; or the ∆≤nguentum Jovis, prepared of fre≈øh Butter, with Thla≈øpi minus, or Bowyers Mu≈øtard, (otherwi≈øe narrow-leav'd wild Cre≈ø≈øes,) Cranes-bill, Elder, Poppy, Vervain, and ≈øome ≈øhaved Licori≈øh. Some take nothing but Vervain
and the fre≈øh leaves of Henbane, beaten together, and the Juyce ≈øtrained, and ≈øo u≈øed. Of this Ointment you may make much with confidence; for it will do you very good ≈øervice in Inflammations, e≈øpecially in the ca≈øe of the ≈øwelling of the Groins.

Among≈øt the approved Medicines for this purpo≈øe, may de≈øervedly be reckoned the Plai≈øter made of Soot; which is thus to be prepared: Take of the fine≈øt Chimney-≈øoot one ounce and a quarter; of Leaven, Turpentine and fre≈øh Butter, ana one ounce; of Venetian Soap an ounce and a half; two Yolks of Eggs; of Treacle and Mithridate, ana a quarter of an ounce: Beat all the≈øe together in a Mortar, and ≈øo reduce it to a pa≈øte, and then u≈øe it Plai≈øter-wi≈øe.

When the Anthrax or the Carbuncle is broken, you mu≈øt then handle it very gently and di≈øcreetly, u≈øing only the above-de≈øcribed Egg-≈øalve, putting it into the opening, and covering the Sore only with the common yellow drawing Plai≈øter, or the Plai≈øter prepared of Oyl, Wax and Ro≈øin, or Turpentine. Let the matter work out well, and when you are ≈øure that 'tis very clean, and have a mind to con≈øolidate it, make only u≈øe of Triapharmacon, vulgarly call'd the brown Diachylon; you may be≈øides put into it ≈øome of the ∆≤nguentum de Tutia, and that of the Diapompholox, and one of the Plai≈øters of them upon it. The ∆≤lme-plai≈øter al≈øo, made of Oyl and Ceru≈øe, heals al≈øo very well. But be very careful, le≈øt any of the matter remain lurking in the Ulcer. If here and there any ≈øhould be found yet remaining,
as often happens, then make u≈øe of the Empla≈øtrum Apo≈øtolorum. But if you can prepare the Diapalma, otherwi≈øe called Diacalcithros, make u≈øe of that. I am wont to call it the Fi≈øtula-plai≈øter, becau≈øe it doth not ea≈øily ≈øuffer Fi≈øtula's to ≈øtink, but keeps them clean and ≈øweet. Such a Plai≈øter is al≈øo that, which is called I≈øis, to be found in Galen, and performing the ≈øame thing. They are both to be found in the Augu≈øtan Di≈øpen≈øatory, together with the way of preparing them.

Now what concerns Old Sores, which many are troubled with, in their Leggs e≈øpecially, becau≈øe the humors of the body u≈øually ≈øettle there; you mu≈øt above all things be careful to keep them clean, and to that end wa≈øh them, at lea≈øt once a day, with your own Urine: Or boil Carduus benedictus, Egrimony, Plantain, and Roots of Tormentil, in half ≈ømall Meath and half Wine, and wa≈øh the Ulcer with it, as often as you dre≈øs it. Among the common Plai≈øters for ≈øuch evils is the brawn Diachylum one of the be≈øt. El≈øe you may prepare this Ointment which follows: Take the middle rind of Elder, and St. Johns-wort, boil them in Oyl, putting a little Wine to it, and ≈øo let it boil up till the Wine be boiled away; then take it off from the fire, and let it cool; this done, ≈øtir a little Turpentine among≈øt it, and a Yolk or two of Eggs, according as you make a greater or le≈ø≈øer quantity; mixing with it a little Allum and Vitriol, (the white is the be≈øt,) ≈øtir all well together, and apply it to the Ulcer, and make a bandage, and cover it as u≈øually. For a good Drawing-plai≈øter,
take Ro≈øin, Bees-wax and Oyl-Olive; the quantity of the Ro≈øin mu≈øt be but the half of the Wax: Let them melt together, and ≈øtir among≈øt it ≈øome Tartar exqui≈øitely powder'd. U≈øe not much of fatty things to ≈øuch Ulcers. I have had under my care ≈øuch Ulcers, that were to be healed with only dry things, as with ≈øtrewing in of Crocus Martis, and the red Earth of Vitriol, of which hereafter.

For this rea≈øon the antient Phy≈øicians and Chirurgeons invented a dry Stone, which they kept ≈øo ≈øecret, that they called it Lapis Philo≈øophorum; which is ea≈øily made, as followeth: Take Allum, Hungarian Vitriol, of each one pound, beat them to powder, and mix them well together; then put all into a gla≈øed earthen pot, and pour upon it two quarts of Water, boil them together, and ≈øtir them continually with a Spatula, taking off the ≈øcum: When 'tis boiled in, put to it an ounce of Bolus Armenus, an ounce and a half of Ceru≈øe, a quarter of an ounce of Camphir, all finely powder'd, ≈øtirring it well about; la≈øtly, put it to a quart of ≈øharp Vinegar, and boil all together to a ≈øtony con≈øi≈øtence; which reduce to powder, and of it ≈øtrew a little into the Ulcer, or let ≈øome of it di≈ø≈øolve in a convenient Liquor, and wa≈øh the Ulcer therewith, or dip ≈øome Linnen raggs in it, and lay it over the place.

'Tis al≈øo prepared this way: Take green and white Vitriol, of each a drachm; of Lapis Calaminaris, Ceru≈øe, Bol-Armeniack, of each two ounces and a half; of Sal-Armoniack an ounce. Beat them all to powder, put them in an earthen pot, mingle and ≈øtir them together
in Vinegar, to be a thick pul≈øe; then put your pot upon a hot Charcoal-fire, to let it grow red hot, ≈øo as that the matter be reduced to a ≈øtony con≈øi≈øtence; of which di≈ø≈øolve about half an ounce in half a pint of Water, dip Linnen raggs into it, and put it twice a day upon the Ulcer. 'Tis al≈øo very good for purulent Brea≈øts.

I was ≈øpeaking above of Lavements: The≈øe you may prepare of all ≈øorts of Wound-herbs, by boiling Con≈øound, Bugle; Fluellin, Ground-Ivy, Yarrow, Snake-weed, Avens, Ar≈ømart; you may al≈øo, again≈øt putrefaction and the ≈øettling of purulent matter, mix ≈øometimes a little Myrrh, or Aloes Epatica, Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, quick Brim≈øtone, Camphir, Niter, Allum, Vitriol, or the like. Nor is it needful to bind your ≈øelf to this or that preci≈øely, but you may take ≈øuch of them as you can get.

I have a peculiar Ulcer-≈øalve, which I call ∆≤nguentum Decameron, being made of ten ≈øorts of Juices. Of the≈øe the principal is the Juice of Per≈øicaria, (Ar≈ømart;) to which are added the Juices of Ground≈øel, Tobacco, Yarrow, ≈øharp-pointed Dock, Cranes-bill, broad and pointed Plantain, Centory, St. Johns-wort, and Celondine. The≈øe Juices mu≈øt be well ≈øtrained, and then kept for ≈øome days in gla≈ø≈øes or gla≈øed Ve≈ø≈øels to ≈øettle, and then very gently pour off the clear from the ≈øediment. Which done, boil them with fre≈øh Butter, and ≈øome good Licori≈øh newly ≈øcraped, as al≈øo ≈øome Tormentil and Cumfrey, adding a little red Hounds-tongue Salve and Oyl of Myrrh, and
Deer-≈øuet: Let all be boiled together, till the cracking cea≈øe, and the Juice be boiled in. Then ≈øtrain it through a Linnen Cloth; and add to it ≈øome Venice-Turpentine, Gum Elemi and a little Bees-wax, both the latter melted each a part. Of the Wax there needs no more than to bring the Salve to a due con≈øi≈øtence. Then is this Unguent prepared, to which may be added a little refined Verdigrea≈øe, which will make it perfect. It is of great efficacy in foul Wounds, for both clean≈øing and healing; as experience will ≈øhew.

A Chirurgeon, in meeting with Ulcers, is to ob≈øerve well the purulent matter that i≈ø≈øues, ≈øince he may from thence learn the condition of the evil, whether it proceed from foul Blood, Gall, corrupt Phlegm, or Adu≈øt Melancholy. If the evil grow wor≈øe, and the Humors of the Body force their way copiou≈øly thorow, then beware, and withal exhort the Patient to purge, or to ≈øweat with taking ≈øome Sa≈ø≈øafra≈øs, or the like.

The Sanies or matter that is thick, white, and well dige≈øted, is the be≈øt; but when there runs but a ≈øharp water out of the Ulcer, this is not good, and is withal painful. Which to obviate, you mu≈øt u≈øe Litharge, Ceru≈øe, and the like; putting al≈øo beaten Lead upon the place, and clean≈øing the fi≈øtulat holes with Lead-oyl, qualifying its ≈øharpne≈øs with Oyl of Eggs. This Lead-oyl is made two ways, the the one out of Ceru≈øe, which is green; the other out of Litharge, which is yellow or reddi≈øh Both are prepared with Vinegar.

Boil Celondine in wine, and with this wine
you may al≈øo clean≈øe the Ulcer with good effect. Mix afterwards a drachm of Verdigrea≈øe with about four ounces of the Juyce of Ground-Ivy; u≈øe it with wiecks or raggs dipt therein for the foul Ulcer-holes.

Burn Oy≈øter-≈øhells to powder, and u≈øe it for old Ulcers that need clean≈øing, which this powder will well perform by rea≈øon of the Salt that is in tho≈øe ≈øhells. You may ≈øometimes have occa≈øion al≈øo of the Mercurius praecipitatus, or the Mercurius dulcis Co≈ømeticus. If you can prepare this you have a good Remedy.

As for hard Knobs and Boyls, they commonly owing their ri≈øe to the Venereal Di≈øea≈øe are not ≈øo proper for this place. However you may make a plai≈øter again≈øt ≈øuch Knobs of the phlegm of Althaea or Mar≈øh-mallows, Gummi Ammoniac, Galbanum, Turpentine, Myrrh, Mi≈ø≈øel-toe of the oak, mixing a little Bee-wax therewith and ≈øome Oyl of Earthworms. If you will have it ≈øtronger, mix with it Gumm Elemi, Tacamahaca or Carana. But this can only be compa≈ø≈øed by the rich men; the poor mu≈øt be content with the Melilot-plai≈øter, mixt with Saffron and the Oyl of Mullain or Dill. You may al≈øo prepare for ≈øuch Patients a Salve of Fox-oyl, Dill-oyl, Turpentine, Man-grea≈øe, and the like, mixing therewith ≈øome Oyl of Earth-worms and the Oyl of Mullain-flowers, Camomil and white Lillies.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the Chirurgical means of ≈øtaunching blood, of Wound-bal≈øoms and plai≈øters, of Wound-drinks, and remedies for Burnings.
div.p: THis is the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary Chapter of this whole Tract. For, although in every Camp, yea in every Regiment, and even in every Company there ought to be one or more Chirurgeons; yet becau≈øe in a battle, or the ≈øtorming of a ≈øtrong-hold, there may be wounded a very great number of men, who, by rea≈øon of the multitude, cannot all be dre≈ø≈øed by the Chirurgeons, every common Souldier, that is ≈øound and unhurt, is obliged to a≈ø≈øi≈øt his fellow, con≈øidering it may ≈øoon be his own ca≈øe.

In the fir≈øt place then, refre≈øh thy fellow that is wounded, with wine, cold water, vinegar, or the like; then place him in a right po≈øture. For, if the wounds be in the head or about the brea≈øt, you ought to lay him high with his head and ≈øhoulders, that ≈øo the blood may ≈øink down from the places wounded. If his legg be hurt, put it ≈øo that it may not hang downwards, and thereby the afflux from the body be prevented, which otherwi≈øe might cau≈øe a tumour. If the wounds be in the middle of the body, then place him
≈øo, that, if po≈ø≈øible, he may lye ≈øomewhat hollow with his back.

This done, wa≈øh the wound very gently, (≈øo as not to anger it,) with meer wine, or even with pure common water, only with a very little ≈øalt ca≈øt into it: or with the Patients own urine; and then dry it with lint of long-worn linnen, without much ≈øtirring in the wound, for fear of making the veins bleed again.

If any one do bleed ≈øo copiou≈øly, that it is not ea≈øily ≈øtopp'd, and the Patient is in danger‚ñ™ then receive of his blood in an Iron pan, and letting it run about therein, hold it over the fire till it be dry and between your fingers friable to powder; of which ≈øtrew ≈øome into the bleeding wound, and it will ≈øtop it. But of this ca≈øe more hereafter.

The wound being clean≈øed, and the bleeding ≈øtayed, take fine linnen-raggs, burn them as you are wont to do for tinder, and quench it in Oyl of Olives; and put ≈øome of it into the wound, If you have no plai≈øter at hand‚ñ™ take a ≈ølice of un≈øalted lard and lay it on.
