Again, take of the red Hounds-tongue Ointment, of the bigne≈øs of a great Walnut, di≈ø≈øolve it in warm Broath; it expels all coagulated blood, e≈øpecially if you mix ≈øome Sperma Ceti with it.

If you have any Thorns, Thi≈øtles, Bullets, Small-≈øhot, or the like, to draw out, where perhaps you cannot reach them with In≈øtruments, then burn live Crafi≈øhes in a new Pipkin, until they be reducible to powder, but burn them not to A≈øhes. This powder mix with Hares-≈øuet, and lay it on, and you will find a good effect. Al≈øo take the Roots of the big Reed that grows in Mari≈øhes, dry them to be pulveri≈øed, and mix Virgin-honey with it,
and lay it upon the part; and of the ≈øame powder give the Patient to drink, twice a day, the weight of half a ducat in Wine, or in Broath, or in a vulnerary potion, if you have at hand. The fir≈øt of this I learned of the Excellent Doctor Schleer of Con≈øtance.

The Excrement of a Gander, being applied, is al≈øo powerful in drawing out Iron. Again, Quince-wine mingled with Vinegar, and putting ≈øome Saffron and Gun-powder among≈øt it, if you give it to one that hath been ≈øhot, it will do him good. Otherwi≈øe, they make a plai≈øter of the Roots of Cumfrey, Aron, Polypody, Juniper, and dried Radi≈øhes, all reduced to powder, and mix it with Hares-≈øuet and grey Diachylum, making a thick Ointment of it, and ≈øpreading it over a piece of Hare-skin, and ≈øo laying it on. This is greatly prai≈øed, e≈øpecially when ≈øeconded with good Wound-drinks, of which Ma≈øter-wort is one of the Ingredients: But if you have not this at hand, take a Beet and boil it in Wine, and lay it warm on the wound. Likewi≈øe young Swallows, not yet fledge, burnt to powder, and this powder made by Acetum of Ro≈øes into a pul≈øe, and laid on, does the ≈øame.

You ought al≈øo to be provided for the Synovia: And if you proceed aright with my Wound-bal≈øom above de≈øcribed, and keep the wound warm, you may therewith do much good. Mix with it, ex abundanti, the red Earth of Vitriol, above di≈øcour≈øed of. This Synova is a dangerous thing, and often cau≈øeth almo≈øt intollerable pain, if it be not well handled; the Herb of Straw-berries and its
Juyce have great vertue in this ca≈øe. Some make u≈øe of the White of Eggs, Bol-Armeniack, and the like. The Magi≈øtery of Allum al≈øo belongs hither; for, Allum mixed with Vinegar, and clapp'd on very warm, allays it al≈øo. Elder-blo≈ø≈øoms likewi≈øe, u≈øed every way, are effectual in the ≈øame ca≈øe. Employ al≈øo diligently ≈øuch Defen≈øive-plai≈øters, as are not fatty, becau≈øe fat lays no hold on water.

To proceed to Burnings, I know almo≈øt no better Salve for burning than this; Take a Tench, or any common-Pond-fi≈øh; fry one or more of them with good Butter, pour the fatne≈øs upon cold Water in a broad earthen Pan, and you have an excellent Ointment again≈øt Burnings. When, ≈øome years ≈øince, a Powder-Mill was blown up, and the Attendants upon the work ≈øo mi≈øerably burnt, that they looked as if they had been ro≈øted, they were healed with this Ointment, only a little finely powder'd Sage being mixt with it.

Cream and Lin≈øeed-oyl mingled together, and raggs moi≈øten'd therein, put upon the burnt part, healeth, though the burning were made with Aqua-fortis; for, to my knowledge, a certain Chymi≈øt that had thus burnt all his Arm, was thereby re≈øtored. Or, take Oyl of Elder, or ≈øtale Oyl that hath been long in a burning Lamp; beat half as much, as you take of that, of the Whites of Eggs among≈øt it, and anoint the burnt part therewith. If you can get no Oyl of Elder, take any other cooling Oyl, as of Nymphaea, (Water-lillies) Poppy-≈øeeds, Violets or Ro≈øes, or the Oyl of Poplar-buds, or of Mar≈øh-Marigold Flowers.

If you can have Quince-wine, it marvellou≈øly ex≈øtingui≈øhes the burning of any ≈øhot, dipping a Linnen pledget in it, and drawing it through the wound, or left in it, repeating this every twelfth hour. The Juyce or Wine of Quinces mu≈øt be u≈øed as it comes from the fruit, without any mixture of Sugar. This I learn'd from a Nobleman, a great Souldier, of long experience in the Wars of France, the Low-Countries, and Hungary.

The ∆≤nguentum Jovis, made of Henbane, Vervain and Butter, is al≈øo very u≈øeful for this purpo≈øe. Likewi≈øe the Ointment of Calx viva, which is fir≈øt ≈øix or ≈øeven times to be ≈ølaked and dulcified with pure water, pouring every twelve or ≈øixteen hours fre≈øh water upon it, and decanting the former, ≈øo as to leave always the Calx at the bottom; which is then to be mixed with Oyl of Ro≈øes, or ≈øome other cooling Oyl, for an Ointment.

If you be well acquainted with Elder, and know how to u≈øe it, you may obtain out of it one of the be≈øt Cures of Burnings, e≈øpecially out of its middle rinds. Again, Yolks of Eggs and Lin≈øeed-oyl, equal quantities, mixt together, and ≈øpread over the burning, is al≈øo very good. Egg-oyl likewi≈øe u≈øed by it ≈øelf, and Vernice employed by Joyners, do well al≈øo; but the latter of the≈øe two, if it be mixed with Oyl of Spicanard or Petroleum, is to be mingled among≈øt Lin≈øeed-oyl.

Spread fre≈øh Butter upon Cabbage-leaves, having fir≈øt fryed the Butter with ≈øome blo≈ø≈øoms or the middle rind of Elder; and ≈øo lay them to the burning; Elder being a great re≈øi≈øter
of Inflammations, and therefore very good to allay St. Antonies fire; if you pull its mild green rinds from the ≈øtem, and lay them on, without moi≈øtening them. El≈øe they u≈øe again≈øt the ≈øaid Fire, Flower mixed with the powder of Licorice, to be clapt on with a ragg done over with red Saunders. My way is, to take the ≈øhavings of ≈øome fre≈øh and juycy Licorice, and to fry them in new Butter; then to ≈øtrain the Butter from it, and to fry the like fre≈øh Licorice therein, and to ≈øtrain the Butter from that again; repeating this five or ≈øix times. Among this ≈øtrained Butter I ≈øtir ≈øome pure and fine Ceru≈øe, Whites of Eggs and a little Camphire. And with this Ointment I have, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of God, done much good in the ≈øaid inflammation of St. Antonies fire; and the common people do to this very day call this Ointment by no other name than that of Doctor Minderer's Licorice-Ointment. But to return to the quenching of Burnings.

If you can have Milk-cream, mingle it with Cow-dung fre≈øhly made, and ≈øo clap it on; though fre≈øh Cow-dung alone allays burning. Crafi≈øhes pounded alive, and fryed in fre≈øh Butter or in common Suet, the Butter ≈øtrained here from, is al≈øo a good Ointment again≈øt burnings. Un≈øalted Lard, melted by a Wax-candle, or an hot Iron, and dropp'd upon fre≈øh cold water, and then gather'd up from the water, and carefully rubbed from the ≈øame, hath the like operation. Take one of the cooling Oyls above-named, and fre≈øh Butter, boil the middle rind of Elder in it, and with a
≈øufficient quantity of Wax make of it a Salve, and this al≈øo will cure burning.

You ought al≈øo to be provided with a fit apparatus, Lints, Swathing-clouts, &c. and to take Deer-≈øuet, Oyl of Ro≈øes or Elder, and white Wax, and melt them over the fire, yet ≈øo as that you melt the Wax, by it ≈øelf, and add of it no more to the re≈øt than to make it a thin plai≈øter. Into this compound you mu≈øt dip ≈øome fine lint, and you'l find it very u≈øeful for any angry part; as al≈øo when one limb pre≈ø≈øes or otherwi≈øe incommodes another, as happens in hydropical and other ≈øwollen people, who≈øe belly ≈øo ≈øinks down, that the thighs ≈øuffer by it; in which ca≈øe ≈øuch lints are to be put between the parts, to keep them from immediately touching and pre≈ø≈øing one another.
A grangrene is cured with Sal-armoniac boiled in Urine, e≈øpecially in that of the Patient, and clapping ≈øuch Urine upon the part affected:
The quantity of the Sal-armoniac may be ≈øix drachms.

For frozen Feet, take Gander-≈øuet and Deer-≈øuet; di≈ø≈øolve them together, and pour them into a white excavated Turnip, and expo≈øe this for a while to the Air, Rain, Wind, Hoar-fro≈øt, Snow, according as the ≈øea≈øon ≈øhall be: Then mince the Turnip, and fry it in the ≈øame Suet which you had poured into it; that done, ≈øqueeze it out, and let the fat fall upon cold water; and being there brought to con≈øi≈øtence, take it off, and bring it over the helm from burned Wine, and decant this carefully from it again, and 'tis duely prepared. You
may al≈øo recover frozen Feet with white rotten Turnips, beaten with Butter or Tallow, and ≈øo clapt on.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of ≈øeveral promi≈øcuous Medical Practices, for the Service of the hone≈øt Souldier.
div.p: THis Chapter I have annexed to the former as an Appendix, for the ea≈øe and good of Souldiers; wherein ≈øome things will occurr, not inferiour to tho≈øe that have preceded. But herein I have kept no order, but ≈øet them down promi≈øcuou≈øly, yet faithfully, to ≈øupply what may have been omitted before.

If you be troubled with the Tooth-ach, coming from the cold in winter, take the root of Pyrethrum (Pellitory of Spain) and boil it in Vinegar, and hold this Vinegar warm in your mouth, and it will draw out the phlegm that cau≈øes the pain. Or, take the root of Elder, boil it in half Wine and half Water, and hold it warm upon the Teeth. But what you take of this Decoction mu≈øt be often ≈øpit out, and other fre≈øh taken into you mouth; of which I have found wonderful Effects.
The root of Heath boiled together with the ≈øame herb in wine, and laid on is e≈øteem'd to be powerful in drawing out thorns and ≈øplinters.
You may make a good Ointment again≈øt the Itch and Scabs, of Savin, ≈øtale Fat, Brim≈øtone and Juniper-berries Oyl.

If your Limbs after long ≈øickne≈øs be weak, boil Valerian-roots in Camomil-oyl, and anoint ≈øuch Limbs therewith. Al≈øo the Oyl of Lillies in the valley, and that of yellow Violets, is good for the ≈øame purpo≈øe.
For worms in the Fingers, brui≈øe Par≈øicaria (Ar≈ømart,) and lay it on; or take of a Piggs Bladder of Gall, and put it on the affected Finger like a Thimble.

If you have any coagulated or congealed blood in your Brea≈øt, make a Decoction of Scabious, Chervil, and Germander, in two parts of wine, one part of water; and ≈øtrain it, and drink of it mornings and evenings.

Again≈øt the putrefaction of the Mouth, make a Decoction of Privet in water, adding afterwards a little Allum to it, and u≈øe it for a gargari≈øm. Al≈øo a Decoction of the middle rind of Hawthorn, with a little Allum, is of great effect in the ≈øame ca≈øe.

Cabbage and Colewort-leaves burnt to a≈øhes and a Lixivium made of it, and clapp'd on, cureth a Gangrene, and the wild Fire, e≈øpecially if you mingle a little Oyl of Elder therewith. If you can have no Elder-blo≈ø≈øoms for this Oyl, take the green middle rind of Elder, and boil it in Oyl Olive, and then ≈øtrain the Oyl; which done, take fre≈øh rind of Elder, and proceed with it as before, repeating it three or four times to make the Oyl the ≈øtronger. You may add a little wine to it whil≈øt 'tis boiling, but that mu≈øt all boil away, and
≈øo long till the Oyl cracks no more in the fire.
Southern-wood ≈øtamped with grea≈øe and laid on, draweth out ≈øplinters.

If you have the Itch or are ≈øcabby, and can light upon ≈øome water ≈øtanding in the hollowne≈øs of a Beech-tree, wa≈øh your ≈øelf with it. Or make a Decoction of the brown rind of Alder, (which is under the gray,) in Butter, and anoint your ≈øelf with it; mixing, if you will a little Brim≈øtone therewith.

If you be troubled with the Ring-worm, or any running Scab, infu≈øe Litharge in Vinegar, and let it ≈øtand a night infu≈øed, or make a Decoction of the ≈øame in Vinegar. But your pain or ve≈ø≈øel mu≈øt be of bra≈øs. This Vinegar mingle with Oyl of Elder, or of Ro≈øes, or the like, and it will become a fine gray Salve, curing ≈øuch running Scabs as afore≈øaid, and cooling al≈øo Inflammations.

If your Body be bound, take Sage pulveri≈øed and mix it with grea≈øe, and anoint your Navil with the quantity of a ha≈øel-nut of it. This I have with very good ≈øucce≈øs advi≈øed to women in child-bed, that were thus bound and ob≈øtructed. If you will have it ≈øtronger, mix with it the Gall of a Fi≈øh or of any Animal what≈øoever; but then you mu≈øt not give it to a woman in child-bed.

Gromel (by the Latins call'd Milium Solis) pulveri≈øed, and the weight of half a ducat of it taken in wine or broath, provoketh urine; yet mu≈øt the belly be open'd fir≈øt. The ≈øame doth Linaria or Toad-flax, boiled in wine
or broath. Likewi≈øe di≈øtilled water of Radi≈øhes, repeating the di≈øtillation ≈øeveral times from other fre≈øh Radi≈øhes. Which will have the better effect, if the Patient bath his lower parts in a bath made of Mar≈øh-mallows, Melilot, and the like.

Gromel, above-mention'd, taken in warm broath, expels the birth: And ≈øo do the blo≈ø≈øoms or buds of Walnut-trees; Crabs-eyes al≈øo, pulveri≈øed and taken in warm broath; likewi≈øe I≈ø≈øop boiled in wine, and drank warm. This I have in≈øerted for the ≈øake of poor Souldiers-wives, who among≈øt us often follow the Camp. If they have any great After-pains, let them bath their lower parts in a Bath made of Dill, and Camomil-flowers. And the yolks of hard Eggs, beaten together with ≈øome convenient Oyl (Nut-oyl is the be≈øt,) and a Plai≈øter made of it, and laid to the belly, is al≈øo very good. If they have too great a profu≈øion of blood, let them take a drachm of burnt Harts-horn, and burnt Ivory, in a convenient Vehicle.

In ca≈øe of a mortal wound, take of pure Turpentine four ounces, wa≈øh it with fre≈øh limpid water, and then di≈ø≈øolve it over a mild fire; which done, mix with it two ounces or two ounces and an half of white Wax, di≈ø≈øolved apart: To this add about three ounces of Womans milk, which is ≈øucked by a Boy. The Turpentine and Wax being ≈øomewhat cooled together, mu≈øt be well ≈øtirr'd, and then poured on cold Vinegar; whence, when 'tis brought to a con≈øi≈øtence, it is to be taken off, and made into a Plai≈øter, and ≈øo laid on.
Hor≈øe-tail ‚ñ™ (in Latin, Equi≈øetum) heals the wounds in the urinary parts, the powder of it being taken in broath or Speedwel-water, or the Decoction thereof being drank.
Gummi Ammoniac is a good di≈øcutient of hard Tumors and Knobs: Tacamahaca appea≈øeth pain proceeding from cold, being laid on the part affected.

To make the pellets u≈øed to be put in wounds that are to be kept open, (which here in Germany we call Quellmai≈ø≈øel,) take a Spunge of the fine≈øt ≈øort, put it in Whites of Eggs well beaten and mixed with Ro≈øe-water, to make the ≈øaid Spunge imbibe this moi≈øture. Which done, bind it clo≈øe together with thred, and let it well dry in the Air, and ≈øo convey of it into the wound that is to be kept open: where it will ≈øwell again, and ≈øo di≈øtend the wound.

If you be troubled with the Gonorrhaea, take Hou≈øe-leek growing on old walls (call'd by the Latins, Semper vi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ninus,) put it into your ≈øhoes, and go bare-foot upon it; anoint your loyns and privy parts with Henbane-oyl; and take mornings the quantity of two big ha≈øel-nuts of well wa≈øhed Turpentine, for ≈øome days together, avoiding all aromatic, hard, and ≈øalt meat.

An old Experimenter hath noted, That who≈øoever ≈øhall wa≈øh his head twice a week with a Lixivium made of Juniper-a≈øhes, his ≈øight ≈øhall never fail him, but remain good to his end; nor ≈øhall that per≈øon be troubled with any vermin upon his head, nor with any headach, nor ≈øuffer any change of his hair. For my
part, I never tryed it; but it being a very plain and ≈øafe thing, I thought good here to in≈øert it.
Again≈øt the biting of a Mad-dog, lay A≈ø≈øa foetida with Garlick upon the bite; it will draw out the venom.

To free your ≈øelf from the Gravel, make a Decoction of A≈øh-wood in wine, and drink of it warm once or twice a day upon an empty ≈øtomach; u≈øing withal good baths. Vervin al≈øo the leaves and roots, beaten together, and drank, is very good in this ca≈øe.

If you have a ≈øtrong breath, proceeding from a foul ≈øtomach, infu≈øe Wormwood and Carduus benedictus, together with ≈øome Citron-peels in in wine, and let them boil a little therein, and then drink a good draught of it mornings. Chew al≈øo and ≈øwallow ≈øometimes a little Myrrh, and take now and then three or four Aloes-pills.

I could add many other things, if my lei≈øure would permit: The≈øe which I have ≈øet down, you will take in good part; and though I have not tryed them all my ≈øelf, yet you may re≈øt a≈ø≈øured, that ≈øuch as have not been experimented by my ≈øelf, have been tryed by my honoured Collegues and other hone≈øt per≈øons, and approv'd.
